fields.headline: Wednesday's rumours
fields.trailText: Teddy Sheringham's failure to convince Manchester United that he is worth a two-year deal has prompted interest from a host of clubs. Both the Mirror and the Sun claim that the 35-year-old will be offered a return to Spurs, the club he left in acrimonious circumstances following a rift with recently-departed chairman Alan Sugar. However, it looks as though United's leading scorer this season - with 20 goals so far - will be spoiled for choice if he wants to move. West Ham, Chelsea, Charlton and Fulham would all join the queue of interested clubs.
fields.body:
Teddy Sheringham's failure to convince Manchester United that he is worth a two-year deal has prompted interest from a host of clubs. Both the Mirror and the Sun claim that the 35-year-old will be offered a return to Spurs, the club he left in acrimonious circumstances following a rift with recently-departed chairman Alan Sugar. However, it looks as though United's leading scorer this season - with 20 goals so far - will be spoiled for choice if he wants to move. West Ham, Chelsea, Charlton and Fulham would all join the queue of interested clubs.

Southampton chairman has warned Glenn Hoddle off poaching any players from the Dell, reports the Mirror. Spurs have already been linked with midfielder Hassan Kachloul and defender Dean Richards. And Hoddle is known to be a long-term admirer of Dan Petrescu.

Another former England manager, Bobby Robson, is hoping to lure Saints favourite Marian Pahars away from the Dell. The 24-year-old Latvian marksman will be an £8 million Newcastle target this summer, according to Teamtalk. Robson is in the market for an out-and-out striker, with Michael Bridges and Hakan Sukur also on the shopping list.

But Newcastle may well lose out on Gary Speed, who, the Express report, may move to Craven Cottage at the end of the season. Fulham attempted to force through a deal before transfer deadline day last month and are expected to bid around £5million for the Welsh international's services.

Fulham have also been linked with West Ham's Frederic Kanoute, reports the Daily Mail, which would further strengthen the French connection at the club. Kanoute would look to partner his compatriot Luois Saha up front.

However, Mohamed's millions know no bounds. The Sun report that Anderkecht's 6 ft 7 in Czech striker Jan Koller is poised for a £7 million move to Fulham.

Kevin Keegan is not the man for Southampton, according to the Sun. They say David Platt is the top target to take the manager's job which he apparently turned down in 1997 while still at Arsenal. Platt is also tipped to take on the England U-21s job.

However, The Express says that Keegan is still very much in the frame, but faces competition from the man he usurped at Fulham, Micky Adams. The former Southampton player has been rebuilding his career at Brighton.

Sol Campbell's Spurs future is still in the balance, with Arsenal and Real Madrid waiting in the wings. Spurs plan to make the England defender the highest paid player in the club's history in their efforts to retain his services. The Sun says he would earn £100,000 a week with his endorsements included.

Sunderland and Middlesbrough are locked in a battle to secure the signature of Inter Bratislava striker, Szilard Nemeth. Inter Milan are also interested in the 23-year old forward who cored two goals in Slovakia's 3-1 defeat of Azerbaijan last week.

Charlton are facing a fight to keep on-loan striker Shaun Bartlett. The 28-year-old South African's success at the Valley may have priced him out of the Addicks' range and Udinese are interested in the FC Zurich player, according to the Star.

Charlton are also having to fend off interest from Italian clubs for another striker, Jonatan Johansson. The club is expected to begin talks to extend the Finnish international's contract this week.

Fiorentina goalkeeper Francesco Toldo is to leave the club at the end of the season, according to Reuters, and is expected to join either Lazio or Roma. He said: "Barcelona want me but I want to stay in Italy."

The Italian press are tipping Marcello Lippi for a move to Lazio as coach, despite president Sergio Cragnotti claims that Dino Zoff is staying. Teamtalk say that the former Juve and Inter coach has been in secret talks with Lazio.

French midfielder Jean Yves de Blasiis is to part company with Norwich at the end of the season. The 27-year-old midfielder, signed on a free from Red Star Belgrade, will no tbe offered new terms.

fields.headline: Shares nosedive after reprieve
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Share prices were back under severe downward pressure in New York and London yesterday as nervous investors fled stock markets amid continuing fears about the impact of the deteriorating American economy on global business.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and Larry Elliott  and  David Gow
fields.body:
Share prices were back under severe downward pressure in New York and London yesterday as nervous investors fled stock markets amid continuing fears about the impact of the deteriorating American economy on global business.

A plethora of profits warnings from corporate America - particularly in the vulnerable technology sector - led to some hefty early declines on Wall Street, dragging down the already jittery London stock market in late trading.

With the rally of last week quickly forgotten, all the main share price indices in New York were down by early afternoon. A total of more than 100 points was wiped off the technology-rich Nasdaq index, with the decline of more than 5% taking it below 1,700 points, a level not seen since the autumn of 1988.

The Dow Jones industrial index suffered a decline of more than 230 points, or 2.5%, to just below the 9550 level.

In London, the FTSE 100 had earlier closed down 155 points at 5,463.1, a drop of almost 3% as disappointing trading news from UK companies added to concern about the US economy, underlined yesterday by news of a 0.4% drop in factory orders in February. And the Engineering Employers' Federation said Britain's engineering firms, especially electronics companies, faced a significant slowdown in growth and the laying off of tens of thousands of staff in the next two years.

Even hopes of a cut in interest rates from the Bank of England tomorrow failed to boost the spirits of City traders.

On Wall Street Art Hogan, the chief market analyst at Jefferies and Co, blamed a series of profits warnings from US companies since the beginning of the week for exacerbating an already weak market. Twenty companies warned that earnings would be worse than expected on Monday, followed by half as many again yesterday.

"It's relentless, and it's making people feel that they can't see the light at the end of the tunnel - even to the end of this week," he said.

Among the companies to issue warnings yesterday were software groups Ariba and Inktomi and telecoms equipment manufacturer Redback Networks. Shares in Ariba, the business to business software group, fell 22%.

PSINet, the internet access provider, also warned that it was likely to file for bankruptcy protection as it was running out of cash .

fields.headline: Barclays row over 'elitist' account
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Barclays muscled into the battle for current account holders yesterday by launching a new account intended to give a better deal to loyal customers who have more than one product with a high street bank.
fields.body:
Barclays muscled into the battle for current account holders yesterday by launching a new account intended to give a better deal to loyal customers who have more than one product with a high street bank.

City sources said, however that the new "platinum" current account could be accused of elitism since it was targeting just 700,000 of the bank's 8.3m current account customers and followed on from Barclays' controversial move last year to give lower loan rates to customers with a better record of repayments.

Allan Silverman, head of current accounts at Barclays, said the product was not intended to lure only the better-off and was one of a series of initiatives to be launched over the coming months. "Our intention is to put loyalty at the heart of our strategy," Mr Silverman said. "This is the opposite of elitism," he said. "40% of the customers earn £20,000 or less".

Customers who meet the criteria for platinum banking will pay lower overdraft fees of 12% - compared with closer to the 18% charged by the big four - as well as a fee free overdraft and other perks.

fields.headline: Shocking, timeless Ibsen
fields.standfirst:
Ghosts
Comedy Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Ghosts
Comedy Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
You can't beat Henrik Ibsen. He is, after Shakespeare, the greatest of all dramatists. And, even if Robin Phillips's new production of Ghosts does not erase my haunting memories of Katie Mitchell's and David Thacker's versions, it still dignifies the West End and offers a decidedly upmarket replacement to Under the Doctor.

Since it is staged at the Comedy, I could wish for more relish for Ibsen's implacable irony. His theme, after all, is the need to shed dead ideas and moral conventions. Yet his characters can never quite escape the tenacious past. Mrs Alving, the apostle of enlightenment, finally shrinks from assisting the syphilitic Oswald in an act of merciful euthanasia. The servant Regina, informed that she is Oswald's half-sister, promptly cuts and runs. And Pastor Manders, the embodiment of rectitude, is conned into supporting Engstrand's plan for a maritime bordello. Ibsen is often thought of as grim; in fact, he is drama's supreme ironist.

A little more of his wicked humour would not hurt in Phillips's austerely romantic production. Paul Farnsworth's set, with its large angled mirror, is elegantly hermetic but gives little sense of the way climate affects character. Big moments, such as Mrs Alving's realisation that "there are as many ghosts as grains of sand", are lent a gratuitous portentousness by the use of an echo-chamber effect. And, while Richard Harris's new version is sprightly enough, it misses - unless I misheard - Pastor Manders's great cry, after the burning of the orphanage: "And not insured either!"

But the performances are all decent, and in one or two cases, something more. Francesca Annis's Mrs Alving could do more to suggest a woman intellectually inflamed by new radical ideas. Where she does score is in her recollected revulsion at nursing her diseased husband so that when she tells Manders "I did everything" the lines acquire an extraordinary sexual charge. Anthony Andrews's excellent Manders also combines a poker-backed rigidity with hints of a fiercely repressed sensuality. You feel he is always fighting his own rising desire not only for Mrs Alving but for the provocatively obliging Regina.

And Robin Soans is the creepiest Engstrand I can recall. To Manders he is full of sanctimonious piety. But left alone with his supposed daughter, Regina, he becomes a reptilian pimp; when he talks of "a father's guiding hand" he places it unequivocally on her breast. Sarah Tansey's Regina reacts with proper disgust but also conveys the character's inherited hedonism while Martin Hutson's Oswald movingly portrays the character's progressive deterioration. Maybe there is something melodramatic about Oswald's final collapse. But the play still shows Ibsen to be an intellectual visionary. Desmond MacCarthy, reviewing Ghosts in 1917, called Ibsen "the dramatist of the future". Seeing it revived now, what is shocking is its perpetual relevance to the present.

 Until June 23. Box office: 020-7369 1731. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Missing treasures Aladdin's losses hit London Clubs

fields.headline: Missing treasures Aladdin's losses hit London Clubs
fields.trailText: Pressure on the casino group London Clubs International increased yesterday after it emerged that sales at its main US investment - the Aladdin casino and hotel complex in Las Vegas, pictured - continued to fall short of expectations.
fields.body:
Pressure on the casino group London Clubs International increased yesterday after it emerged that sales at its main US investment - the Aladdin casino and hotel complex in Las Vegas, pictured - continued to fall short of expectations.

Shares in London Clubs dropped to a new low, down 3p to 33.5p, on the announcement. There was speculation that the group, which owns four London clubs - Les Ambassadeurs, St James's, the Sportsman and the Golden Nugget - would require a rights issue to help meet its debt repayments.

Other options include a takeover by venture capi talists or leisure magnate Trevor Hemmings, who already holds a 10% stake, or the sale of some of its operations to rivals Stanley Leisure.

A spokesman said: "They haven't decided yet what they are going to do."

The British group has a 40% stake in the struggling $1.3bn (£915m) Aladdin, on Las Vegas's famous Strip, which reported pretax losses of $8.56m for 2000. This is the latest bad news from holding company Aladdin Gaming Enterprises, which has been forced to cut staff numbers from 4,500 to 3,100 since opening in August last year.

The US company said that poor performance, particularly in its hotel and slot machine divisions over recent months, meant that bank loans might have to be revised again. They were reviewed last week to meet financial obligations.

Last week, the Los Angeles Times reported that financial pressures have created bad blood between Aladdin's stakeholders, and that competitors appeared poised to take over. "This is not a matter of if it goes bad, it's a matter of when," one US banker told the newspaper.

Analysts said the casino's weak performance was largely the result of poor marketing, but added that the venue has also been hit by the wider slowdown in the US economy.

Aladdin said it was starting to resolve the "teething problems".

fields.headline: Barclaycard aims for £1m smart buy
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Barclaycard is abandoning attempts to build up its internet shopping centre IndigoSquare, instead splashing out £1m on the current leader, ShopSmart. By Jill Treanor.
fields.body:
Barclaycard is abandoning attempts to build up its internet shopping centre IndigoSquare into the biggest in Britain, instead splashing out £1m on the current leader, ShopSmart.

Yesterday's offer for ShopSmart, which claims more than 500,000 online visitors each month, consists of £1m in cash and 10% of the combined business, which is yet to be named.

IndigoSquare is a joint venture between Barclaycard and Japanese investment bank Nomura.

Barclaycard refused to reveal how many customers IndigoSquare had attracted since its launch in November but admitted it was much smaller than ShopSmart, which was set up in 1998 and claims to be the largest internet retailer in the country.

Barclaycard said it had agreement from 72.5% of the shareholders in ShopSmart.

The new site will carry the Barclaycard brand, with a view to persuading customers to use their Barclaycard to shop over the internet - where, according to NOP, 70% of transactions involve the use of a credit card.

Neither Barclaycard nor ShopSmart were able to reveal the identity of the 27.5% of ShopSmart shareholders who have yet to accept the offer and have 28 days to do so.

The offer is supported by the board and the main shareholders in ShopSmart, which was founded by brothers Daniel and Leo Gestetner and Martin Reeves.

webTitle: House prices lag in rural areas

fields.headline: House prices lag in rural areas
fields.trailText: House prices rose sharply last month but the twin impact of stock market turbulence and the foot and mouth crisis are starting to take their toll on the property markets in London and some rural areas.
fields.body:
House prices rose sharply last month but the twin impact of stock market turbulence and the foot and mouth crisis are starting to take their toll on the property markets in London and some rural areas.

Prices rose by 1.4% in March, lifting the value of the average property by £1,763, or £56 a day, according to Nationwide building society. The typical price tag is now £85,077 compared with £79,393 a year ago.

The annual rate of house price growth has slipped back slightly to 7.2%, however, because prices rose very strongly in the first quarter of last year.

And a warning was sounded that the foot and mouth outbreak could knock as much as 0.5% off the annual rate of house price growth.

Nationwide's figures also reveal the extent to which the stock market turbulence has hit the property market in London - the region which led the market's recovery. There, the annual rate of price growth has fallen from 25.5% a year ago to 5.6% - the lowest of all regions in Britain except for Scotland.

"The recent stock market falls will have reduced expectations among City workers about pay increases and bonuses. Reduced job security may also dent confidence with some potential homebuyers deciding to put off the decision to move," said a society spokesman.

The London housing market's fortunes are closely linked to those of the stock market, and the society is pre dicting that if shares continue their downward slide, this will continue to moderate growth in the capital's house prices.

Nationwide said "the jury remains out" as to the impact of the stock market on the rest of the country.

Meanwhile, in addition to hitting the farming and tourism industries, the foot and mouth crisis is hitting property sales in rural areas as it has led some homebuyers to steer clear of the countryside.

"Many rural homebuyers are likely to have postponed their house-hunting in order to avoid making non-essential journeys in the countryside. Farming-related incomes are also likely to fall, albeit over the short-term," said the spokesman.

The society believes that when the outbreak subsides there is likely to be little long-term impact on house prices in rural areas, and the crisis is unlikely to make much difference to the broad regional house price indices.

"At the very worst UK annual house price inflation could be reduced by 0.5% as a result of the crisis if it persists in coming months."

A regional breakdown of prices shows that Northern Ireland has recorded the highest rate of annual price growth - 11.2%. There, the average price of a home is £72,797. The West Midlands was close behind with a rate of 10.9% (average price £79,114). The typical property price in London now stands at £147,983, while in Scotland, which achieved annual price growth of 2.1%, the figure is £64,138.

"At the very worst UK annual house price inflation could be reduced by 0.5% as a result of the crisis if it persists in coming months." A regional breakdown of prices shows that Northern Ireland has recorded the highest rate of annual price growth - 11.2%. There, the average price of a home is £72,797. The West Midlands was close behind with a rate of 10.9% (average price £79,114). The typical property price in London now stands at £147,983, while in Scotland, which achieved annual price growth of 2.1%, the figure is £64,138.

fields.headline: Software crash reverberates
fields.trailText: The prospect of another dismal quarter for US corporate earnings sent investors scurrying for cover yesterday, driving the FTSE 100 back towards 29-month lows and sparking another round of blood-letting in the hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
The prospect of another dismal quarter for US corporate earnings sent investors scurrying for cover yesterday, driving the FTSE 100 back towards 29-month lows and sparking another round of blood-letting in the hi-tech sector.

The damage occurred overnight when a number of Nasdaq stalwarts, including software groups Ariba, Broadvision and Inktomi, issued gloomy earnings forecasts, and was reinforced by Wall Street's nervous reaction. As worried London traders headed home, the Nasdaq was around 100 points lower.

All of which left the FTSE 100 down 155.4 points at 5,463.1, not far from last month's low of 5,314.8.

Given warnings from groups such as Ariba and i2, software stocks bore the brunt of the selling. Anglo-Dutch concern CMG was the worst affected, losing 109.5p to 460p, with Logica, down 120p to 850p, and Sage, off 22.75p at 220.75p, not far behind. The FTSE Techmark 100 closed 136.76 points weaker at 1,771.02, a level last seen in August 1999.

Telecoms stocks were also in the firing line, with Marconi taking another dive as evidence grew that its full-year figures will prove disappointing. The latest piece of the jigsaw came from French rival Alcatel, which has been forced to cut 1,100 jobs in North America because of slowing customer demand. Marconi, which does 40% of its business on the other side of the Atlantic, lost 42p, or 12.28%, to close at 300p. The shares fell 53% in the first quarter.

The Alcatel news also unsettled optical components maker Bookham, 48p weaker at 249p. ARM Holdings shed 55p to 265p on fears that next week's first-quarter figures could disappoint.

In the media sector, Carlton Communications dropped 35.5p to 347.5p as UBS Warburg set about placing a lump of 14m shares at a 345p - a 35p discount to Monday's closing price.

Outside of the new economy things were little better. Rail track was again under pressure as several brokers downgraded the stock in the wake of Monday's loss of important infrastructure projects. UBS Warburg was among the most negative, lowering its rating to "hold" from "strong buy". Railtrack fell 90p to 480p.

Speciality chemicals group ICI surrendered 35p to 405p, unsettled by industry leader Du Pont cutting 4,000 jobs. Market professionals are con vinced that ICI is about to issue a profits warning.

Some things were going up, however. The utilities sector was one, lifted by its perceived defensive qualities and a couple of broker upgrades.

National Power spin-off International Power put on 16p to 280p after Deutsche Bank lifted its rating to "buy" and target price to 350p. At current levels, Deutsche said, the shares were assuming 25-30% earnings growth, but if US power prices stay high and new power stations can be completed in time for the summer peak, earnings could double in 2001.

Elsewhere in the sector, United Utilities crept 1.5p higher to 620 and bid target Powergen rose 3p to 709p.

Innogy, the other part of the former National Power, topped the mid-cap leader board with a rise of 17.5p to 213.5p as Merrill Lynch turned buyer of the stock after the regulators waved through its acquisition of Yorkshire Power.

Independent Insurance shares reached their lowest level in four years following an institutional placing of 2.3m shares at 123p - a sizeable discount to Monday's closing price of 151p. Independent shares closed down 15.5p on the day to close at 135p.

Internet security specialist and former FTSE 100 company Baltimore hit a 27-month low, down 16.5p to 68.75p, rocked by a profits warning from US rival Entrust.

In the smaller companies world, IT company Torex eased 32.5p to 705p on word that bear raider Simon Cawkwell, better know as Evil Knievil, has started to short the stock.

fields.headline: BBCSO/Davis
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
The Danish composer Per Norgard seems to be in vogue here right now. Last summer the Almeida festival presented the British premiere of his latest opera, Nuit des Hommes, as well as assorted works; at this concert the BBC Symphony Orchestra introduced a new orchestral piece, Terrains Vagues, that it commissioned.

Many people admire Norgard's individuality; I wish I could share their enthusiasm. Terrains Vagues develops material from his Sixth Symphony, completed in 1999: the last minute of the earlier piece, chopped about, forms the opening of the new one. Taking its title from a poem by the Danish writer Klaus Rifbjerg, the profile of the 25-minute score is clear: three sections that trace a steady progression from the seismic convulsions of the beginning to the relative tranquillity of the close.

The ideas that fill out this framework, though, are much less convincing. Aggressive gestures that were old hat 20 years ago - mass string glissandi, ticking percussion, stabbing brass and punctuations from an accordion, which seems to have become a fashion accessory for composers in the 21st century - are queasily juxtaposed with lurches into triumphalist tonality, and the brooding landscape it creates is hard to assimilate. Still, it was reassuring to see the BBCSO reunited with its former chief conductor Andrew Davis, and the quality of the playing suggested that the orchestra was glad to have him back too. Every detail of the Norgard seemed secure, and there was no lack of drama in the way it was vividly presented.

The rest of the programme was much more satisfying. Davis has always been a first-rate Stravinsky conductor, and the way he launched the programme with the Symphony in Three Movements affirmed that - weighty and forbidding in the first movement, delicately tracery in the second and a wonderful play of orchestral sonorities in the finale. A similarly all-inclusive account of the Symphony of Psalms with the BBC Symphony Chorus ended the evening, with the magical coda lit up with the purest of tone. And the enchanted backdrop that conductor and orchestra created for Ravel's song cycle, Sheherazade, allowed the beguiling mezzo Angelika Kirschlager to deliver the erotically-charged texts with fabulous sensuality.

fields.headline: Barbara Thompson's last tango
fields.standfirst:
Barbara Thompson's Paraphernalia
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.trailText:
Barbara Thompson's Paraphernalia
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.body:
You can't escape technology, even in a darkened jazz club in Soho. It informs most aspects of Paraphernalia's performance, from the studio-quality sound mix (courtesy of Miles Ashton) to the miniature mission control behind Peter Lemer's keyboards. Drummer Jon Hiseman remarked later how vital the internet had become since his wife (and bandleader) Barbara Thompson was diagnosed as having Parkinson's disease several years ago: they have been in contact with all the major international research institutions, concluding that she should abandon harmful medication, stop touring and concentrate on composing.

This is the last chance to see Paraphernalia until better treatment emerges, and they are on good form for this final lap of honour. Thompson's condition did not appear to affect her performance: she paced herself carefully to keep fatigue at bay. The quintet comprises Lemer, Hiseman, the leader on saxes, Dave Ball on bass and Billy Thompson (no relation) on violin. Over the past 25 years, Paraphernalia have carved out a remarkably independent career, their musical direction following Thompson's compositional instincts into several genres outside jazz, the latest of which is tango.

Before settling into Anglo-Argentinian mode they opened with the stadium fusion of Guardians of the Deep, effortlessly scaled down to jazz-club volume, with Hiseman's virtuoso drumming underlining every gesture. Smoky Embrace, a number from the Intuition CD, was a ballad-like setting for an emotive violin solo and Lemer's distinctive, authoritative electronic grand-piano playing.

Their interpretation of the tango is hard and muscular, rather than having the romantic intensities of Gidon Kremer or the ironies of Carla Bley. Thompson's arrangements are complex and dynamic and their extended solo and collective blowing had the freedom and confidence that comes from continuous work in sympathetic venues - they are at the end of a five-week tour.

The sneaky funk of Tango 1 gave way to the brittle Tango 2, which gave Billy Thompson a chance to let rip. Tango 3 had a big spongy riff for fretless bass, crafting a dense carpet of sound for the tenor/violin lead. Tango 4 began with a bass solo, accompanied by keys and drums, that nearly raised the venue's low ceiling: chorus after chorus of incendiary virtuosity over a sequence similar to Astor Piazzolla's Libertango (once recorded by Grace Jones as I've Seen That Face Before). The two Thompsons joined in from the wings before moving centre stage to play the unisons that led into a flamboyant drum solo with everything you expect from Hiseman: the speed and charm of a good salesman, jazz musicianship and rock'n'roll showmanship.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

fields.headline: Artists at the Hustings
fields.standfirst:
Sir John Soane's Museum, London
***
fields.trailText:
Sir John Soane's Museum, London
***
fields.body:
The translation of politics into art is explored in this timely exhibition, based on William Hogarth's series of paintings, The Election. Satirical images of politicians come and go, but how many survive as art?

Hogarth's four paintings narrate in slightly exaggerated detail the corrupt contest for Oxfordshire in the 1754 general election, a seat rechristened Guzzledown by the artist. His scepticism about the electoral process knows no bounds, yet his paintings are anything but despairing. If politics is good for nothing else, it is good for a laugh and this is echoed in this display, including Thomas Rowlandson's The Poll, in which the parties are represented by two fat women on a see-saw, and Ronald Searle's 1954 work The Girlfriend, a cautionary tale in which a glamorous student sleeps her way to becoming minister of health.

Hogarth depicts potential Whig voters gorging themselves on oysters, and the pissed parson taking off his wig to wipe his sweaty head, while the Tory crowd outside abuse foreigners and Jews. When the triumphant Tory candidate is carried through the streets, rioters cudgel each other. The monstrousness of it all is ripely British. These are some of Hogarth's most sophisticated paintings, with a brilliant grasp of motion that sends your eye swooping from face to grotesque face and a pastiche of European art. Hogarth also evokes grand 18th-century history painting.

This exhibition emphasises artists who emulated Hogarth's high aspirations, such as the radical history painter Benjamin Robert Haydon, whose Chairing the Member (1828) is a coded depiction of the corrupt debtor's prison in which Haydon was incarcerated.

We are not as systematically corrupt as the Britain these artists depict - are we? Electile Dysfunction, by the Guardian's Steve Bell, has Uncle Sam against a pink sunset, a map of the sunshine state hanging flaccidly in front of his striped trousers. Bell is chosen here as a practitioner of the grand tradition in political art, in which cartoons aspire to be as rich as paintings. The Pant Burning, published the morning after the 1997 general election, has John Major's underpants in flames on the Thames in front of Parliament, a reference to JMW Turner's The Burning of the House of Lords and Commons (1835). What pathos.

 Until August 25. Details: 020-7405 2107.

webTitle: Our fate hangs in the balance

fields.headline: Our fate hangs in the balance
fields.standfirst: Forget dot.bombs and industrial decline. Britons' consuming passion could tip the country into recession
fields.trailText: June 1970. It is the Sunday before the general election and to the delight of the prime minister, Harold Wilson, England are beating West Germany in the quarter final of the World Cup. Goals from Mullery and Peters have put Alf Ramsey's team 2-0 up and, as far as Wilson is concerned, success in Mexico will translate into votes for Labour four days later.
fields.body:
June 1970. It is the Sunday before the general election and to the delight of the prime minister, Harold Wilson, England are beating West Germany in the quarter final of the World Cup. Goals from Mullery and Peters have put Alf Ramsey's team 2-0 up and, as far as Wilson is concerned, success in Mexico will translate into votes for Labour four days later.

Sadly, it does not work out that way. The West Germans fight back to win 3-2 in extra time and Ted Heath snatches victory from the jaws of defeat. In the search for scapegoats, Labour says the tummy bug that laid low goalkeeper Gordon Banks and the arrival of the two new jumbo jets that magnified the trade deficit helped to change the mood of the electorate.

June 2001. On the eve of the date set for the general election, England are due to play a World Cup qualifying match against Greece. Greece are not West Germany, but then England in 2001 are not the England of 1970. Moreover, the economic outlook, which had looked so promising in the early spring, has suddenly turned gloomy as a result of the twin effects of the global stock market meltdown and the foot and mouth epidemic. The dreaded R word - recession - is back in use for the first time in almost 10 years and, to the dismay of ministers, feelgood turns into feelbad. Against all the odds, William Hague ends up as the new occupant of 10 Downing Street.

Not immune

Unlikely? Implausible? Impossible? Given the extent of Tony Blair's lead in the opinion polls, it would seem so, but the prospect of the economy taking a sudden turn for the worse is something that haunts Labour's strategists. The latest survey of manufacturing from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply this week showed that Britain is not immune from the economic malaise seeping out of the United States. Output from factories is down, order books are weak, jobs are being cut.

Fortunately for the government, manufacturing is only one part of the economy. While the problems faced by the industrial sector are real and worrying, for the time being they can be disguised by low inflation, low unemployment, rising real incomes, a robust housing market and the seemingly insatiable appetite of the British consumer to spend, spend, spend. The government's preferred measure of inflation, the retail prices index excluding mortgage interest payments, shows that the cost of living is rising by 1.9%, while unemployment is at its lowest level since the mid-1970s.

With average earnings rising at 4.4% a year and taxes coming down, real incomes are rising strongly, leading to the fastest increase in consumer spending since the Lawson boom of the late 1980s. Job security plus additional spending power are the two main ingredients of a feelgood factor, and it is this that the government was seeking to exploit to the full with a May poll.

So what could spoil the party? The most obvious threat to the government's carefully laid election plans is the continued turbulence in the global economy. Share prices were falling again yesterday, reflecting concern over the health of the US economy, fears that Japan is poised to go back into recession and signs that Germany is slowing down rapidly. The effects of all this have already been felt by exporters, but the danger for the government is that the bear market in global equities will feed through into a wholesale collapse in consumer confidence.

Despite signs that individuals are becoming more pessimistic about the outlook for the economy as a whole, they are still relatively upbeat about their own prospects. Ministers fear that this may not be the case in October, let alone in the spring of next year.

For the time being, any weakness in the domestic economy can be offset by cuts in interest rates. The Bank of England has the scope to ease monetary policy either tomorrow or at its next meeting in early May, and the weakness of the global economy should mean that imported goods fall in price over the coming months, keeping inflation well below its 2.5% target. This will enable the Bank to keep on cutting and consumers to keep on consuming.

However, this will merely amplify a deeper problem in the British economy - the tendency for spending to outstrip the increase in productive capacity. Richard Jeffrey, director of economics at Charter house Securities, said that over the past five years household spending has increased by 4% a year on average, and of the 2.8% average growth in GDP over that period 2.5% has come from household consumption. "While it is to be expected that in most years consumers will be the mainstay of the economy, their role in the recent period has been too prominent. The result has been growth in domestic demand that has far outstripped the economy's ability to supply."

Gordon Brown has acknowledged that this is a long-term problem for Britain, and has come up with ideas to boost investment and productivity. However, these will take years to bear fruit and in the meantime the Treasury's figures show that domestic final demand is expected to grow by 4% in 2001 while the economy as a whole is predicted to grow by 2.5%.

Higher government spending and stronger investment are part of the reason for the buoyancy of domestic demand, but the real driving force will be consumer spending.

Age-old problem

For decades, that tendency to spend more than the nation produces has been flagged by the imbalance between demand and supply showing up in the current account. The portents here are not good. Between 1992 and 1997, Britain's trade deficit in goods remained steady at between £11bn and £13bn a year, and the shortfall was almost entirely offset by Britain's surplus in trade in services. The deficit in goods rose to £20.5bn in 1998, £26.2bn in 1999 and £28.7bn in 1999.

The ballooning of the trade deficit is not just the result of the US-induced downturn in the global economy; the current account is now feeling the full impact of the over-valuation of sterling, which makes exports dearer and imports cheaper.

However, a strong pound, the absence of foreign tourists, falling US demand and slower global growth suggest that at some point in the not-too-distant future the age-old problem of the balance of payments will again rear its head.

As Geoffrey Dicks, chief economist with the Royal Bank of Scotland, puts it: "It cannot be reassuring that we seem to have to expand spending 1.5 times to get 1.0 back on output since a large part of the spending goes straight into imports and the current account deficit. One bad set of trade figures is said to have cost Harold Wilson the 1970 election; Messrs Blair and Brown must be hoping the same does not happen again."

The Bank of England has the scope to ease monetary policy either tomorrow or at its next meeting in early May, and the weakness of the global economy should mean that imported goods fall in price over the coming months, keeping inflation well below its 2.5% target. This will enable the Bank to keep on cutting and consumers to keep on consuming. However, this will merely amplify a deeper problem in the British economy - the tendency for spending to outstrip the increase in productive capacity. Richard Jeffrey, director of economics at Charter house Securities, said that over the past five years household spending has increased by 4% a year on average, and of the 2.8% average growth in GDP over that period 2.5% has come from household consumption. "While it is to be expected that in most years consumers will be the mainstay of the economy, their role in the recent period has been too prominent. The result has been growth in domestic demand that has far outstripped the economy's ability to supply." Gordon Brown has acknowledged that this is a long-term problem for Britain, and has come up with ideas to boost investment and productivity. However, these will take years to bear fruit and in the meantime the Treasury's figures show that domestic final demand is expected to grow by 4% in 2001 while the economy as a whole is predicted to grow by 2.5%. Higher government spending and stronger investment are part of the reason for the buoyancy of domestic demand, but the real driving force will be consumer spending. Age-old problem For decades, that tendency to spend more than the nation produces has been flagged by the imbalance between demand and supply showing up in the current account. The portents here are not good. Between 1992 and 1997, Britain's trade deficit in goods remained steady at between £11bn and £13bn a year, and the shortfall was almost entirely offset by Britain's surplus in trade in services. The deficit in goods rose to £20.5bn in 1998, £26.2bn in 1999 and £28.7bn in 1999. The ballooning of the trade deficit is not just the result of the US-induced downturn in the global economy; the current account is now feeling the full impact of the over-valuation of sterling, which makes exports dearer and imports cheaper. However, a strong pound, the absence of foreign tourists, falling US demand and slower global growth suggest that at some point in the not-too-distant future the age-old problem of the balance of payments will again rear its head. As Geoffrey Dicks, chief economist with the Royal Bank of Scotland, puts it: "It cannot be reassuring that we seem to have to expand spending 1.5 times to get 1.0 back on output since a large part of the spending goes straight into imports and the current account deficit. One bad set of trade figures is said to have cost Harold Wilson the 1970 election; Messrs Blair and Brown must be hoping the same does not happen again."

fields.headline: M&S faces bonus row
fields.standfirst: Chairman fails to deliver on promises but is in line for £650,000 reward
fields.trailText: Chairman fails to deliver on promises but is in line for £650,000 reward.
fields.body:
The directors of Marks & Spencer are risking a row with shareholders over plans to pay a performance bonus equal to one year's salary to chairman Luc Vandevelde.

The retailer, which last week delivered another set of dismal trading figures, agreed a £650,000 bonus for Mr Vandevelde when he joined M&S last March. The remuneration committee approved the bonus "on the delivery of certain specific strategic and qualitative targets" which have not been made public. The payment was due after 13 months, which have now passed. There are no plans to withhold it.

Last night a spokesman for M&S refused to spell out the targets Mr Vandevelde had to meet but said the company had received no indication that shareholders would object to any payment.

But fund managers believe that if the bonus is paid it will prompt outrage, because Mr Vandevelde has so far failed to show any signs of turning the company around and has failed to deliver on all his promises.

When he took the job he pledged to achieve recovery within two years, although he now admits that only the first signs of a turnaround might be visible by then. He promised the retailer would deliver "a wonderful Christmas" - before being forced to announce dreadful Christmas trading figures - and admitted that the group's fashions were "simply not good enough".

Last week he announced a new recovery plan, involving the loss of more than 4,000 jobs. He is closing the group's European operations and is to sell its US offshoots, despite insisting last year that retailers had to be international to be successful.

One shareholder said: "Marks & Spencer is a potentially problematic company. We are waiting to see whether Mr Vandevelde has got his bonus. He might have achieved some internal targets, but that is not really the point.

"It would look bad if he was taking a huge bonus. There is a need for some sensitivity. The fact is that M&S has under-delivered on every target since his appointment was announced. We are waiting to see what explanation the annual report will give".

Marks & Spencer pointed out that the payment to Mr Vandevelde still had to be ratified by the company's remuneration committee, which agreed the original deal.

The company had taken months to find a new chairman following the resignation of Sir Richard Greenbury and breached several corporate governance guidelines in order to hire the Belgian retailer.

It agreed to make him chairman and chief executive - when guidelines suggest the two roles should be split - and gave him a two-year contract, which is now regarded as unacceptably long. M&S also awarded him a share package which could deliver £10m if he manages to turn the company around.

The remuneration committee will meet to discuss the payment at the beginning of May, before M&S announces its full-year profits on May 22. The company's spokesman added: "Any decision the remuneration committee makes will have to be justified to shareholders."

The remuneration committee is chaired by the former head of MI5, Dame Stella Rimington, and includes Brian Baldock, the former deputy chairman of Guinness, former Prudential boss Sir Martin Jacomb, former Unilever chief Sir Michael Perry and Sir Ralph Robins, the chairman of Rolls-Royce.

fields.headline: Quality Control
fields.standfirst:
Site Gallery, Sheffield
****
fields.trailText:
Site Gallery, Sheffield
****
fields.body:
Picasso's portrait of his wife Olga is expected to reach £30m when it goes up for auction in May. An original photo-work by Stephanie Bolt recently went at a car-boot sale in exchange for an old sock. The Picasso is currently on display at Christie's; you will have to head for the Site Gallery if you want to visit the sock.

Bolt, an artist who knows the value of everything and the price of nothing, has teamed up with the madcap inventor Max Dean for a show that hilariously mocks the pretensions of art's marketable value. Squaring up to the hostile "I wouldn't give you tuppence for that" response, Bolt has boldly taken her work to boot sales and let the public give her tuppence for it. Or an old sock, or whatever item was considered to represent a fair exchange.

Ask yourself how much the Bolt originals pinned to the walls are worth, however, and a sensitive calculation that carefully weighs cost and quality of materials against input of labour and overall aesthetic impression, leads one to an estimate of... probably about tuppence. Bolt's method is to write off to industrial manufacturers asking for a sample of their write-offs. She then photocopies the faulty items and displays the illegibly blurred results alongside explanatory letters from the manufacturers' quality control departments detailing what is wrong with her pictures.

Some of these are gems of ham-fisted industrial aesthetics. "Your letter provoked quite a discussion in terms of a definition of what is perfect," reply Allenwest Brentford Ltd, "but our test and inspection procedure is associated with meter readings which are not visually interesting." Given that Bolt's work is not particularly visually interesting either, the electrical components manufacturer's concern seems touchingly misplaced.

Dean's mean shredding machine was last seen at the Venice Biennale; this is the robot's first appearance in Britain. A rogue automated photo-lab that dispassionately destroys snapshots, this evil mechanism has to be stopped. You can do so, at any time, by placing your palm on a sensor which determines that the pic will be saved. But you can't stand there rescuing shots of fluffy kittens all day. In this grim battle of wills, the machine always wins. I only recommend that you never let Dean develop your photos.

 Until May 6. Details: 0114-281 2077.

webTitle: Richard Williams on Europe's new ruling power, Spain

fields.headline: Spain throw down the gauntlet
fields.standfirst: Deportivo are in the vanguard of the century's new ruling power. England beware. By  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: Spain is Europe's new ruling power. As a direct confrontation between two leagues who both consider themselves the world's best beckons, English clubs need to be on their guard.
fields.body:
In La Coruna smartly dressed old ladies and families with small children leave Saturday evening mass in the church by the sea and stroll up the broad avenue, passing the bust of "Chacho" - Eduardo Gonzalez Valino, 1911-1979, whose plaque carries a citation for "the unforgettable nobility and warmth he brought to the football of his native city". A few yards further on they pause opposite the main entrance to the Estadio Riazor to watch the late arrivals joining a crowd of 30,000 for the match between Deportivo and Villarreal.

The kick-off is a quarter of an hour away and the mood is festive. There are no mobs of aggressive young men, no beer cans rattling around the gutters, no raucous chanting. A few minutes later the priest himself arrives, the morning's sports paper tucked under his arm, greeting friends and parishioners before entering to take his usual seat.

Nobility and warmth, you could say, are what we think of when we think of Spanish football - the nobility of Real Madrid, eight times champions of Europe, and the warmth of Barcelona's 100,000-strong aficion , fired by regional pride. A third defining characteristic might be the vast wealth, or at least the semblance of it, which allows hugely indebted clubs to set new world records for transfer fees practically every season.

Such conspicuous consumption is not on display in La Coruna. But the other qualities can be found, albeit in a lower register, in this medium-sized fishing town in Galicia, in the top left-hand corner of Spain, where Deportivo, founded in 1906, are the reigning champions of La Liga and ready to challenge Leeds United for a place in the semi-finals of the European Cup.

Deportivo's 4-2 victory over Villarreal at the weekend consolidated their second place in the domestic table and extended an unbeaten home league record stretching back 14 months. It was also an example of almost everything that is best about Spanish football, which has entered the new century as Europe's ruling power. Deportivo played on Saturday as if the only point of the game were to score more goals than the opposition, and to accomplish the task with grace and dash and wit.

Test of the best

Emerson Leao, Brazil's national coach, must have felt at home as he watched from the VIP box, and not just because of the presence of several of his fellow countrymen on the pitch. Still smarting from last week's historic 1-0 defeat at the hands of Ecuador, Leao was there to check the form of Deportivo's Djalminha and Emerson Costa but came away praising the match for its overall entertainment value.

Four Spanish teams are among the 12 taking part in this week's rounds of the major European club championships, and three of them are drawn against English sides. Apart from Leeds and Deportivo, Arsenal meet Valencia tomorrow and Liverpool travel to Barcelona to contest a place in the Uefa Cup final on Thursday. The fourth Spanish club, Real Madrid, continue the defence of their title against Galatasaray tonight and, if they make the semi-final, they will meet the winners of the tie between Manchester United and Bayern Munich.

The Spanish clubs currently occupy the four top positions in their domestic league, as do their English counterparts, which means that the next couple of weeks offers a direct confrontation between two leagues who both consider themselves the world's best. The Spanish, in particular, are hoping to repeat their feat of last season, when the supporters of Real Madrid and Valencia borrowed the Stade de France to turn the European Cup final into a glorious party.

At Elland Road tomorrow night Leeds's David O'Leary will find a formidable opponent in Javier Irureta, the quiet Basque who has coached Deportivo for the past three years. With the backing of Augusto Cesar Lendoiro, a local businessman who took over the presidency in 1988, when the club were in danger of relegation to the third division and had only 5,000 members, the coach has assembled an impressive squad.

Its depth is such that it can ride the absence through injury of players such as Mauro Silva and Cesar Sampaio, the midfield anchors of Brazil's 1994 and 1998 World Cup teams, and Walter Pandiani, the Uruguayan forward whose hat-trick brought Deportivo back from a three-goal deficit at home to Paris St-Germain last month and gave them an astonishing 4-3 victory. On Saturday the substitutes included Roy Makaay, the Dutch international forward, who came on in the final minutes to score the fourth goal with an expert flourish.

Before that, however, the supporters had been treated to a display of the flickering genius of the 30-year-old Djalminha, whose instant control brought him the opening goal, and the developing talent of Diego Tristan, a 24-year-old centre- forward who showed his power on the ball and his instinct for an opening with two fine goals. An athlete with the rangy build of a Steven Gerrard or a Sebastian Deisler, the Seville-born Tristan promises to become as significant a figure for Spain as he already is for La Coruna.

Their habit of giving the ball away in midfield, often via over-ambitious flicks from the Brazilian duo, and frequent lapses of concentration in the central defence will have interested the two spies O'Leary sent to the Riazor on Saturday. But, as long as the goals keep going in, the club's 27,000 voting members will be happy.

"The fans like the football here because every game is an open competition," Makaay said on Saturday night. "That makes it very different from Italy.

"People in Spain are very proud of what their football has achieved. Spanish clubs have reached five European finals in the past few years. And it's not just the big clubs. Alaves did well in Europe last year and there was the surprise of Valencia reaching the Champions League final. But English football is good, too. We know that Leeds have a good young team and I think we'll be starting 50-50 with them."

Perhaps the excellent health of Spanish football is also due to the closer involvement of the supporters, who enjoy real rights in return for their ardour. Barcelona's 104,000 members, for example, can vote their presidents into and out of office. After losing Luis Figo to Real Madrid last summer, their team has not had a great season in the league and the Nou Camp was barely half full on Sunday, which means that a mere 55,000 were present when Barca met 12th-placed Las Palmas, captained by Vinny Samways, the former Tottenham midfield man, but a 4-1 win left the crowd in a mood that matched the balmy evening.

Leao was present once again, this time to keep an eye on Rivaldo, whose play had been notable only for its incoherence when, in the 72nd minute, he ran through the visitors' defence to meet Frank de Boer's 60-yard diagonal pass. One velvety touch to control the dropping ball, an instant left-foot shot and Barca had their third goal, capped two minutes later by an effort from Dani which ended Las Palmas' resistance.

They could have had half a dozen more - but they could have given away a few more, too, and it is hard to imagine Liverpool allowing Marc Overmars the kind of space and time in which he was able to exploit a string of passes from the impressive 20-year-old Xavi.

For all the excellence of the five Dutchmen who wore Barca's shirt on Sunday, this season might be the last for the orange-dominated team assembled by their former coach, Louis van Gaal. The emergence of Xavi, Tristan and Las Palmas' outstanding pair of local boys, the 19-year-old midfielder Jorge and the 21-year-old forward Antonio Guayre, prove that Spain is nurturing a new generation of gifted young players, but the probable arrival of the Argentine coach Hector Cuper from Valencia in the summer has prompted Barcelona to prepare an investment at least equal to the £40m received from Real Madrid for Figo in order to attract a pair of Buenos Aires prodigies, Juan Riquelme from Boca Juniors and Javier Saviola from River Plate.

The brandishing of vast sums of money, which maintains the aura of power and enables the top clubs to offer their fans the promise of glory, represents one face of Spanish football. But there is another side and it could be seen in La Coruna on Saturday night, an hour after the final whistle, when Irureta was leaving the ground, on his way to celebrate his 53rd birthday with a group of friends.

His progress towards his car, which was parked across the street, was delayed for many minutes while he paused willingly to sign autographs and accept kisses from young girls and admire the ball-juggling tricks of small dark-eyed boys with dreams of their own. Here, a stone's throw from Chacho's statue, nobility and warmth could still be found.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Effi and other Teutons from outer space

fields.headline: Effi and other Teutons from outer space
fields.trailText: Drunk driving, assault and sent home from a World Cup - if anyone has fought tirelessly to overturn the stereotypical image of the diligent Teutonic footballer it is Stefan Effenberg.
fields.body:
The appearance of Bayern Munich at Old Trafford tonight will doubtless occasion much talk of discipline, well-oiled professionalism and "the German mentality".

For those of us who bridle at such generalisations the news that Bayern's skipper Stefan Effenberg has recovered from a back injury is therefore most welcome. Though he has certainly been well oiled on a number of occasions, the tall midfielder has otherwise fought tirelessly to overturn the stereotypical image of the diligent Teutonic footballer.

Effi has been convicted of drunken driving, accused of assault, sent home from a World Cup after giving a single-digit salute to German fans and fined by his club after a fracas in a disco. If Gheorghe Hagi is the Maradona of the Carpathians, then Effenberg is the Edmundo of the Bavarian Alps.

The years have not mellowed the man who once ridiculed Bayern's Bundesliga rivals as "too stupid" to win the title. "Nobody tells me how I should present myself in public. I will completely shit on anyone who does that," the tall midfielder responded when his choice of costume for the club Christmas party was criticised - reasonably you might think since it included lederhosen and a stetson - by Bayern's president Franz Beckenbauer.

Not that Beckenbauer is not used to abuse and in-fighting. Indeed it is probably a relief to have it coming from only one direction for a change because, despite the prevailing image of Germany's players as the ultimate worthy professionals, the truth is that over the past three decades the Bundesliga has produced a bumper crop of dissidents.

Mindful perhaps of Berti Vogts's maxim that "he who buries his head in the sand dies therein", these dissenters have made a habit of never allowing team-mates, managers or administrators to avoid reality no matter how unpalatable it may be. Or, as Mario Basler once put it: "People throw their mustard."

One fellow who was definitely keen on chucking the brown stuff was Beckenbauer's international team-mate Paul Breitner, a man who does not so much court controversy as molest it at every opportunity. The World Cup winner was nicknamed "Der Afro" after his flossy hair, though he might as justifiably have been dubbed "Der Aggro" in honour of a stirring ability that suggests a past life as a cement mixer.

And then he would say that, if he had known it was a cowboy job you wanted sorting out, he would have sent the Lone Ranger.

Matthäus's career as a troublemaker had many high points but probably reached its peak in 1995 when he called for his dispute with Jürgen Klinsmann to be settled in a televised duel.

Basler and Matthäus have gone but luckily, when it comes to causing ructions, Effenberg seems capable of doing the work of three men. "When I get pushed into a corner, then I get personally unpleasant," he snarled recently. His back injury may have cleared up but Effi still has the hump.

fields.headline: Keane at the cutting edge
fields.trailText: It's the midfield battles that will decide whether Bayern can avenge their 1999 European Cup final defeat, and whether Sir Alex Ferguson will stay on track for the second title he hankers for, writes David Lacey.
fields.body:
Manchester United are only three victories away from their first hat-trick of championship titles yet the season at Old Trafford will begin to ring a little hollow should Sir Alex Ferguson's team fail to achieve the sort of result against Bayern Munich tonight which will keep alive their hopes of another European Cup triumph.

United's manager has set his heart on winning the trophy again before he retires at the end of next season. But to reach the last four they have to overcome not the best Bayern team there has ever been, but one still tasting the bitterness of a 2-1 injury-time defeat by United in the final two years ago. "This time we will be fully concentrated for 95 minutes," said Stefan Effenberg, Bayern's captain.

"I just hope that this time the godfather of football is looking towards FC Bayern," added Franz Beckenbauer, the club president.

The pattern of tonight's match, with a second leg in the Olympic stadium in 15 days, will largely be decided by who wins the midfield: Roy Keane and Paul Scholes or Effenberg and Jens Jeremies. The United pair were suspended for the 1999 final, when Jeremies alone promised to win the match. Ferguson had switched Ryan Giggs to the right wing and put David Beckham in the middle with Jesper Blomqvist on the left. The result was both unbalanced and ungainly.

This evening Bayern, who have lost the injured Thorsten Fink from the right of midfield, will face a full-strength Manchester United. "1-0 would be fine for me," said Ferguson yesterday.

Much depends on the ability of Ferguson's players to set a brisk tempo while remembering to keep their shape and not set themselves up for the sort of sucker punches with which Real Madrid knocked them out in last season's quarter-finals.

"We felt we should have done better last time," Ferguson said, "but maybe it was Real's year, I don't know."

Bayern, like United, rested several players at the weekend and lost 3-2 at home to Werder Bremen. Afterwards the coach Ottmar Hitzveld said that if his team played as badly tonight "we have no chance, we might as well stay in Munich".

United should be so lucky. They know that the return of Mehmet Scholl, suspended against Bremen, will pose the kind of threat between midfield and back four which has undone them in the past. And the crosses of Bixente Lizarazu from the left will be as big a potential danger as Beckham's from the right at the other end.

United, moreover, will not need reminding, that at Highbury Bayern came from 2-0 down to hold Arsenal 2-2. Tonight, a clean sheet will be almost as welcome as a win.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Barthez; G Neville, Brown, Stam, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Sheringham, Cole.

Bayern Munich (probable, 4-3-1-2): Kahn; Linke, Kuffour, Andersson, Lizarazu; Salihamidzic, Jeremies, Effenberg; Scholl; Elber, Jancker.

Referee : AJ Lopez Nieto (Spain).

fields.headline: Kuffour ready for revenge
fields.trailText: Bayern's Sammy Kuffour is a bitter man, but the one-time shoeshine boy from Kumasi is ready to do the right thing at Old Traford tonight despite a torrid weekend in the Bundesliga.
fields.body:
Stefan Effenberg has promised to dance in his "favourite red lederhosen" and climbing boots if, as he has vowed, Bayern Munich avenge their bitter Champions' League final defeat by Manchester United. Quite how Sammy Kuffour will celebrate, no one knows.

Kuffour's tears and beating fists as he crouched with his head in the Nou Camp turf - he had to be borne up like a funeral mourner as he awaited his loser's medal - are the abiding images in the moment of cruel defeat in the 1999 final.

"It was as if the whole world had fallen on me," he recalls. "I couldn't control my tears. I cried again when my daughter called me from Accra after the match. I have not watched the tape to see what might have gone wrong."

If, in Bayern's eyes, wrongs are righted against United over the next fortnight, then expect the African defender's joy to be as spontaneous and as vividly expressed as his grief in Barcelona. But, whatever this devout Christian does, "God will direct," he says. "His grace is always with me. I want everyone to know He is with me at all times."

Judging by Bayern's performance in Saturday's 3-2 home defeat by Werder Bremen, when Kuffour was blamed by some for all three goals, the Ghanaian will not be alone in needing assistance from above at Old Trafford tonight.

But, as an important member of one of the continent's most powerful teams, he can also boast Bundesliga and German Cup medals - not bad for a one-time shoeshine boy from Kumasi who left school at 13 and Africa at 15.

For many neutrals the 24-year-old was the man of the match in the Nou Camp, subduing Dwight Yorke with his powerful, aggressive defending. His list of admirers has increased since. He claimed he had "a lengthy talk with Manchester United officials" after the 1999 final. Lately it has been Barcelona.

Kuffour, contracted to Bayern until 2003, was told he was going nowhere and fined £3,000 last month for talks over a meal in Munich with Bernd Schuster, who was acting for Barcelona. The player initially retorted: "I'm no slave. I can go out for dinner after training with whoever I like." Later, he admitted: "I was a little bit foolish."

The Ghanaian attributes much of his success to Giovanni Trapattoni, the Italian former Bayern coach: "He is the best in the world. He made me the player I am today." Trapattoni reciprocates: "In terms of athleticism and commitment he is first rate. He sticks so close to his striker that you expect him to follow the man to the changing room at half-time."

German critics were not so kind to Kuffour after Saturday's error-strewn display. But no one knows which Kuffour will be seen at Old Trafford: the disciplined marker, or the headstrong defender who was sent off for Bayern five times last season. For tonight, and for his entire future, "God will direct."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Manchester United 0 - 1 Bayern Munich
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Manchester United Barthez, Gary Neville, Brown, Stam, Silvestre, Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs, Cole, Solskjaer. Subs: Van Der Gouw, Irwin, Butt, Sheringham, Phil Neville, Yorke, Chadwick.

Bayern Munich Kahn, Kuffour, Andersson, Linke, Salihamidzic, Effenberg, Jeremies, Lizarazu, Scholl, Jancker, Elber. Subs: Dreher, Sagnol, Weisinger, Sergio, Tarnat, Zickler, Santa Cruz.

Referee Antonio Jesus Lopez Nieto (Malaga).

1 Solskjaer and Cole start up front for United who get the game underway at a packed Old Trafford. Giggs knocks it back to Silvestre who tries an early ball to Beckham on the right. Kahn clears for Bayern as Salihamidzic makes an early charge for the visitors.
5 Big roar, surprise, surprise, as Beckham pops up on the left. Doesn't do much and Mr Stroppy (otherwise known as Herr Effenberg) gets in on the action with a clearance.
7 Cole's cross - or was it a shot, you can never be too sure - spins across the Bayern goal with no one there to meet it.
8 Corner to United after Silvestre gets all the way to the Bayern area before being disposessed by Kuffour. The ball bounces in and out of the area, a United throw follows, Beckham whips one in. Bayern clear as Salihamidzic tries to feed it out Scholl - asked too much of him.
10 Another corner to United - Beckham takes, a little deeper this time, but Kahn makes the save when United eventually get round to popping it in. Swift passing by United has given them the advantage in the opening minutes. The pressure's on Bayern at the moment.
12 Great ball by Scholes over the top to Solskjaer; he tries to square the ball to Cole but a Bayern defender gets there first. Silvestre yet again makes a telling run into the Bayern area - Bayern acting as if they have never seen him before.
16 Bayern starting to get themselves together as Effenberg and Jeremies start to knock the ball around in midfield. Jeremies wins a corner after pressuring Barthez. Scholl takes towards Jancker, Linke gets his head to it but United clear. Good cross and a warning to United.
19 Superb ball by Bekham finds Cole in perfect position but the United marksman gets confused, thinks he is in an England shirt and drills the ball into the ground (one England won't erase all the misses, Andy).
22 Not much offensive action from the Germans as they try to take the sting out of United's lively start. That said, Jancker then has a shot on goal as Bayern step up the pace - easy for Barthez.
24 Booking Beckham for a challenge on Effenberg. Harsh as not even Effenberg seemed too bothered by it. Beckham will now miss the return at the Olympic stadium.
27 Bayern turn defence into offence when Effenberg breaks a United attack to find Lizarazu; Bayern break and Salihamidzic blows the chance when he blasts his shot wide.
28 Booking Salihamidzic - he also misses the return in Munich. Free-kick to United just outside the area. Beckham takes - straight at Kahn.
32 United free-kick; Silvestre to the feet of Giggs five yards out, he finds Cole but again it is easy for Kahn.
35 Giggs has a run at Kuffour in an attempt to get United out of their own half, Kuffour stands firm.
36 Solskjaer beats the offside trap to reach the left side of the Bayern area but he goes too wide and Bayern clear for a United corner. Beckham takes but it comes to nothing.
38 Another corner to United. Beckham towards Keane, in and out and at the end of it all, Beckham clashes with Effenberg yet again when the Bayern captain trips him just outside the area. Effenberg booked for his trouble. Beckham takes the free-kick but it comes to nothing.
41 Salihamidzic tries to get Keane booked but the ref is having none of it.
43 Bayern free-kick just inside the United half, but Effenberg doesn't make it count. Bayern keeping United pinned back in the final minutes of the half.
44 Silvestre tries to break out with a ball over the top towards Giggs - comes to nothing.
45 No stoppage time as the ref blows for half-time. Finely poised so far with both sides giving heaps of respect to the other. Despite three bookings, respect rules the atmosphere on the pitch and brotherly love abounds. Not much in it.

46 Bayern get the second 45 underway.
47 Free-kick to the Germans one yard outside the United area; Effenberg takes and puts it on the roof of the net - close escape for United.
49 Some needle developing when Effenberg refuses to shake hands after being up-ended by Beckham. the ref has to step in to make sure they kiss and make up.
50 The friendly mood of the first half looks to be crumbling as Brown and Jancker clash - Jancker concedes to foul.
51 Bayern break with Jancker and force a corner on the United left - United clear.
53 Scholl bursts through the middle to play in Elber on the edge of the United for a snap shot that Barthez tips over. Corner comes to nothing. Lively start by Bayern leaves United looking dodgy at the back after a couple of good chances for the visitors.
56 Great work by Jeremies to deny Scholes a shooting chance from a Cole cross to the far post.
57 Beckham knocks the ball back to Cole just outside the area but he can't get in a shot.
59 Scholes with a 40 yard pass towards Solskjaer up on the right, but the ball runs out.
62 Silvestre does well to make space for a shot; Kahn spills it, Cole lays it back for Scholes 15 yards out but Scholl slides in for the challenge.
64 Stam comes off best in the battle of the big men when Jancker is muscled off the ball on the edge of the United area.
65 Great 30-yard shot by Jeremies has Barthez stretching to tip over. Scholl takes the corner but Bayern are forced out.
68 Solskjaer does well to play in Beckham on the edge of the Bayern area. Backham knocks it in and Bayern make a meal of the clearance.
69 Substitution Zickler on for Jancker.
70 Barthez quick off his line to deny Zickler.
72 Free-kick to United bang on the edge of the Bayern area after Lizarazu fouled Beckham; Beckham takes and fires high into the crowd.
74 Stop of the night by Barthez after Jeremies forces his way into right side of the area - Barthez stands tall and makes the save.
77 Substitution Sergio on for Scholl. Solskjaer gets play unserway again with a charge to the edge of the United area; Kahn gets down to save, albeit with a small spill just to keep things lively. United's build-up play not looking as sharp as the first half.
79 Kahn forced down again at the near post by a 20-yard Silvestre shot.
80 Elber pulls away from Brown 20 yards out; finds Effenberg, who puts his tame shot wide of the right-hand post. Bayern looking confident and controlled as United start to look just a little desperate and anxious.
82 Zickler turns on sixpence in the United area and blasts against the bar as United ride their luck. After Scholl's and Jancker's srtikes against the bar in the closing minutes of the 1999 final, is this a good omen for United?
84 Booking Lizarazu for a tackle on Cole just outside the Bayern area. Lizarazu the third player to rule himself out of the second leg. Beckham plays the free-kick square for Scholes to fire into the crowd.
86 GOAL: Manchester United 0 - 1 Bayern Munich Sergio gets the vital away goal for Bayern; Linke knocks the ball into space six-yards out to find Sergio unmarked from a looping ball over the top by Effenberg..
87 Substitution Yorke on for Beckham.
90 No signs of the 'traditional' United comeback, but Giggs wins a corner on the Bayern right. Bayern clear. Barthez comes out almost to the half-way line and looks for Yorke in the area - no go. Bayern have the last chance of the game as Zickler runs on to a long ball and shoots over from 10 yards. Full-time: Manchester United 0 - 1 Bayern Munich. Great performance away from home by the Germans and a deserved victory, all told.

webTitle: Lobbying for the future of the NHS

fields.headline: Lobbying for the future of the NHS
fields.standfirst: Nigel Edwards turned down a lucrative consultancy position because his job at the NHS Confederation keeps him where the action is
fields.trailText: Nigel Edwards turned down a lucrative consultancy because his job at the NHS Confederation keeps him where the action is.
fields.body:
Name Nigel Edwards
Age 39
Job policy director of the NHS Confederation
Salary "Comparable with a senior manager in a large NHS organisation"

Nigel Edwards worked as an NHS manager, and as a health policy consultant at the London School of Tropical Hygiene before joining the NHS Confederation in 1999.

"Lobbying is a big part of what we do," he says. "One of the most interesting jobs is talking to special advisers and civil servants, and talking about where the NHS goes next.

"One of the things I have discovered is that the way to influence policy is to be 'upstream' - meaning ahead of the game. You have got to be in there [Whitehall] saying 'this is an interesting idea' before the policy is actually written."

Mr Edwards says it is practically no use only responding to formal government consultation documents - because by then the policy is already practically decided.

For Mr Edwards, it is the nature of the job - the meetings with special advisers, civil servants and ministers, of briefing journalists, of finding solutions to policy problems, of influencing policy, the "big picture" stuff - that attracts.

"Before I took the confederation job I was offered a post with a consultancy. The salary difference was a substantial five-figure sum. I chose the confederation because I go to work whistling."

fields.headline: Kicking off the shackles
fields.standfirst: A job in NHS policy can unleash the critical faculties and give ex-managers and clinicians an opportunity to speak their minds
fields.trailText: A job in NHS policy can unleash the critical faculties and give ex-managers and clinicians an opportunity to speak their minds, writes Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
So bland and cautious is the corporate culture of the modern NHS, it is difficult not to see in that small cadre of ex-managers and clinicians who have swapped a job in the health service for the world of NHS policy a certain subversive glamour.

Combining academia, lobbying, journalism, consultancy and politics, they write articles for the British Medical Journal, pop up with soundbites on Newsnight or in the Guardian, write pamphlets, lobby ministers and discuss "the big picture" at conference seminars.

At a time when publicly criticising health policy can be career kamikaze for NHS managers or civil servants, those people in organisations such as the NHS Confederation and the King's Fund have a clear - and luxurious - licence to say the "unsayable".

A few years ago, Jennifer Dixon, director of health care policy at the King's Fund, published an article which revealed that GP fundholders received disproportionately more funding than their non-fundholder colleagues.

The article was highlighted by the media, and became the basis for an inquiry into fundholding by the Commons health select committee. The then health secretary Virginia Bottomley was livid. Says Dr Dixon: "There are times when you score a direct hit."

The former public health doctor contrasts this with her spell as an "insider" on secondment to the Department of Health as policy adviser to former NHS chief executive Alan Langlands between 1998 and 2000.

"In the department you are less pro-active. Most of your work is non-attributable to you, and although you help develop policy, political advisers tend to formulate the new ideas. At the King's Fund I can be much more my own person."

Dr Dixon also had a spell in academia. "The difference between here and the University is that here if you appear in the newspaper, that is seen as part of your job, which is refreshing. In the University it is seen as rather eccentric."

Although she sometimes misses the contact with patients that frontline NHS clinical work brings, she has no regrets about moving to the King's Fund. "I did not find medicine intellectually stretching; you can easily get stuck on a kind of tramline and feel you cannot do anything else."

Nigel Edwards, director of policy at the NHS Confederation, says: "I enjoyed my time as a health service manager, but as a manager you spend so much time on day-to-day stuff, and less on fundamental policy questions. I was more interested in the 'big picture' stuff."

The confederation represents NHS trusts and health authorities, lobbies ministers on their behalf, briefs its members and the media on policy issues, and disseminates good practice.

It counts among its most recent successes the work it did on the NHS plan in spring 2000. It sat on government working groups and ended up steering several confederation ideas - including human resources policy and ambulatory care hospitals - into the final document.

Mr Edwards points out that although on occasion it has been critical of government policy - such as over the private finance initiative - it does not have the total freedom of independently-funded organisations like the King's Fund.

Getting to the heart of policy formulation requires a difficult political balancing act - speaking honestly about members' concerns and yet securing and maintaining the trust of ministers.

"Do you go onto the Today programme and say the NHS is failing and in meltdown - and then find that your appointment with the minister is cancelled? That is death for an organisation like ours. If that means sometimes biting your lips then we have to do it."
