webTitle: From the NHS frontline to policy work

fields.headline: From the NHS frontline to policy work
fields.trailText: There is no conventional career structure, formal training course or qualifications should you want to move from the NHS frontline to policy work, and jobs are few and far between.
fields.body:
There is no conventional career structure, formal training course or qualifications should you want to move from the NHS frontline to policy work, and jobs are few and far between.

"You need to have a rigorous mind, a mind that sees the bigger picture; you need political awareness; you need to be able to write; and you need to be able to distil complex ideas simply and swiftly," says Jennifer Dixon, director of health care policy at the King's Fund.

It's less corporate, less pressured, and certainly less routine than NHS management or medicine. But it's probably not as well paid, and there's no guarantee you can pick up your NHS career should you want to go back.

NHS policy is not a natural career move for the ambitious manager or clinician, and certainly not guaranteed to propel people into top NHS positions, although it can lead to a job in politics and/or consultancy.

Peter Griffiths, a former NHS manager who became deputy chief executive of the King's Fund, believes young managers should be encouraged to take secondments out of the NHS or Department of Health into independent policy-making organisations.

However, Mr Griffiths, now chief executive of the charity Health Quality Service, adds: "I do not think we have in the management culture of the NHS a feeling that deliberately constructing different kinds of experience is something that you are encouraged to do."

Nigel Edwards, policy director of the NHS Confederation, is unconvinced. "I find operational managers are less interested in policy as such. It would broaden their knowledge but would not necessarily help them if they went back to the NHS.

"The reason why they employ us is because its hard to think about policy when you are trying to keep the operational wheels in motion on a day-to-day basis."

fields.headline: Clash over 'hostels' for nurses
fields.trailText: The Conservatives and Labour have clashed over Tory proposals to provide "hostels" for nurses and teachers priced out of the property market.
fields.body:
The Conservatives and Labour have clashed over Tory proposals to provide "hostels" for nurses and teachers priced out of the property market.

The idea was put forward by Tory housing and regeneration spokesman Tim Loughton at a pre-election housing debate sponsored by the Guardian.

He suggested large public sector employers such as the NHS should consider housing their own staff in hostels or shared accommodation.

The idea was dismissed as "nebulous" by housing minister Nick Raynsford.

Nursing leaders also attacked the suggestion. Dee Borley, director of the Royal College of Nurses' help and support service Nurseline, said she was "alarmed" by the proposal.

Speaking at the debate she told Mr Loughton that the idea suggested nurses would have to become "backpackers".

"The issue in London is about the loss of experienced staff. Hostel accommodation is not going to help," she told SocietyGuardian.co.uk.

Ms Borely also attacked the idea of "tied cottages" for key workers.

Mr Loughton later distanced himself from his earlier comments and claimed he was not suggesting "bunk beds" for nurses, but added that hostel or shared accommodation would need to be part of the solution.

Mr Loughton also criticised the government's £250m starter homes initiative for key workers and claimed it would stoke demand for housing without increasing supply.

"It will actually make the problem worse, because it's a demand-side solution rather than a supply-side solution," she said.

But Mr Raynsford replied: "Tim Loughton's view is a complete cop out. His party presided over the most appalling housing environment for people who were first priced out of the market and then forced to leave their homes in repossessions."

Housing for key workers has emerged as one of key social problems since the last election, as the effects of property boom in the south-east have begun to bite. The shortage of housing for staff has led to a recruitment crisis that threatens to undermine government initiatives on crime, health and education.

It was one the main source of disagreement at the debate, which was organised by the Chartered Institute of Housing.

Mr Loughton admitted that the parties "agree a lot on social housing".

But he also taunted the government for failing to hit its target of 60% development on previously developed land. Mr Raynsford admitted that the government had only achieved 52% development on brownfield sites but claimed it was "well on course to meet the 60% target".

Mr Raynsford praised the former conservative environment secretary John Gummer for recognising the need to protect greenfield land, but pointed out that only 42% of development was on brownfield land under the last government.

"John Gummer repented in the end for the sins of his colleagues, but it was a very late repentance," he said.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Jess
fields.trailText: I spent six weeks in New Zealand myself. Rotorua is definitely worth a visit - try to do a tour around the geezers and mud pools. Queenstown in the south of the South Island is the place for outdoor pursuits.
fields.body:
Hi Sue!

Its been most interesting reading about your adventures. I spent six weeks in New Zealand myself. Rotorua is definitely worth a visit - try to do a tour around the geezers and mud pools, etc. Queenstown in the south of the South Island is the place for outdoor pursuits, and if you are feeling brave, go bungy jumping! You won't regret it - an adrenalin rush, that's for sure - and Queenstown is the place where it started! Milford Sound is beautiful - you can take a boat trip down the fjiords and try some penguin- and dolphin-spotting. Try to get a ferry from South island to North island, cheap and cheerful!
Good luck!

webTitle: The charged atmosphere of creative writing courses

fields.headline: Rumour at the top
fields.standfirst:
The poet laureate is embroiled in a bitter dispute with one of his writing students. Each accuses the other of harassment. Novelist Anna Davis explains how the highly charged atmosphere on such courses can lead - at the very least - to gossip

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The poet laureate is embroiled in a bitter dispute with one of his writing students. Each accuses the other of harassment. Novelist  Anna Davis explains how the highly charged atmosphere on such courses can lead - at the very least - to gossip
fields.body:
Andrew Motion, the poet laureate, has complained to the authorities at the University of East Anglia, where he runs the prestigious MA course in creative writing, that he has been harassed by a former student. The student, meanwhile, claims that it was Motion who was harassing her. Motion's wife, the writer and critic Jan Dalley, is reported as saying the student had a "crush" on her husband which turned "sour", and also that "crushy-type relationships" are bound to happen to creative writing tutors because "they talk about emotions".

I teach on Manchester University's MA course in novel writing. A few years ago, before getting my first publishing deal, I was a student on the East Anglia course, and know just how high the stakes are for writing students. Studying on a creative writing course is not like studying 20th-century history or astrophysics. It is deeply personal and highly precarious. Writing is striptease: even when not writing about your own life and experiences, you are constantly revealing yourself on the page; you are showing something about your obsessions and preoccupations; about the creative energy which drives you. Being accepted on to one of these courses is a real buzz - someone "in the know" is saying that your writing is attractive; that you are attractive.

Most creative writing courses feature "the workshop", in which students disclose their work to the tutors and the group. Workshops are terrifying - you feel that you are really laying yourself on the line. Sometimes you emerge feeling as though you have been ripped apart. Other times you might be showered with praise: "I love your work. Your writing is so passionate, so gorgeous and sensual. I just think you're so clever." It's hardly surprising that in such a highly charged environment, students get crushes on their tutors - and vice versa.

The creative writing tutor is a charismatic figure. You are a published novelist (or poet), which means you know "the secret". Your praise means so much more than that of fellow students because it comes from this position of secret knowledge. The students know that you must believe some of them to be better writers than others, and occasionally students vie to be "the one" whose work you truly rate.

For so many of them the creative writing course is about dream fulfilment - and you are the one with the power. Many tutors play favourites, giving more attention to a few talented students than to the rest - taking the chosen ones to restaurants and bars, visiting them in their homes . This can be the start of something - perhaps gossip; or perhaps something more. It is very easy to take advantage of people who look up to you; who hang on your every word.

It is not always the student who pursues the tutor. Contrary to popular belief, writers do not typically lead glamorous lives. The writer spends most of his or her time in a tiny room, trying to force words out on to a blank page or screen. It is a lonely and frequently boring existence, and sometimes you wonder if anyone is actually out there listening to you. Think how wonderful it is, then, to emerge into a room full of people who think you are something special. Some of these people might be genuinely talented - a fresh talent that hasn't yet slipped into the mire of cynicism and bitterness in which so many seasoned writers languish. And some of them might be young and nubile .

Now, I'm sure - and, in fact, hope - that any of my current and former students reading this article will have just laughed their cornflakes across the table. We're by no means all "at it". But there are far too many potentially libellous stories circulating around the "creative writing circuit" - and featuring a wide array of tutors and students from MA courses, short residential writing courses and writing workshops at literary festivals - for them all to be complete fabrication. Writing teachers are the new Rodins and Gauguins. Sex with students is like sex with the life model or apprentice in their day - just good bohemian fun. There are lots of people "at it" out there. You know who you are.

It is easier for male tutors who wish to indulge in this particular form of recreation than it is for heterosexual women - mainly because there are always so many more women studying creative writing. The class I am currently teaching has three men and 10 women, which is typical. Most of the stories you hear are about young female students and older male teachers, and this of course fits in rather neatly with all the old cliches. But women tutors are also subject to temptation.

Until very recently all this talk of sex with students and of certain colourful characters who "play the circuit" seemed remote to me. But a few months ago, I was employed to teach a one-off creative writing workshop. In my class there was a very beautiful, friendly and articulate man who was about 10 years my junior. He was really rather lovely; he looked like a Greek god and he wrote very well.

Nothing improper happened, I hasten to say - I didn't so much as go for a cup of tea with him - but for the first time in my teaching experience, I felt certain that if I had wanted something to happen with this man, it would have done. Never mind that under normal circumstances he was too beautiful to be attracted to someone like me : I had the lure of the published novelist that day, and he was giving clear signals that he was available. The incident made me feel strange. It made me understand how easily these things can happen, and I had never actually understood it before.

Of course, so many of the rumours are unfounded, and some of them are very sad. Writing classes can and should be fun. I happen to think my students are a nice bunch of people and I enjoy the odd pint with them after class - with all of the students who turn up at the pub, not just a hand-picked few.

Writing students seem to expect to get to know their tutors on a personal level, perhaps more so than on other courses, and I'm sure that some of the most useful things I have said to my students have been in the bar. Does this mean I am laying myself open to allegations? I would hate to have to be frosty and distant in order to be beyond suspicion, but is this sufficiently prudent? I know of other novelists who have taken the decision to withdraw entirely from social interaction with students after bad experiences with aspiring writers who became infatuated and evolved into semi-stalkers. These people talk about "the need to be careful". What a shame it would be if this turned us all into a bunch of stiffs.

 Cheet by Anna Davis will be published by Hodder & Stoughton on May 21, priced £10.99

It is not always the student who pursues the tutor. Contrary to popular belief, writers do not typically lead glamorous lives. The writer spends most of his or her time in a tiny room, trying to force words out on to a blank page or screen. It is a lonely and frequently boring existence, and sometimes you wonder if anyone is actually out there listening to you. Think how wonderful it is, then, to emerge into a room full of people who think you are something special. Some of these people might be genuinely talented - a fresh talent that hasn't yet slipped into the mire of cynicism and bitterness in which so many seasoned writers languish. And some of them might be young and nubile . Now, I'm sure - and, in fact, hope - that any of my current and former students reading this article will have just laughed their cornflakes across the table. We're by no means all "at it". But there are far too many potentially libellous stories circulating around the "creative writing circuit" - and featuring a wide array of tutors and students from MA courses, short residential writing courses and writing workshops at literary festivals - for them all to be complete fabrication. Writing teachers are the new Rodins and Gauguins. Sex with students is like sex with the life model or apprentice in their day - just good bohemian fun. There are lots of people "at it" out there. You know who you are. It is easier for male tutors who wish to indulge in this particular form of recreation than it is for heterosexual women - mainly because there are always so many more women studying creative writing. The class I am currently teaching has three men and 10 women, which is typical. Most of the stories you hear are about young female students and older male teachers, and this of course fits in rather neatly with all the old cliches. But women tutors are also subject to temptation. Until very recently all this talk of sex with students and of certain colourful characters who "play the circuit" seemed remote to me. But a few months ago, I was employed to teach a one-off creative writing workshop. In my class there was a very beautiful, friendly and articulate man who was about 10 years my junior. He was really rather lovely; he looked like a Greek god and he wrote very well. Nothing improper happened, I hasten to say - I didn't so much as go for a cup of tea with him - but for the first time in my teaching experience, I felt certain that if I had wanted something to happen with this man, it would have done. Never mind that under normal circumstances he was too beautiful to be attracted to someone like me : I had the lure of the published novelist that day, and he was giving clear signals that he was available. The incident made me feel strange. It made me understand how easily these things can happen, and I had never actually understood it before. Of course, so many of the rumours are unfounded, and some of them are very sad. Writing classes can and should be fun. I happen to think my students are a nice bunch of people and I enjoy the odd pint with them after class - with all of the students who turn up at the pub, not just a hand-picked few. Writing students seem to expect to get to know their tutors on a personal level, perhaps more so than on other courses, and I'm sure that some of the most useful things I have said to my students have been in the bar. Does this mean I am laying myself open to allegations? I would hate to have to be frosty and distant in order to be beyond suspicion, but is this sufficiently prudent? I know of other novelists who have taken the decision to withdraw entirely from social interaction with students after bad experiences with aspiring writers who became infatuated and evolved into semi-stalkers. These people talk about "the need to be careful". What a shame it would be if this turned us all into a bunch of stiffs.  Cheet by Anna Davis will be published by Hodder & Stoughton on May 21, priced £10.99

webTitle: Poorly-paid postgrads providing up to half of all university teaching

fields.headline: Wanna study? Start teaching
fields.standfirst: Untrained, poorly paid postgrads are providing up to half of all university teaching, says  Tillie Harris
fields.trailText: Untrained, poorly paid postgrads are providing up to half of all university teaching, says Tillie Harris
fields.body:
As the Research Assessment Exercise casts its shadow over Britain's universities, we are again reminded that an academic's role is to research rather than to teach. But as undergraduate numbers continue to rise, someone has to teach students and this job is increasingly going to postgraduate students.

Virtually unheard of 30 years ago, postgraduate teachers now take on up to half of most universities' teaching. Most of these students are usually studying for PhDs. They are approached by their departments and invited to run seminars and mark work. It is unusual for a university to have a policy on employing postgraduates, and their working conditions vary widely.

"On the whole, postgraduates are at the mercy of unregulated and often bizarre policies," says a spokesperson for the Association of University teachers (AUT). "If they are lucky enough to have a contract - and a great many don't - it will be entirely different to that of the person they are sitting next to, even if they're working for the same university."

Andy Charlwood works as a postgraduate teacher at the London School of Economics where, he says, there are nearly 500 postgraduate teachers. "I was appointed by my head of department, without an interview. Postgraduates aren't interviewed, and while some departments provide a bit of training, nowhere near all of them do. Pay varies widely, too."

Charlwood is paid £90 for one hour of teaching, one hour of preparation and one hour of marking every week. But, he says, "in reality, the preparation to run a seminar takes four hours, and the marking always takes more than two hours a week."

A recent survey by the NUS and the AUT backs him up. The survey says that "postgraduate students primarily employed in teaching roles worked an average of 11.2 hours and were paid for an average of 5.3 hours".

While discrepancies between work done and payment received is hardly news in higher education, postgraduates feel particularly vulnerable as so much of their role is dictated by departmental whim rather than policy.

Rebecca Taylor, who has worked as a postgraduate teacher in Essex Uni versity's sociology department for the past three years, had no choice but to take up teaching duties. "It was a condition of my funding. The department advised me not to apply for funding, saying that I could have a bursary from them instead. What they didn't tell me was that I was obligated to teach for free in return.

"I had no training, and absolutely no support. And there was this sense of it all being such a big favour. I'm not sure undergraduates receive the kind of teaching they deserve."

Many students talk of the academic baptism of fire they face whenstarting to teach without training. One described how she was told she wasn't receiving much money but she was being rewarded by "symbolic capital".

This kind of work may provide a form of training for would-be lecturers, but the AUT worries how their employment affects existing staff and students.

It warns that postgraduate teaching "also impacts on the quality of undergraduate instruction and on other academic staff, whose conditions of employment may be undermined by the presence of a cheap unregulated labour force."

Dr Cris Shore, head of Goldsmith College's anthropology department, says the possibility of an academic being overlooked in favour of cheap postgraduates is unlikely. "They're different budgets," he says. "This department has £42,000 this year for postgraduates. We've used it to employ postgraduates on the highest pay we can.

"Postgraduates are not taking jobs away from academics - if we could not use them we'd just have to stop holding seminars. It's not something that you can blame departments for; every year the government spends proportionately less on universities - they are slowly being starved -while the RAE encourages an obsession with research. I don't think there is an academic in the country whose career has been furthered by the excellence of their teaching."

So as universities desperate to plug the gap in their teaching continue to recruit and employ PhD students, the unions are having to recognise that postgraduate teachers are here to stay. The AUT has revised its membership to include postgraduate teachers. It is also compiling a postgraduate employment charter in the hope of encouraging good practice.

Meanwhile, undergraduate students are receiving up to half their teaching from often poorly trained, under-supported post graduates. They may be gaining valuable "symbolic capital", but they are struggling to pay their "symbolic" rent.

webTitle: Radical measures needed to shore up falling demand for study places

fields.headline: Reversing a global trend
fields.standfirst: Radical measures are needed to shore up falling demand for study places. Susie Wild  reports
fields.trailText: Radical measures are needed to shore up falling demand for study places. Susie Wild reports
fields.body:
Engineering is in crisis. We may be in a technological age, but recruiting for the technology industries is reaching a desperate low. Numbers for university and HND courses in engineering and the traditional sciences have fallen steadily over the past few years, leaving the technology industry fearing for its future.

Despite last month's Budget announcement of an increase in funds for research and the development of new technology, there simply aren't the numbers of student applicants to meet demand.

The number of applicants to engineering courses fell across the board last year, said a Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (Ucas) spokesman. "The downward trend can be seen in traditional sciences, too, over the last few years, as more and more turn towards information technology."

Ucas applications to engineering and technology fell from 24,836 in 1998 to 22,184 last year, while maths and informatics applications increased from 27,830 in 1998 to 35,265 in the same period.

Sussex University said its engineering department had seen a 38% increase in applicants, but these related mainly to information technology and mechanical engineering.

It seems the science world is aware of the desperate situation. National Science Week, held last month, aimed to foster an appreciation of the role that science, engineering and technology plays in our lives, and the British Association and National Environment Research Council ran many events across the country to encourage young people to start a career in science.

The Institution of Mechanical Engineers in London hosted the Engineering Careers Awareness Day to give pupils information about different engineering careers and the practical problems engineers are required to solve. Meanwhile, Cardiff University held the Engineering Challenge 2001 to encourage local sixth-formers studying physics and maths to become engineers.

The head of civil engineering at Cardiff University, Professor Vernon Morgan, believes the problem of recruitment in engineering is not just a British one: "Only last week Sir David Davies was saying engineering applications are falling in Europe and worldwide. We've been fortunate in that we've held our numbers and are still demanding that 80% of our applicants for the BEng have more than 18 Ucas points.

"Some newer universities are fighting very hard to keep departments open, but our prospective figures for next year suggest we are no worse off than last year. We do, however, have to wait longer than departments such as history, who fill their quota within the first day of Ucas applications."

The endeavours of events such as National Science Week should bring some comfort to Ann Bailey, head of education and training at the Engineering Employers Federation. She is worried about the steady decline in engineering applicants. "We need a substantial number to enter engineering," she said. "It's so diverse a subject, encompassing telecoms, finance, leisure and tourism. We have an ageing population in the industry which means most will have retired in the next 10 years. It is therefore increasingly important that we have more people entering the industry at every level.

"The government needs to recognise the value of engineering, which should help people see a career in engineering as one within an industry of exciting opportunities."

However, despite the general belief in academia that IT applicants are on the increase, even this will not meet the demand in this sector. A new report by the e-skills training body, undertaken by Mori and NOP, reveals that the industry needs to recruit one million skilled people over the next five years.

The image of IT among schoolchildren also needs addressing, as they tend to see the industry as an option for nerds and geeks (and for males). The researchers suggest the introduction of a new programme to reinvigorate IT classes in schools and encourage work experience.

In response to the IT skills issue, the government is introducing a major new initiative backed by private sector companies, among them Ericsson, IBM, Intel and Microsoft.

fields.headline: Houllier: 'FA decision favours Ipswich'
fields.trailText: An angry Gerard Houllier has attacked the Premier League's decision not to move Liverpool's match at Ipswich next Tuesday as "an unfair ruling which favours Ipswich."
fields.body:
An angry Gerard Houllier has attacked the Premier League's decision not to move Liverpool's match at Ipswich next Tuesday as "an unfair ruling which favours Ipswich."

Houllier, Phil Thompson and Liverpool chief executive Rick Parry met Premier League officials in London on Friday to plead for the crucial game to be moved from April 10th to later in the season, to avoid his players "being treated like horses."

But today the Premier League ruled the match will go ahead despite Liverpool's protests - prompting a furious reaction from Houllier.

"They obviously want Ipswich to be in the Champions League rather than Liverpool," he said. "They say they care about English clubs in Europe but it appears they are doing everything against that and don't care about our Uefa Cup tie."

"Don't worry, we will cope," he added. "We have the physical and mental strength to do well in these games. And we take comfort in the fact that Liverpool's success is obviously annoying many people."

The match should have been staged this coming Saturday, but had to be moved because of Sunday's FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Wycombe Wanderers. Liverpool had suggested that the game be switched to the next international week, which starts on Monday, April 23. But that did not meet with league or Ipswich's approval.

"We felt we had a good meeting with the League on Friday and thought we presented a reasonable argument," said Parry. "We also didn't feel that we were asking for anything that was impossible.

"We didn't, for example, ask for the season to be extended and we always realised that the success we are having this season was going to present problems."

"It is fair to say that Ipswich were reluctant to move the match from next Tuesday," he added.

webTitle: Political scientists attempt to shake off the theory that dominates their discipline

fields.headline: Unreal, man
fields.standfirst: Political scientists have turned guerrillas in an attempt to shake off the stranglehold of the dogmatic, unworldly theory that dominates their discipline.  Kurt Jacobsen reports
fields.trailText: Political scientists have turned guerrillas in an attempt to shake off the stranglehold of the dogmatic, unworldly theory that dominates their discipline. Kurt Jacobsen reports
fields.body:
Throughout history, revolutions have caught the ruling elite unawares - even, it seems, when they are professors of political science. No one expected an argument about the use of mathematical modelling and "rational choice theory" in politics and economics research journals to blow up into an academic uprising which has spread from France to the rest of continental Europe, Britain and north America.

In the process it has highlighted the self-perpetuating elite that runs the most influential academic body in the subject, the American Political Science Association. This counts among its luminaries Henry Kissinger and president George Bush's foreign affairs adviser, Condoleeza Rice. The revolt has spawned scores of email guerrillas, inspired by "Mr Perestroika", who protested against the stranglehold of the rational choice theorists on academic journals - and hence on hopes of tenure and promotion. But most operate anonymously for fear of jeopardising their hopes of promotion and tenure.

Rational choice theory - the hottest thing in the social sciences - derives from neoclassical economics, which political scientists cannot help but notice grabs lots of Nobel Prizes.

The theory deploys a set of simplifying assumptions about human behaviour that boils down our complicated lives and societies to prioritised "rational" choices that we presumably make in order to maximise our "utility" in any given situation.

Rational choice, and mathematical models that accompany it, undeniably have merits when used with a bit of humility, especially in studies of collective action. But its critics argue the results are often trivial or else fail to display even a nodding acquaintance with reality.

Last June, in France, a "post-autistic economics" movement erupted in protest against the excesses of formal economics discourses. Over 800 university economics students and 150 professors signed a petition demanding reform of the curriculum to incorporate a "plurality of approaches adapted to the complexity of the object studied". Mathematics had become an end in itself, resulting in an "autistic science with no relation to real life".

In fierce counter-attacks the leading figures in the discipline perceived, or tried to portray, this revolt as doltish opposition to statistical techniques. The French government appointed a commission to examine the issue.

The movement quickly spread to Spain and across much of continental Europe, and is making inroads in the UK. French insurrectionists Gilles Raveaud and Ioana Marinescu appeared at King's College, Cambridge University at a workshop chaired by Professor Tony Lawson, whose book Economics and Reality is a favourite among these dissidents.

"The mathmaticisation of economics is happening everywhere, and students are voting with their feet and going elsewhere," says Lawson. The movement's aim was "greater pluralism".

Rational choice practitioners quickly became notorious for forming potent coteries that expanded their influence within departments in Britain.

"The governing principle in most sensible political science departments is that rational choice theorists should be on tap but not on top," says the chair of a top UK politics department, who prefers diplomatic anonymity. "They should exist, be permitted to flourish, but never be permitted dominance. Once dominant they are incapable of appointing other than their own: the more vulgar they are the more this is true."

In the United States the movement ignited in political science, which has been eagerly aping economics in its fondness for mathematical modelling. The American Political Science Association had been taken over by rational choice exponents and its journal, which is often a vital publishing outlet for aspiring academics, reflected their views.

The top echelon of the association may write about democratic politics - but they don't practise it, according to the dissidents who are now linking the dominance of rational choice in political science to the absence of internal democracy in their association.

Under a cosy arrangement an annually chosen president appoints his (80 times "his" versus only twice "her") ruling council who pick the next president who picks the next ruling council, and so on in a self-perpetuating process.

"In an era that values transparency, this looks like a glaring instance of a closed process," observes Lloyd Rudolph, professor of politics at Chicago University.

Keep in mind, if national security advisers are anything to go by, that the APSA gave us Henry Kissinger, who remarked that the Chilean people had no right to elect a socialist leader, and Zbigniew Brzezinski, who cheered democracy so long as the unlettered masses obeyed their betters and now Condoleeza Rice, who is of much the same bent.

The membership stayed in line, although many alienated political scientists quietly dropped out, until a clarion call came last November in a mass email. "Mr Perestroika" - probably a junior faculty member - lashed out against "poor game-theorists who cannot for the life of me compete with a third-grade economics student" yet are allowed to crush "diversity of methodologies and areas of the world that APSA 'purports' to represent". Mr Perestroika became the scarlet pimpernel of the reform movement.

Within a month of the emailing, a movement of several hundred insurgent professors crystallised, led by a committee of eminent scholars whom the association dared not ignore. By January 222 tenured faculty mem bers had signed a milder perestroika petition for reform, crafted by Yale's Roger Smith. This included 24 with named chairs - ranging from Yale political ethnographer James C Scott to Chicago University security specialist John Mearsheimer to Penn's semiotician Anne Norton.

The revolt transcends familiar categories of conservative, liberal and leftist.

"It's a wicked coalition," says Susanne Hoeber Rudolph, distinguished service professor at Chicago University, with a wry smile. "It is about getting pluralism back into political science. Why does the Association of Political Science Review seem so intensely focused on technical methods at the expense of the great substantive political questions?"

In a written response to the perestroika manifesto, APSA representative Ada Finifter revealed her belief that only personal ambition was at stake. She could not imagine why signatory dissenters were griping since they are twice as successful as anyone else at publishing in the review. She appeared oblivious to the ominous ambiguity of claiming that all is well so long as scholars provide "high-quality work using methods appropriate to the research problem" - as if the definition of thoseappropriate methods were not a major issue.

A conciliatory APSA recently announced the selection of a Perestroika-backed candidate as president, Theda Skocpol of Harvard University. Even this move is viewed with some suspicion. Might the APSA leaders calculate that Skocpol, despite being renowned as no pushover, might be most easily co-opted into the business-as-usual "East coast Brahmin" network and preserve the old undemocratic mechanisms? (In a body where everyone has read their Machiavelli, it is harder to be successfully Machiavellian.)

Most dissidents are willing to wait and see if Skocpol will carry out reforms that, as Mr Perestroika put it, dismantle "the Orwellian system that we have in the APSA and that we will see a true perestroika in the discipline".

It speaks volumes that many junior scholars are worried about revealing their identities in a profession that purports to prize vigorous and open exchange. Yet APSA deputy director Robert Hauck expressed great surprise that they needed to shield themselves from reprisals.

Perestroikans certainly do not oppose formal methods or mathematical models, Susanne Rudolph stresses, but rather their consecration as holy devices, squeezing out and denigrating cultural, historical and psychological understanding. Like Finifter, she agrees that the objective is to support "high-quality work using methods appropriate to the research problem", but like fellow Perestroikan Margaret Keck, and the Cambridge realist workshop, she believes that the "problem should dictate the method", not the other way around.

The ultimate aim is to improve democracy at large as well as within the organisation.

"The governing principle in most sensible political science departments is that rational choice theorists should be on tap but not on top," says the chair of a top UK politics department, who prefers diplomatic anonymity. "They should exist, be permitted to flourish, but never be permitted dominance. Once dominant they are incapable of appointing other than their own: the more vulgar they are the more this is true." In the United States the movement ignited in political science, which has been eagerly aping economics in its fondness for mathematical modelling. The American Political Science Association had been taken over by rational choice exponents and its journal, which is often a vital publishing outlet for aspiring academics, reflected their views. The top echelon of the association may write about democratic politics - but they don't practise it, according to the dissidents who are now linking the dominance of rational choice in political science to the absence of internal democracy in their association. Under a cosy arrangement an annually chosen president appoints his (80 times "his" versus only twice "her") ruling council who pick the next president who picks the next ruling council, and so on in a self-perpetuating process. "In an era that values transparency, this looks like a glaring instance of a closed process," observes Lloyd Rudolph, professor of politics at Chicago University. Keep in mind, if national security advisers are anything to go by, that the APSA gave us Henry Kissinger, who remarked that the Chilean people had no right to elect a socialist leader, and Zbigniew Brzezinski, who cheered democracy so long as the unlettered masses obeyed their betters and now Condoleeza Rice, who is of much the same bent. The membership stayed in line, although many alienated political scientists quietly dropped out, until a clarion call came last November in a mass email. "Mr Perestroika" - probably a junior faculty member - lashed out against "poor game-theorists who cannot for the life of me compete with a third-grade economics student" yet are allowed to crush "diversity of methodologies and areas of the world that APSA 'purports' to represent". Mr Perestroika became the scarlet pimpernel of the reform movement. Within a month of the emailing, a movement of several hundred insurgent professors crystallised, led by a committee of eminent scholars whom the association dared not ignore. By January 222 tenured faculty mem bers had signed a milder perestroika petition for reform, crafted by Yale's Roger Smith. This included 24 with named chairs - ranging from Yale political ethnographer James C Scott to Chicago University security specialist John Mearsheimer to Penn's semiotician Anne Norton. The revolt transcends familiar categories of conservative, liberal and leftist. "It's a wicked coalition," says Susanne Hoeber Rudolph, distinguished service professor at Chicago University, with a wry smile. "It is about getting pluralism back into political science. Why does the Association of Political Science Review seem so intensely focused on technical methods at the expense of the great substantive political questions?" In a written response to the perestroika manifesto, APSA representative Ada Finifter revealed her belief that only personal ambition was at stake. She could not imagine why signatory dissenters were griping since they are twice as successful as anyone else at publishing in the review. She appeared oblivious to the ominous ambiguity of claiming that all is well so long as scholars provide "high-quality work using methods appropriate to the research problem" - as if the definition of thoseappropriate methods were not a major issue. A conciliatory APSA recently announced the selection of a Perestroika-backed candidate as president, Theda Skocpol of Harvard University. Even this move is viewed with some suspicion. Might the APSA leaders calculate that Skocpol, despite being renowned as no pushover, might be most easily co-opted into the business-as-usual "East coast Brahmin" network and preserve the old undemocratic mechanisms? (In a body where everyone has read their Machiavelli, it is harder to be successfully Machiavellian.) Most dissidents are willing to wait and see if Skocpol will carry out reforms that, as Mr Perestroika put it, dismantle "the Orwellian system that we have in the APSA and that we will see a true perestroika in the discipline". It speaks volumes that many junior scholars are worried about revealing their identities in a profession that purports to prize vigorous and open exchange. Yet APSA deputy director Robert Hauck expressed great surprise that they needed to shield themselves from reprisals. Perestroikans certainly do not oppose formal methods or mathematical models, Susanne Rudolph stresses, but rather their consecration as holy devices, squeezing out and denigrating cultural, historical and psychological understanding. Like Finifter, she agrees that the objective is to support "high-quality work using methods appropriate to the research problem", but like fellow Perestroikan Margaret Keck, and the Cambridge realist workshop, she believes that the "problem should dictate the method", not the other way around. The ultimate aim is to improve democracy at large as well as within the organisation.

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: higher news
fields.body:
The third degree

 For several of those hard-pressed academics who breathed a sigh of relief when David Blunkett issued a reprieve, promising no more heavy-handed old style visitations from the Quality Assurance Agency police, here is the bad news: 151 heavy-handed, old-style inspections will carry on this autumn. The funding council wants a full set, apparently, before moving to the fabled "lighter touch". So for philosophers, theologians, classicists and political scientists there is no hiding place from bumf just yet.

 Meanwhile the battle royal over teaching quality assessments between the agency and its opponents in the funding councils and the universities is raging behind the scenes. Chief executive John Randall was (coincidentally?) a few thousand miles away in India when the education secretary was persuaded to order a 40% cut in inspections.

In a furious letter to Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the agency's chairman Christo pher Kenyon said: "I will not conceal my disappointment at this latest turn of events."

The agency had been wanting to move to a lighter touch last year, but Hefce had insisted on sticking to the old methods. The question of who should be exempt from future visits is by no means settled, it seems. In the meantime, Randall has taken to quoting remarks about Marks and Spencer in the Observer. "They . . . had been left for too long under the control of smug, arrogant managements who thought they could peddle any old tat as long as it bore their illustrious names." Remind you of anyone? He asks innocently.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com or lee.elliot major@theguardian.com

News

Endowments

The central plank of the Conservative Party's higher education policy is looking increasingly flimsy, under closer inspection from university officials. The Tories say they'd give universities greater academic independence by replacing annual government grants with huge endowment funds generated by the sale of government assets.

Last week the Association of University teachers estimated it would cost almost £90bn (the equivalent of opening over 2,000 new hospitals or about 270 new universities) to endow all universities. The figure dwarfs the sums the Tories say are needed for their plans - an initial £3.5bn, with extra money from the sale of student debt. University heads have privately put the figure even higher - at about £100bn. Only then could they generate enough money from the interest on the funds, after accounting for inflation over future years, to survive without recurrent funding council block grants for teaching and research.

And now Tory officials are telling vice-chancellors the money would be loaned, not given. This would mean the government could still limit the numbers of students recruited by universities, and the tuition fees they charge. Academic leaders wonder if there are in fact any benefits at all to the half-baked Conservative plans.

Research news

Gene genius

The Nuffield Council on Bioethics (www.nuffieldfoundation.org/bioethics/) wants the public's views on the implications of links scientists are making between genes and human behavioural traits such as aggression, homosexuality and intelligence.

Play our tune

More academic work needs to be done to uncover the health benefits of Mozart's music, says Professor John Jenkins in the Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. Research shows listening to his piano sonatas improves spatial reasoning skills.

Universe

BA, humbug

On the news that one of Hong Kong's internet tycoons had not, as he had let it be known, "graduated with a degree in computer engineering" from an elite Californian university, local reporters revealed other misunderstandings over academic pedigrees, writes David Cohen on the Education Guardian website. The South China Morning Post in Hong Kong compared that case with the one in Britain involving Lord Archer and his apparent suggestion that he had had a degree from a prestigious US university. A misunderstanding by reporters, of course.

webTitle: UK students to benefit from a report on US student borrowing

fields.headline: On pain of debt
fields.standfirst: UK students will gain ground from a report on US student borrowing, says Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: UK students will gain ground from a report on US student borrowing, says Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
American students are going deeper and deeper into debt to pay for degree courses, and most have completely unrealistic expectations of how much they will owe when they graduate.

New findings by the influential Public Interest Research Groups will be welcomed by students in the UK, who last week launched a campaign to bring back grants for students from low income families. The report, Big Loans, Bigger Problems, will also embarrass David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, who has attempted to bury student funding as an election issue by ruling out top-up fees.

The report notes the massive increase in student debt in the US dur ing the 1990s. Federal government spending on loans rose from $15bn in 1992-93 to £35bn last year. "More students are increasingly dependent on loans to pay for their education," say the authors Tracey King and Ivan Frishberg. "More students are taking out loans and students are taking out larger loans."

The number of loans rose from 5.1m to 9.4m and the average annual loan increased from $3,186 to $4,041 as the purchasing power of student grants declined.

The PIRG groups based in different American states campaign in the public interest against lobby groups. This report urges Congress to be wary of proposals from private colleges and some of the more expensive public universities to increase the size of loans that students are allowed to take out. At present a student in col lege for five years can borrow $22,625 (about £16,000) from the federal government.

While some universities argue that loan limits have not kept up with college costs and students are being forced to turn to more expensive private loans, King and Frishberg argue that students are already getting into more debt than they realise.

Students were frequently shocked on graduation to discover their debt was much larger than they expected or planned, they said: "If they do not understand loan costs they may borrow more than they can afford and experience difficulty repaying their loans." Their survey of 1,012 students from 55 colleges found eight out of 10 students underestimated their total loans by an average of nearly $5,000. Many of them failed to understand the impact that interest payments would have on their total debt.

In the UK students can take out loans of up to £3,725 a year (outside London) and are expected to repay them after leaving their course at the rate of 9% of any income over £10,000. The Student Loans Company collects the original sum loaned plus inflation, so that although students benefit from a zero real interest rate, their debt does increase during their course and after graduation.

Half of all students do not pay the tuition fees that were introduced by the Labour government in 1997, while some pay only part of the £1,050 fee. But evidence to the Commons select committee on education showed that the poorest students were running up the largest debts to cover living costs.

Professor Claire Callender, of South Bank University, who carried out a major study of student debt for the Department for Education and Employment, found evidence that both further and higher education students were underestimating the costs of following their courses. Of university students she surveyed, half disagreed with the statement "My financial situation is better than expected".

The problem in the UK, she said, was less to do with course fees than the hidden costs of travel, books and equipment: "Students don't understand what their costs will be."

The PIRG report argues for more grant aid based on the need to help low income students graduate without incurring huge levels of debt. In the US student debts have increasingly become an issue, and leading universities such as Princeton have scrapped or reduced tuition fees to attract good students.

fields.headline: Total recall
fields.standfirst: For many students, Easter spells revision and long hours poring over lecture notes. But does it really help? New research suggests it reinforces what students picked up first time round - warts and all.  Tony Mooney on some uncomfortable findings
fields.trailText: For many students, Easter spells revision and long hours poring over lecture notes. But does it really help? New research suggests it reinforces what students picked up first time round - warts and all. Tony Mooney on some uncomfortable findings
fields.body:
Brother and sister Toby and Lotte Friedrich, along with many other undergraduates this Easter, will be showing their first signs of nerves about next term's exams. They will soon be drawing up revision timetables and considering how best to cement in their minds all the information thrown at them during the academic year. They will return to the methods that seem to have worked for them in the past to repeat or even improve on previous performances.

Lotte is a second-year student at Sussex University studying for a BSc in human sciences. She admits her revision will be the usual last-minute dash. "I usually start a week or two before the exam because up to then there is so much other work to complete. I shall look through my notes and course handouts and write brief summary notes. I shall concentrate on the material I didn't understand at the time. The material I did understand at the time I tend to remember. I do a lot of talking with my friends on the course. We tend to swap essays and start up discussions about them. It seems to help us to remember."

Her brother, Toby, is in his final year of a BA in conservation and restoration studies at City and Guilds of London Art School. He also depends a lot on what he gleans from lectures. "I tend to write things out. I shorten the notes I have taken in lectures and concentrate on key words and equations. I make a lot of flash cards and keep testing myself on them. The things I keep getting wrong are put on one side for special attention. I need to fix those flash cards in my mind."

Like many students, Lotte and Toby seem to rely heavily on the material they took from their lectures when revising. But how can they be so sure their memory of what they heard and saw is accurate? If they read the findings of a recent joint study carried out by Dr Catherine O Fritz of Bolton Institute with colleagues at Lancaster University and the University of California, Los Angeles, in the British Journal of Psychology they might start to panic. And that really would hinder their swotting.

Of course, the researchers didn't call it swotting, but they set out to investigate whether revision simply reinforces the mistakes and misunderstandings students have picked up first time round.

In the 1950s, Harry Kay at the Institute of Experimental Psychology, Oxford University, found in a series of experiments that "one of the major difficulties experienced by adult subjects was that of amending the mistakes which they themselves had introduced into their learning, so much so that in many instances the feature of the whole learning process was this unlearning of wrongly acquired responses."

In one experiment Kay read out twice two prose passages totalling 300 words to a group of 10 adults aged between 18 and 35 years in a psychology class at the Cambridgeshire Technical College. They then listened to further unconnected material and five minutes later were asked to attempt written recall of the original passages. Kay then read out the two passages again. A second recall attempt was made by the students a week later and the original passages read out once again at the end of the session. This procedure was repeated at weekly intervals in another five sessions and then four months later after a vacation.

Kay admitted his procedures were unusual in experimental research but were very similar to much educational practice in which tutors give "instruction in a subject, then make some examination of what has been learned, correcting it, followed by further testing at some subsequent date".

You would expect that, with early feedback, the students would have corrected their own mistakes. You'd be wrong. Kay measured both the number of words accurately reproduced and the meaningful content of their efforts. At each recall session, the typical student reproduced very accurately what they had recalled before, irrespective of whether the recall had been correct or incorrect. None of them learnt from the repeated presentations of the correct passages.

An incorrect word that had appeared on all of a student's recall attempts in the first three weeks had an 80% chance of occurring again in week four. There was little improvement in recall between the first and seventh weekly sessions.

Kay found the persistent unconscious assumptions and impressions they made to help them make sense of the information became a barrier to accurate recall. This was illustrated by the second world war pilot still engaged in flights over Germany who four times reproduced the "varied political opinions of mankind" as "varied as the political opinions expressed in Mein Kampf".

Thankfully, for students, reproducing 300 words of prose, verbatim, is not something they have to do very often. But when measuring a student's understanding of content, Kay found the first attempt established the content of the passage. Although the first version was fairly accurate (on average 70% correct), there was little change in understanding from one version to the next. They tended to repeat the preceding version.

Depressingly, Dr Fritz's new research finds that Kay was right. But this time the experimenters went further and tested three possible explanations for the failure of further learning, using 57 students enrolled on an introductory psychology course at the University of California:

 The first explanation tested was based on the assumption that in tests after the first one, the students are basing their recall on their memory of previous tests, rather than previous presentations. The students were split up into four groups and three passages on architectural mouldings, air traffic control and the patent process were read to them. Special efforts were made to warn participants "against basing their recall on their previous recall efforts and specifically directing them to base their recall on their passages". It was no use; there was no noticeable improvement in recall.

 Second, the researchers tried to find out if making each presentation more distinctive would improve the amount of material remembered. To test this, one group saw four different readers during the experiment, each of which had different styles of presentation. Once again the researchers found little improvement in what had been remembered.

 The third hypothesis was the possibility that "during the presentations that follow a test, learners fail to notice information omitted from or inconsistent with their previous reports". To try to eliminate this effect, attention in one group was focused on areas that would benefit from further learning for each participant.

An omissions and errors page was provided and each student was asked to make a tally mark in the appropriate column whenever they noticed, while listening to the passage, that they had omitted some information from the previous test or made an error. New pages were provided for each presentation following each test. Despite all the effort, drawing attention to omissions and errors actually led to poorer, not better, recall.

Dr Fritz and her colleagues are rather stumped by their findings that the "failure-of-further-learning effect appears to be robust and not easily overcome". They also highlight the fact that the existing accounts of human memory would not lead us to predict the failure of further learning. They ask a whole series of questions that need answers:

 Is further learning failure limited to some particular level of initial performance?

 Does it apply to learning of different sorts of materials?

 Is it to some degree a function of a learner's expectations about their performance?

But the researchers are certain that overcoming the failure of further learning is crucial for effective education and training. These results cast serious doubt on the practice in most schools and some universities, of testing students and then going over the test with a teacher on the assumption that correcting students' answers will improve their understanding and prevent errors recurring.

If Lotte and Toby Friedrich feel these findings make their revision attempts rather meaningless, they should remember that scientists who have tried to quantify our rate of forgetfulness say that we can forget up to half of what we learn within a day. After a month we have forgotten 70%.

Sadly, the examiner will not take this fact into account so students will have to continue seeking ways to remember the facts they have been bombarded with over the year.

If Lotte and Toby Friedrich feel these findings make their revision attempts rather meaningless, they should remember that scientists who have tried to quantify our rate of forgetfulness say that we can forget up to half of what we learn within a day. After a month we have forgotten 70%. Sadly, the examiner will not take this fact into account so students will have to continue seeking ways to remember the facts they have been bombarded with over the year.

webTitle: House prices up to 20% higher in areas with good state schools, study shows

fields.headline: House prices up to 20% higher in areas with good state schools, study shows
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Parents are prepared to pay almost 20% more for their homes to ensure their children get places at good state schools, according to a study.
fields.body:
Parents are prepared to pay almost 20% more for their homes to ensure their children get places at good state schools, according to a study.

An analysis of house prices in Coventry showed that they were significantly higher in the catchment areas for Finham Park and Coundon Court school and technology college, both high-demand schools.

In 1999, Coundon Court received 412 applications for 270 places, while Finham Park received 317 for 230 places. In both cases the main criterion for choosing pupils is whether they live within the school's catchment area.

Dennis Leech and Erick Campos, economists from Warwick University, produced an analysis of advertised house prices in Coventry to test statistically anecdotal evidence that house prices were higher because of the schools. They said it showed the "real cost" of the best comprehensive education.

Having eliminated the normal causes of house price variation such as type of house, number of rooms and extra garaging, they discovered that location inside Coundon Court's catchment area added 19% to the house price, and 15% inside Finham Park's.

Houses in the Coundon or Radford areas of Coventry outside the Coundon Court school catchment area cost on average £53,510, but inside the catchment area they cost £63,677.

In the Allesley/Eastern Green area, houses outside the Coundon Court catchment went for £111,199 on average, and those inside for £132,327 - more than £20,000 higher. Inside Finham Park's catchment area in Earlsdon, the average cost of a house was £111,937, compared with £97,362 outside.

The researchers said: "These figures imply that places at the schools can be obtained through the housing market by moving house but that there is a financial cost of between £700 and £1,400 per year on average in the areas sampled in higher mortgage costs. The admissions policy is not therefore egalitarian in the true sense of the comprehensive system and there is in practice an element of ability to pay."

The researchers used data from 248 houses in their sample. The areas and schools were chosen to limit the variability caused by other factors.

David Kershaw, head of Coundon Court school, said: "It doesn't surprise me, but it saddens me a little. I have a passionate commitment to comprehensive education. I want all Coventry's children to have the opportunities that our children have got."

His school became a technology college in 1997. It is a beacon school, ranked in the top 25% of schools with similar levels of free school meals. Some 63% of its pupils got five good GCSEs last year.

Mr Kershaw said he had been conscious in recent years of people moving to the area because of the school. But it was "just a few youngsters here and there - it's not changed dramatically".

Most children still came from families who worked in the car industry.

fields.headline: Labour loses teachers' votes
fields.standfirst: NASUWT
fields.trailText: Teachers' support for Labour is set to slide by more than ten per cent at the forthcoming general election, according to a survey of voting intentions among members of the second largest teaching union
fields.body:
Teachers' support for Labour is set to slide by more than ten per cent at the forthcoming general election, according to a survey of voting intentions among members of the second largest teaching union which was published yesterday.

While more than half (53 per cent) of the sample of members interviewed by the National Association of School Masters/Union of Women Teachers voted Labour at the 1997 general election, only 42 per cent signalled that they would support Tony Blair at the next poll.

The Tories and Liberal Democrats between them would pick up some of the extra votes, with 11 per cent of teachers saying they would vote for William Hague - compared with nine per cent last time, and 19 per cent for Charles Kennedy, up from 17 per cent in 1997.The sample consisted of 1,000 members of the NASUWT (which has 186,000 members in total) who were interviewed in mid-March.

fields.body:
Music Maker

(Resource, www.resourcekt.co.uk tel: 01509 672222, £45.23 inc VAT)

Age: Nursery, KS1, special needs

This program is designed to help deliver music, but can also support children with sequencing skills, as required in maths, and listening skills. It has five areas of activity, including composition work, listening to pieces and looking at visual images that represent notes on the keyboard. Activities are visual with clear audio instructions. All of them are differentiated, so all children are able to access the program. Pupils may work on the program independently of the teacher and share results with other class members with a genuine sense of achievement.

KS3 Bitesize Revision Science

(BBC, £9.99 inc VAT)

Age: KS3/4

This title has equal value to students revising the KS3 syllabus and double and single science at GCSE. The multimedia is well integrated, with animation, video and sound used in various sections. The package is easy to use, and keeps a record of each student's achievements to allow them to pick up their testing at the point they leave it. Revision sections are well thought-out and provide a good series of questions. This is a valuable revision tool.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My youngest son has a September birthday. Born in 1997, he now has to wait until September 2002 before starting school, when he will be just a few days off being five. I approached the local authority about whether there were any exceptions and was given a flat "no". He is bright and my main concern is that he will be the oldest in a class of 30 children starting from scratch and, therefore, may become very bored. We cannot afford private education. I swear I am not a "pushy parent". Is there anything I can do?
fields.trailText: Leading experts advise on your problems
fields.body:
This is complicated and parents do worry about whether their child is disadvantaged because their birthday is in the autumn. Each LEA is slightly different and reception provision and starting dates do vary, but the statutory age to start school is the beginning of the term after the child's fifth birthday. Many authorities do take children in before the statutory date. In fact, children who have an autumn birthday actually have an advantage. It is those with summer birthdays - the youngest in their year - who may end up with just one or two terms in reception before going on to year one and year two. By the end of key stage one, summer birthday children may have spent up to two terms less in school because they were not able to start at the beginning of the school year in the autumn. Those with autumn birthdays tend to get nine terms over three full years in school, three in reception and three each in year one and year two.

Chris Girdler
Assistant secretary, education department, National Association of Head Teachers

Lots of people feel that children shouldn't start their formal education before five and I would encourage this parent to keep her son in nursery provision and to take him on outings to let him learn through play and exploration. Research shows that, in particular, boys who start school at four don't flourish; they like to do lots of activity, learn by doing and exploring, and they don't like being made to sit down and learn passively. If they are made to do this before they are ready, they will dislike it. Montessori teachers are trained to work with children up to the age of six, and the advantage of choosing a Montessori school is that we identify the potential of each child and try to develop it. There is enough flexibility to enable us to nurture each child, and learning in a Montessori class doesn't just mean sitting around. At the same time, if a child is ready for more academic work it will be offered automatically; the curriculum is made around the child, not run to a prescribed formula.

Barbara Isaacs
College chief executive, Montessori Centre International

I know this situation and it's not easy. But this child is very young - he won't be quite five when he starts school, and a four-year-old in a class of five- and six-year-olds is not necessarily a good thing. However, if he is all primed and ready, it would be a great pity for him not to start a term before, at four years and nine months. This parent could see the headteacher - perhaps not now but in six months' time - and try to persuade the school. Most schools do have a three-term intake. In the meantime, she needs to get him into a nursery where there is some form of structured education, rather than just play - perhaps a Montessori school. She could use the local facilities, primarily the library, which is an enormously under-used resource, and take the child to the local park, which is packed with birds and flowers. The key is to do things with her son, not just give the child jobs to do. And she should help him develop his social side, which sometimes gets left out with a bright child; sometimes parents put the emphasis on learning, learning, learning. She should also tactfully prepare the school before her son arrives: see the teachers beforehand, and get his nursery to write an objective report on him.

Prof Joan Freeman
Founder president of the European Council for High Ability, and author of How to Raise a Bright Child (Vermilion, £8.99).

Coming next

My seven-year-old daughter has been diagnosed as having dyspraxia. She is now being removed from mainstream schooling. I would like to know what options are available for her.

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax it to 020-7239 9933 or e-mail to education.letters@theguardian.com

Contact the Montessori Centre International on 0207-493 0165.

The manufacturer says:

We will use it in our top infants' 'golden moments' sessions where the children are given five minutes to do something they choose."

webTitle: Wirral mothers going back to school years after giving up on education

fields.headline: Never too late
fields.standfirst: Years after giving up on education, Wirral mothers are going back to school.  Hester Lacey discovers why
fields.trailText: Years after giving up on education, Wirral mothers are going back to school. Hester Lacey discovers why
fields.body:
Rosie is small, slight and very pretty. She looks even younger than 25 years old; it's hard to believe that she has four sons, aged seven, six, four and 19 months. She left school when she was 11; she was, she says, truanting, or bunking, all the time. Now she's back at college studying for City and Guilds certificates in maths and English, though it's a struggle given how little free time she has. She wants her children to do better at school than she did.

Vicky, who is 20, has a daughter of three. She officially left school a week before her 16th birthday, but in fact she missed the whole of her fifth year. She was put in a class for badly-behaved children, though she'd been diagnosed as dyslexic, and the experience was too much for her, so she simply didn't go to school. Vicky believes her daughter is already shaping up to be "brainier" than she was; and wants to help her achieve.

Kelly is 21, and has three children under the age of four. She hated school and left at the age of 14. She says she was always bullied and her education suffered; it's embarrassing, she says, that she can't spell well enough to fill in forms. She wants her children to be "really good" at school.

All three of them have been helped by a special course run by Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Groups on the Wirral as part of its parenting classes programme. The Successful Learning pilot scheme aims to break down parents' barriers to learning, because these in turn undermine their own children's potential to do well at school. If parents lack basic skills themselves, they can feel humiliated and confused and unable to help their children. And if they have felt let down by their teachers, they pass that on. It is, says Jean Robb of Successful Learning, a vicious circle. "If parents have had a disruptive attitude in school, those belligerent attitudes are carried over when they have to deal with their children's teachers," she says.

It's important to explain to parents, says Jean, that if they don't play their role in a supportive way so that teachers and students can play theirs in turn, then disorder is the result. "Then everyone feels confused, disappointed, irritated and exhausted," she says. Many of the parents that Jean has been working with left school with very negative views of education. "They'd been getting into trouble, they'd been told they were thick, they felt it wasn't worth going," says Elaine Banks of the Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Groups. "We want to break that cycle, give them the confidence to keep going and help their own children."

The effectiveness of the Successful Learning course, she says, is striking. Each of the nine smaller groups within the Family Groups has had four two-hour sessions with Jean and her colleague Hilary Letts. "It has been wonderful to see how they have blossomed," says Elaine Banks. "One mother who had always struggled with spelling was standing up in front of the class spelling a 13-letter word forwards and backwards." She is referring to Kelly, who says of her achievement: "I just couldn't believe it; I went around smiling all day."

So how is it done? The emphasis of Jean and Hilary's work is on learning how to learn; on breaking tasks down into manageable smaller tasks, then building them back up. One morning last week in a church hall in New Ferry, seven mothers had begun their session by making up a couple of child's jigsaws, one showing a country farm and one showing a city park. Easy enough to do; but, guided by Jean and Hilary, they were then using the completed jigsaws to illustrate all kinds of classroom lessons. Hilary asked them to find similarities and differences between the two pictures. "This is something children have to do all through school," she explained. "They might have to compare life as a Roman with life as a Greek, for example."

The women began by making a list of things that were the same in each picture, then by making a list of things that were different. Then Jean asked them to describe the similarities more fully, using prepositions such as "beside" or "under". "Lots of children can't write down their ideas because they don't understand about prepositions," she said. "But once they can do that, they're away."

It was a lively class, with plenty of humour; within a few minutes adjectives and relationships between people had been added to the mix. "The black and white dog is pulling the boy over the grass, across the path, and into the pond," said Karen, one of the mums, triumphantly. "Do you see how it's not difficult, you don't need a huge vocabulary?" asked Jean. "Once you can describe something relative to something else, you've got a full and rich use of language. So if you're looking at a picture book or a jigsaw with your child, get them to describe it, write it down."

Next came maths. Beginning by simply counting different objects in the jigsaw pictures led on quite naturally to drawing graphs and algebra.

"Making a mistake doesn't matter," encouraged Jean. "You know when you were at school and the teacher said 'That's wrong' and you then think 'She hates me. I hate her too.'?" There were nods of recognition all round the room.

"Saying something is wrong isn't personal. The teacher can help you get it right."

The class by now was adding 2A to B as if they'd been doing it all their lives. They are enthusiastic about the methods they are using and keen to take them home. "I'm not very good at maths," said Karen, 35. She has two daughters, Siobhan, aged eight and Latoya who is just two, and who had spent the morning in the free creche that is attached to all the Ferries and Port Sunlight Families Group training courses. "School was more about fun for me and I left at 15. Now I can help my older daughter with her homework; when I was at school my parents couldn't help me. I want better for my daughters than it was for me."

It's funny, says Becky, who's 22, how much she hated school at the time; now, she says, she'd go back like a shot. She's studying for her City and Guilds numeracy and English exams. In the meantime, she's using the techniques she's learned with Jean and Hilary with her son, who's nearly five. "He just wasn't interested in anything, you'd do a jigsaw or something and it would last five minutes, but now I've learned ways to do things with him, little games to make him interested in learning numbers and colours."

Because Jean and Hilary's approach depends entirely on what's required by the parents, their classes cover a wide range of different needs; there is no set curriculum and they are able to be very flexible. Their afternoon class that day was a group of mothers who wanted pointers on helping their children with class projects and computer work. But for some, the requirements are very grass-roots indeed. One mother, says Jean, doesn't send her children to school at all because of her own experiences. "No education is provided for these children at all, because their mother doesn't know how to deal with school. That's why classes are so important."

The ultimate success of schemes like this will depend on the Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Group's success in obtaining more funding. The pilot Successful Learning classes were funded by the BBC's Children in Need appeal. The budget may be tight but its successes are striking. Vicky, who missed her entire fifth year, is so enthusiastic that she is taking extra classes with Jean and Hilary. She has just started reading White Teeth, by Zadie Smith. And she is reading out loud to her own daughter.
