"If parents have had a disruptive attitude in school, those belligerent attitudes are carried over when they have to deal with their children's teachers," she says. It's important to explain to parents, says Jean, that if they don't play their role in a supportive way so that teachers and students can play theirs in turn, then disorder is the result. "Then everyone feels confused, disappointed, irritated and exhausted," she says. Many of the parents that Jean has been working with left school with very negative views of education. "They'd been getting into trouble, they'd been told they were thick, they felt it wasn't worth going," says Elaine Banks of the Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Groups. "We want to break that cycle, give them the confidence to keep going and help their own children." The effectiveness of the Successful Learning course, she says, is striking. Each of the nine smaller groups within the Family Groups has had four two-hour sessions with Jean and her colleague Hilary Letts. "It has been wonderful to see how they have blossomed," says Elaine Banks. "One mother who had always struggled with spelling was standing up in front of the class spelling a 13-letter word forwards and backwards." She is referring to Kelly, who says of her achievement: "I just couldn't believe it; I went around smiling all day." So how is it done? The emphasis of Jean and Hilary's work is on learning how to learn; on breaking tasks down into manageable smaller tasks, then building them back up. One morning last week in a church hall in New Ferry, seven mothers had begun their session by making up a couple of child's jigsaws, one showing a country farm and one showing a city park. Easy enough to do; but, guided by Jean and Hilary, they were then using the completed jigsaws to illustrate all kinds of classroom lessons. Hilary asked them to find similarities and differences between the two pictures. "This is something children have to do all through school," she explained. "They might have to compare life as a Roman with life as a Greek, for example." The women began by making a list of things that were the same in each picture, then by making a list of things that were different. Then Jean asked them to describe the similarities more fully, using prepositions such as "beside" or "under". "Lots of children can't write down their ideas because they don't understand about prepositions," she said. "But once they can do that, they're away." It was a lively class, with plenty of humour; within a few minutes adjectives and relationships between people had been added to the mix. "The black and white dog is pulling the boy over the grass, across the path, and into the pond," said Karen, one of the mums, triumphantly. "Do you see how it's not difficult, you don't need a huge vocabulary?" asked Jean. "Once you can describe something relative to something else, you've got a full and rich use of language. So if you're looking at a picture book or a jigsaw with your child, get them to describe it, write it down." Next came maths. Beginning by simply counting different objects in the jigsaw pictures led on quite naturally to drawing graphs and algebra. "Making a mistake doesn't matter," encouraged Jean. "You know when you were at school and the teacher said 'That's wrong' and you then think 'She hates me. I hate her too.'?" There were nods of recognition all round the room. "Saying something is wrong isn't personal. The teacher can help you get it right." The class by now was adding 2A to B as if they'd been doing it all their lives. They are enthusiastic about the methods they are using and keen to take them home. "I'm not very good at maths," said Karen, 35. She has two daughters, Siobhan, aged eight and Latoya who is just two, and who had spent the morning in the free creche that is attached to all the Ferries and Port Sunlight Families Group training courses. "School was more about fun for me and I left at 15. Now I can help my older daughter with her homework; when I was at school my parents couldn't help me. I want better for my daughters than it was for me." It's funny, says Becky, who's 22, how much she hated school at the time; now, she says, she'd go back like a shot. She's studying for her City and Guilds numeracy and English exams. In the meantime, she's using the techniques she's learned with Jean and Hilary with her son, who's nearly five. "He just wasn't interested in anything, you'd do a jigsaw or something and it would last five minutes, but now I've learned ways to do things with him, little games to make him interested in learning numbers and colours." Because Jean and Hilary's approach depends entirely on what's required by the parents, their classes cover a wide range of different needs; there is no set curriculum and they are able to be very flexible. Their afternoon class that day was a group of mothers who wanted pointers on helping their children with class projects and computer work. But for some, the requirements are very grass-roots indeed. One mother, says Jean, doesn't send her children to school at all because of her own experiences. "No education is provided for these children at all, because their mother doesn't know how to deal with school. That's why classes are so important." The ultimate success of schemes like this will depend on the Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Group's success in obtaining more funding. The pilot Successful Learning classes were funded by the BBC's Children in Need appeal. The budget may be tight but its successes are striking. Vicky, who missed her entire fifth year, is so enthusiastic that she is taking extra classes with Jean and Hilary. She has just started reading White Teeth, by Zadie Smith. And she is reading out loud to her own daughter.

webTitle: The foot and mouth crisis has forced one school into providing lessons by post

fields.headline: Deliver us from crisis
fields.standfirst: With students trapped at home by foot and mouth,  Martin Wainwright  reveals how a Northumberland school has been forced into the expensive option of lessons by post
fields.trailText: With students trapped at home by foot and mouth, Martin Wainwright reveals how a Northumberland school has been forced into the expensive option of lessons by post
fields.body:
David Thompson literally froze when he heard the words "foot and mouth outbreak" on local radio; and his brief paralysis has been grimly justified. Closing in silently on his high school at Haydon Bridge, the disease is playing havoc with everything good, hard-working and Ofsted-praised in Northumberland's farming valley of the South Tyne.

"We lost a third of our students immediately," says the long-serving headteacher, whose beetle brows and craggy face make comparisons with a shepherd inevitable. His flock of pupils covers the biggest catchment area of any school in England, miles of forest and moor from Spadeadam (the eerie old launchpad for the Army's Blue Streak rockets) to the leadmines at Alston in Cumbria.

Imprisoned at various lonely points on this great map are sixth-formers tackling A-levels, younger GCSE students and the poor guinea pigs of year 12 who have AS-levels and key skills to contend with.

Looking horribly like wreckage are their not-quite-finished modules of exam coursework: painstaking studies of a river which can no longer be visited; practical work on lambing at the school's 74-hectare (183-acre) farm, now strictly out of bounds.

There is plenty of lunch-break football, joking and even a positive, crisis-born community spirit at the comprehensive, but these are not good times for a keen 16-year-old like Graeme Fowler. For a start, he had to miss the Northumberland schools rugby cup-final (Haydon won, but only because they were the away team in a 12-12 draw); and then there's not much Russian spoken on the Cumbrian farm where he lives with his parents.

"Russian's one of my AS-levels and I need to practice for the oral", he says, "but if I have to stay at home (and foot and mouth is now very close to his parents' farm) it's going to be hard to 'phone in to try to catch my teacher."

Six staff and more than 300 of Haydon Bridge's 750 students didn't come back to classes after half-term when the disease broke - the start of the whole epidemic is only ten miles down the South Tyne at the notorious pig unit in Heddon-on-the-Wall.

This year's musical, Grease, was promptly postponed because so few of the putative Californian teenagers could rehearse; and librarian Avril Kirsopp was soon bulk-buying stamps.

"We're spending £20 a day on them now," she says, coordinating an emergency scheme of sent-out homework which has seen all Haydon's staff working overtime. On commandeered tables in the library, yellow files are filled for absent year 10s, red ones for year 11s and so on.

"Thank goodness that we still have an efficient rural post service," says David Thompson, as completed work arrives back in the school's stamped, addressed envelopes. "Local postmen probably know all our kids and the importance of the exams they're taking."

Empty desks were gradually filled after the initial, instinctive "don't leave the farm" reaction of many parents, but last week absentees were climbing back over 100 again. The list of cancellations meanwhile grows: the school's enterprising trip to Kili manjaro this summer can no longer raise sponsorship, as normal, by timed scrambles up Skiddaw, Helvellyn and Scafell Pike. And the budget is facing other squeezes.

In an area where the next bus often comes 24 hours later and the nearest teenager can be four miles away, Haydon Bridge takes 62 weekly boarders. At weekends their wing, Ridley Hall, is hired out to field trips from all over Britain to earn money; but not now.

"We've either had cancellations or we've had to tell them not to come because of spreading foot and mouth," says Mr Thompson. On top of the unexpected stamp and envelope fund, that's a loss of at least £8,000.

Everyone is under the foot and mouth strain, too. The head was on the 'phone last night for a long talk with a key parent-governor farmer, and then fielded two more foot and mouth calls before going home at 9.45pm.

Students like Thomas Carrick, who is debating whether to stay with friends or relatives (like several dozen Haydon students) rather than risk being trapped on his farm during A-lev els, also can't get the disease out of their heads.

"It's always on your mind," says the 18-year-old, who is aiming to read biology at Leeds university. "I'm anxious about dropping grades, but one trouble is that all the people I might stay with are in farming as well."

Alice Pattinson, another 18-year-old who hopes to study agriculture at Harper Adams college in Shropshire, is on a different rack. She lives with her parents' dread that a sheep flock reared and carefully bred by the family for 80 years may be slaughtered.

Katie Teasdale, similarly deep in A-levels, wakes every morning to remember that her parents' three holiday cottages haven't got a single summer let.

Meanwhile James Johnson, 17, who is trying to retrieve all he can of A-level geography projects, has to spend revision time helping with his parents' farm.

"We're lambing now and we've usually got two part-time workers, but because of foot and mouth restrictions they can't come, so obviously you pitch in," he says.

Like the school budget, students' own small economies are also being devastated. Alice's farm is on the Roman wall, within sight of the closed English Heritage fort at Housesteads and the barred National Trust walk to Steel Rigg, the most photographed stretch of the wall.

"The holiday trade, where we all get jobs to save for university, is just packing up," she says. Her own part-time waitressing work has only been saved because Ministry of Agriculture vets and slaughtering staff have booked a local hotel en bloc.

Haydon Bridge is stuck in for a long haul, which means major curriculum shifts for staff like Ian Hopper, the school's senior teacher, who is trying to find alternative places for fieldwork as the countryside shuts down.

He says: "We're having to look at Hexham (the only town for miles) to do an urban study for geography GCSE. But the kids haven't done settlement as part of their classroom coursework. That's the sort of juggling going on."

All eyes are on the three exam boards which deal with the school, and which have already sanctioned unavoidable exams for pupils trapped at home, with timing and invigilation based on trust. Heather Howard, head of English, says: "We have to hope they realise the full extent of the crisis. They've offered to delay modules, but that means that students will face extra work at exam time this summer. We need to get across that we're living in a world where parents are ringing in, saying desperately: "Look, is my daughter even going to be able to take her A-levels?"

Mrs Howard's own nieces have been among the faces missing from Haydon's desks; and a strength of the crisis is the palpably close community But a glaring weakness - the stunning weakness for any urban outsider - is the primitive nature of rural IT.

Only biology teacher Nick Sandeman has had the training and money to set up a website, and the sort of wired up, email-your-teacher world, which forms the happy fantasy of cyber-classroom enthusiasts, is just that: a fantasy.

Contemplating the library's folder factory - using methods unchanged since Baden Powell's "postal Brownie" system of the 1920s - David Thompson knows why.

"Thanks to the standard spending assessment formula, Northumberland students have had less per head spent on their education than every other kid in the country," he says.

"But how long have you got? Because that's another story."

Diary of a headmaster

Half-term holiday

A welcome respite from considering threshold assessments and school budgets. Before important matters such as would Sunderland beat Leicester can be mulled over those dreaded words are uttered: foot and mouth disease.

Sunday February 25

Such alarm bells are cast aside by a return to Arctic conditions.

Wednesday February 28

The forecast is for severe overnight blizzards so the school is closed.

Thursday March 1

The longest day. Foot and mouth is approaching. Those living in the "restricted zone" cannot come to school if they have been in recent contact with livestock. White snow; grey clouds. We shall send work to those marooned on their farm and contact the exam boards about contingency plans for modules not taken and coursework not completed.

Friday March 2

268 absentees, or 40% of the student roll. Final preparations are made for posting work home. Staff, as always, respond magnificently.

Saturday/Sunday, March 3-4

All the community is within a restricted area. A whole swathe of students, and six staff, could be absent for weeks rather than days. How ironic that information travels fast via the internet; many of our students not at all. Our longstanding pleas for improved IT facilities in this most rural area have often been ignored.

Monday March 5

Contact is made with MAFF and the NFU. The County's Emergency Team confirm that students and staff can return to school, subject to specific restrictions and general common sense.

Tuesday March 6

Still 40% away from school.

Friday March 9

Only 160 students are absent, and all staff have reported back.

Attention returns to the school budget which will not balance. It never does.

As for the next week, or weeks - who knows? The staff will continue to enable the students to learn and to achieve, no matter what.

David Thompson, headteacher

webTitle: Are computer games doing our children good or causing them harm?

fields.headline: Game generation
fields.standfirst: Are computer games doing our children good or causing them harm?  Shyama Perera  investigates
fields.trailText: Are computer games doing our children good or causing them harm? Shyama Perera investigates
fields.body:
For those of us who spent our formative years playing "had" and mooning over David Cassidy, the relentless conquest of our progeny effected by the advance of computer games continues to cause alarm and unease.

This is an age where couch potato has become almost a term of endearment and the debating skills of young people often consist of a series of impenetrable guttural utterances. Parents understandably worry that they are aiding and abetting the dark forces of cyber-culture by turning out successive generations of socially impaired and brain-numbed adults.

Past studies into the effects of computer games on the young have muddied the issue. Some claim increased violence on screen is making children more aggressive. Others say they are improving their spatial skills.

Now, a Home Office research study suggests that, whatever the short-term effects, in the long term the child who becomes a computer "geek" is more likely to go to university and to move into a better-than-average job.

"Well of course we do," says Simon Fullarton, one of the first generation of games players. "Games don't just give you a buzz - they require intelligence and intuition.

"If you look at a game like Half Life, you're a character in an experimental, make-believe world that's gone horribly wrong. It's been taken over by flesh-eating zombies who are after you. To clear an escape you have to deal with natural disasters, pick up visual clues, avoid capture and devise strategies. It's all about problem-solving."

A prizewinner at the Royal College of Music, Fullarton gave up his studies to become a Cisco engineer specialising in networking. He deals with switching and routing, getting international systems talking to each other. The most experienced Cisco contractors earn around £1,000 a day.

But games have changed. While the first Atari tennis games were simplistic and easy, today's virtual reality scenarios are violent, bloody and often encourage on-screen lawlessness. Grand Theft Auto, a current favour-ite, requires players to stop cars, pull out and punch the driver, and go joyriding, progressively notching up points for misdemeanours including running over pedestrians and police.

"I don't let my boys play the more violent games," says Martina Milburn, head of the charity, Children in Need. "But many scenarios are no more aggressive than the robust games of cowboys and Indians we played as children.

"My eldest son is dyslexic and the skills he has built up through games have helped enormously with other areas of use. For example, he has trouble with books but was able to do his GCSE revision using a CD-rom.

"My youngest, who is five, already has mouse and keyboard skills and uses the computer to play games traditionally played on the carpet - snap and matching. He is not preparing for a future dominated by computers, but a present dominated by computers."

And therein lies the rub. For the luddites, computers are still a new-fangled fad. In reality they provide the infrastructure of modern life. In the same way that our parents pointlessly restricted TV watching, we try to stem an unstoppable tide.

The games will proliferate because computer skills are essential and they help to develop them.

Martina Milburn's middle son, Daniel, is 12. "All my friends play computer games," he says. "We do play gangster games but they're just for fun. I've learned all sorts of things from the more serious ones: about the stock market and the transport and the battles in the second world war."

As internet cafes spring up around the country, more children are taking their interests away from the home. My own daughters enjoy the socialisation that computers offer.

Far from becoming geeks, they see themselves as part of a wider community. The six-year-old plays simple games on the Cartoon Network site and the nine-year-old successfully runs a theme park, buying, selling, caring for animals and organising her shop on Neopets.

Esther Bromnick, regional manager for Nextlifecentres.co.uk, which has 10 outlets in Bristol and throughout the south-east, believes the benefits far outweigh the low points. "We've a five-year-old with an online diary. She uses a thesaurus and in years to come she'll not only have vital language skills but a fantastic archive.

Bromnick does, however, sound a warning note: "I think there is a definite balance to be had. Without question children learn mouse and keyboard skills and spatial awareness. They also learn to search on the web and to network. But a lot of games have no great merit."

Her mother Eléne, 75, has played a Nintendo Game Boy for between two and four hours a day for the last 10 years. A retired history teacher, she believes it has definite uses: "You really do have to have intense concentration and perseverance.

"My favourite games are Dr Mario and Tetris. They take away stress and I find they improve my hand-to-eye co-ordination. My view is that they are generally beneficial for children."

Bromnick's story highlights the difference between the geeky games that required just one person and a screen, and the way they now encompass not just friends but also players from other parts of the world.

In other words, worries about social skills may not be well founded.

The Home Office report, put together by Jessica Harris, reached no specific conclusions about the wider fears parents may have about these games because research continues to be contradictory. But the finding that children who play games are more intelligent than average and are, therefore, more likely to go into higher education, must be some comfort.

So, too, the fact that those studied over a 10-year period went into better-paid jobs. But does the social factor have some influence here as well?

Dr Susan Rose, senior lecturer in history at the University of Surrey, Roehampton, teaches modules on computer applications for historians. She also uses spreadsheets and databases, but is cautious about the study's findings.

"Ten or 15 years ago the playing of computer games was something done only by a very select group of children from technically and educationally clued-up homes," she says. "In other words, homes where there is opportunity and support.

"That has changed now and I feel this research may be misguided. Didactic games should open a child's imagination but often the choice of solutions is closed. Once you have learned the knack of doing them, there is nothing left to learn."

"We do play gangster games but they're just for fun. I've learned all sorts of things from the more serious ones: about the stock market and the transport and the battles in the second world war." As internet cafes spring up around the country, more children are taking their interests away from the home. My own daughters enjoy the socialisation that computers offer. Far from becoming geeks, they see themselves as part of a wider community. The six-year-old plays simple games on the Cartoon Network site and the nine-year-old successfully runs a theme park, buying, selling, caring for animals and organising her shop on Neopets. Esther Bromnick, regional manager for Nextlifecentres.co.uk, which has 10 outlets in Bristol and throughout the south-east, believes the benefits far outweigh the low points. "We've a five-year-old with an online diary. She uses a thesaurus and in years to come she'll not only have vital language skills but a fantastic archive. Bromnick does, however, sound a warning note: "I think there is a definite balance to be had. Without question children learn mouse and keyboard skills and spatial awareness. They also learn to search on the web and to network. But a lot of games have no great merit." Her mother Eléne, 75, has played a Nintendo Game Boy for between two and four hours a day for the last 10 years. A retired history teacher, she believes it has definite uses: "You really do have to have intense concentration and perseverance. "My favourite games are Dr Mario and Tetris. They take away stress and I find they improve my hand-to-eye co-ordination. My view is that they are generally beneficial for children." Bromnick's story highlights the difference between the geeky games that required just one person and a screen, and the way they now encompass not just friends but also players from other parts of the world. In other words, worries about social skills may not be well founded. The Home Office report, put together by Jessica Harris, reached no specific conclusions about the wider fears parents may have about these games because research continues to be contradictory. But the finding that children who play games are more intelligent than average and are, therefore, more likely to go into higher education, must be some comfort. So, too, the fact that those studied over a 10-year period went into better-paid jobs. But does the social factor have some influence here as well? Dr Susan Rose, senior lecturer in history at the University of Surrey, Roehampton, teaches modules on computer applications for historians. She also uses spreadsheets and databases, but is cautious about the study's findings. "Ten or 15 years ago the playing of computer games was something done only by a very select group of children from technically and educationally clued-up homes," she says. "In other words, homes where there is opportunity and support. "That has changed now and I feel this research may be misguided. Didactic games should open a child's imagination but often the choice of solutions is closed. Once you have learned the knack of doing them, there is nothing left to learn."

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.standfirst: Poetry | Chaucer
fields.trailText: Poetry | Chaucer
fields.byline: Compiled by Jim Merrett and Lyndsey Turner
fields.body:
Poetry

Giggle, Giggle

robertpottle.com

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

A collection of funny short poetry by Robert Pottle. A colourful site, though the poetry is not so well presented. You can vote for your favourite.

Fun for Kids

aatalbert.songbird.com/PapasPoems

Suitable for: KS1 teachers & parents

An extensive collection of poetry suitable for reading to infant and pre-school children. Being a US site, not all the poems are suitable, so check out those that work best with your class.

Astra's Sageness of Weird

madasafish.com/~slcastra/slc/slcindex.html

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

A wonderful mix of verse and images such as angels, rainbows, dreams and stars. Children will be highly motivated by this site, although it isn't specifically aimed at them.

Click

www.clickteaching.com/english

Suitable for: KS1/2 teachers

Similes and metaphors to help with poetry writing. Entertaining lesson ideas, including one on narrative poetry based on The Lady of Shalott.

Jabberwocky

www.jabberwocky.com/carroll/jabber/jabberwocky.html

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

The poem is well displayed, with links to a Lewis Carroll site -and if you have ever wondered what a jabberwocky looks like, there's an illustration.

Poetry for Kids

www.poetry4kids.com

Suitable for: KS2 pupils & teachers

Written by Ken Nesbitt, the 40 poems featured here are all of a humorous nature.

Erin's Site

www.cswnet.com/~erin/child.htm

Suitable for: KS1/2 teachers, KS2 pupils

Traditional poems are included on this site, along with other less well known offerings, although illustrations are scarce. The site has been edited by a real fan.

Haiku

www.toyomasu.com/haiku/

Suitable for: KS2 teachers & pupils

A great many children love the challenge of writing haiku. This site defines the term, explains how to write it and provides masses of examples, both old and modern.

Chaucer

Geoffrey Chaucer

icg.fas.harvard.edu/~chaucer/index.html

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

One of the best sites for researching the background to the wide-ranging references in Chaucer's texts. History, pilgrimages, courtly love and the treatment of women are all here. Language, linguistics, science and medieval literature are also addressed in a resource which is ideal for older pupils and, with a little direction, younger students too.

Chaucer Pedagogy

cwolf.uaa.alaska.edu/~afdtk/pedagogy.htm

Suitable for: KS4/5 pupils & teachers

Aimed at older students. Sensible questions such as "Why is Chaucer important?" and "What happened during Chaucer's lifetime?" are answered with clarity. Teachers are catered for with notes, lesson ideas and links. Hosted by the University of Alaska, this site is not specifically geared towards the national curriculum, but there is a considerable amount of crossover.

The Canterbury Tales

www.canterburytales.org

Suitable for: KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

Two full editions of the Tales, one in Middle English and one in modern. Both can be downloaded with ease and provide clear, readable text. The search facility allows students and teachers to use the site as a concordance for the whole of the work.

Summaries

www.gradesaver.com/ClassicNotes/Titles/canterbury/

Suitable for: KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

Readable summaries of the Prologue and all the Tales interspersed with textual analysis. Although these are aimed at older students, the language would be accessible for younger students. "About Geoffrey Chaucer" gives a short and useful biography.

Luminarium

www.luminarium.org/medlit/chaucer.htm

Suitable for: KS5 pupils & teachers

A more academic site, with good links to other sources. Essays on the dual narrative structure, the narrator and individual characters might help a more advanced student, and may even allow a teacher to brush up on some modern textual criticism.

webTitle: Reviews: The New Faber Book of Children's Verse, and Heathrow Nights by Jan Mark

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.standfirst: Lindsey Fraser looks at The New Faber Book of Children's Verse, and Heathrow Nights by Jan Mark
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at The New Faber Book of Children's Verse, and Heathrow Nights by Jan Mark
fields.body:
The New Faber Book of Children's Verse
Edited by Matthew Sweeney, illustrated by Sara Fanelli

(Faber, £16.99)

Age: 9-15 yrs

To be asked to compile an anthology must be among the loveliest of literary invitations, but to do the job properly must be one of the most daunting. In his introduction to this substantial anthology, Sweeney gives some insight into the inherent dilemmas and anxieties of the role. How much should he update the classic Faber collection published in the 1950s? Should children's verse necessarily have been written for children? He has resolved this by avoiding a thematic approach, showcasing the contemporary and the classic in the context of imaginative, artistic and intellectual discovery.

Heathrow Nights
Jan Mark
(Signature Hodder, £4.99)
Age: 12-17 yrs

When he's not being benignly heedless, Russell ponders the parallels between Hamlet and himself, both of them outraged stepsons. His insightful questioning of the play is woven through a plot that finds him wandering around Heathrow to escape punishment for a childish prank. This is an excellent parallel text for those reading Hamlet - humane, often witty, and stimulating. Its perspective should endear it to teachers tackling the play for the umpteenth time with a new set of puzzled faces, offering fresh angles from which to view that tragic hero alongside a perceptive depiction of the rougher edges of grief.

webTitle: Fiasco as thousands of students are told they haven't passed key skills after all

fields.headline: Results fiasco
fields.standfirst: Thousands of students are told they haven't passed key skills after all, reports  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Thousands of students are told they haven't passed key skills after all, reports Peter Kingston
fields.body:
The exam board Edexcel has written to 10,000 students apologising for a computer blunder which led to them getting the wrong results in their key skills tests.

Colleges say that the error is doubly damaging. It was the first time that many of the students had passed an exam in their lives and now 3,705 must be told they actually failed.

And it is a blow to colleges' efforts to persuade other 16- to 18-year-old students that the new tests, introduced this year with Curriculum 2000, are worth doing.

"They took some convincing to do these exams - this is bad news," said Sally McEnhill, principal of Merton college, south west London, one of about 340 colleges and schools affected.

Many principals fear it will be difficult to coax all the youngsters who were misinformed that they had passed to do the tests again.

A spokeswoman for Edexcel, which is offering free re-sits in May to the 3,705, who sat the tests in January, said the exam board was appalled by the error in what was the first time that these new qualifications were tested.

"The guy who actually made the mistake is completely devastated and so are we," she said.

She stressed that the tests, in information technology, communication and application of number, were correctly marked. The mistake happened when the marks were put into a computer.

"We had a test programme which had a default pass mark of 70% for IT," she said. But a higher pass mark had since been set. "It was the default pass mark rather than the actual pass mark which was applied. As a result some students were told they had passed when they hadn't. They had not yet passed - we don't use the word fail here."

It will be easier telling the 6,466 students incorrectly told that they haven't passed the communications and application of number tests that they actually were successful.

In their cases the actual pass mark which should have been applied was lower than the default pass mark on the computer.

The tests were at the lowest levels, 1 and 2, and each accounted for half a unit of the particular skill. They are sat by and large by youngsters who will not be going to university.

Many of them are categorised as disaffected by their colleges and have have not had successful experiences of education to date. To aquire each key skill they have to sit a written test and submit a portfolio.

Edexcel has sent each of the misinformed students a letter via their colleges. But Sally McEnhill has so far not informed 13 of the 149 Merton college students who took the tests that they have been given wrong results, and that nine have failed.

"We've told Edexcel they've got to come down here and tell the students themselves," she said.

"They're going to be upset and their parents are going to be upset."

Judith Norrington, of the Association of Colleges, said: "We feel this is a devastating experience for some learners.

"It's very unfortunate given that colleges have for a long time supported the need for a range of underpinning skills.

"We've been lobbying hard for universities to take key skills seriously. It would be a huge shame if this affected the way people think about key skills."

webTitle: Teacher training to become compulsory for all further education lecturers

fields.headline: Solid support?
fields.standfirst: Teacher training is to become compulsory for all further education lecturers, but will the proposed new courses be up to scratch, asks  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Teacher training is to become compulsory for all further education lecturers, but will the proposed new courses be up to scratch, asks Simon Midgley
fields.body:
The notion that people who teach in colleges should be trained just as they have to be in schools is one which few would quibble with. But now this is about to start happening, fears are rumbling in the universities due to carry out the training that the qualifications they are being asked to provide are sub-standard.

The universities are also worried that they could lose potential students to new, shorter and more inexpensive training courses being developed in colleges.

It has long been compulsory for teachers in schools to be qualified in the skills of teaching as well as in their subject specialisms. Up until now, however, this has not been the case for further education lecturers in England. It is estimated that more than 37% of the 48,000 full-time further education teachers in England do not possess a postgraduate certificate in education or certificate in education or the equivalent.

Moreover, of the 79,000 part-time teachers, the proportion holding any recognised teaching qualification could be as low as 40%. More than half the further education curriculum, it is estimated, is being taught by part-timers.

Over recent years inspection reports from the outgoing Further Education Funding Council have noted that some areas of teaching in colleges needed improving. So in a bid to raise stan dards the government decided that, from September, all lecturers in England, including those who teach basic skills such as numeracy and literacy to adults, should have a teaching qualification. This, it is believed, will help to raise student achievement and improve retention.

The further education national training organisation, Fento, which is responsible for devising teaching and learning standards in England and Wales, conducted research to determine what kind of new qualifications might be required. The government then consulted the colleges, universities, awarding bodies and other interested parties on Fento's proposals. In November at the funding council's AGM, Baroness Tessa Blackstone, the higher education minister, announced a proposed new qualifications framework.

This requires all new lecturers in England to obtain an appropriate teaching qualification. Colleges will also be given financial help towards getting unqualified staff qualified. Full-time and fractional (employed on a proportion of a full-time contract) teachers will need to get a certificate in education (FE) or equivalent. Part-time teachers will have to get a stage 1 or stage 2 qualification depending on the number of hours they teach. These qualifications are staged by breadth of competencies rather than academic levels. Ministers have decided that the entry qualification for new full-time teachers will be as intellectually rigorous as the first year of university study. In other words it will be an H1 -level qualification, the equivalent of level 4 in the national qualifications framework. H2 and H3 are the equivalents of the second and third years of university study, H5 is the equivalent of a PhD.

Some 29 universities offer teacher training qualifications in further education and many have set up networks of franchise partnerships with more than 80 further education colleges. A significant number of these universities are now worried that they could lose parts of their teacher training work and that the depth of such training could be diluted in future. This is because under the new qualification arrangements other qualification providers, for example, City and Guilds and Edexcel, will also be able to create new H1-level training qualifications for full-time lecturers.

So worried are some universities, in fact, that John Homewood, chair of the Universities' Council for the Education of Teachers' Post-16 Committee has just written to Baroness Blackstone to express concerns about how the new framework will be implemented.

The government is making available up to £80m from the Standards Fund in 2001-2 to match-fund half the cost of staff training in the colleges, £95m in 2002-3 and £105m in 2003-4. Some universities fear that princi pals will prefer to train lecturers by sending them on new one-year, part-time courses leading to a H1-level qualification rather than on a two-year, part-time course in a university. At least one awarding body is thought to be working on a new qualification which colleges could offer instead.

The universities are also concerned that the quality of training could be diluted. At present, most certificates of education are offered at H2, the level of a second-year course at university. Providers - noting that they would not have to provide such high-level training in future - might choose to reduce the intellectual challenge of their courses to H1 level.

Before the minimum entry level was decided there had been some lobbying that the level of qualification for would-be full-time teachers should be set at H2-level. This would make it easier for a further education teacher to top up his or her qualifications to the H3-level qualification required of teachers in schools, ie, a BA Hons Education or a first degree with a PGCE.

It would also have made it easier for lecturers and teachers to move back and forth between schools and colleges. At present you can qualify to be a schoolteacher and teach in further education, but lecturers qualified in further education cannot teach in schools.

Homewood fears that other awarding bodies will develop new qualifications that are at H1-level, but are shorter and involve less studying than courses offered by the universities. These could then be licensed to further education colleges to stage on their own premises.

"If I were a principal I would be very tempted to send my lecturers to the course that took them away from the classroom for the least time," he said.

"And it could be staged at the college. Up until now people have either gone to a university to take a course or they have done a university-franchised course with an identical structure in a further education college."

Developing a compulsory teacher qualification framework, he added, was a "brilliant thing" but he was worried about how it might be implemented.

Veronica Windmill, Fento's Director of Standards and Qualifications, said: "We are thrilled that the government is putting raising standards and further education back into the centre of the picture, because we feel that further education has been ignored for too long.

"We work with the universities and the awarding bodies and listen to what they say, because they are the people who create the qualifications. We understand that some universities have concerns, but we do feel that there is a way through this and would not like such concerns to halt progress."

Born: June 13, 1964

Occupation: Actress, playwright, director. Versatile performer - equally at home with Mary Tudor and Waynetta Slob. Teenage idol for her uncanny portrayal of Harry Enfield's slimy adolescent sidekick, Perry. Recently beatified on telly by Stephen Fry.

Attended: Kingsway college, London

Dates: 1980-81

Courses: Speech and drama

Speech? That's what they say at Kingsway. Apparently the "speech" bit has since been dropped.

She says: "I'd never go out and do a romantic lead part. I don't think that Julia Roberts has got anything to worry about. But Kathy Bates - now she had better watch her back."

fields.headline: So you want to learn...meteorology
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: Oo ar! Hello there.
fields.body:
Oo ar! Hello there.

Looks loik rain. Precipitation is in sight.

You what? I said: You're right, it looks like rain.

We've had enough rain this year. Certainly it's been wet.

This summer's bleddy awful. You think so?

We 'ant 'ad no decent summer for five year. Actually it's been the warmest June since records began.

Worr, rubbish! It's true. Mean temperatures are 0.8C more than the previous record month.

They're mean temperatures all right. I don't think you quite understand.

That's 'cos you talk like one of they weather people on the telly. Well, now you mention it, I am actually . . .

Load of silly tossers! . . . a meteorologist.

And what's that when it's at home? I'm one of those weather people.

Really. Then mine's a pint. Er, right.

But before you get one, tell me what use you are, you metallurgists? The role of the meteorologist is to study, understand and predict the behaviour of the weather.

Understand and predict? Yes, we collect and analyse data to produce weather forecasts and research global patterns to predict long-term climate changes.

And where do you do that then, Mars? No. The main employer of meteorologists in the UK is the Meteorological Office, the Met Office, which employs approximately 2,300 staff, half of whom are based at its head office in Bracknell.

And what do they do with themselves all day? They produce nearly 3,000 forecasts every day for a variety of clients, including the armed forces, local authorities and the National Severe Weather Warning Service.

3,000!? So why do we get so much crappy weather? Don't blame us!

Where do you get it all from? Much of the information we use comes from weather stations, satellites, observation platforms and aircraft. The data, which includes temperatures, humidity and wind speed, is transmitted via telecommunications to the Met Office. Most meteorologists are office-based, although some may have to work at remote locations with extreme weather conditions.

You needs lots of qualifications, I suppose? A degree is standard, normally in maths, physics, or a related field such as electronics and computer science. Several universities offer first degrees in meteorology or one of the related subjects. Alternatively the postgraduate route offers courses in climate change, meteorology and weather modelling. The Met Office has its own college in Reading where it trains all new entrants. All applicants must have proven oral and written communication skills.

Good career prospects? Meteorologists can transfer from one area to another, eg from research to forecasting. Other opportunities are available with the Natural Environment Research Council, the British Antarctic Council, and agricultural and fishing institutes.

The outlook is very dry. Pardon? I don't follow.

Where's my pint? Ah, right.

The Meteorological Office
London Road, Bracknell, Berkshire RG12 2SZ.
Telephone: 0845 300 0300
www.met-office.gov.uk

learndirect (0800 100900) may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Reach for the stars
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock craves the bright lights and a little adulation
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock craves the bright lights and a little adulation
fields.body:
There hasn't been so much media interest in the college since the unfortunate incident over the principal and the chain of beauty salons in southern Portugal. But even that didn't make it big in all the newspapers.

The last week has seen a frenzy of tabloid activity, and all because of Marcus.

Marcus has shot to stardom as the latest pop sensation. I am reading this from the press release his management company has issued. Apparently, Marcus is a talented performer with boy-next-door good looks who is driving teenage fans wild. He has released a song that will become the unofficial anthem of his generation. Also, he begins a world tour next month.

And to think that up until last term he was merely a student who arrived late, sat at the back, never had his work with him and always missed deadlines. In fact, your average student. Well, this is what I told a member of the music press only yesterday. I failed to mention that he was also on a final disciplinary warning about his threatening behaviour.

Seduced by journalists wielding microphones and getting matey with me with their offers of "Have anything you like off the college cafeteria menu," I fell into the kind of bland answers that read like PR puffs. Was it while trying to swallow a mouthful of treacle tart that the word "intelligent" came out?

I suppose I should enjoy being in the shadow of this new celebrity. As far as the college is concerned the publicity is a gift. It is a perfect distraction from the story in the local paper about the cannabis plants grown by one of our lab technicians.

"You should cash in on it," suggested my mate Colin from maths. "Ask for money before you tell them anything."

I couldn't lower myself to such behaviour, so it was disconcerting to overhear one of my students haggling with a hack as I entered the classroom yesterday.

"Call it a grand and I'll throw in a photo of Marcus snogging his mate's bird," said Roxanne.

It's funny how everyone now knows Marcus. He appears to be the best friend of about 2,000 students. The woman who works in the local chip shop is now bribing me with free pea fritters in the hope that I will come up with a Marcus autograph.

In fact, it was while working my way through the most enormous portion of chips I have ever seen and taking a swig from my complimentary can of Tizer that I reflected on the nature of celebrity. Or rather I wondered if the shadowy and unfashionable world of further education could benefit from any reflected limelight.

I imagined what it would be like for lecturers to have celebrity status. Given the right marketing and media management it might be possible for a further education lecturer to achieve at least a minor degree of fame, at a kind of City and Guilds pre-celebrity foundation level perhaps.

But what am I thinking about? I can't sing, can't dance and I don't have those cute lecturer-next-door looks. I think I'll settle for selling some dirt on good old Marcus to the highest bidder, before it's too late and the next teenage celebrity comes along.

fields.headline: Room at the top
fields.standfirst: To thrive in the new age colleges will need top-class leadership, says  Nadine Cartner
fields.trailText: To thrive in the new age colleges will need top-class leadership, says Nadine Cartner
fields.body:
Every further education college brims over with stories of students whose lives have been transformed by their achievements at that college. And - in spite of the well aired divisions between us - those who work in the college sector will, collectively, bring a precious resource to the dealing floor of the learning and skills environment: a passion for empowering people. It is in the DNA of the college sector.

The sights of the day-old Learning and Skills Council are set, however, not on individual empowerment, but on systemic change. The Learning and Skills Council is the child of the "knowledge economy" analysis, the fundamental premise of which is that in the 21st century the main determinant of a nation's economic prosperity will be the skill levels of its people. The historical significance of factors such as capital, raw materials and cheap labour has diminished compared to that of skills and knowledge.

Although the UK's high-skill elites equal the best in the world, the proportion of the population with few skills or qualifications is disturbingly large in comparison with those economies against which we would ordinarily benchmark ourselves. Thus there is an economic as well as an ethical imperative to combat exclusion and this lends muscle and political determination to the Learning and Skills Council's operation. A society in which seven million people are illiterate, innumerate, or both, is economically reckless, as well as socially unjust. The nation can no longer afford to squander people's potential in this fashion.

Thus colleges have the opportunity to contribute to a national challenge of no mean historic importance. At the annual conference of the Association for College Management, delegates and speakers analysed how we should rise to that challenge. We have much to offer - passion, experience, nous, expertise and street wisdom. Even so colleges will need to raise their game to thrive in the new environment. One vital ingredient, identified by Association for College Management conference, will be excellent leadership.

The model of top class leadership developing in the sector (through the work of organisations such as Fento, the Agency, and Association for College Management) is holistic and increasingly well theorised. The best leaders understand that thefuture is not predestined, but is yet to be created, and that those with vision and skills will be the authors of the future. This model of leadership rejects the negativity and fatalism of the "nobody has ever understood or valued us", "the Learning and Skills Council odds are stacked against colleges", "it's everybody else's fault but ours" approach to the future. At its most gloomy this perspective embodies a perverse self satisfaction in cynicism, a fondness for the role of victim and an obstinate determination to opt for blame rather than resolution. Further education's fatal flaw.

By comparison excellent leaders will have the strategic skills that enable them to describe and communicate the future and how it will be achieved. These strategic skills will aid them to reposition their colleges on their local Learning and Skills Council landscape, and in readiness for key national initiatives such as "Centres for Vocational Excellence". The dense everyday complexity of colleges - communication, planning, funding, monitoring, employment, plant and legal issues - will continue to demand operational and technical skills of a high order. Above all excellent leaders will have people skills approaching those of Sir Alex Ferguson with which to inspire, motivate and empower colleagues. As the "knowledge economy" analysis tells us, capable, innovative and engaged people are the most valuable resource, and a successful college will promote continuous learning that equips colleagues not just with specific vocational skills, but also with confidence, creativity and readiness for change.

On the broader political stage, the best college leaders will forge a public presence and identity for colleges that is intelligent, constructive, collaborative, and learner centred. None of this is to deny problems and obstacles in the new environment that must be tackled. But effective problem-solving will employ reasoned and learner-centred analysis as the basis for lively, forceful negotiation.

webTitle: A footballer who can tell a good tale

fields.headline: And he's scored!
fields.standfirst: John Crace meets a footballer who can tell a good tale
fields.trailText: John Crace meets a footballer who can tell a good tale
fields.body:
"It's the seventh minute of a fifth round FA Cup tie and we're up against Liverpool, the top club in Britain. We're in the second division and expected to lose by two or three. I dispossess Terry McDermott on the half-way line and it's a flat out dash for goal. Bruce Grobelaar is coming out towards me and I've got various thoughts running through my head. Do I try to chip the keeper, dink the ball round him or blast it?"

"Chip it," shout out a few of the kids gathered on the floor. "Round the keeper," calls out a lone voice. "Blast it," yell the majority.

"I decide to blast it and I can see the ball going wide. But then I look up and see my mum blowing hard from the touchline and the ball veers right and dips inside the lefthand post. I've just scored and we're one-nil up against the favourites."

It's gripping storytelling and there's not a fidget in earshot. It also happens that every word is true - well, with the possible exception of the bit about his mum - as the speaker is Peter Rhoades-Brown, the former Chelsea winger, who is now Oxford United's community affairs officer.

Oxford may be struggling to find inspiration on the pitch this season, but it's a different matter off it as the club is making friends in all sorts of unlikely locations, the most recent of which is Sonning Common library.

This visit is part of a week-long hike around nine Oxfordshire libraries, where Peter Rhoades-Brown, aka Rosie, and Patrick Ryan, a professional storyteller, tell stories to groups of school children.

"We aimed to target the lads who normally sit at the back in class and don't get too involved in lessons," says John Pilling, a senior librarian with Oxfordshire County Council. "We wanted both to stimulate these children's imaginations and to encourage them to read. We were delighted by the success of the project and would happily do it again if funding were made available."

The project was Ryan's brainchild. He's an American by birth, but Irish by descent and has collected a huge array of folklore tales over the years. For the last 15 years or so has made a living going round the world telling them. After a one-off event with Rhoades-Brown went down a storm last year, he put together the idea of a longer tour and persuaded Southern Arts Board to stump up the cash for it.

"It was particularly great for the kids to have strong male role models involved," he says. "Many boys grow up wanting to be professional footballers and they'll listen to what they have to say far more readily than they would their teachers. It's not just the boys who get a lot out of it; even though a lot of the stories are football based, the girls never got bored."

But there's another group for whom story-telling has been a learning process. The Oxford first-team footballers. On one occasion Rhoades-Brown brought in the Welsh Under 21 international Rob Folland, Ross Wetherstone and John Shepherd to show that current players value reading, and that relaxing with a book before a big game can improve performance, but it was the players who went away with the education.

"Footballers have a comparatively short career," says Ryan, "and most move on to jobs in coaching, the leisure industry, running a pub or public speaking. For all these careers, players will need good communication skills and telling stories to a bunch of schoolkids is great practice for the future."

Rhoades-Brown couldn't agree more. "When I was a youngster with Chelsea, I had almost no self-confidence and wouldn't say boo to anyone," he adds. "These days I'm quite happy standing up in front of 500 kids at a school assembly."

Ryan and Rhoades-Brown hope to repeat the experiment next year, and Ryan is also talking to Queens Park Rangers and Leyton Orient about similar projects.

There's also a possible knock-on benefit for the rest of us. The post-match interview of: "At the end of the day it's a game of two halves and the lads done good," may soon be a distant memory.

webTitle: New course aims to ease the process of dispensing medicines

fields.headline: Triple checked
fields.standfirst: John Crace on the course that's got the right prescription
fields.trailText: John Crace on the course that's got the right prescription
fields.body:
You're one of the lucky few. You're cured of your original complaint, you've escaped a secondary infection and the doctor has just discharged you. You're home free. Right? Not quite. You've still got to collect your going-home prescription from the hospital dispensary. At the very least you'll have a few hours' wait to pick up any more passing germs and if you're unfortunate you might even go home with the wrong stuff. As with most parts of the National Health service, money is tight, staff are overworked and mistakes happen.

This could soon change, though, as Preston College have introduced a new BTec level 4 professional development certificate in Dispensing Technician Checking. The course, the first of its kind in the country, has proved so successful with hospitals in Preston, Warrington, Liverpool, Manchester and Bolton in the north-west, that the college has been invited to deliver it to hospital staff in Newcastle in the north-east.

The process of ensuring medicines are correctly dispensed is strictly controlled. The doctor writes the prescription, which is checked by the pharmacist to make sure it is suitable for the patient and of the correct dosage. The prescription is then made up by a dispensing technician before being given a final check for accuracy by the pharmacist.

But as Dr Chris Walton, the course co-ordinator explains, there is plenty of room for errors. "Doctors' writing isn't always the easiest to decipher," he smiles, "and decimal points for dosages do get in the wrong place. Likewise, a medicine is sometimes given in pill form instead of a cream. New drugs are coming on the market the whole time and they often have remarkably similar names to existing ones. Dispensers can also make numerical errors, either by giving too many pills or too few."

All things considered, very few errors are made and even fewer get out to patients, but when a single mistake can be fatal, accuracy is paramount. Which is where Preston College comes in. In recent years, hospitals have struggled to recruit pharmacists, and some have taken to training dispensing technicians to make the final check.

Preston's course consists of five half-day training sessions, two weeks apart and an observed hospital-based assessment of 1,000 items over a period of time, and has proved popular with all hospital staff.

"Under the old system, there were only two people, the pharmacist and the dispenser, involved in the checking process," says Natasha Walters, pharmacy manager at Blackpool Victoria hospital. "We now have a third person, the dispensary checking technician, which ought to ensure even fewer mistakes are made."

Research has proved Walters right. It has been shown that final checks done by technicians show a reduced number of errors compared to those done by pharmacists, who tend to be more distracted. What's more, it's not just the patients who can now go home with a smile on their face. Dispensing technicians cost the hospital roughly half the salary of a pharmacist and take much less time to train. Which obviously leaves far more in the kitty for the hospital trust manager's productivity bonus. For once, everyone's a winner.

Dispensers can also make numerical errors, either by giving too many pills or too few." All things considered, very few errors are made and even fewer get out to patients, but when a single mistake can be fatal, accuracy is paramount. Which is where Preston College comes in. In recent years, hospitals have struggled to recruit pharmacists, and some have taken to training dispensing technicians to make the final check. Preston's course consists of five half-day training sessions, two weeks apart and an observed hospital-based assessment of 1,000 items over a period of time, and has proved popular with all hospital staff. "Under the old system, there were only two people, the pharmacist and the dispenser, involved in the checking process," says Natasha Walters, pharmacy manager at Blackpool Victoria hospital. "We now have a third person, the dispensary checking technician, which ought to ensure even fewer mistakes are made." Research has proved Walters right. It has been shown that final checks done by technicians show a reduced number of errors compared to those done by pharmacists, who tend to be more distracted. What's more, it's not just the patients who can now go home with a smile on their face. Dispensing technicians cost the hospital roughly half the salary of a pharmacist and take much less time to train. Which obviously leaves far more in the kitty for the hospital trust manager's productivity bonus. For once, everyone's a winner.

fields.headline: Milosevic faces death penalty
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic and his wife face the death penalty in Yugoslavia as they prepare to answer murder charges.
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic and his wife face the death penalty in Yugoslavia as they prepare to answer murder charges.

The Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, says Mr Milosevic will be charged within two months with ordering the murders of personal and political enemies.

He says he also expects Mr Milosevic's wife, Mirjana, to face murder charges.

Since the former president was arrested in the early hours of Sunday morning on corruption charges, Yugoslav authorities have stepped up investigations into other criminal complaints against the 59-year-old deposed leader.

Serbia's interior minister, Dusan Mihajlovic, joked that the former Yugoslav president may even volunteer to go to the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague, which cannot order executions.

"There are [] indications that Slobodan Milosevic was involved in severe criminal acts for which the death penalty is provided," he said.

Mr Milosevic, however, remained defiant, denouncing his arrest as "politically staged". In a written statement, the deposed president admitted siphoning off £260m from state funds to finance Serb rebellions that bloodied Bosnia and Croatia in the 1990s.

"These expenses could not, as a state secret, be accounted for in the state budget," he wrote, denying police allegations that he had used the cash for personal gain.

He is being held in Belgrade's central prison for at least 30 days, as authorities try to build a case of alleged corruption and abuse of power against him. Mr Milosevic is also charged with inciting his bodyguards to shoot at police as they tried to arrest him last weekend.

A court today rejected his appeal to be released from jail. Under Yugoslav law, investigative courts can decide whether to jail a suspect in criminal cases or to release them pending trial.

As part of the ongoing investigation, an investigative judge has summoned three of Mr Milosevic's former aides for questioning. Two of them - Nikola Sainovic and Jovan Zebic - refused to testify, citing immunity as members of parliament.

fields.headline: Watchdog reins in French Connection
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: French Connection will have all its advertising pre-vetted after watchdogs ruled it had brought the industry into disrepute, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
French Connection will have all its advertising pre-vetted by the regulators after an advertising watchdog ruled it had brought the industry into disrepute by persistently breaking the rules.

The fashion retailer has gained a reputation for flouting advertising regulations with its controversial FCUK campaign.

The decision to impose the sanction follows an Advertising Standards Authority ruling that a poster campaign carrying the line "fcukinkybugger" was offensive and irresponsible.

The decision means all French Connection advertising for the next two years will have to be approved by a committee of advertising experts before it can be carried by media owners under the self-regulatory system.

The sanction was introduced by the ASA in 1998 as a deterrent to advertisers that persistently flouted the watchdog's rules.

So far it has been applied to just 18 advertisers. These include among others Yves St Laurent, which was censured over a poster campaign for Opium perfume featuring a naked Sophie Dahl, and Gossard, the lingerie firm behind the Hello Boys adverts.

The ASA said it had told French Connection in the past that "fcuk" should not be used in the company's advertising where it could be misinterpreted as "fuck".

It added that it was concerned that the company had used such words in an advert that could be seen by children.

Trevor Beattie, the brains behind the fcuk campaign, has repeatedly spoken out against the regulators for their attitude to the campaign - most notably when, earlier this year, a planned TV commercial was banned before it had even been shot.

fields.headline: Matthaus: 'Today's the day for revenge'
fields.trailText: Lothar Matthaus has backed Bayern Munich to avenge their 1999 Champions League final defeat against Manchester United tonight, insisting: "there is no reason for Bayern to shit in their pants because they are playing at Old Trafford."
fields.body:
Lothar Matthaus has backed Bayern Munich to avenge their 1999 Champions League final defeat against Manchester United tonight, insisting: "there is no reason for Bayern to shit in their pants because they are playing at Old Trafford."

In his column for the German newspaper Bild today, Matthaus urged Bayern coach Ottmar Hitzfield to start with three up front up to put the pressure on United's back four.

"It would be best to focus on attack like Bayern did two years ago when the game finished in a 1-1 draw and three strikers are the best recipe against Manchester's experienced back four," Matthaus claimed.

"The return leg will be played in Munich and we have all saw how good English teams are when they play abroad when Arsenal lost 1-0 in Munich."

Matthaus, who watched United's 2-1 Champions League comeback from the bench after being substituted, also admitted: "I, together with millions of football fans, have had to wait 678 long days, but today is the day of revenge."

But Matthaus also warned his former team-mates not to get carried away. "Bayern have to delete their memories of the 26th of May 1999 and better remember that we were the better side not only in the final, but also in the two group stage matches," he added.

webTitle: China refuses to bow to Bush over spy plane

fields.headline: China refuses to bow to Bush over spy plane
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: China was doing its best to make George Bush sweat yesterday after the US president called on Beijing to arrange "the prompt and safe return" of the grounded American EP-3 spy plane and its 24-person crew from Hainan island following Sunday's mid-air clash with a Chinese jet.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington and  John Gittings in Shanghai
fields.body:
China was doing its best to make George Bush sweat yesterday after the US president called on Beijing to arrange "the prompt and safe return" of the grounded American EP-3 spy plane and its 24-person crew from Hainan island following Sunday's mid-air clash with a Chinese jet.

While Washington demanded that Beijing should free the naval surveillance plane and its crew without examining the aircraft's secret equipment, Chinese officials were in no hurry to oblige. Foreign ministry officials said that three American diplomats who travelled to Hainan from Beijing would only get their first access to the crew today, more than 48 hours after the incident. Meanwhile US officials complained that the Chinese had boarded the plane, which should be "sovereign and immune".

Both sides struggled to avoid an uncontrolled escalation of rhetoric over the incident. But the cold war-style stand-off has sent a chill through relations between two countries which, until January, had described themselves as strategic partners and which now seem set for an era of confrontation.

Three US navy destroyers were ordered to stay in the Hainan island area "indefinitely" rather than continue their journey from Hong Kong to Hawaii, officials said.

Mr Bush huddled with his top foreign policy advisers at the White House yesterday before emerging to say that he was "troubled by the lack of a timely Chinese response" to the US demands. "Failure of the Chinese government to react promptly to our request is inconsistent with standard diplomatic practice and the expressed desire of our countries for better relations," he said.

The 24 Americans were officially reported safe, but Beijing's denial of immediate US access to the spy plane and its crew came as Chinese public opinion reacted angrily to Sunday's incident, in which the Chinese fighter jet crashed into the South China Sea. The pilot is missing.

China insists that the crash followed a deliberate swerve into the fighter's path by the US plane, which then also suffered damage, losing one of its four engines, damaging its left wing and being forced to make an emergency landing on Hainan, 70 miles away. The US says the Chinese fighter bumped into the American jet.

The US crew was said to have been moved to a military guesthouse near Lingshui airfield while the plane was standing empty where it had landed.

American concern was focused as much on the fate of the EP-3 as on the return of its crew. The last communication from them was that armed soldiers were boarding shortly after the plane landed, US officials said. Mr Bush called for the plane to be returned "without further tampering".

"We physically cannot prevent the Chinese from boarding the plane," Admiral Dennis Blair, commander in chief of the US Pacific command said. "What protects the plane really is the concept of sovereign immunity."

The EP-3E Aries II plane at the centre of the incident had taken off from Kadena airforce base on Okinawa island, Japan, more than 1,000 miles away. It carries a range of electronic and cryptological eavesdropping technology which enables itto track radio, fax, phone other electronic messages on the ground.

Standard procedure under the circumstances would be for the crew to destroy as much of the plane's equipment as possible once it landed on Chinese territory, a US navy analyst said. "There is a considerable amount of equipment on there that is, I would guess, superior to the Chinese military's," Norman Polmar told the New York Times.

The US ambassador to China, Joseph Prueher, said in Beijing that China had no legal basis to hold the crew. "It is inexplicable and unacceptable that the crew has been held incommunicado for 32 hours," he told a news conference.

His comments echoed those of Mr Bush, who said "I expect them to heed the message". Mr Bush said the US believes its jet was in international airspace, not inside China..

The Chinese foreign minister said he hoped that diplomatic damage from the incident would be limited. "I hope an adequate solution can be found to this question," Tang Jiaxuan said in Paris.

fields.headline: 'Flood Bush' email stalls White House server
fields.standfirst: Click here to read the Friends of the Earth email
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: BP and Shell have joined a Friends of the Earth email campaign targeting President Bush, writes Julia Day.
Click here to read the email
fields.body:
Oil giants BP and Shell have joined a Friends of the Earth email campaign pleading with President George W Bush not to renege on the Kyoto Protocol climate-change treaty.

The campaign is believed to have stalled the White House internet server, which can only handle 150 messages a minute.

So far, 33,000 emails have been sent to the White House as part of FoE's bid to make the US stick by its commitment to prevent global warming.

At present, 1,000 emails an hour are being sent to President Bush.

The email is being dispersed across the globe as recipients pass it on to friends and colleagues.

An FoE Europe spokesman said more than 200 members of the European Parliament and 140 European Commission members have sent the email, as well as BP and Shell employees using their work computers.

FoE will tomorrow send out emails to some of the 10m people that signed an email petition in the run-up to the climate change summit in the Hague.

Spanish, French, Russian and Japanese versions of the emails are being sent out this week.

The organisation says the "Flood Bush" campaign may be even bigger than the Hague campaign.

webTitle: 'Race not issue' over accused Met officer

fields.headline: 'Race not issue' over accused Met officer
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard yesterday launched a furious defence against claims that it has conducted a racist witch-hunt against one of the country's most senior ethnic minority officers.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard yesterday launched a furious defence against claims that it has conducted a racist witch-hunt against one of the country's most senior ethnic minority officers, who was suspended pending an inquiry into widespread allegations of corruption.

The force described the conduct of Superintendent Ali Dizaei before he was removed from duty as "absolutely horrendous". His behaviour could not be ignored, even though senior officers feared a backlash.

An 18-month inquiry by the Metropolitan police revealed an officer who was "totally and utterly out of control", a source told the Guardian.

"Mr Dizaei seemed to think he could do whatever he wanted. He seemed to think he was bomb proof."

The row between the Met and Supt Dizaei, once tipped as a future chief constable, has embroiled the country's biggest force in one of the most poisonous race disputes of recent years.

Supporters of Supt Dizaei, who has joint Iranian and British citizenship, have demanded to know why he was suspended on January 18, and told the Met to provide proof of allegations that range from misuse of drugs to deception, corrupt practice, assault, sex with prostitutes and divulging confidential information. Supt Dizaei has denied any wrong-doing.

Telling the Met to "put up or shut up", the National Black Police Association (NBPA), which is supporting the officer, yesterday accused the force of victimisation. "Can they [the Met] name another white officer who's had an investigation of this magnitude targeted against them?" said Ravi Chand, its chairman.

Mr Chand said Supt Dizaei was caught in a "racist witch-hunt". But the Met insisted ethnicity was not a factor.

The Guardian has been told the initial investigation was sparked by a complaint made by someone outside the force who referred to the strange behaviour of a senior Met officer, who was not named. "We didn't know who the officer was at that point, so ethnicity didn't come into it," said the source.

The Met's complaints investigation bureau, which conducted the inquiry, was subsequently contacted by other witnesses, who alleged Supt Dizaei was involved in a range of corrupt practices.

One of the allegations centres on whether Supt Dizaei demanded free tickets for the Googoosh, an Iranian music festival at Wembley Arena in January.

"You cannot say this is a minor issue," said the source. "It's the kind of thing that used to happen in the bad old days. It is the kind of thing the Met has fought back against in recent years. We couldn't ignore this. To describe the allegations that he has been accused of as minor is ridiculous."

Supt Dizaei has told friends the tickets were sent to him unsolicited.

CIB files allege Supt Dizaei accepted numerous free meals and did not lodge them in the Met's hospitality register, a requirement for senior officers. This alleged behaviour was symptomatic of his arrogance to duty and was part of an "awful pattern of behaviour", said the source.

Rather than suspending Supt Dizaei immediately, the Met asked outside specialists, including Beverley Thompson, chairwoman of the Met's independent advisory group, to look at the CIB case.

"We kept asking ourselves, are we overreacting to this?", said the source. "Nobody has told us we have overreacted. The independent advisers have supported our action."

The Met claimed its investigation has been hampered by supporters of the officer threatening potential witnesses. "The Iranian community has closed ranks," said the source.

When the second phase of the investigation is complete - which could take months - Supt Dizaei will be interviewed. Only then will decisions be taken on disciplinary proceedings, or possible referral to the crown prosecution service.
