webTitle: UK 'most racist' in Europe on refugees

fields.headline: UK 'most racist' in Europe on refugees
fields.standfirst:
Commission blames media and government

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Racism against asylum seekers and refugees is "particularly acute" in Britain, according to a Council of Europe survey of prejudice across the continent.
fields.body:
Racism against asylum seekers and refugees is "particularly acute" in Britain, according to a Council of Europe survey of prejudice across the continent.

The council's European commission against racism and intolerance blames the media for "xenophobic and intolerant coverage". But it also criticises the government for adopting and enforcing "increasingly restrictive asylum and immigration laws".

The Council of Europe, in Strasbourg, promotes democracy and human rights in its 43 member states. Today's report is the second in almost as many weeks to single Britain out for its negative attitude towards refugees. Last month, the EU's racism and xenophobia monitoring centre in Vienna found that, of all 15 member states, Britain was the most hostile to political refugees.

Field work for the latest report, carried out last May and June, raised concern about the "general negative climate concerning asylum seekers and refugees in the UK". The print media were blamed for "contributing to creating such a climate" by "consistent inflammatory attacks" on asylum seekers and migrants, in local and some national newspapers.

The new report, covering the code of practice of the newspaper industry, said it was "ill-suited to countering the publication of articles containing general racist assumptions and stereotypes against particular groups of persons".

But the council also said that frequent changes in immigration and asylum policies had played a fundamental and negative role.

The report added: "Many politicians have contributed to, or at least not adequately prevented, public debate taking on an increasingly intolerant line with at times racist and xenophobic overtones. Public statements have tended to depict asylum seekers and 'economic migrants' explicitly or by inference, as a threat to security, economic stability and social peace. Politicians should not only avoid promoting the general assumption that most asylum claimants are not genuine, but also the vilification of those who are considered by the authorities not to have valid asylum claims and who are sometimes defined as 'economic migrants', 'economic refugees', or 'bogus asylum seekers'.

"It is unacceptable for politicians to direct the general public's feelings of insecurity on one specific group of persons, irrespective of whether these persons have a valid claim to remain in the country or not."

The researchers praised attempts to counter institutional racism in the police after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report, but said racial prejudice in the police "continued to constitute an element of concern". Criminal and civil laws were not always effective in countering racist, xenophobic or discriminatory behaviour.

Some of the harshest criticism in the report was reserved for Austria, where last year's rise to power of Jörg Haider's freedom party was accompanied by extreme anti-foreigner rhetoric.

fields.bodyText: Racism against asylum seekers and refugees is "particularly acute" in Britain, according to a Council of Europe survey of prejudice across the continent. The council's European commission against racism and intolerance blames the media for "xenophobic and intolerant coverage". But it also criticises the government for adopting and enforcing "increasingly restrictive asylum and immigration laws". The Council of Europe, in Strasbourg, promotes democracy and human rights in its 43 member states. Today's report is the second in almost as many weeks to single Britain out for its negative attitude towards refugees. Last month, the EU's racism and xenophobia monitoring centre in Vienna found that, of all 15 member states, Britain was the most hostile to political refugees. Field work for the latest report, carried out last May and June, raised concern about the "general negative climate concerning asylum seekers and refugees in the UK". The print media were blamed for "contributing to creating such a climate" by "consistent inflammatory attacks" on asylum seekers and migrants, in local and some national newspapers. The new report, covering the code of practice of the newspaper industry, said it was "ill-suited to countering the publication of articles containing general racist assumptions and stereotypes against particular groups of persons". But the council also said that frequent changes in immigration and asylum policies had played a fundamental and negative role. The report added: "Many politicians have contributed to, or at least not adequately prevented, public debate taking on an increasingly intolerant line with at times racist and xenophobic overtones. Public statements have tended to depict asylum seekers and 'economic migrants' explicitly or by inference, as a threat to security, economic stability and social peace. Politicians should not only avoid promoting the general assumption that most asylum claimants are not genuine, but also the vilification of those who are considered by the authorities not to have valid asylum claims and who are sometimes defined as 'economic migrants', 'economic refugees', or 'bogus asylum seekers'. "It is unacceptable for politicians to direct the general public's feelings of insecurity on one specific group of persons, irrespective of whether these persons have a valid claim to remain in the country or not." The researchers praised attempts to counter institutional racism in the police after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report, but said racial prejudice in the police "continued to constitute an element of concern". Criminal and civil laws were not always effective in countering racist, xenophobic or discriminatory behaviour. Some of the harshest criticism in the report was reserved for Austria, where last year's rise to power of Jörg Haider's freedom party was accompanied by extreme anti-foreigner rhetoric. Special report: race issues in the UK European Commission against racism and intolerance

fields.headline: The Guardian graduate jobs email
fields.trailText: In a week when it was reported that IT and the internet has taken over from consultancy as the career of choice among today's college leavers, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.
fields.body:
In a week when it was reported that IT and the internet has taken over from consultancy as the career of choice among today's college leavers, here is this week's email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.

For those unconvinced by the IT world, we take a look at ALL the best graduate jobs offered by Jobs Unlimited - the website devoted to finding you the best vacancies.

We also review last Saturday's Rise and take a sneak preview of next week's issue. In addition we've included a link to a past article featured in Rise that we think is worth a second read in Rise Gold.

If you were too busy honing your keyboard skills to get to the newsagent, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 31 March).

Believe it or not, the Foreign Office has leapt up the rankings and ousted the BBC to become the place where most graduates want to start their working lives. They surveyed 5,500 grads at 43 Unis to come up with the top 100 - check out where your chosen employer came.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,465969,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you are feeling a bit run down, you might need a detox - it will not only cleanse your system but you'll allegedly gain extra energy and improved creativity. Absolutely no alcohol and lots of water.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,465972,00.html?bnr=email.grad

There was also a look at how the right secondment can be a platform for success, and some advice on how to share your workload with a charming skiver - never say we don't tackle the big issues at Rise!

NEXT WEEK'S RISE takes a long hard look at University careers services and asks whether they are any good. There's advice on how to use humour and comedy in interviews or presentations, and a look at how you need to adapt your modus operandi according to the sex of your boss.

This week's RISE GOLD is a look at the old live/work balance and how you can get it right. This is a hot topic at the moment but Rise first looked at this in April last year. Read Hilary Freeman's guide on how to burn the candle at BOTH ends. http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3986373,00.html?bnr=email.grad

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP

You may not think they do any good, but head down to your campus careers service. It's a fact that those who make the most appearances are the first to hear about the best jobs. Put your prejudices aside and head down there.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS.

Do you know a bargain when you see it? The Department for Education and Employment is looking for a Value for Money Analyst to investigate and report on management and operational processes in schools. It would be probably help to be a Scot.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112108,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you've always fancied two years in Taiwan and you have a TEFL qualification, look no further. Free accommodation, Chinese lessons and a salary to boot - just watch out for the missiles from the mainland.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112133,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Insurance giant Cornhill's publications division is looking for graduates to negotiate advertising contracts with chief executives of large corporations worldwide. It's promising £25K-£45K OTE.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100111518,00.html?bnr=email.grad

At the other end of the financial spectrum, University College London is looking for an administrative assistant for its Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. Starts at £14,174 including London allowances.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112143,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If phys ed is your thing, St Martin's College in Lancaster is seeking to recruit three enthusiastic Sport and Exercise Scientists at L/SL level and it's even inviting informal enquiries - you'd expect nothing less.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100112056,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If you have an economics background and a desire to become a reporter, this company wants to train you up to report on the international financial markets. Get it right and you'll never be out of work again.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100111638,00.html?bnr=email.grad

For those tie and dye experts, John Lewis has the dream job. It's looking for a graduate in surface printed textile design with an excellent sense of colour and an eye for commercially successful design. And the best bit, "a knowledge of bed linen would be a distinct advantage".
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100111603,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Although it doesn't say why, The Lancet is launching a monthly publication on Infectious Diseases and naturally it's looking for a Manuscript Editor. If you can marry up these two skills - the job's probably already yours.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100111489,00.html?bnr=email.grad

And finally, if you speak Italian and want to get into the dark world of conferences, this company has lots of positions. Slightly worryingly, it quotes John D Rockfeller in the ad, but if you can get past this - and all the "dynamic" talk, it could be the job for you.

http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100111511,00.html?bnr=email.grad

fields.headline: Viewers clock off BBC1 drama
fields.trailText: 5pm TV overnights: BBC1 drama Clocking Off failed to chime with the viewers, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The first programme in the second series of acclaimed BBC1 drama Clocking Off failed to chime with the viewers.

Clocking Off, written by Paul Abbott, has been described by one critic as containing "moral complexity, sophisticated psychology and plain good writing".

But it attracted only 5.8m viewers and 24% of audience share last night, according to unofficial overnight ratings.

Clocking Off was moved to from its Sunday-night slot to Monday nights by BBC drama chiefs a few weeks ago after dramas like Rebel Heart and Love in a Cold Climate failed to ignite the ratings.

It was moved despite protests from the writer and friendly advice from experts, including ITV drama boss Nick Elliott, that it should have stayed in the weekend slot.

The first series won both critical acclaim and huge audiences of up to 11m viewers.

But on its return, the drama had the bad fortune to have been positioned opposite Who Wants to be a Millionaire, which took 9.4m viewers, 39% of audience share on ITV.

The BBC also suffered from the huge number of people who changed channels when EastEnders was over.

When Lee Evans's sitcom So What Now? came on at 8.30pm, the BBC saw its audiences slump from 13.9m to 6.5m.

This sank even further to just 5.8m when Clocking Off came on.

Over on ITV, Coronation Street pulled in 13.8m. But the audience plummeted to just 5.1m, and 20% share for the following programme, Wish You Were Here.

webTitle: Lewisham provides a model example to post-Milosevic Belgrade

fields.headline: Lewisham provides a model example to post-Milosevic Belgrade
fields.standfirst: Lewisham council officers travelled to Belgrade to spread the democratic word and share their local government expertise. Paul Richards reports
fields.trailText: Lewisham council officers travelled to Belgrade to spread the democratic word and share their local government expertise. Paul Richards reports.
fields.body:
It is not immediately obvious what Lewisham has in common with the Serbian capital of Belgrade. Assassinations, vote rigging and state oppression, until recently part of day-to-day life under Slobodan Milosevic, are thankfully unknown in south-east London.

But despite their very different political climates, Lewisham's councillors and officers have been working with their counterparts in Belgrade as part of a ground-breaking scheme to share know-how, culminating in a conference in Belgrade last month. Some 16 of the city's mayors - equivalent to the leaders of London's boroughs - and their chief executives met to discuss democratic structures, consultation and reform with British local government experts.

The Lewisham link, helped along by the Foreign Office and the Local Government International Bureau (LGIB), has been in place since before Milosevic was forced out of power by mass street protests. Opposition leaders in Belgrade local government were contacted and brought to the UK for training in democracy. The mayor of the Cukarica municipality, Zoran Alimpic, and his adviser, Dusan Spasojevic, both only in their 30s, visited Lewisham council in 1999. Now the opposition leaders are in control and can conduct their work free from the surveillance of the Serbian secret police.

The mayors who attended the conference were mostly young men, untainted by the previous regime. They had been active in student politics, in street demonstrations, and in political agitation against Milosevic's Socialist Party. Many had won municipal elections in 1996 and 2000. Now, having gained power through the Democratic Party, they were keen to learn about the applications and limitations of democracy.

Zeljko Ozegovic is mayor of New Belgrade municipality, a concrete suburb built since 1948 to house workers in the west of the city, with little thought given by the socialist planners to infrastructure, schools, hospitals or entertainments. There are 320,000 people living in New Belgrade, but no theatre, no hospital, and just 19 schools. "Everything is damaged," says Mr Ozegovic. He cites the recent bombing and trade sanctions, which haven't helped the city, but points too to decades of systematic under-investment. There are regular power cuts and water shortages. Unemployment is high, drugs and crime are exploding, and the city is filled with refugees from throughout the Balkans.

These problems are shared by the rest of the city. The new local government leaders were faced with widespread corruption within the town halls - bribes for licences, planning agreements, and the provision of services were part of the culture. They needed to make cuts to the bloated town hall bureaucracy, to cut down on the chauffeurs and mobile phones. They were faced with huge budget deficits, and their spending capped and controlled by central government. The main issues - capping, underinvestment, and democratic reform - are familiar to UK councillors. It is the scale of them that makes Belgrade different.

Zoran Alimpic says: "We inherited huge debts, no money, the economy was ruined and there were too many refugees. We had no computers." Faced with such a scale of problems, where do you start?

The new leaders of Belgrade's councils started with cultural changes - they opened the doors of the town halls to the voters, and positioned themselves as champions of their communities. They tried to help people get their water supplies fixed or their electricity back on. They took up cases with the national government.

Today, most mayors in Belgrade are known to a majority of their community - they are feted as they walk down the street. They are symbols of the new democracy, in a country where democracy is seen as a precious new commodity.

They have begun to reform the services and structures of local government. Mr Alimpic says: "The whole system needs change. We need to decentralise and devolve power. We need changes in electoral law and directly-elected mayors." His adviser Mr Spasojevic adds: "The whole system is in crisis, from the federal level to the regions, to the cities, to the municipalities."

After only a few years in office in Cukarica, Mr Alimpic has introduced information technology to the council, rooted out the corruption, and started slowly to improve services. He is determined to use his mandate to improve his people's lives.

Driving round Belgrade, the scale of the challenges these young men face is obvious. The streets are filled with potholes, the buildings are filthy and covered in graffiti, there are beggars on every corner. The evidence of the bombing is apparent too - the socialist party headquarters towers above Belgrade, dwarfing the new international hotels. It took a direct hit, and has been deserted ever since. It is a symbol of the demise of the Milosevic regime - but it also bares a striking resemblance to Labour's Millbank Tower.

During the bombing, the people of Belgrade had crowded onto the city's bridge to create their own human shield and prevent them being becoming targets. Among the politicians at least, there appeared little resentment towards the British, whose airforce had bombed the city only a few months before.

The conference was deemed a success, and indications from the Foreign Office, which funded the event, are that there will be more. The link scheme could serve as a model of how local government in Britain can provide practical support in new democracies. The Belgrade mayors are hungry for advice on how to make change, refelcted in the conference being attended by 16 mayors for five days - it is hard to imagine council leaders in Britain showing so much enthusiasm.

The British conference participants learned a great deal too, not least how fortunate they are. Councillors in this country have their difficulties to deal with, but compared to Zoran, Zeljko, Dusan and the rest, they should remember to count their blessings.

webTitle: Shaw can shore up England pack

fields.headline: Shaw can shore up England pack
fields.trailText: With this season's Six Nations Championship now officially an unfinished symphony, England are in limbo. In normal circumstances this weekend's encounter with France might have provided an excuse to reach for the post-match title champagne; instead Clive Woodward's squad must try and suppress any sense of anti-climax and vow to finish the job in the autumn.
fields.body:
With this season's Six Nations Championship now officially an unfinished symphony, England are in limbo. In normal circumstances this weekend's encounter with France might have provided an excuse to reach for the post-match title champagne; instead Clive Woodward's squad must try and suppress any sense of anti-climax and vow to finish the job in the autumn.

To do that, of course, they must first avoid losing the plot against the French and today's team announcement will reinforce that business-as-usual message. England will kick themselves all summer if they suffer a surprise defeat on Saturday and Woodward, still without a grand slam in his portfolio, is particularly loth to see all the hard work of recent months go to waste.

Assuming Jonny Wilkinson's neck spasms are as matter-of-fact as his Newcastle boss Rob Andrew has implied, the main selectorial focus will be on the pack. Both Phil Vickery and Danny Grewcock, ever-present in the championship to date, are missing through injury and filling Grewcock's berth in the second row has presented the management with something of a dilemma.

The two prime candidates are the Wasps lock Simon Shaw and his younger, uncapped Bath counterpart Steve Borthwick. If the opposition was anyone but France, the 21-year-old Borthwick would be almost certain to get the nod; his former Bath coach Andy Robinson is a known supporter, he performed well in the midweek team on last year's tour to South Africa and Woodward has never been afraid to promote talent regardless of age.

Shaw, though, is a bigger, stronger scrummager, some two stones heavier and three inches taller than his rival, who has never let England down in his 15 previous Tests spread over five years since his debut against Ireland in 1996. He came off the bench to replace Grewcock in both Tests against the Springboks last year and has still to accept there is no place in the interchangeable modern game for men of his rumbling bulk.

The impending birth of Jason Leonard's second child did not prevent England's rock of ages reporting for duty as usual yesterday and Saracens' Julian White is the obvious replacement for Vickery at tight-head.

For those outside the England camp suddenly left with a yawning void in their schedules, however, the rugby world is suddenly a flatter place. The tournament sponsors Lloyds TSB expressed "bitter disappointment" at the failure to complete the championship this season and it will be some time yet before fresh dates are confirmed for the autumn.

"It feels as though the season has petered out rather than reaching its natural conclusion," admitted the Scotland coach Ian McGeechan, whose side were originally due to host the Irish this weekend.

 It is two years since the Wales coach Graham Henry afforded himself the luxury of announcing an unchanged team, but Wales will go to Rome this week for Sunday's international at the Stadio Flaminio with the line-up which earned them an unexpected victory in Paris last month. The scrum-half Rob Howley and the wing Gareth Thomas will be winning their 50th caps.

Wales: R Williams , Thomas (both Cardiff), Taylor , Gibbs (both Swansea), James (Llanelli); N Jenkins , Howley (both Cardiff), Morris (Swansea), McBryde (Llanelli), Young (Cardiff, capt), Gough (Newport), Moore , Charvis (both Swansea), M Williams (Cardiff), S Quinnell (Llanelli). Replacements: A Lewis (Cardiff), Anthony (Swansea), C Quinnell (Cardiff), G Lewis (Swansea), Cooper (Bath), Jones (Llanelli), Bateman (Northampton).

The two prime candidates are the Wasps lock Simon Shaw and his younger, uncapped Bath counterpart Steve Borthwick. If the opposition was anyone but France, the 21-year-old Borthwick would be almost certain to get the nod; his former Bath coach Andy Robinson is a known supporter, he performed well in the midweek team on last year's tour to South Africa and Woodward has never been afraid to promote talent regardless of age. Shaw, though, is a bigger, stronger scrummager, some two stones heavier and three inches taller than his rival, who has never let England down in his 15 previous Tests spread over five years since his debut against Ireland in 1996. He came off the bench to replace Grewcock in both Tests against the Springboks last year and has still to accept there is no place in the interchangeable modern game for men of his rumbling bulk. The impending birth of Jason Leonard's second child did not prevent England's rock of ages reporting for duty as usual yesterday and Saracens' Julian White is the obvious replacement for Vickery at tight-head. For those outside the England camp suddenly left with a yawning void in their schedules, however, the rugby world is suddenly a flatter place. The tournament sponsors Lloyds TSB expressed "bitter disappointment" at the failure to complete the championship this season and it will be some time yet before fresh dates are confirmed for the autumn. "It feels as though the season has petered out rather than reaching its natural conclusion," admitted the Scotland coach Ian McGeechan, whose side were originally due to host the Irish this weekend.  It is two years since the Wales coach Graham Henry afforded himself the luxury of announcing an unchanged team, but Wales will go to Rome this week for Sunday's international at the Stadio Flaminio with the line-up which earned them an unexpected victory in Paris last month. The scrum-half Rob Howley and the wing Gareth Thomas will be winning their 50th caps. Wales: R Williams , Thomas (both Cardiff), Taylor , Gibbs (both Swansea), James (Llanelli); N Jenkins , Howley (both Cardiff), Morris (Swansea), McBryde (Llanelli), Young (Cardiff, capt), Gough (Newport), Moore , Charvis (both Swansea), M Williams (Cardiff), S Quinnell (Llanelli). Replacements: A Lewis (Cardiff), Anthony (Swansea), C Quinnell (Cardiff), G Lewis (Swansea), Cooper (Bath), Jones (Llanelli), Bateman (Northampton).

webTitle: Motor Racing: Future perfect for Williams as Montoya makes his mark

fields.headline: Future perfect for Williams as Montoya makes his mark
fields.trailText: While torrential rain lashed the Interlagos district of Sao Paulo after the Brazilian grand prix, Sir Frank Williams and his technical director Patrick Head huddled in the pit-lane garage, grinning at each other like schoolboys.
fields.body:
While torrential rain lashed the Interlagos district of Sao Paulo after the Brazilian grand prix, Sir Frank Williams and his technical director Patrick Head huddled in the pit-lane garage, grinning at each other like schoolboys.

They knew that Juan Pablo Montoya's performance in Sunday's third round of the world championship had made an important point, suggesting that the head of the formula one field could soon be changing.

There is nothing surprising about the fact that Montoya is quick. His performances on the European F3000 and US Champcar scene had left that beyond question.

What was so startling about his Brazilian performance was the way he despatched Michael Schumacher to the grass, not merely overtaking him but making it clear that the triple world champion's reputation counted for nothing.

His impressive spell in the lead before an unfortunate early exit was confirmation that Williams had been right to take Montoya on after his two-year exile driving Champcars in North America.

"There were people who thought we were taking quite a risk bringing Juan over," said one Williams insider. "But we knew just how good he was from his testing programme with us three years ago. His performance came as no surprise."

The Colombian driver's dramatic emergence as a front-runner may come to be seen as a seminal moment in contem porary formula one history. Just as Ayrton Senna signalled his genius with a brilliant run to second place in the 1984 Monaco grand prix at the wheel of an uncompetitive Toleman and Alain Prost had McLaren scrabbling to find a draft contract after barely half a dozen laps of formula one testing in 1979, so Sunday's race will be talked about in years to come as the moment a new star announced himself.

In many ways Montoya is like Senna. He has a cheerful insouciance which masks his iron will and determination. He appears to be relaxed and easy going but that is just a cover for his burning competitive spirit.

The combination of Montoya and the very competitive Williams-BMW - its other driver Ralf Schumacher qualified on the front row in Brazil - suddenly means that there is a third force in formula one.

No longer can the 2001 world championship battle be regarded as a private affair between Ferrari and McLaren-Mercedes. With 14 races left, Williams could yet challenge for their first title since 1997.

The BMW competitions director Gerhard Berger was also extremely impressed with Montoya's performance, which was accentuated by the fact that he had sufficient fuel aboard for a single pit stop. Schumacher, running with a lighter Ferrari on a two-stop strategy, could still do nothing about him.

"Young drivers like to leave their calling card," said Berger. "And Montoya certainly did that at Interlagos" - in Michael Schumacher's pocket.

fields.headline: Monty leads the nearly men
fields.standfirst: April can be the cruellest month for the Masters contenders
fields.trailText: For a handful of golfers, those who are very, very good but not yet considered great, April is an extra-special month. It is the time of the US Masters, the first major of the year, and a time when they hope to discard the tag that they love and hate, that of being the "best golfer never to have won a major championship".
fields.body:
For a handful of golfers, those who are very, very good but not yet considered great, April is an extra-special month. It is the time of the US Masters, the first major of the year, and a time when they hope to discard the tag that they love and hate, that of being the "best golfer never to have won a major championship".

Over the years the description - flattering in its assessment of a player's ability, disparaging of his capacity to confirm it - has been attached to many an accomplished player. Some, like Tom Kite, Davis Love and Vijay Singh, have managed to discard it, although in Kite's case only after a lifetime of trying.

He had spent much of that time spouting the clichés that golfers in his position invariably pour forth: "If I never win a major it won't affect my life one bit" . . . "I am more than happy with my career as it is and a major will make no difference" . . . "My family is far more important to me than any trophy . . ." and so on.

Then, when he finally did win the US Open, at Pebble Beach in 1992, he came into the interview area, heaved a huge sigh of relief and, with eyes full of tears, confessed that it meant the world to him. He never won another.

For much of the time there has really been only one "best never", readily recognisable by his achievements, which led everyone to think that his winning of a major was only a matter of time. But such has been the surge in the game in recent years that there are now four men without a major in the world's top 10, 13 in the top 20 and 38 in the top 50.

The ultimate "best never" tag could probably be attached to five or more players, any one of whom would be worthy of it, all of whom would be delighted to be rid of it.

The current No2 is Phil Mickelson who, remarkably, has achieved that exalted status without winning a major. The American left-hander is an extraordinary golfer, technically with a flaw or two in his swing but with the kind of flair around the greens that can only be gifted, not learned.

At the BellSouth event in Atlanta last week he hit a shot that amazed even knowledgeable commentators like Johnny Miller - twice a major winner himself - when, needing to chip a ball some 10 yards, he took a full swing with a wedge and slid the blade under the ball so deftly that it rose almost vertically.

It flew about 30 feet into the air and feathered down right by the pin. Miller, who had been speculating that the best Mickelson could do would be to get within 20 feet, confessed he did not know how he had produced that shot.

Mickelson smiled his "gosh, crikey, look at that" smile and went on to finish third. He is too talented not to win a major but is he hard enough to win one?

For years - seven to be precise - Colin Montgomerie dominated the European game and anyone who saw him doing just that was certain that he would become a major champion. But so far the best the Scot has done is to get into two play-offs, one for the US Open and another for the US PGA, and lost both.

There is no doubt that he is good enough to win at the highest level - he is a much, much better ball striker than many who have multiple majors to their names - but there is more to it than that. The Scot, as PG Wodehouse would have it, "hears the roars of butterflies in adjoining meadows" and, intelligent man though he is, has singularly failed to address and deal with this deficiency.

David Duval is a man who has returned a 59 in the full glare of a US Tour event and he did it in the final round of a tournament to win it. There was a time, two years ago, when he seemed to be the only man with a chance of challenging Tiger Woods, and he got to No2 in the world.

Now, through injury and loss of form, he is down to eighth and has withdrawn from three of his past five events. This week, though, he is full of confidence, saying he feels "fresh" because of enforced absences and, for a withdrawn and essentially non-communicative man, is talking a good game.

Thomas Bjorn has quietly but very efficiently crept into the circle of those with whom the thought of winning a major can be associated. The Dane is not always good but, when he is, he is very, very good. He plays with a deadpan face, giving him an extremely serious look, and in Dubai this year played all four rounds with Woods.

The American started out with rounds of 64, 64 but Bjorn remained unfazed and in the final round birdied the 17th to stand on the 18th tee level. He hit the perfect drive, Woods found position Z and Bjorn won by two shots. He has placed second and third in majors and a first may not be far away.

Jesper Parnevik is a really good player who has twice had chances to win majors. At the 1994 Open, the first at Turnberry, after not looking at the leaderboard, he played the last thinking he needed a birdie when a par would have done. In straining for the birdie he bogeyed and lost to Nick Price.

Then, in 1997, he was beaten by a fantastic putting display at Troon by Justin Leonard - the American missing eight of nine greens on the final nine but single putting almost mechanically. The Swede could, maybe should, have won both of those championships. If he ever does manage one, it is only to be hoped that he takes his cap off for the presentation.

 Tiger Woods is the 11-8 favourite with William Hill . Vijay Singh is joint second favourite with Phil Mickelson on 12-1. Others include Davis Love (14-1), Ernie Els (22-1), David Duval (28-1) and Jim Furyk (33-1). Colin Montgomerie, Sergio Garcia, Jesper Parnevik and Lee Westwood are 40-1 while the 1999 champion Jose Maria Olazabal is 50-1.

fields.headline: Hingis blames 'stalker' for shock defeat
fields.trailText: Martina Hingis yesterday blamed an alleged stalker for an astonishing first-round defeat at Wimbledon.
fields.body:
Martina Hingis yesterday blamed an alleged stalker for an astonishing first-round defeat at Wimbledon.

The 20-year-old Swiss player told a Miami court that her shock elimination in 1999, when she was top seed, was mainly due to Dubravko Rajcevic who, it is claimed, stalked her for more than a year. That Wimbledon upset at the time was put down to her temporary split with her mother and closest confidante Melanie.

But of that defeat by Jelena Djokic, the Wimbledon teenage sensation that summer, Hingis said yesterday: "I never do that. I never did in a grand slam tournament until that time. Part of it was because of him."

The 46-year-old Rajcevic, a Croatian-born naval engineer and now an Australian citizen, is charged with one count of stalking and three of trespassing at last year's Ericsson Open in Key Biscayne, Florida. He faces up to a year in jail if convicted on all counts.

Hingis told the court how she had been pursued with love letters, flowers and phone calls from Rajcevic and was forced to confront him in an attempt to end all contact.

"I told him he should go away and get out of my life," Hingis said, explaining that she spoke to Rajcevic through the gate of her Swiss home only weeks before that fateful Wimbledon. She was then 18.

"He didn't believe Mario [Widmer, her manager] that I didn't want to tell him to stop showing up, that I didn't love him, that I didn't want to do anything with him," Hingis said. "He told me we were engaged. He was looking at me, smiling at me."

Yesterday, Rajcevic often laughed and shook his head as Hingis spoke. He was warned by the judge that he would be removed from the courtroom if he was not silent after making a series of outbursts and trying to engage Hingis in conversation.

"It must be love," Rajcevic at one point blurted out as she said that he had not stopped ringing the doorbell at her Swiss home.

Later, said Hingis, "I could not walk freely." She feared "the obsession and love for me might turn into hate and aggressiveness towards me, and that is what I am scared of most".

Rajcevic claims he wanted to start a romantic relationship and did not threaten Hingis. His lawyer Frank Abrams said: "I will be defending a man's right to love a woman and to pursue the object of his affection as a legitimate and non-malicious purpose in this world."

Rajcevic has spent the last year in custody in Miami after his arrest because he cannot pay the bail of £1.4m.

fields.headline: Beau gives Llewellyn high hopes
fields.standfirst: Papillon aims for repeat win as Irish cross the water for Grand National
fields.trailText: Beau will carry top weight of 11st 10lb in Saturday's Martell Grand National at Aintree following the expected defection of Marlborough yesterday. There were 16 withdrawals at the five-day stage leaving a total of 57 horses, but only 40 will be allowed to run.
fields.body:
Beau will carry top weight of 11st 10lb in Saturday's Martell Grand National at Aintree following the expected defection of Marlborough yesterday. There were 16 withdrawals at the five-day stage leaving a total of 57 horses, but only 40 will be allowed to run.

While his mount has failed to live up to the high hopes of him this term following a highly-impressive win in the Whitbread Gold Cup at Sandown at the end of last season, Beau's jockey, Carl Llewellyn, is convinced there is better to come on Saturday.

"Owing to the fact that he came back to us fairly late you could say I've been happy with his performances," said Llewellyn.

"The ground has been wrong for him and he showed us last year that he is a spring horse. He looks to be arriving and I'm sure Nigel (Twiston-Davies) will have him spot-on on the day," he added.

Horses at the head of the weights have had a wretched record of late, but one of the fascinating aspects of this year's renewal is that it lacks classy runners and Beau's official rating is much lower than those at the top of the handicap in recent years.

He was certainly given anything but a punishing race when second to See More Business at Cheltenham in January and if the rain continues to stay away he would have to be strongly considered, even allowing for his punishing burden. Despite 15mm of rain, the going on the National course was good to soft, good in places yesterday.

The surprise news that Irish horses were being allowed to take their chance prompted Ladbrokes to introduce last year's winner Papillon as their clear 7-1 favourite. The 2000 runner-up, Mely Moss, still heads the market with Coral, Hill's and the Tote, with trainer Charles Egerton reportedly unconcerned that his charge, in a similar scenario to last year, has not had a run this season. Mely Moss meets Papillon on 3lb better terms for a one-and-a-quarter lengths beating this time.

The fences, more sloped and therefore more inviting, may have been modified again in preparation for this year's race, but accurate, sound jumping is still a vital factor in any potential National winner's armoury.

Earthmover's slipshod jumping has often proved his downfall in the big events and he was a faller at the fourth fence in the National last year.

However, his trainer, Paul Nicholls, is still full of hope and said: "A lot of horses fall in the race one year and then go back and run very well the next time. He has really bounced back to something like his old self and he will run a big race."

After 13 years spent mostly treading the boards of the northern gaffs, jockey Adie Smith reckons he has "a really good chance" of shining on Inn At The Top, just touched off by Heidi III in the Great Yorkshire Chase at Doncaster last time and well supported in recent days.

Smith said: "We really fancied him at Doncaster, but he was giving Heidi 22lb and the weight just beat him.

"They said he wouldn't stay three miles, but he got the trip that day. He used to be very keen, but is much more relaxed now."

webTitle: Irish horses get Grand National go-ahead

fields.headline: Irish horses get Grand National go-ahead
fields.trailText: The Martell Grand National received a much needed injection of life yesterday when Irish trainers decided to send runners to Aintree this week.
fields.body:
The Martell Grand National received a much needed injection of life yesterday when Irish trainers decided to send runners to Aintree this week.

It had been thought that because of the foot and mouth epidemic trainers would be advised to keep their horses away from the world's greatest steeplechase on Saturday.

However, the Irish Department of Agriculture stressed that horses that do travel will have to stay in Britain until further notice.

Michael Heffernan, of the Irish Agriculture press office, said: "There was never a legal ban on horses leaving Ireland. They could do so under permit. But Irish-trained horses going to the Grand National, or any other race at Aintree, will not be allowed to return to Ireland for the foreseeable future."

However, this is not likely to be a serious obstacle as the race comes towards the end of the national hunt season.

Before yesterday's decision by the Irish trainers, ante-post betting on the Grand National was down by more than 25% on last year's figures.

With seven Irish horses standing their ground at the five-day acceptance stage yesterday - Papillon, Feathered Leader, Inis Cara, Rathbawn Prince, Delgany Royal, Hollybank Buck and Merry People - the race has sprung into life.

Ted Walsh, who will be attempting to win the race for the second year running with Papillon, said: "It looks as though we'll be coming to Aintree now. The horse is well and my son Ruby will ride him again. I've no plans for Papillon after Saturday."

Ante-post bookmakers quickly reacted to the Irish inclusion with Ladbrokes making Papillon 7-1 favourite, pushing Mely Moss, who was runner-up last year and long-time market leader to go one better on Saturday, out to 8-1.

Heffernan added: "It is difficult to say when racing will resume. Talks are still taking place, but a decision should be known within the next couple of days."

fields.headline: Manchester gets Microsoft boost
fields.trailText: Athletics
fields.body:
Athletics

The beleaguered organisers of the 2002 Commonwealth Games in Manchester had something to celebrate yesterday when they announced the signing of a multi-million-pound sponsorship deal with Microsoft.

The computer software company is to commit £3m in cash and services to the event, which will be the biggest multi-sports festival staged in Britain.

However, even with this latest deal, the £62m needed in commercial revenue is still only halfway to being secured, leaving some to fear that council-tax payers in Manchester could be left with a multi-million-pound bill if the games fail to meet their cash targets.

But Niels de Vos, the commercial director of Manchester 2002, claimed that with the games running ahead of their target figure and the revenue from ticket sales still to be added when they go on sale in October, things were looking bright and that more sponsors would soon be unveiled.

Organisers say they are at the same stage in attracting sponsors as any other recent Commonwealth or Olympic games and that they have already raised more than the cricket and rugby union World Cups played in this country and that talk of a shortfall is premature.

"Achieving £30m worth of sponsorship is not an insignificant sum," said De Vos, "and we are in negotiation with other companies to a similar amount."

Last month the government made it clear to organisers that, after contributions of £130m towards the capital costs of building the facilities and venues for the 11-day event, there were no plans for further financial help.

Manchester City Council has underwritten the games, already backed with a large amount of national lottery money. Observers see the success of the event as essential if Britain is to have credibility in making bids for Olympics or World Cups.

As well as providing cash, Microsoft will use its expertise to help Manchester run a web-site that they are predicting will receive 140m hits a day from around the world during the competition.

 Dick Pound has confirmed that he will stand for election as president of the International Olympic Committee. The IOC vice-president, a Canadian lawyer, is the fourth person challenging for the post made vacant by the retirement of Juan Antonio Samaranch. The vote is due to be held in Moscow on July 16.

webTitle: Cricket: Ambrose curt to the final over

fields.headline: Ambrose curt to the final over
fields.standfirst: Michael Atherton pays tribute to his old West Indies foe in the 2001 edition of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack
fields.trailText: Michael Atherton pays tribute to his old West Indies foe in the 2001 edition of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack.
fields.body:
A cricketer's retirement, in both its timing and manner, can often tell you as much as you need to know about that player's career. In Curtly Ambrose's case the timing, like his approach to the crease, was near perfect.

He was still at the top of his game, as the 2000 series in England showed. Yet some of his trademark pace and fire was beginning to wane and in his final spell the aging legs seemed to be sending him a message. Rather than risk a trip too far to Australia, which with its unremitting heat, big grounds and flat wickets is no place for old bones, he decided enough was enough and left us with memories of how great he is rather than was.

The manner of his retirement, too, was typically Ambrose-like. He announced at the beginning of the summer, with no histrionics, that the series against England would be his last and, with little or no fuss from the big man himself, he was true to his word. There were precious few titbits for the media to scrap over, although he did give his old pal Michael Holding one interview to ruin that oft-quoted phrase, "Curtly talks to no one". In this modern age of image and spin, with the accent on style rather than substance, he has been a refreshing change.

He went, as he came and then conquered, with little to say. And yet, despite the low-key approach to retirement from Ambrose himself, rarely can a crowd or an opposition team have acknowledged a cricketer's leaving in such a fashion, an indication, if one were needed, of the high esteem in which he is held. It was one of the most touching moments I have seen on a field, when the Oval crowd rose to Ambrose and his great mate Courtney Walsh to applaud them off the field for an assumed last time.

They left, arm in arm, one sensed close to tears, and halfway up the pavilion steps Ambrose symbolically removed his famous white armbands, safe in the knowledge that his legs would have to do no more pounding.

The next day, as he walked to the crease with West Indies on the brink of a famous defeat, the England team lined up and applauded him all the way to the wicket. It was a fitting mark of respect and, no doubt, a private thank-you that their tormentor was finally on his way. (A few of us had remembered his wave to the Oval crowd five years before, hoping we would not see him again.) In the middle of the salute he mumbled: "Thanks, lads," which is about as much as I have heard him say. In cricket, even when you are losing, you can sometimes be a winner.

In statistical terms Ambrose's career ranks among the very best the modern game has to offer. He took 405 Test wickets at a shade under 21, with a strike rate of a wicket every 54 balls. Testimony to his parsimony is the 1,000th maiden in Test cricket that he notched up during last summer's series.

As the man he dismissed more times than anybody else I may be reasonably well qualified to comment and compare him with the other fast bowlers from the last decade of the last millennium. At his best there is no doubt he moved beyond the fine line that separates the great from the very good.

Quality bowlers essentially need two of three things: pace, movement and accuracy. Ambrose had all three. He was certainly quick, especially in the mid-1990s, and the extra bounce he generated from his beanpole frame made life even more awkward for the batsman. More than anything, though, he was a mean bowler: he hated giving runs away. Twice during last summer's series it took me half an hour to get off the mark, and then it was only a nudge off the inside edge through square-leg for one. But each time Ambrose was livid with himself for offering even this measly morsel.

His best spell against England was undoubtedly at Trinidad's Queen's Park Oval in 1994. On a wearing fourth-innings pitch we needed 194 to win. But from the very first ball, which he nipped back to trap me lbw, it looked a distant target. For the final frenetic hour on the fourth evening Ambrose steamed in, reducing the England innings to tatters (40 for eight) with as good a display of hostile and aggressive fast bowling as you will see. One look at Graham Thorpe's eyes as he walked off that evening told you everything.

Ambrose's performance prompted Lord Kitchener to pen a calypso about him and about that extraordinary hour, and for the remainder of the tour the whole of the West Indies could be seen dancing to its beat. Lest you think it was only the English he harassed, his spell at Perth in 1993, when on the first day he took seven wickets for one run in 32 balls on a trampoline of a pitch, was apparently even more devastating. One can only be glad not to have been 22 yards away at the time.

As West Indies became more fragile during the second half of the 1990s, they came to rely on their fast bowlers more and more. So often defeat seemed inevitable, and yet some- how Ambrose and Walsh responded to the call. They always had.

Their classic comeback was probably in the inaugural post-apartheid Test against South Africa at Bridgetown, where the West Indians, outplayed for four days, roused themselves through Walsh and Ambrose to an astonishing victory on the last day in front of a deserted Kensington Oval. With South Africa, eight wickets in hand, requiring another 79 runs, Ambrose took four for 16 and Walsh four for eight.

In spite, or maybe because, of the hostility of his bowling, there was never a battle of words with Ambrose. There was no need. In the truest sense he let his cricket do the talking. The most I ever heard him say was "Morning, skipper," and there were never any verbals during our frequent battles in the middle.

Over time, however, there was a little more animation, to add spice to the contest. Before the first ball of the innings he came to have a habit of walking down the wicket, yards from the batsman, and looking at that area of the pitch he deemed to be the "business area".

He would rub his hands with anticipation and invariably at the end of the day there would be a cluster of ball marks worrying the patch. This discipline and professionalism typified his bowling throughout his career. With his going, and the imminent departure of Walsh, West Indies have lost the last link with their great teams of the 1980s and early 1990s.

Thankfully, for batsmen, there will no longer be the sight of Ambrose stood in mid-pitch after another wicket, pumping his arms skywards. He has been a magnificent servant to West Indies cricket, playing his part fully in carrying forward the famous fast-bowling legacy. He leaves an enormous hole to fill.

 South Africa declared on 197 for nine in the third Test in Bridgetown yesterday, leaving West Indies an impossible task of scoring 265 to win in little more than a session on the final day. Daryll Cullinan scored 82 in an invaluable seventh-wicket partnership of 70 with his captain Shaun Pollock after the South Africans had slumped to 97 for six. Pollock then became Courtney Walsh's 508th Test victim when he was caught by the West Indies captain Carl Hooper for 40 just after lunch. South Africa are one match up in the five-match series with the next game in Antigua.

Mike Atherton writes on cricket for the Sunday Telegraph and Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Profile: Caroline Aherne
fields.trailText:
Caroline Aherne was working in an office admin role at Granada TV when her talent first got noticed, writes Jason Deans.
April 3: Aherne takes a breather
April 3: Royle Family goes multi-racial
fields.body:
Caroline Aherne was working in an office admin role at Granada TV when her talent for creating comic characters first got noticed.

She first became a household name as spoof geriatric chat-show host Mrs Merton, who managed to prick the pomposity of celebrities ranging from Michael Winner to Paul Daniel's wife Debbie McGee.

The identity of the real woman behind the housecoat remained a mystery for a while, but once the show took off, Aherne was everywhere.

The BBC was so keen to hang onto Mrs Merton that it agreed to allow Aherne to develop a BBC2 comedy in return for a third and fourth series.

This show became the Royle Family, a critical and ratings success that in turn got promoted to BBC1.

Aherne was also part of the team that created BBC2's Fast Show.

But Ms Aherne never really took to being a celebrity - she eschewed the trappings of showbusiness and hated living in London.

However, there was a time when she was rarely out of the headlines - mainly because of her generous behaviour at awards ceremonies and her tempestuous relationship with then husband Peter Hook.

And at one stage she admitted herself to a rehabilitation unit, but within a year was back on form wowing audiences and BBC bosses with the Royle Family.

At the time it was just the remedy BBC bosses were looking for - a critically acclaimed series that became a mass hit.

However, the last series has not received as much attention and Aherne feels she needs time off to recharge her batteries.

fields.headline: What the US papers say
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown reviews the American press coverage of the Bush administration's recent foreign policy decisions
fields.trailText: Derek Brown reviews the American press coverage of the Bush administration's recent foreign policy decisions.
fields.body:
These are uncomfortable times for Americans who want their country and its leadership to be admired around the world.

President Bush's withdrawal of US support for the Kyoto agreement on global warming, and his more recent squaring up to the Chinese, have added to the instinctive unease among America's friends, as well as its enemies, about the new hardline regime in the White House.

William Pfaff, a syndicated columnist based in Paris, has a thought provoking piece in the Chicago Tribune about the nature of current anti-Americanism in the world:

"The angry reaction in Europe and Japan against the Bush administration's rejection of the 1997 Kyoto agreement on reducing greenhouse gas emissions - principal subject of disagreement during German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's Washington visit - holds that the United States is ignoring the general international interest in preventing global warming.

"This stance is seen as a cynical payback to industry campaign contributors, indifferent to larger human concerns. The Bush administration promises a future, new approach to global warming, but the violently anti-American reaction of the present moment is inescapable."

On the narrow issue of the US-China confrontation, most papers back the President's firm stand. The New York Times, for example, believes that Bush did the right thing: "President Bush was right yesterday to register a strong protest of Beijing's failure to give American diplomats immediate access to the 24 crew members and to insist on the return of the plane and its crew as soon as possible. Encouragingly, the state department said it had received word that a meeting between the diplomats and the crew could come today."

The Chicago Sun-Times also applauds Bush's tough talking in the standoff with China: "On the issue of our downed plane, Bush, in his short term in office, has viewed China with eyes wide open. He has been careful when describing China to avoid using adjectives typically reserved for friends.

"In recent weeks, rhetoric has sharpened. Bush called out Beijing on China's assistance to Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein. The Chinese issued stern warnings about high-tech weapons sales to Taiwan. When 24 American crew members are being held, there is certainly an urgency to settle the matter. Still, Bush should stay with his practice of dealing with the Chinese firmly."

In a thoughtful analysis in the Washington Post, staff writer John Pomfret takes a more balanced view - and implicitly criticises Bush's hard line - as he tries to read the mindset of Chinese officials: "China's ability to compromise on such incidents is limited in part by growing Chinese nationalism, which the Communist party has promoted as a replacement for communism as market-oriented reforms have made Marxist ideology seem more and more unreal.

"In addition, the cultural and ideological gaps between Beijing and Washington remain wide despite the exploding trade relationship, creating space for misunderstandings. For instance, many Chinese - civilians and officials - questioned the motivation of the US Pacific Command in releasing information about the collision hours after it occurred. One Chinese official said many of his colleagues would have preferred that the incident remain secret until it was resolved. 'Were you trying to make us lose face?' he asked, and he was not alone."

On the more general issue of Bush's style of government, Joan Vennochi has an acid piece on the op-ed page of the Boston Globe.

She is scathing about the president's "compassionate conservatism", a campaign slogan which, she writes, he consistently refused to define: "Today, the phrase that marketed a presidential candidate mocks more than it soothes. That is because, three months into this new administration, President Bush is promulgating policies that are definitely conservative and notably lacking in compassion. Most everything else he does is just for show. National polls show approval of Bush's job performance at nearly 60%. But public disapproval is edging up from the 20s to the 30s. It is not difficult to understand why the bloom is off the bush, at least a little."

fields.headline: Procter & Gamble makes marketing Emmperative
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Procter & Gamble's new £35m online marketing company Emmperative claims to make brand launches faster and cheaper. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble's new £35m online marketing company Emmperative claims to allow companies to bring brands to market 30% faster while cutting costs by up to 50%.

P&G used to be one of the most secretive organisations in the world, but is now intent on sharing the knowledge it has accumulated on order to realise its value.

The company is launching Emmperative as a joint venture with web-based marketing company Worldwide Magnifi to tap what it believes is a £3.5bn market.

The new company's service, EMM, which stands for Enterprise Marketing Management, is based on the marketing expertise used by P&G to develop brands including Fairy Liquid, Ariel, Sunny Delight and Pringles.

The service allows companies to develop new products, plan and evaluate marketing activity online, allowign executives spread across the globe to access the same information.

Emmperative believes the system allows companies to bring brands to market 30% faster and can cut marketing implementation costs by up to 50% by automating administration tasks.

Philips Domestic Appliances is the first European company to start using the EMM system. It is used in the US by Coca-Cola and P&G.

"P&G's first priority is to build our global brands," said Bob Wehling, global marketign officer at P&G.

"We will use the EMM service ourselves to collaborate more effectively and free our brand managers to spend more time listening to consumers and creating winning brand strategies."

fields.headline: Thompson quits 365
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Digital media group 365 has announced the departure of chief executive and co-founder Dan Thompson. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Digital media group 365 has moved fast to defuse rumours of discord by announcing the departure of chief executive and co-founder Dan Thompson and immediately appointing interim replacements.

Mr Thompson, who owns 3.2% of 365, will step down from his post by the end of June.

Finance director Martin Turner will step into his shoes, but as deputy chief executive, and Nik Philpot, currently responsible for the consumer telecommunications business, will become consumer group managing director.

365 said it had already begun the search for a successor to Mr Thompson, who will continue to act as a freelance consultant and adviser to the board.

A spokesman for 365 said Mr Thompson, described as a serial entrepreneur, had decided it was time to move on to the next challenge.

"Dan has made an outstanding contribution to building the company to its present size and establishing its reputation," said Ian Martin, chairman of 365 chairman.

"Dan leaves the business in good shape, focused on a clear path towards profitability."

But 365, which floated in December 1999, has suffered because of the slump in the media and telecoms markets.

Mr Thompson, former founder of Renegade Software, set up 365 in 1997 with two friends - Simon Morris from Ginger Productions and radio and TV journalist Danny Kelly.

The company's shares debuted on the London Stock Exchange at 259.5p but now wallow around 22.5p.

Nevertheless, 365 insists it is on track to break even in the third quarter this year, and claims to have around £40m left in the bank.

fields.headline: Chinese question US intentions
fields.standfirst:
China is demanding to know what the US spy plane was doing when it collided with one of Beijing's fighters, says John Gittings

Special report: China
fields.trailText: China is demanding to know what the US spy plane was doing when it collided with one of Beijing's fighters, says John Gittings.
fields.body:
China's first reaction to the US spy plane incident on Sunday over the South China sea was a simple question put to the American ambassador in Beijing that same evening: why did one of your planes approach so close to China?

President Jiang Zemin has now said that the US should stop reconnaissance flights so near to the Chinese coast. At a more popular level, many Chinese are posing the same question: why should the US be fooling around just outside our back door?

Anywhere along the Chinese coast is likely to touch a raw nerve in Beijing, but the area where the midair collision took place is in a sensitive class of its own.

Hainan island and large stretches of the mainland southern coast were military zones for nearly 30 years of acute cold and sometimes hot war. The area is still linked today to two issues of serious strategic concern to China - Taiwan and its territorial claims in the South China sea.

It is obligatory for any Chinese map to include the extent of China's territorial claim in depicting the South China sea. The bold dotted line that must be printed extends in a huge U-shape from the offshore waters to the east of Taiwan southwards, passing close to the Philippines and Brunei before sweeping round to nudge the coast of Vietnam.

The line does not actually indicate a claim of sovereignty over the entire South China sea though some western commentators - and many ordinary Chinese - may interpret it in such a way. However, it does indicate a predominant if not exclusive interest in two important ways.

First ,China does assert sovereignty over all the "islands and shoals" within the U-shaped line with the waters adjacent to them. This is what has led to armed conflict or contention at different times with Vietnam and the Philippines.

Second, China has asserted a special historic interest in the whole maritime area, even though it is willing to cooperate over its development.

The issue first became critical in the 1970s when Chinese relations with Vietnam deteriorated while new techniques for oil extraction focused interest on the area's mineral resources.

No Chinese official has actually said that the incident took place in international airspace as the US claims. However, Beijing appears to concede this by complaining that the US plane proceeded to violate Chinese airspace after it collided with one of the Chinese fighters - when it made an emergency landing on Hainan island without permission.

China presumably regards its territorial waters off Hainan as extending for the internationally accepted 20 kilometres: the air incident took place 104 kilometres away from the island.

Yet for many Chinese, perhaps from President Jiang himself to the angry contributors to website chat rooms, the issue of sovereignty is not the main point. It is the US assumption that it is entitled to snoop around freely in China's backyard.

The US view is of course very different. First, it regards the South China sea as an area where it is vital, for economic and strategic reasons, to maintain freedom of international movement on the water and in the air.

The US uses the sea for transit by its fleets between Asia and the Indian ocean. It also sees them as critical for the flow of oil between the Middle East and Japan.

Second, the US claims a legitimate interest in monitoring Chinese military dispositions - at the moment, particularly missile deployment - along the southern mainland coast facing Taiwan.

Avoidance of military conflict in the area, says Washington, is a justifiable concern of the international community. This argument has been ratcheted up since the Bush administration took office by Pentagon and anti-China lobby claims that Beijing is increasing the number of missiles targeted at Taiwan.

True or false, the claim is being used to buttress the case for the supply of advanced anti-missile technology to the island. Such an argument only further angers China, which insists its relations with Taiwan are "an internal matter brooking no interference."

"The (US plane's) surveillance", said the official China Daily today, "over Chinese territory... constitutes a serious threat to China's national security."

Again, many ordinary Chinese are expressing outrage that such snooping has gone unchecked in the past.

This crisis may have some way to go before its immediate effects are dealt with.

The underlying problems of the South China sea's undefined status - and of the ambiguous status of Taiwan - will taken even longer to resolve.

fields.headline: Times marketing chief quits newspapers
fields.trailText:
3pm update: Patrick Sherriff, marketing director of the Times, says he is quitting the newspaper industry for good, reports <B<Julia Day.
Apr 3: Times marketing chief quits
fields.body:
Patrick Sherriff, marketing director of the Times, says he is quitting the newspaper industry for good.

Mr Sherriff, 35, who is also marketing chief of the Sunday Times, has resigned and been put on three months' gardening leave.

He said he did not have another job lined up, but wanted to move out of newspaper marketing in to another media arena.

"There have been a lot of changes at News International in the past year or so and, as I've been here for seven years, I am almost seen as the old guard," said Mr Sherriff.

"I've been at the front end of the newspaper wars and it's not going to change. Everyone is fighting for market share and managing decline."

"I want to move in to a new sector and I want more control over the product. After a yea-and-a-half as marketing director for the Times and Sunday Times I have learnt a lot about brand-building and can take my skills with me."

Mr Sherriff has held talks with potential employees, but rules out following his predecessor Toby Constantine into the dot.com arena.

Mr Sherriff decided to resign after spending 10 days crewing a Times-sponsored yacht in a round-the-world race.

"It was a very levelling experience and I just realised time is precious. I got back, walked in to Camilla's office and resigned," he said.

webTitle: 'Cut benefits to electoral roll dodgers to boost turnout'

fields.headline: 'Cut benefits to electoral roll dodgers to boost turnout'
fields.standfirst: With voter turnout expected to drop below 70% at the next election, Phil Woolas, the Labour MP, explains why he wants to link benefits to to the electoral register.
fields.trailText: With voter turnout expected to drop below 70% at the next election, Phil Woolas , the Labour MP, explains why he wants to link benefits to to the electoral register.
fields.body:
I'm not going to pretend that ensuring everybody who claims benefits is on the electoral roll means that they will vote. It doesn't. But it makes it more likely, not least because it gives the local political parties a contact point for the individual to help them get involved.

Beyond that, it almost goes back to the principle of "No taxation without representation" - at least in that if you are claiming money back from the taxpayer, you should be part of the democratic process.

My idea for a private members bill arose out of the 1997 general election. Then I noticed there were estates in my constituency where 80% of the electoral roll comprised of women - despite the estates being 50-50 male/female like anywhere else.

The reason was the men would leave the women, often single mothers, to register alone so they could claim the single person rebate on the council tax - about a 25% discount. Now sometimes this was fraud, and sometimes it wasn't, but what it means for the bigger picture is that their local council wasn't getting as much money from central government as it should.

That's because spending is allocated per capita, and the local authority will use the electoral roll to calculate the population rather than the census, because it is more up to date. However, if there are significant numbers of people missing from the roll, we're not getting the money we are entitled to - shooting ourselves in the foot, essentially.

What I am proposing is for benefits claimants to be able to show they have an electoral roll number before receiving welfare.

There may be complaints from people worried about civil liberties, but - although not many people know it - you can register privately on the electoral roll if you so wish. Battered women in refuges, for example, already do.

I'm not suggesting it will be a panacea for low turnouts, but it can only help.

 Phil Woolas is the Labour MP for Oldham East and Saddleworth

webTitle: Census goes ahead later this month

fields.headline: Census goes ahead later this month
fields.standfirst: Operation can be managed 'without risk'
fields.trailText: The government pressed ahead yesterday with plans for a national census on April 29 in spite of the decision that local elections should not be held on May 3 because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
The government pressed ahead yesterday with plans for a national census on April 29 in spite of the decision that local elections should not be held on May 3 because of the foot and mouth crisis.

Len Cook, national statistician for England and Wales, said census forms would be delivered to every household by 70,000 enumerators who would be alert to local precautions to avoid spreading the disease.

If necessary, the forms would be sent by post or handed over at the end of farm lanes, and in exceptional circumstances householders would be able to complete the questions by telephone. Similar arrangements were being put in place for Scotland and Northern Ireland.

Mr Cook said the decision to go ahead had been reviewed every week since the start of the epidemic, but there was never any reason to doubt the operation could be managed without risk.

Unlike local elections that were held on a single day, collection of census data could be spread over a longer period. "If necessary the deadline for returning forms will be extended," he said.

Mr Cook was asked why it was more dangerous for people in affected areas to vote by post than to receive and send back census forms by post. He said he was not responsible for local elections, but the census arrangements were approved by the Ministry of Agriculture and National Farmers' Union.

"Senior census officials last week visited teams in the regions worst affected by foot and mouth. They confirmed the practicality of the special arrangements for delivering census forms in rural areas where there are restrictions.

"I am certain that, with these arrangements in place, the census can be carried through without danger of contributing to the spread of the disease," he said.

Graham Jones, census director, said: "At the end of every farm lane there is a phone number, put there under Maff advisory restrictions. We'll be able to phone the farmer to check how he'd like the form to be delivered, or whether to complete via telephone if that was necessary," he added.

For the first time the census will include a voluntary question about religious beliefs. Mr Cook said the census would cost £250m. A campaign to advertise the 10-yearly event was launched yesterday.

webTitle: Parties rush to cancel costly posters for hold-up

fields.headline: Parties rush to cancel costly posters for hold-up
fields.standfirst: Town halls face £4m bill for polls hold-up
fields.trailText: Political parties are in urgent talks with advertising agencies to see if they can extricate themselves from expensive poster campaigns. By Patrick Wintour and Lucy Ward.
fields.body:
Local government is facing a £4m bill and the political parties a similar sized financial headache, following the decision to delay the local and general elections by a month.

The two big political parties yesterday started urgent talks with advertising agencies and the outdoor poster market to see if they could extricate themselves from expensive, and now badly mistimed, poster campaigns.

Local parties will also be checking the rules with the electoral commission to ensure they do not overspend on the general election.

In the Commons, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said he was considering allowing political parties to spend an extra 50% in the local elections because of the delay. He rejected calls from Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, for cash for political parties to compensate for printing local election literature urging people to vote on May 3.

The national party machines will be seeking talks with three big poster site firms - JC Decaux, Maiden Outdoors, and Mills and Allen. The parties fear they could face substantial cancellation fees if they pull out of the poster campaigns theybooked for the middle two weeks of April.

The parties also face the danger that late rescheduling will mean new poster campaigns in mid-May being sited in "back alleys", instead of mostly at premium sites on the main roads.

Jeremy Mail, chief executive of JC Decaux, said that penalties normally kick in if a client pulls out of a booked advertising campaign. Penalties across the industry are set at 90% of the planned cost if a client pulls out within a month of delivery.

Mr Mail said: "If any company fails to gets its product to market on time, then the firm may want an advertising campaign to be postponed. We cannot bear the cost of that, but if we can find someone else to take all or some of the sites, we will take that properly into account."

Mr Mail said outdoor poster advertising was buoyant at present, making it difficult for poster firms to readily find, at such short notice, premium sites for the political parties in the run up to a June 7 election.

With the US economy downturn, advertising generally in Britain is on the decline. Television advertising is thought to be down between 5% and 10%. By contrast, in the first four months of the year outdoor advertising was buoyant and is expected to have risen 10% on the previous year.

Advertising industry sources are predicting that the political parties will plan to take up only between 10% and 15% of total advertising outdoor sites - which could mean 3,500 to 4,500 poster sites. By comparison in the final two weeks of the 1997 general election there were 3,700 Conservative posters on 48 sheet hoardings, as opposed to Labour's 2,600.

The lower numbers in part reflects the caps on electoral spending introduced by the political parties, referendums and elections act. The act placed a limit of £14.8m on the parties if the election takes place in May, but this rises to £15.8m in June.

Local councils were yesterday told they would be compensated for costs they say could reach £4m as a result of postponing the local elections until June 7.

As individual authorities warned the costs of deferral could rise as high as £100,000, Mr Straw said that emergency legislation to postpone the elections would also hand the government powers to reimbursefor extra administration expenses.

Mr Straw also told MPs in a Commons statement that, in recognition of the possibility that some council candidates may incur costs as a result of the postponement - for example though re-printing election literature - the legal limit on their expenses would be raised by half.

The Local Government Association last night welcomed the arrangements, after its own initial survey of the 34 English county councils and 11 English unitary authorities affected, suggested that wasted spending would total between £2m and £4m.

Councils have paid out for printing of ballot papers and other election literature and for hiring of premises for use as polling stations.
