fields.headline: Aherne takes a breather
fields.trailText:
3pm: Caroline Aherne is taking a year off from the television business, after working non-stop for the past eight years. By Jason Deans.
Royle Family goes multi-racial
fields.body:
Caroline Aherne is taking a year off from the television business, after working non-stop for the past eight years.

Andy Harries, the Granada Television executive who has overseen all Aherne's TV projects, said she was taking some time out to "recharge her batteries".

"She may write another series of the Royle Family this year, but it won't be going into production," added Mr Harries, Granada TV controller of comedy and drama.

"Caroline has been working flat out for the past seven or eight years. In that time she's done four series of Mrs Merton, three of the Royle Family and a documentary in India.

"She's gone from being a complete unknown to a major British institution."

Related story

fields.headline: The virtual supercomputer
fields.standfirst: Scientists in Oxford want you to download a screensaver that will perform molecular research into cancer and feed results back to them over the internet. Here's our guide to the best sites on virtual supercomputing
fields.trailText:
NetNotes: Scientists in Oxford want you to download a screensaver that will perform molecular research into cancer and feed results back to them over the internet. Here's our guide to the best sites on virtual supercomputing.
More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. Scientists in Oxford hope to create a virtual supercomputer to help with molecular research into cancer - by giving away a screensaver which will perform calculations when your computer is not in use.

2. Project leader Graham Richards is chairman of Oxford University's department of chemistry and an expert in computer-aided molecular design, which makes him a bit of a big cheese. Check out his CV here.

3. He's working in conjunction with the US National Foundation for Cancer Research and software firm United Devices, so the project will reach a huge audience.

4. The idea is that, as most computers don't use most of their resources, there ought to be space on your hard drive for an extra program that might actually do some good.

5. In crude terms, finding the right drug to block a tumour is a case of finding the right molecular match for a human protein. It's a bit like playing an enormous game of 3D Tetris.

6. For all the fun with none of the altruism, get your Tetris screensaver here.

7. It's not the first time the internet has been used to make a virtual supercomputer. Seti@home, begun in 1998, aims to find extra-terrestrial life (but hasn't). And a US ISP, Juno, has just launched its own virtual supercomputer project.

8. It's not even the first time that a university has got on board: Folding@home is a Stanford University project, set up by a 17-year-old student in order to understand the problem of "protein folding". The screensaver shows real-time visualisations of the simulations being performed.

9. Other ways to get altruistic online include charitable fundraising and sponsor donations. For something political, there's always the Guardian's Steve Bell screensaver.

10. Of course, environmentalists will tell you to switch off your computer when you're not using it - otherwise you'll contribute to greenhouse gases, which could increase rates of skin cancer. Sh...

fields.headline: Royle family goes multi-racial
fields.trailText: 2.30pmThe Royle Family will be transformed into a multi-racial family when it crosses the Atlantic, writes Jason Deans .
fields.body:
Racial tensions are going to be introduced into The Royle Family when it crosses the Atlantic with a black character introduced to TV's most famous sofa.

Denise Royle's boyfriend - played by Craig Cash - will be turned into a black character.

The change to Dave's character is just one of a number of alterations being made by the Americans who have demanded "a bit more story" to add to the drama of the loafer's sitcom.

A pilot for the US version, which will be called The Kennedys, is being shot by CBS this weekend.

"It will be set near Boston, with a blue collar, working class family," said Andy Harries, controller of comedy and drama at Royle Family producer Granada Television.

"It's not the show one Royle Family script, it's been Americanised, but British viewers would be familiar with a lot of incidents from the first series.

There also will be a bit more story and the Craig Cash character is black," said Mr Harries.

The theme of the Royle Family will remain the same however - the Kennedy's will revel in doing nothing and watch thrash television just as their British cousins do.

webTitle: 'Children in care missing out on education'

fields.headline: 'Children in care missing out on education'
fields.trailText: Children in care are failing to get the education they deserve from local authorities, schools inspectorate Ofsted said today.
fields.body:
Children in care are failing to get the education they deserve from local authorities, schools inspectorate Ofsted said today.

While most were in stable situations with foster parents or extended families, hundreds of children in the 26 local education authorities (LEAs) visited by inspectors were "virtually unknown" to town hall officials responsible for keeping tabs on their progress.

And while many were making "reasonable progress" at school, a substantial number were not reaching the standards expected of their age group, and chief inspector Mike Tomlinson said LEAs had to do better.

The Ofsted report was based on inspections of 26 LEAs and interviews with more than 300 children in care, as well as visits to 120 primary and secondary schools, children's homes and secure units in England.

It follows a damning report published by inspectors in Scotland last month, which found that looked-after children north of the border were being failed by the education system.

Up to 75% of children in care leave school with no qualifications and last year the government admitted that the system failed too many of them.

In March 1999, there were nearly 60,000 children up to the age of 18 in care, of whom three-quarters were 16 or under.

While councils have clear legal duties as "corporate parent" to these children, the education they provide is still too variable, said Ofsted.

Inspectors found poor communication between education and social services and patchy record-keeping - in some authorities as many as 100 children were not being monitored. Lack of effective links between schools and social workers was a "major problem" in primaries in particular, although the national literacy and numeracy strategies had led to a marked improvement in performance, said the report.

Ofsted also found that lack of space in foster or children's homes in some areas meant children were being placed some way away from their families and friends.

That, when combined with frequent changes of school, had a negative effect on their school work, inspectors said.

Ofsted chief inspector Mike Tomlinson said: "The local authority is the corporate parent for these children and it is clear that some are being failed.

"There is a need to build on the good practice found in some local education authorities to ensure these vulnerable children receive the quality of education and care they need and deserve."

Schools minister Jacqui Smith said: "Change will not happen overnight but we have made progress in recent years and the report shows that the education of children in public care is improving.

"However, it is clearly unacceptable that only about one in four children leaves care with qualifications."

Inspectors visited the following local authorities in England for the survey: Birmingham, Bradford, Brighton, Cambridgeshire, Camden, Durham, Hackney, Hampshire, Kensington and Chelsea, Kent, Kingston Upon Thames, Knowsley, Leeds, Luton, Newcastle, Newham, Norfolk, Northamptonshire, Nottinghamshire, Slough, Southend, Suffolk, Sunderland, West Sussex, Wigan, Wiltshire.

Ofsted chief inspector Mike Tomlinson said: "The local authority is the corporate parent for these children and it is clear that some are being failed. "There is a need to build on the good practice found in some local education authorities to ensure these vulnerable children receive the quality of education and care they need and deserve." Schools minister Jacqui Smith said: "Change will not happen overnight but we have made progress in recent years and the report shows that the education of children in public care is improving. "However, it is clearly unacceptable that only about one in four children leaves care with qualifications." Inspectors visited the following local authorities in England for the survey: Birmingham, Bradford, Brighton, Cambridgeshire, Camden, Durham, Hackney, Hampshire, Kensington and Chelsea, Kent, Kingston Upon Thames, Knowsley, Leeds, Luton, Newcastle, Newham, Norfolk, Northamptonshire, Nottinghamshire, Slough, Southend, Suffolk, Sunderland, West Sussex, Wigan, Wiltshire.

webTitle: Public inquiry may herald farming shake-up

fields.headline: Public inquiry may herald farming shake-up
fields.trailText:
The government is to set up a wide-ranging public inquiry into the foot-and-mouth
disease crisis, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, said today.
fields.body:
The government is to set up a wide-ranging public inquiry into the foot-and-mouth disease crisis, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, said today.

It will investigate the reasons for the outbreak and look at a major shake-up in farming with more organic locally-produced meat and crops, he said.

Public inquiries were set up after the 1967 foot-and-mouth outbreak and in 1952. Mr Meacher, head of the government's rural task force, said: "Unquestionably, there will be one this time, to ascertain the cause and how it happened, and the way we can prevent it happening again.

"We will want to know how the disease got such a hold and the levels of animal transport across the country."

He said the future of farming, with more emphasis on organic production, small abattoirs and local production methods, would come under the spotlight. Mr Meacher, speaking at the launch of the Countryside Agency's third annual report, said that although farming in the UK accounted for only 1% of gross domestic product (GDP), farmers were responsible for caring for 70-80% of the landscape.

He added that a longer-term view was needed "about what we mean about sustainability in agriculture".

"I think we have to accelerate this shift away from what is subsidised agriculture to agri-environment, on a much larger scale and roll out many of the measures that are in the rural white paper.

"We need a fundamental re-think of what we expect farming to produce.

"It will certainly be more localised, it will be less internationalised, less dependent on chemicals and fertilisers, it will be more low impact agriculture, more organic.

"We are at the outset of what has to be a widescale public debate."

webTitle: Britain: not the most racist country in Europe

fields.headline: Britain: not the most racist country in Europe
fields.standfirst: The details of a new report into racism disprove the idea that the UK has the worst record for treating asylum seekers and refugees, writes the Guardian's home affairs correspondent, Alan Travis.
fields.trailText: The details of a new report into racism disprove the idea that the UK has the worst record for treating asylum seekers and refugees, writes the Guardian's home affairs correspondent, Alan Travis.
fields.body:
The idea that Britain is the most racist country in Europe when it comes to the treatment of asylum seekers and refugees is not only wide of the mark but also a gross misrepresentation of the report published today which has seemingly given further credence to the claim.

The Council of Europe's commission on racism and intolerance is right to highlight the persistent and acute problems in the treatment and media image of asylum seekers. This was especially true as its researchers based their findings on a visit in May 2000, immediately after the most virulent local election campaign that Britain had seen for nearly 20 years.

But it is completely wrong to claim that the report by the 43-nation human rights organisation in some way brands Britain as the "most racist country in Europe". In fact the commission published five separate reports yesterday on five different countries, including Austria, Macedonia and Albania.

The commission reserved its harshest words for Austria, where it says that existing anti-racism laws fail to protect black people, the use of racist propaganda in politics is widespread and the police attitudes are especially worrying.

Britain's record cannot possibly be compared with those of Macedonia and Albania, both of which have been the scene of violent campaigns against different minority ethnic groups, and which regularly lead to asylum seekers fleeing to the rest of Europe, including the UK.

The other country the commission looked at is Denmark, which is perhaps more comparable to Britain. But even in this country the Strasbourg researchers said that the prevailing political culture was of "deep concern", probably even more so than Britain.

This week's report did not cover France and Germany but, by nearly every measure, Britain could not be said to be more racist than either country. Indeed, its most trenchant criticisms of the treatment of asylum seekers in Britain probably apply equally to Germany, as the British system is modelled on what happens in Germany.

The reasons for deep concern about the treatment of asylum seekers in Britain include fears about their detention and the powers of immigration officers. However, on a European scale Britain is by no means the worst country.

In fact, the Strasbourg report goes on to praise Britain for the progress it has made in the past two years in fighting institutional racism and placing a positive duty on public bodies to promote racial equality in the wake of the murder of black teenager, Stephen Lawrence.

Britain is not, despite what you may have heard, the most racist country in Europe.

fields.headline: Messier fuels rumours of Yahoo! alliance
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: The chief executive of Vivendi Universal has admitted his admiration for ailing internet giant Yahoo! By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Jean-Marie Messier, chief executive of Vivendi Universal, has admitted his admiration for ailing internet giant Yahoo!, amid reports the companies are set to form an alliance.

He confirmed the Paris-based media group is planning to sign distribution deals with internet companies, as it seeks to rival the reach of internet and cable rival AOL Time Warner.

"I am looking to the internet as an additional distribution channel. I want to distribute my content through as many platforms as possible. Yahoo! can be one of them as it is a very strong brand," he added.

However, Mr Messier told the Dow Jones European media and entertainment conference he was making "no comment" on rumours of a Yahoo! deal and added he was looking to close deals with as many competitors as as possible.

"Is Napster a potential partner? If it sorts out its copyright issues, yes. Is MP3 a potential partner? Yes, and so and so on. This is a world where as a content provider we have to provide all contents in a legitimate way on all sorts of platforms," he said.

Vivendi has been openly searching for a distribution partner in the US, following its blockbuster merger with Universal group owner Seagram late last year, which gave it control of a massive film and music library.

Yahoo! is in turn desperate for partners, as dire revenue warnings and the departure of key management members has left it struggling for survival.

But Mr Messier said cash-rich Vivendi is looking to expand through partnerships and not acquisitions.

"If you think Vivendi Universal is going to buy something else you are wrong and have been misled. We are going to focus first on partnerships, commercial agreements and not acquisitions," he said.

webTitle: Hague's call for military lead gets cool response

fields.headline: Hague's call for military lead gets cool response
fields.standfirst:
 Brigadier rejects idea army should take charge
 Hague claims Maff is over-stretched
 Cattle and sheep buried in 'unsuitable' plot
fields.trailText:
 Brigadier Birtwhistle rejects idea that army should take charge
 Hague claims Maff is over-streched
 Cattle and sheep buried in 'unsuitable' plot
fields.body:
A leading army officer today criticised suggestions that the military should be given a free rein to take charge of the foot and mouth crisis.

The idea, put forward by the Tory leader, William Hague, was rejected by Brigadier Birtwhistle, one of the officers leading the army's response to foot and mouth, who said he would not like to take the lead.

Mr Hague said that the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) was now badly over-stretched and should relinquish control.

Speaking on a visit to Usk, Monmouthshire, the prime minister, Tony Blair, said there was no constraint on the army's role but added that they may be reluctant to take on some of the tasks.

He stressed that a joint effort between the military and Maff was needed to bring the disease under control.

The Conservatives have repeatedly used the low level of army involvement in dealing with the crisis as a means to attack the government.

"When we called for the army to be brought in, the slaughter backlog was just over 30,000 animals. It now stands at nearly 350,000 - over 10 times higher," Mr Hague said.

"At the current rate of slaughter, it would take 15 days to slaughter those animals that have already been authorised to be culled."

Mr Hague's call came as it emerged that the carcasses of almost 900 cattle and sheep will have to be dug out of the ground after Maff realised that they had been buried in an "unsuitable" plot.

The environment agency expressed fears the carcasses could pollute an underground spring that runs between two villages and supplies local farms.

The rotting carcasses of the 650 sheep and 242 cattle - buried more than two weeks ago after foot and mouth reached Low Houselope Farm, near Tow Law, County Durham - will be dug up and buried elsewhere.

The exhumation is expected to begin on Friday

An environment agency spokeswoman said: "We advised this site was not suitable but for whatever reason that advice was not followed."

A mass burial site for tens of thousands of animals that have already been slaughtered is due to open today.

The graveyard at Throckmorton airfield, near Pershore in Worcestershire, will be of a similar size to the one currently in use at Great Orton, Cumbria.

There are 943 confirmed cases of foot and mouth in the UK, the latest Maff figures show.

However, there are some signs the outbreak could be tailing off.

A fresh analysis by scientists at Imperial College, London, is expected to offer a revised - and lower - forecast of the number of cases anticipated by June, which was estimated at more than 4,000 earlier this month.

fields.headline: US Senate passes campaign funds bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: John McCain's drive to overhaul America's notoriously lax campaign finance laws passed a major milestone last night when the Republican senator's bill, jointly drafted with the Democrat Russell Feingold, won a comfortable 59-41 majority in the Senate. "Obviously we're very pleased," he said after the vote.
fields.body:
John McCain's drive to overhaul America's notoriously lax campaign finance laws passed a major milestone last night when the Republican senator's bill, jointly drafted with the Democrat Russell Feingold, won a comfortable 59-41 majority in the Senate. "Obviously we're very pleased," he said after the vote.

The measure was passed because Mr McCain and another 11 Republicans defied their party to join 47 Democrats in voting for it. Three Democrats voted against it, along with 38 Republicans.

"It's a very, very satisfying moment," Mr Feingold said.

"There's much more that needs to be done to bring people back into the political system, but this is a major step in the right direction."

The triumph could be short lived, however. The bill now goes to the House of Representatives, whose Republican leadership has vowed to defeat it.

The bill bans the unlimited "soft money" contributions to political parties by companies and trade unions which allowed the Republicans and Democrats to each raise more than $240m (£169m) for their election war chests last year.

It will also prevent the institutions running expensive "issue ads" within 60 days of polling day. These ads, which stop just short of naming candidates, and thus comply with existing laws, have been a favoured source of informal election pressure.

Opponents of reform say that banning them is unconstitutional and infringes on the right to free speech.

Mr McCain and Mr Feingold have not got their bill through without some compromises, however.

Last week the Senate passed by 84 votes to 16 an amendment from Senators Fred Thompson and Dianne Feinstein doubling the existing $1,000 (£700) limit on individuals' "hard money" contributions to candidates, the first increase since 1974.

And before the vote was taken last night, the Republican House whip, Tom DeLay, said: "I'll do everything I can to protect the freedom of the American people. You bet. I'll work as hard as I can to beat this."

The bill must also win the support of the White House, where President George Bush has said he will only sign into law a bill which "improves the system".

The House, where the Republicans have a nine-seat majority, could simply reject the bill, approve it word for word, or pass a less stringent version.

The last is thought the most likely outcome, in the recent opinion of several politicians.

"It's not a perfect bill, but certainly by banning soft money we're going to take hundreds of millions of dollars out of the American political campaigns, and we think that's very beneficial," Mr McCain said before the vote.

Others, such as the leading opponent of the reform, Senator Mitch McConnell, disagree.

"There won't be a penny less spent on politics in the next election cycle," he said. "I assure you."

webTitle: Ex-service personnel to sue over trauma

fields.headline: Ex-service personnel to sue over trauma
fields.trailText: Lawyers acting for hundreds of ex-service personnel allegedly suffering from post traumatic stress disorder are to sue the Ministry of Defence in one of the biggest claims against a government department, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
Lawyers acting for hundreds of ex-service personnel allegedly suffering from post traumatic stress disorder are to sue the Ministry of Defence in one of the biggest claims against a government department, it was disclosed yesterday.

Malcolm Lewis, a lawyer acting for 350 former soldiers, said they were suing the MoD for clinical negligence for failing in its duty to diagnose and treat personnel with symptoms of the stress disorder.

The soldiers were engaged in operations since the 1970s in Northern Ireland and Bosnia, or fought in the 1982 Falklands war and the 1991 Gulf war. The group action could cost the ministry £15m or more, depending on the number of ex-service personnel who register by a November 2 deadline.

"The MoD has only just caught up with PTSD as a genuine disorder caused by war-fighting," said Toby Elliott, chief executive of the Ex-Services Mental Welfare Society (Combat Stress).

The charity has a list of 5,000 former personnel who have suffered psychiatric injury while serving in the armed forces

The society expressed concern that the court case, due to start next February, could be damaging if the public viewed it as "yet another unpleasant example of the compensation culture which is beginning to preoccupy British society".

webTitle: In brief: Erin Brockovich's attorney convicted of extortion

fields.headline: Erin Brockovich's attorney convicted of extortion
fields.standfirst: Plus: X-Men director plans a follow-up; Spy Kids proves a hit; Salma Hayek sees off Jennifer Lopez's challenge
fields.trailText: Plus: X-Men director plans a follow-up; Spy Kids proves a hit; Salma Hayek sees off Jennifer Lopez's challenge
fields.body:
 The attorney of the real-life Erin Brockovich has been convicted of trying to extort $310,000 (£218,000) from Brockovich and her boss, Ed Masry. John Reiner was found guilty on two counts of attempted extortion and one of conspiracy to commit extortion. He faces up to four years in prison. Reiner attempted to extort the money by threatening to tell the media that Brockovich, a movie of whose story won Julia Roberts an Oscar last month, was a bad mother and that she and Mr Masry had an affair.

 Bryan Singer has been discussing the follow-up to his year 2000 hit, X-Men. The director signed a contract last month to bring the sci-fi mutants back to the big screen. According to Singer: "One of the key phrases in the X-Men movie is when Magneto acknowledges that a war is coming. I think that the tension between good mutants, not so good mutants and humans will only escalate." Singer also promises more from Patrick Stewart, who stars as Xavier, and more about Wolverine's "mysterious past." But if his current ideas can't be squeezed into X-Men 2, Singer isn't worried. "I'm thinking of it in terms of a universe, like the comic. It has room for expansion if it's cared for and nurtured properly."

 Spy Kids, directed by Robert Rodriguez, became the fourth highest March opening of all time in the US this weekend. Its $26.5m tally boosted what has so far been a disappointing spring in Hollywood. Fox's Someone Like You debuted in second place with $10m. Third place on the weekend went to Heartbreakers, starring Sigourney Weaver.

 Jennifer Lopez has lost her battle with fellow latina Salma Hayek to star as the Mexican artist Frida Kahlo. Lopez has officially abandoned her Kahlo project and instead is in negotiations to appear in Ridley Scott's crime thriller Taking Lives. Hayek's rival movie now gets a clear run at dramatising the life of the troubled artist. The actress claims to own a monkey exactly like the one that used to sit on Kahlo's shoulder. The Hayek-starring, Miramax-produced biopic is to be directed by Julie Taymor, and co-star Geoffrey Rush.

fields.headline: Lib Dems survive poster fallout
fields.standfirst: Political parties face huge bills if they cancel pre-election poster bookings, but do they really need to bother advertising at all?
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Political parties face huge bills if they cancel pre-election poster bookings, but do they really need to bother advertising at all, asks Claire Cozens.
April 3: Parties rush to cancel costly posters
Picture gallery: battle of the billboards
Special report: general election and the media
fields.body:
The news that Labour and the Conservatives have been trying frantically to cancel their poster campaigns to avoid losing hundreds of thousands of pounds must have put a smile on the face of Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy.

His party's cash-strapped status means it has little money to spend on pre-election advertising and no poster bookings to worry about.

Labour and the Tories booked heavyweight poster campaigns for this month in anticipation of a May 3 election, and both face charges of up to 90% of the cost of the bookings if they cancel at the last minute.

This means the electorate faces the bizarre prospect of a major publicity blitz two months ahead of the planned election, followed by a resounding silence in the run-up to polling day.

This is partly because a £14m cap on campaign spending will restrict the two parties from booking further campaigns and partly because a boom in the poster industry means there is little spare capacity left in May.

The dilemma has led some in both parties to think the unthinkable - do they really need to bother advertising at all?

The evidence against the power of political advertising is pretty overwhelming.

In 1997, the Conservative party spent almost twice as much as Labour on its pre-election campaigns, only to suffer its worst defeat for decades.

And a recent survey conducted by the Chartered Institute of Marketing concluded political advertising had virtually no effect on the way people vote.

The report found the vast majority of voters were completely uninfluenced by political adverts.

And negative political campaigns such as the Tories' infamous 1997 "demon eyes" posters can voters into the arms of the opposition.

Labour's huge lead in the opinion polls has already led some Conservatives to question the wisdom of spending millions of pounds of the already cash-strapped party's funds on advertising when the result of the election is pretty much a foregone conclusion.

For Labour, the problem is more complicated. The party's biggest problem this time around is voter apathy, something that will not be helped by a drawn-out campaign and a bored electorate.

The more the media talks about Labour having it in the bag, the more likely the voters are to stay at home.

And while political advertising is unlikely to change anyone's vote, it could be used to scare Labour supporters into turning out on polling day.

fields.headline: Russia pulls troops from Chechnya
fields.standfirst:
 Putin reviews first year in office
 Violence remains a problem
 Nato must not supplant UN
 Economic reforms needed

Special report: Chechnya
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText:
 Putin's state of the union address
 Troops out of Chechnya but violence still expected
 Nato must not supplant UN
 Economic reforms needed
fields.body:
The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, said in his state of the union address today that while Russian troops were being withdrawn from Chechnya, much work remained ahead to "liquidate the centres of terrorism".

Mr Putin's remarks, in a sober review of his first year in office, come 10 days after Chechen rebels were blamed for three car bombs in Russia that left 21 dead. The Russian president halted his speech today for a moment of silence for Russian troops and pro-Russian Chechen policemen who had been killed in the 17-month-old war in Chechnya.

Mr Putin punctuated the rest of his speech with calls for efficiency, transparency and clarity in state policy and reforms in medical care, education and pensions that could increase citizens' confidence in the government.

He said his government had achieved its goal of strengthening the federal centre's control over all levels of government.

However, he lamented that other goals remained out of reach. The standard of living in Russia remains "extremely low", he cautioned, and investment is strangled by state interference.

"Russian entrepreneurs continue to invest in the country's economy with caution", while bureaucrats "continue to put pressure on business, squeezing business initiative and activity", he told members of Russia's political elite gathered in the Kremlin's Marble Hall.

Mr Putin made a plea for structural reforms in the economy, warning that without them the nation could sink into stagnation.

He said that instead of developing its manufacturing base, the country was becoming even more dependent on exports of raw materials, and too much wealth was being accrued through the redistribution of state resources rather than production.

"This is a road to economic and social stagnation," Mr Putin said. "This can be avoided if the efforts to achieve structural transformations don't end simply with the writing of concepts and programs."

His hour-long speech was filled with proposals on further strengthening the government, but it was lacking in specifics on how economic reform could be realised.

In the foreign affairs sphere, Putin called for Russia to cultivate its ties with Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States, a loose grouping of former Soviet republics.

He reiterated that Russia's economic interests should help dictate foreign policy, and that the Nato alliance had no right to usurp the right of the UN security council to sanction force or the threat of force to resolve conflicts.

Mr Putin has been 15 months in office - first as acting president, after Boris Yeltsin's unexpected resignation in December 1999, then after winning the election last March.

During his time in power, he has concentrated on regaining the Kremlin's firm political grip on all levels of government and trimming back the extensive powers of regional leaders.

Last week, he further strengthened his hand with changes to the cabinet that landed his loyalists in the key positions of defence and interior minister. They are charged with pushing through reforms in the armed forces and police.

Mr Putin has advocated market-oriented reforms, overhauled the labyrinthine tax system and put liberal economists in top advisory posts, but real economic reform has lagged.

webTitle: Fergie is the world's best manager - official

fields.headline: Fergie is the world's best manager - official
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson is the best manager in the world, according to a statistical analysis of coaches in the leading European and South American leagues.
fields.body:
Alex Ferguson is the best manager in the world, according to a statistical analysis of coaches in the leading European and South American leagues.

Ottmar Hitzfeld, the Bayern Munich manager whose team face United in the Champions League quarter-final first leg tonight, came second in the survey, which is based on a managers performance over the last four seasons.

Under Ferguson, United have won 63% of the matches in the last four years, while Hitzfeld has had a 62% success rate with Bayern and Borussia Dortmund.

Holland coach Louis van Gaal, who was waved out of Barcelona by a 100,000 Nou Camp handkerchiefs last season, comes in at the surprisingly high position of joint third - along with Boca Juniors' coach Carlos Bianchi on 57%.

England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson is in fifth place with a 56% success rate at his former clubs Lazio and Sampdoria, just ahead of Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger, won has won 55%

Ferguson also leads the way on honours won, with 24 domestic trophies and six international honours secured with United and Aberdeen. Hitzfeld again settles for second place with 15 domestic titles and two international cups, while Eriksson is in third with 14 domestic trophies and two international titles.

And Ferguson can also lay claim to producing the most exciting team during the last four years. Over that period his Manchester United side have averaged 2.1 goals per game - a figure only van Gaal's sides can match.

In fact the only category where Ferguson doesn't come out on top is on goals conceded - according to the survey in the Daily Telegraph he's pipped to that honour by River Plate coach Ramon Diaz and Arsene Wenger.

fields.headline: Former Telegraph boss dies
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Lord Hartwell, the former chairman and editor-in-chief of the Daily and Sunday Telegraph, has died aged 89.
fields.body:
Lord Hartwell, the former chairman and editor-in-chief of the Daily and Sunday Telegraph, has died aged 89.

Lord Hartwell, who was made a life peer in 1968, was editor of Glasgow's Sunday Mail, managing editor of the Financial Times and chairman of LWT.

He became chairman and editor-in-chief of the Daily Telegraph in 1954 and held the post until 1987.

In 1961 he took on the same roles at the Sunday Telegraph, again retiring in 1987.

Lord Hartwell's son Adrian Berry said a private funeral would be held next week.

webTitle: Livingstone severs links with London boroughs

fields.headline: Livingstone severs links with London boroughs
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone has broken off his shaky relationship with the capital's boroughs in the wake of a series of high-profile disagreements between the two sides.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone has broken off his shaky relationship with the capital's boroughs in the wake of a series of high-profile disagreements between the two sides.

The mayor's threat to walk out of the borough umbrella group, the Association of London Government (ALG), first came to light last week, when the matter was discussed at Mr Livingstone's management board.

He has now written to local government leaders with the simple message: "I have concluded that the Greater London Authority (GLA) should withdraw from the ALG with immediate effect."

Mr Livingstone's letter flatly admits that one of the key factors behind the decision was his recent conflict with the boroughs over the GLA's budget.

The mayor wanted to raise the authority's council tax precept by nearly £40 a year, partly to pay for an extra 1,050 police officers, but opposition in the London assembly, combined with that of the boroughs, forced Mr Livingstone to rein the increase in to less than £30. The figure still represents a 22% precept increase.

In his letter, Mr Livingstone says: "As mayor, I am bound to be lobbied by boroughs where the GLA's policies impact on local government. It goes without saying that it can become contradictory to be a member of a body which is carrying out a lobbying exercise against your own policies. This was most clearly reflected in the recent debate over my budget."

Publicly, the GLA is attempting to appear conciliatory over the split, claiming the pull-out is really an attempt to "enhance" its work with the boroughs. The mayor's letter says: "I want to see the GLA develop the best possible working relationship with London boroughs and I will continue to ensure the authority devotes enough resources to do so."

Mr Livingstone's advisers are the real force behind the pull-out. Some are thought be angry about borough attacks on the GLA administration that have included the budget clash and a spat over the fireworks display planned for last New Year's Eve.

The mayor joined the ALG last year in a bid to ensure smooth working relationships with the capital's councils, which still provide the vast majority of frontline services to Londoners.

ALG chairman Sir Robin Wales said: "We regret that mayor Livingstone has found it necessary to take this step but we take comfort in the fact that there is some indication that the GLA will continue to liaise with the ALG and work with individual boroughs or with groups of boroughs over specific issues."

Sir Robin claimed that Mr Livingstone intended to continue the relationship established by an agreement between the two sides last year. This means that the mayor should continue to consult the ALG as a matter of course.

webTitle: Travolta reacts to Raspberry awards win

fields.headline: Travolta reacts to Raspberry awards win
fields.trailText: John Travolta has responded to his across-the-board triumph in this year's Golden Raspberry awards - the annual commemoration of Hollywood's worst movies, after the sci-fi epic Battlefield Earth won almost a clean sweep at the ironic gongfest
fields.body:
John Travolta has responded at last to his across-the-board triumph in this year's Golden Raspberry awards - the annual commemoration of Hollywood's worst movies of the year. Last month, Travolta's sci-fi epic, adapted from the work of scientology guru L Ron Hubbard, won almost a clean sweep at the ironic gongfest. As well as being named worst film of the year, Battlefield Earth earned Travolta a Razzie for worst performance by an actor.

"I didn't even know there were such awards," says Travolta, deploying the good humour so evident in Battlefield Earth. "I have people around me whose job it is to not tell me about such things. They're obviously doing their job." He continues: "Not every film can be a critical and box office success. It would have been awful only if Battlefield Earth was neither. That's not the case. It is edging toward the $100m mark which means it has found an audience even if it didn't impress critics. I'd rather my films connect with audiences than with critics because it gives you more longevity as a performer."

Lighten up, John! Let the actor Barry Pepper, who received a worst supporting actor award for his work in the same execrable film, be an example to us all. "I wish somebody had invited me to the ceremony," he laughs. "I would have gone and accepted it. That would have been so much fun." Travolta is still trying to gain the upper hand, however. When informed that Madonna had bagged Worst Actress for the film Next Best Thing, the Pulp Fiction star purred, "I liked what she did in that film so I feel I'm in good company."

fields.headline: Keeping up the electoral pressure
fields.standfirst: The old issue of top-up fees will not be swept under the electoral carpet this time round
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Alderman: The old issue of top-up fees will not be swept under the electoral carpet this time round
fields.body:
Election time is looming, so we can be sure the Labour and Conservative parties will try to keep certain delicate education issues off the political agenda until well after polling day. This happened last time, when the Tories, with Labour's blessing, launched the Dearing inquiry so as to deflect public attention from the funding of higher education in the run-up to the 1997 election, and more or less ordered Sir Ron not to report until after the results had been declared.

This time neither party will have it so easy. Sir William Taylor has recently delivered his report, New Directions for Higher Education, to Universities UK, in which he sets out a series of funding options for higher education. The hope is that vice-chancellors will rally round one of his options and present a united front to an incoming government.

At Westminster Barry Sheerman has been giving an independent steer to the House of Commons' education committee, which he chairs. He has not flinched from confronting fundamental issues, such as so-called "top-up" fees . At the end of January the committee heard from experts that British universities would be forced to charge top- up fees to enable them to pay realistic salaries. This was to avert a "swinging 60s timebomb", predicted to explode when the generation of academics trained in the 1960s retire in a few years.

But the committee has also heard that students are dropping out of higher education because they cannot pay tuition fees. Even self-styled elite institutions face laying off staff because of fee-related under-recruitment.

Meanwhile, the Quality Assurance Agency has threatened that institutions wanting to charge fees (assuming they are permitted to do so) risk much more intrusive quality inspections. Little wonder that the Russell Group of universities is split on the issue of top-up fees: some members are gung-ho, while others are suddenly backtracking on fees as fast as they can. I can easily understand why.

In the US the top universities are abolishing fees, not increasing them. From next September Princeton says it will replace student loans with scholarships, to enable all its eligible undergraduate students to obtain their education without incurring thousands of dollars of debt. There will also be more financial aid for graduate students.

This generosity will cost Princeton around $11m next year. The money will come from the interest on Princeton's endowment income, which now stands at about $8bn. In the British debate about fees, the use of endowment income has not figured very largely, though the Conservatives are de bating whether to back the idea of a one-off endowment "starter" to replace the teaching block grant. In the US, by contrast, the tax regime encourages the raising of endowments and the philanthropic activities of those who fund them. Philanthropy magazine has reported Harvard University's endowment to be around $19.2bn, more than the annual budgets of 140 nation states. According to the Wall Street Journal (January 13, 2001), just two weeks' worth of interest from this endowment would pay the tuition costs of all Harvard's undergraduates.

Few UK institutions could begin to emulate Princeton's example. The polytechnics were not permitted to retain financial surpluses, while the unspoken conditions attached to state aid to the pre-1992 universities suppressed any desire on their part to increase endowment activity. Vice-chancellors knew they risked losing state income if the Treasury suspected that institutional endowments (other than at Oxbridge, naturally) were significantly large.

The truth is that universities and colleges in the UK are hooked on the drug of government funding, which carries with it more or less complete loss of institutional autonomy.

Neither Labour nor the Conservatives will endorse a fees free- for-all before the election: to do so would be to frighten off middle England. But a radical reform of charity tax-breaks to encourage the raising of university endowments could be made politically attractive. The UK tax regime should be reformed to encourage more individual and corporate giving. Tougher education institutions can then gradually be weaned off state grants and the regulations that go with it.

Professor Geoffrey Alderman is vice-president of Touro College, New York, and formerly pro vice-chancellor at Middlesex University, London.

fields.headline: Gameplay in sale talks
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Troubled online games retailer Gameplay has called in investment bankers to help with the sale of the company. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Troubled online games retailer Gameplay has appointed an investment bank to help with the sale of the company.

In a statement to the stock exchange this morning, the ailing games business admitted it had been in talks with third parties about the "future of the boxed games division and the technology division" - effectively Gameplay's core business after its restructure in February.

Gameplay said Commerzbank Securities had been brought in to review all options and essentially finalise the discussions with third parties.

Industry sources predict that an all-out sale to a company the size of Vivendi may be a possibility.

The future of Gameplay has been the subject of much industry speculation, with rumours that the retailer would only survive a further two weeks.

The Gameplay board will report on developments to shareholders in the next few weeks, in time for the publication of the group's interim results on April 30.

The news comes less than two months after Gameplay's restructuring plan, which hived off "non-core operations and got rid of almost 300 staff.

The AIM-listed company - backed by BT, Dixons and BSkyB - lost £35.6m last year. Its share price has been floundering around the 23p mark for months.

"The board remains committed to positioning Gameplay at the forefront of digital delivery of games but is equally committed to maximisation of shareholder value particularly in the light of stock market conditions and the company's current share price," said the company in today's statement.

webTitle: Homophobia rears its head at the NUS conference

fields.headline: Hurt pride
fields.standfirst: Joe Plomin reports from the NUS conference, where homophobia reared its head
fields.trailText: Joe Plomin reports from the NUS conference, where homophobia reared its head
fields.body:
Helen Aspell, the treasurer of the National Union of Students, was punched on her way home to the hotel in the early hours of Wednesday morning. Her attacker was a badge-wearing delegate from the NUS's own conference in Blackpool, an elected representative of university students.

Worse still, the attacker's motive is clear. It wasn't alcohol. Proud not to be in the closet, Aspell made no secret of her sexuality and campaigned to be NUS president with the firm backing of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transsexual liberation movements.

In an incredible scene on the conference floor, she denounced her attacker to 1,000 delegates, knowing that he was almost certainly among them: "What you had was a woman at 1.40 this morning who was walking home, and someone came up and stopped me. This person called me a 'queer fucking bitch' and hit me.

"Delegate, you did not have the brains to take your delegate badge off, you ran away. You didn't have the guts to face what you'd done. You probably think it's OK to hit any LGBT [lesbian, gay, bisexual or transsexual] member, but you are not welcome in this national union. I'm not going to run away."

The attack was not an isolated incident. Since her speech, there have been rumours of several students suffering similar incidents after a week in which disabilities, gender, religion and sexuality were all verbally attacked in student election campaigns and meetings. Some delegates were reduced to tears. Aspell says the union cannot pass this off as an attack by a fringe malcontent: something has gone wrong in this year's conference, and a run of events led to her being targeted: "This homophobia has been stoked up throughout this conference. Those of you at presidential hustings who were shouting abuse that night, you may not have been responsible for my attack, but the homophobia you whipped up was responsible for the attack on me."

That homophobia and sexism should strike in Britain's most progressive union was a shock to the NUS. The union represents ethnic minority communities in larger numbers than most British institutions, women make up more than half the executive platform and LGBT members are keynote speakers in every debate.

Off the conference floor, Aspell thinks that at the heart of the attack on her is something even more dangerous than right-wing views in NUS.

"There are a certain number of delegates who think it's funny to subject women to a storm of sexist abuse at this conference," she says. "But this comes out of a society where politicians from all parties have been using racist language, particularly in the asylum debate, making it sound like intolerance is acceptable."

Despite having been through a week of political rancour and infighting, the threat of homophobia united the conference in a standing ovation.

"The NUS cannot just be about voting in policies," said the re-elected president, Owain James. "We have to take equality throughout the movement and into wider society. We have to realise what happens when we let people say these things in conference - it only takes one person. I want to send out a clear message to students that this is not tolerable."

In the last ten minutes of the conference, Beth Aze, NUS LGB (Lesbian and Gay Branch) officer, took the stage with every out and proud delegate to say, "All the last two days we've been called dikes and the harassment has continued. This is the most dangerous, sexist environment I have ever known. Kind words and applause are not enough. Helen is not a victim, she is a survivor."

This sort of sentiment could be bubbling away most years. According to the previous president Andrew Pakes: "There's a myth that students are overwhelmingly progressive. I don't think they necessarily are, but this does sound like the worst I have seen in a long long time."

Although the far-right threat united students, the week before that there was an intense political in-fight. And some delegates complained that speakers were too quick to begin using Aspell's experience for political capital, saying "we will not tolerate homophobia" simply to get a cheer.

In student politics, the stakes are both low and high: you can count significant press stories about the NUS on one hand, but parliamentary benches are stuffed with former executives. And student groups certainly take it seriously.

This is the last year that the NUS conference will be held in a hall that looks like a derelict airport lounge on the west side of Blackpool - rumour has it that it will become a casino. Underneath piped medleys ranging from trad jazz to movie classics, groups of Socialist Workers spent the last week bellowing: "The students, united, will never be divided." When they tried to take that on to the conference floor, the chair said, "I'm sure you won't be, dears. But can you keep it down?"

The screaming and the shouting, the stamping and the clapping are only the peak of the electioneering that takes place at the conference. "The organised end of student politics is Labour and those that call themselves independent, but who are connected to Labour," said Toby Rumford, president of Sussex University's student union. "They know how to get people to vote, how to use conference procedure, which unfortunately I don't think the further left groups do."

Ben Monks, re-elected national secretary on Tuesday and a leading light in Labour Students, agreed: "I wish there was some kind of gulag of Labour students. It would make life a lot easier. But our success really just reflects that we are a real organisation that represents our members."

And it is not entirely one-sided: a far-left student politician and dedicated race and further-education campaigner, Sandrea Morgan was elected vice-president for further-education and union development by a narrow margin on Tuesday. Her victory was a fillip for the left, who lost every other full-time election post.

A student from Southgate College in north London, Sandrea's main opponent was a Warwick University student, Nicholle Lennon, who was on the NUS national executive. Most delegates put Lennon's failure down to her running for a post looking after further education when she is a higher-education student.

The NUS's failure to represent further education colleges was central to this year's conference. Late on Wednesday night, further education students stormed the conference hall, screaming: "We've been fucked over."

Alleging that students had not been allowed to ask questions and that too little time had been given for debate in the evening's separate FE session, the protesters demanded more time be given to their concerns.

Katherine Foster, from Worthing Sixth Form College, said, "What just happened in there is why people don't send delegates. We had two minutes. We couldn't get through our motion, it was just destroyed." And in the last minutes of the conference delegates rejected a proposal to allow only FE delegates to vote for the FE post.

The machinations and old-style politics depress, or even disgust, most delegates. Organisers on balconies indicating to their flock how to vote and when to clap, filibustering and group deals are not why most students go into politics.

"We come here to represent people more than for NUS politics," said first-time delegate Matt Hood, a Cambridge University student. "But here you don't get educated debate. It's not a conference: it's a political game where people push and shove. They try to gather up enough pawns from around the country to win.

"People putting forward motions waived their right to speak to members of the national executive almost as the norm, to help them get elected. We have to think whether we should be talking about elections at the same time as setting policy," he added.

But newly-elected vice-president education Brooks Duke says the conference procedure has value -if only of an anthropological kind. "People can't experience what happens at NUS anywhere else. Other unions have abandoned confrontational politics in their conferences. It is fun."

Outside of the hall, a mournful pack of campaigners on issues from health to Cuba felt their causes were falling to student apathy this year. Husam Zomlot, president of the General Union of Palestinian Students, said: "Last year it was more active: students were much more interested in more things, more involved with other issues. Now they just come and elect people."

Jim Gledhill, from the Cuba Solidarity Campaign did not think it was as bad as all that, saying he'd signed up new members and had a lot of interest. But the conference concentrated on issues directly affecting most students much more than last year.

Yet within the confusion, and disenchantment, the NUS set its policy for next year, a policy it hopes it can take to the centre of the national election. The union is campaigning for an inquiry into education funding and for a means-tested grant. It has given greater representation to black students and begun to tackle, or at least talk about, the under-representation of further education.

webTitle: Wirral mothers going back to school years after giving up on education

fields.headline: Never too late
fields.standfirst: Years after giving up on education, Wirral mothers are going back to school.  Hester Lacey discovers why
fields.trailText: Years after giving up on education, Wirral mothers are going back to school. Hester Lacey discovers why
fields.body:
Rosie is small, slight and very pretty. She looks even younger than 25 years old; it's hard to believe that she has four sons, aged seven, six, four and 19 months. She left school when she was 11; she was, she says, truanting, or bunking, all the time. Now she's back at college studying for City and Guilds certificates in maths and English, though it's a struggle given how little free time she has. She wants her children to do better at school than she did.

Vicky, who is 20, has a daughter of three. She officially left school a week before her 16th birthday, but in fact she missed the whole of her fifth year. She was put in a class for badly-behaved children, though she'd been diagnosed as dyslexic, and the experience was too much for her, so she simply didn't go to school. Vicky believes her daughter is already shaping up to be "brainier" than she was; and wants to help her achieve.

Kelly is 21, and has three children under the age of four. She hated school and left at the age of 14. She says she was always bullied and her education suffered; it's embarrassing, she says, that she can't spell well enough to fill in forms. She wants her children to be "really good" at school.

All three of them have been helped by a special course run by Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Groups on the Wirral as part of its parenting classes programme. The Successful Learning pilot scheme aims to break down parents' barriers to learning, because these in turn undermine their own children's potential to do well at school. If parents lack basic skills themselves, they can feel humiliated and confused and unable to help their children. And if they have felt let down by their teachers, they pass that on. It is, says Jean Robb of Successful Learning, a vicious circle. "If parents have had a disruptive attitude in school, those belligerent attitudes are carried over when they have to deal with their children's teachers," she says.

It's important to explain to parents, says Jean, that if they don't play their role in a supportive way so that teachers and students can play theirs in turn, then disorder is the result. "Then everyone feels confused, disappointed, irritated and exhausted," she says. Many of the parents that Jean has been working with left school with very negative views of education. "They'd been getting into trouble, they'd been told they were thick, they felt it wasn't worth going," says Elaine Banks of the Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Groups. "We want to break that cycle, give them the confidence to keep going and help their own children."

The effectiveness of the Successful Learning course, she says, is striking. Each of the nine smaller groups within the Family Groups has had four two-hour sessions with Jean and her colleague Hilary Letts. "It has been wonderful to see how they have blossomed," says Elaine Banks. "One mother who had always struggled with spelling was standing up in front of the class spelling a 13-letter word forwards and backwards." She is referring to Kelly, who says of her achievement: "I just couldn't believe it; I went around smiling all day."

So how is it done? The emphasis of Jean and Hilary's work is on learning how to learn; on breaking tasks down into manageable smaller tasks, then building them back up. One morning last week in a church hall in New Ferry, seven mothers had begun their session by making up a couple of child's jigsaws, one showing a country farm and one showing a city park. Easy enough to do; but, guided by Jean and Hilary, they were then using the completed jigsaws to illustrate all kinds of classroom lessons. Hilary asked them to find similarities and differences between the two pictures. "This is something children have to do all through school," she explained. "They might have to compare life as a Roman with life as a Greek, for example."

The women began by making a list of things that were the same in each picture, then by making a list of things that were different. Then Jean asked them to describe the similarities more fully, using prepositions such as "beside" or "under". "Lots of children can't write down their ideas because they don't understand about prepositions," she said. "But once they can do that, they're away."

It was a lively class, with plenty of humour; within a few minutes adjectives and relationships between people had been added to the mix. "The black and white dog is pulling the boy over the grass, across the path, and into the pond," said Karen, one of the mums, triumphantly. "Do you see how it's not difficult, you don't need a huge vocabulary?" asked Jean. "Once you can describe something relative to something else, you've got a full and rich use of language. So if you're looking at a picture book or a jigsaw with your child, get them to describe it, write it down."

Next came maths. Beginning by simply counting different objects in the jigsaw pictures led on quite naturally to drawing graphs and algebra.

"Making a mistake doesn't matter," encouraged Jean. "You know when you were at school and the teacher said 'That's wrong' and you then think 'She hates me. I hate her too.'?" There were nods of recognition all round the room.

"Saying something is wrong isn't personal. The teacher can help you get it right."

The class by now was adding 2A to B as if they'd been doing it all their lives. They are enthusiastic about the methods they are using and keen to take them home. "I'm not very good at maths," said Karen, 35. She has two daughters, Siobhan, aged eight and Latoya who is just two, and who had spent the morning in the free creche that is attached to all the Ferries and Port Sunlight Families Group training courses. "School was more about fun for me and I left at 15. Now I can help my older daughter with her homework; when I was at school my parents couldn't help me. I want better for my daughters than it was for me."

It's funny, says Becky, who's 22, how much she hated school at the time; now, she says, she'd go back like a shot. She's studying for her City and Guilds numeracy and English exams. In the meantime, she's using the techniques she's learned with Jean and Hilary with her son, who's nearly five. "He just wasn't interested in anything, you'd do a jigsaw or something and it would last five minutes, but now I've learned ways to do things with him, little games to make him interested in learning numbers and colours."

Because Jean and Hilary's approach depends entirely on what's required by the parents, their classes cover a wide range of different needs; there is no set curriculum and they are able to be very flexible. Their afternoon class that day was a group of mothers who wanted pointers on helping their children with class projects and computer work. But for some, the requirements are very grass-roots indeed. One mother, says Jean, doesn't send her children to school at all because of her own experiences. "No education is provided for these children at all, because their mother doesn't know how to deal with school. That's why classes are so important."

The ultimate success of schemes like this will depend on the Ferries and Port Sunlight Family Group's success in obtaining more funding. The pilot Successful Learning classes were funded by the BBC's Children in Need appeal. The budget may be tight but its successes are striking. Vicky, who missed her entire fifth year, is so enthusiastic that she is taking extra classes with Jean and Hilary. She has just started reading White Teeth, by Zadie Smith. And she is reading out loud to her own daughter.

fields.headline: TiVo warning for advertisers
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Lowe Lintas has warned the TiVo personal video recorder service will spark a revolution in TV advertising, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Advertising giant Lowe Lintas has warned that the TiVo personal video recorder service will spark a revolution in the TV advertising industry.

Chris Thomas, chief executive-designate of the UK agency, admitted the service will make it much harder for companies to reach a mass audience, since it allows viewers to make a "virtual channel" and edit out adverts.

"It will have an effect. It completely changes that way that TV companies construct their programming, which is very interesting for advertisers," said Mr Thomas.

"We have to make sure that the revenues are not reduced."

Despite a high-profile marketing pact with BSkyB, Tivo has failed to take off in the UK, and has modest year-end target of 30,000 subscribers.

This weekend it launched a major advertising drive in national newspapers in a bid to get consumers to accept the eyebrow-raising £600 price tag for the service.

But TV broadcasters consider the long-term threat of TiVo and similar technologies to be very real, with consultancy Forrester Research predicting 25% of UK TV homes will be using personal video recorder systems by 2005.

However, Mr Thomas said the advertising industry will survive the advent of PVR, and it will not "kill TV".

"It will not be the end of advertising as we know it. Advertisers always find a different route for advertising," he said.

Mr Thomas added that advertisers will still be able to reach mass audiences for the foreseeable future, but not through TV.

"Our view is that there will still be many opportunities to reach mass audiences. But there is an increasing switch away from finding mass audiences through TV alone," he said.

fields.headline: Crime victims gain new rights
fields.trailText: Victims of crime are to be consulted on the conditions of release for the 200 to 300 violent and sexual criminals who leave jail each month.
fields.body:
Victims of crime are to be consulted on the conditions of release for the 200 to 300 violent and sexual criminals who leave jail each month.

The statutory duty, to ask victims or their families if they want a say in the release of paedophiles and other sex offenders, came into force yesterday, alongside the launch of the national probation service.

Paul Boateng, the Home Office minister, said there would be a "law enforcement" emphasis in the national probation service, which replaces the old structure based on 54 localities. There will also be a £500m expansion in resources with staff increased by 4,500 beyond the existing 16,000 total. The probation service hopes to recruit an extra 3,000 staff, including former teachers and psychologists, within the next 12 months alone.

Eithne Wallis, director of the national probation service, said yesterday she was determined to see probation shed its "soft option" tag, with targets to reduce reconviction rates by 5% for the 200,000 offenders under its supervision.

Additionally, there will be "multi-agency public protection panels" involving the police, probation and clinical psychologists, who will assess risk and decide how paedophiles and other dangerous offenders are released into the community. The panels will also include representatives from the local health and education services.

Ms Wallis said it would not mean parents having the right to know if a sex offender moves to their area, but people would be informed about any measures taken - though not necessarily offenders' addresses.

The probation service also plans to expand places on sex offender treatment programmes outside jail. So far, only about 500 known sex offenders in the community take part in the courses. The aim is to involve all 4,000 known sex offenders outside jail within two years.

All those serious offenders serving a prison sentence of more than 12 months will fall under the scheme to consult the victims over their release.

fields.headline: Man United to sell pensions
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The football club is set to exploit its brand loyalty even further by providing pensions, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Over the past five years, the club has endured a barrage of criticism for squeezing money from those on the terraces.

Now Manchester United is set to exploit its brand loyalty even further by providing pensions.

In a move that will delight investors and astound purist fans who believe the game has become over-commercialised, the club will launch its own-brand pensions as part of a plan to roll out Man United financial services across the world.

The revelations come as the club reports pre-tax profits up 42% to £17.3m for the six months to 31 January 2001.

Turnover increased to £72m from £64m for the same period last year.

Man United marketing director Peter Draper said the club was talking to financial services providers about branded pensions, insurance products, savings schemes and card services.

It already offers a savings account through Britannia Buiding Society and a credit card through MBNA.

"The financial services we have at the moment are very successful so we are exploring how to move forward," said Mr Draper. "We are looking to offer our financial services globally."

Mr Draper confirmed new services would launch later this year.

"We have a complicated and varied business and are looking to understand our customers' needs through research, including focus groups," he said.

These "customers" are United's 50m fans around the world, 7m of whom are in the UK.

The club is believed to be looking at ways of creating a comprehensive fan database, which it will use to sell services.

Man United's half-year results have been boosted by a string of lucrative sponsorship deals.

Sponsorship income increased to £11.1m for the period, up from £8.8m in 2000.

The club has a £30m, five-year deal with Vodafone and recently signed a £303m, 13-year merchandising deal with Nike, which starts on August 1 2002.

A commercial alliance with US baseball team the New York Yankees will attempt to break the club into the US football market.

The club is also planning to show repeat games on its part-owned TV station MUTV and over the internet within a year.

fields.headline: Jamie Oliver - the Naked TV Producer
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Celebrity chef Jamie Oliver has set up his own production company with Pearson Television, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Celebrity chef Jamie Oliver has taken steps to ensure his television career doesn't go stale overnight.

He has set up his own production company with Pearson Television that will guarantee a financial income above and beyond his fees for appearing on TV shows.

Oliver will use the new company, Fresh Productions, to develop non-cookery shows.

Executives say this could lead to Oliver hosting gameshows or entertainment shows.

"I think everyone recognises that Jamie is not just a good chef - he has oodles of charisma and charm and that's what makes him appealing to viewers," said a spokeswoman for Pearson.

Last year Oliver held talks with Channel 4 about a possible new show to replace Chris Evans's TFI Friday.

But he is also exploring the possibility of developing shows that involve other presenters.

And it could be the recipe for long-term success - sources at Pearson say Oliver is acutely aware that TV stars' careers can often be extended by a sensible rationing of appearances.

At the moment he not only appears in hit BBC2 cookery show Naked Chef, but he also stars in a high-profile advertising campaign for Sainsbury's as part of a £2m deal he clinched last year.

Anthea Turner, for instanc,e has seen her career flop after she saturated the screens with her presence.

Similarly Carol Vorderman has attracted criticism after she agreed to do what many saw as too many shows for ITV.

Oliver, whose catchphrase is "pukka", made his name as the infectiously enthusiastic Essex star of the BBC2 series.

He is currently filming his last series of Naked Chef and his contract with the BBC ends this year.

Oliver will own 75% of the new company, guaranteeing a major stake in any commercial spin-offs from his career.

Pearson said the company would be developing "original, cutting-edge, high quality programming" across the world.

"I am absolutely over the moon and very excited, this is a great opportunity for me to be really creative and explore TV cookery. I can't wait to get started," said Oliver.

"I'm delighted Jamie has chosen Pearson Television to be his partner and we are looking forward to working with him on a wide variety of programming," said Alan Boyd, chief executive of UK productions at Pearson.

fields.headline: Straws in the wind
fields.standfirst: Every few days, Guardian Unlimited is checking with a panel of people whose lives and livelihoods have been touched by the foot and mouth crisis. In our latest report from the front line, Derek Brown detects some small glimmers of light in his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire
fields.trailText: Every few days, Guardian Unlimited is checking with a panel of people whose lives and livelihoods have been touched by the foot and mouth crisis. In our latest report from the front line, Derek Brown detects some small glimmers of light in his home town of Chipping Norton in Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
Maybe it's the lovely springlike weather we've had for the last couple of days. Maybe it's the sight of the first trickle of trippers and tourists, in the run up to Easter. Or maybe it's just the blessed relief that the wretched disease has still not reached our immediate neighbourhood.

Whatever the reason, the straws in the wind are suddenly blowing a tad more hopefully. The Cheltenham festival has gone for good this year, and that is a heavy blow to the hotels and guest houses, but at least there is some prospect of salvaging the summer season. And with the prospect of a non-stop nine-week election campaign, folk will doubtless need their days out in the country.

The restaurateur

The Stones bar-restaurant has had its second successive decent weekend's trade, helped no doubt by the sunshine and the return of some passing trade.

"It wasn't bad at all," said temporary manager Roy Sparry. "It's difficult to judge, not having anything to compare with [Stones has been open only a few months] but all in all we have not been doing too badly."

The butcher

John Kench is not doing too badly either. His butcher's shop was quiet today but Saturday, he reckons, was his busiest day ever - barring Christmas weeks - since he came to the town several years ago.

"I know for a fact I am getting people in who normally go to the supermarkets. They want to know exactly where the stuff is coming from, and of course I can tell them. My certificates [of origin] in the window are getting lots of interest. I see people all day long stopping to read them," he said.

John also runs an outdoor catering business, providing barbeques and pig-roasts and the like. A couple of weeks ago he was looking bleakly at an almost blank order-book. Now the bookings have starting coming in again.

"People have started to re-organise parties and things, for June and July. It's as if they have decided it will all be over by then," he said.

The supermarket manager

Tony Hatch, in charge of the Co-op store, is looking forward to getting some British meat back on his shelves in time for the Easter trade. The Co-op has had to plug some gaps in its supplies with imports from Europe, New Zealand, and even some frankly rather sorry-looking Argentine steaks.

Tony says there were no raised eyebrows from his customers over the South American meat, but he would clearly prefer to be offering more local meat.

"I'm just waiting for confirmation that we will be getting our British supplies back again soon. We are still trying to offer as wide a range of products as we can, and in addition we will be back to offering our special promotion prices over Easter,on things like topside and silverside, which we hope will be British," he said. "We will also have the usual supplies of poultry. In the past we have had French turkey, but this year we are able to offer British."

The farmer

Buying British is a favourite theme of Marilyn Ivings of Mill Farm at Church Enstone. Her 35 suckler cows have so far produced 17 calves - 11 of them in the past five days. ("That bull of ours must have been a busy old fellow," she says with a chuckle.)

There is a cheering prospect that those calves will eventually command a premium price at a time when farms will be desperate to restock their herds.

But there is also, of course, the more immediate threat to contend with - and the knowledge that even if foot and mouth passes them by, Marilyn and Ted will never make a truly decent living from the land.

They have 165 acres of their own land, and work another 50-odd leased acres. Besides their cattle and crops, they have several hundred free-range chickens. Remarkably, they live on their state pensions.

Little wonder that Marilyn tends to chuckle wryly at mention of rich farmers raking in subsidies, destroying the landscape and spreading disease with dubious methods of intensive rearing and cultivation. As she tirelessly points out, calamities like BSE and foot and mouth have far more to do with legislation than with farming methods.

Marilyn is not greatly moved by the debate over the election date, though she is not enamoured of the idea of a nine-week campaign. "I don't think the farming community is that bothered about the election either way,"she said.

"The sooner it's over and done with the better."
