fields.bodyText: Maybe it's the lovely springlike weather we've had for the last couple of days. Maybe it's the sight of the first trickle of trippers and tourists, in the run up to Easter. Or maybe it's just the blessed relief that the wretched disease has still not reached our immediate neighbourhood. Whatever the reason, the straws in the wind are suddenly blowing a tad more hopefully. The Cheltenham festival has gone for good this year, and that is a heavy blow to the hotels and guest houses, but at least there is some prospect of salvaging the summer season. And with the prospect of a non-stop nine-week election campaign, folk will doubtless need their days out in the country. The restaurateur The Stones bar-restaurant has had its second successive decent weekend's trade, helped no doubt by the sunshine and the return of some passing trade. "It wasn't bad at all," said temporary manager Roy Sparry. "It's difficult to judge, not having anything to compare with [Stones has been open only a few months] but all in all we have not been doing too badly." The butcher John Kench is not doing too badly either. His butcher's shop was quiet today but Saturday, he reckons, was his busiest day ever - barring Christmas weeks - since he came to the town several years ago. "I know for a fact I am getting people in who normally go to the supermarkets. They want to know exactly where the stuff is coming from, and of course I can tell them. My certificates [of origin] in the window are getting lots of interest. I see people all day long stopping to read them," he said. John also runs an outdoor catering business, providing barbeques and pig-roasts and the like. A couple of weeks ago he was looking bleakly at an almost blank order-book. Now the bookings have starting coming in again. "People have started to re-organise parties and things, for June and July. It's as if they have decided it will all be over by then," he said. The supermarket manager Tony Hatch, in charge of the Co-op store, is looking forward to getting some British meat back on his shelves in time for the Easter trade. The Co-op has had to plug some gaps in its supplies with imports from Europe, New Zealand, and even some frankly rather sorry-looking Argentine steaks. Tony says there were no raised eyebrows from his customers over the South American meat, but he would clearly prefer to be offering more local meat. "I'm just waiting for confirmation that we will be getting our British supplies back again soon. We are still trying to offer as wide a range of products as we can, and in addition we will be back to offering our special promotion prices over Easter,on things like topside and silverside, which we hope will be British," he said. "We will also have the usual supplies of poultry. In the past we have had French turkey, but this year we are able to offer British." The farmer Buying British is a favourite theme of Marilyn Ivings of Mill Farm at Church Enstone. Her 35 suckler cows have so far produced 17 calves - 11 of them in the past five days. ("That bull of ours must have been a busy old fellow," she says with a chuckle.) There is a cheering prospect that those calves will eventually command a premium price at a time when farms will be desperate to restock their herds. But there is also, of course, the more immediate threat to contend with - and the knowledge that even if foot and mouth passes them by, Marilyn and Ted will never make a truly decent living from the land. They have 165 acres of their own land, and work another 50-odd leased acres. Besides their cattle and crops, they have several hundred free-range chickens. Remarkably, they live on their state pensions. Little wonder that Marilyn tends to chuckle wryly at mention of rich farmers raking in subsidies, destroying the landscape and spreading disease with dubious methods of intensive rearing and cultivation. As she tirelessly points out, calamities like BSE and foot and mouth have far more to do with legislation than with farming methods. Marilyn is not greatly moved by the debate over the election date, though she is not enamoured of the idea of a nine-week campaign. "I don't think the farming community is that bothered about the election either way,"she said. "The sooner it's over and done with the better." webTitle: Why I dumped the City job with the six-figure salary

fields.headline: Why I dumped the City job with the six-figure salary
fields.standfirst: Bruce Robinson is happier earning a pittance working for a charity
fields.trailText: Bruce Robinson is happier earning a pittance working for a charity
fields.body:
September 1999: I'm on a trading floor, talking down a phone, selling derivatives to an obstinate American client. I'm earning six figures a year, and I'm utterly miserable. Fast-forward a year. A different office. I'm still talking down a phone, but now I'm working for a homelessness charity. I'm earning nothing and I've never been happier. How the hell did that happen?

After eight years in the Square Mile, my life in the fast lane had run out of gas. I no longer cared about the markets or my clients, and wasn't even bothered about my bonus. I snoozed in front of my screens, waking to find dribble on my desk. I was moody and moany, vacantly sullen, a fun guy to be with.

Having hated my job for a year, my performance was pretty poor. I told myself that it was just temporary, but in my heart I knew my career was comatose. Yet how could I leave? What else could I possibly do? The markets provided few skills transferable to the real world, and nothing else paid nearly as well. It took a friend to open my eyes. On discovering the ruddy-faced health of my bank balances, she pointed out that I could afford to leave the next day: the only thing stopping me was myself.

Only then did I begin to consider life outside the City. Over the next six months I applied for a few jobs, but my lack of conviction was transparent, and rewarded accordingly. I didn't know what I wanted to do; I only knew what I didn't. More months passed with me stuck in my silken rut until another friend got drunk to the point of truthfulness and, exasperated, snapped that I should "go and work for a charity or something".

Immediately everything became obvious. I decided to take some time off and volunteer for a charity. If I guaranteed them six months, I reasoned, I would surely find an interesting, challenging job that would account for my time away from paid employment. Meanwhile I could rethink my options and look for a new career. Everyone would be a winner. All I had to do was find the charity.

This proved to be the tricky part. There are a lot of voluntary organisations out there. With ignorant simplicity I discarded entire sectors and ultimately decided on 12, ranging from overseas aid to homelessness. I updated my CV, wrote some letters and sat back for the flood of replies.

It was a long wait. After a month of silence I was getting discouraged. This was compounded by the few replies that tiptoed back. One said they were very keen and would be in touch. I never heard from them again. Another said they had no need for me, a third had envelopes to be stuffed.

Finally I began to get some interest and arranged surreptitious meetings: with bonus time approaching, I didn't want anyone to know my plans. But the suggested jobs - databases, media monitoring - were useful rather than interesting. Not unreasonably, several people wanted me to twist some City arms into stumping up serious money. Yet the last thing I wanted was to turn up with a begging bowl and a big smile, trying to tap my former friends.

After three months my plan was wobbling badly. The organisations I was talking to seemed to be in a state of chaos, or unable to think beyond the narrowest boundaries. Almost every one had failed to reply, lost my details, didn't want me or needed me only as unskilled office-fodder. Only a lucky break saved the situation. A friend of a friend suggested her old employer, a campaigning charity working with homeless people. It had been on my original list of 12. I had written to them twice but received no reply. She suggested I try again, and gave me a name.

This short cut made progress delightfully swift. Within days I had met my new contact. She seemed enthusiastic and quickly came back with a proposal. As a history graduate with eight years of trading interest rates, I understood little of her spiel on green papers, but understood that she wanted me to research smart schemes that prevented or alleviated homelessness. Anything valuable would be used in their response to this green paper thingie, and so might actually achieve something, she said. After years mentally treading water, I liked the idea of learning something new, even housing policy. I was eager to start - as soon as my bonus was banked.

In February 2000, four months after I began my search, I left the City. My colleagues confided over drunken celebrations that they had thought I'd never really do it, and how they'd considered doing the same but "didn't have the nerve". Yet as a single person, with only a small mortgage and bonuses stashed away, I was in a unique position. And only I knew how desperate I was to leave.

Unusually muted and nervous, I found my first weeks endlessly surprising. Accustomed to the buzz of a trading floor, this new environment was disturbingly quiet. I could hear the tapping of keyboards and conversations on the phone. Even these were different: people spoke in whole sentences, without the "yeah, yeah, right, right, offer this, bid that, done" tempo I knew so well. As for the people, I was expecting a collection of meek do-gooders, but I was surprised to find genuine friendliness, with my previous career attracting only curiosity mixed with sympathy.

The biggest surprise, however, was me. Arriving for a six-month stint, steeped in City cynicism, I never expected to enjoy it so much. The office was basic and the computers prehistoric, but I loved it. With the tedious zeal typical of converts, I had found a home and had a new subject to bore friends with. It helped that I enjoyed the project, that the office hummed with purpose and every day brought something new. And I liked the people, even when I forgot I was no longer on a trading floor and they had to tell me to stop shouting.

It took five months to complete my project. That done, I had no desire to leave and volunteered for another couple of months, writing bits and pieces, even stuffing envelopes. Just as I was planning to go and earn some money, I was asked to stay and temp in the press office. By September I was earning much less and working much harder than ever before, but according to everyone who knew me well, I was "a new man".

This was an eye-opener, coming from an environment where your worth was your bonus. It was novel to be working 14-hour days without complaint for what I once regarded as a pittance. It was amusing to see the faces of former colleagues, who assumed I was massaging my conscience, when I told them - truthfully - that I had never worked harder.

I don't think the City is an easy life. There are too many egos, too much bullshit, for it ever to be a breeze. Equally, it's not that tough; it just wasn't right for me. Considering myself reasonably intelligent, I'm somewhat embarrassed it took me so long to figure that out. I'm just bloody glad I got there in the end and, looking back on the best year of my life, I wouldn't have changed a thing.

fields.headline: Hang on, where are the wings?
fields.standfirst: With three classes of seating and an aisle you could drive a drinks trolley down, the enormous Chrysler Voyager is more of an aeroplane than a car
fields.trailText: With three classes of seating and an aisle you could drive a drinks trolley down, the enormous Chrysler Voyager is more of an aeroplane than a car.
fields.body:
The Chrysler Voyager is only a car in the most flexible sense of the word. More specifically, it's a minibus with some of the aspects of an aeroplane. Driving it, I found myself remembering the old joke about the novice one-man-oper ated bus driver who, questioned about the accident on his first day, says, "I have no idea what happened. I was upstairs collecting fares at the time."

Make no mistake about it, the Voyager is block-the-road vast. There is, literally, no getting round it. We're used to the sight of gigantic family vehicles these days, but the Voyager takes the biscuit, along with all the biscuit-eating members of your extended family and anything else you want to put in it.

It's bigger than its rivals - and prettier, though a line-up of people carriers would be no beauty parade. More importantly, beside the Voyager, the Renault Espace seems . . . well, short of espace . Squeezing it on to the drive of an evening felt all wrong. I felt I should have been reversing it into a depot and then climbing down and going for a cup of tea in the canteen.

Technically, it's a seven-seater, though clearly you could get an entire under-11 football team in there if a few people were prepared to sit on the floor. The kit would go in the boot and you could put the goalposts on the roof. Then you could set off at great speed because the Voyager's engine (or certainly the 3.3-litre version I drove) appears designed to lug buildings around without complaining or even, really, making much of a noise beyond a polite and utterly unconcerned hum.

Actually, pleasurable feelings of effortlessness are to be enjoyed all around the car. Naturally, a vehicle this size has meat-locker-style doors to the side and rear that ordinarily would cost you some sweat to open, and perhaps even require you to wear industrial gloves.

But here they don't, because you simply press the button on the remote control and the car does the work for you. The side doors automatically slide back, as in a 70s vision of the house of the future, and the rear door rises, accompanied by some impressively self-important warning bleeps.

Four-year-olds in particular seem to find these aspects of the car immeasurably entertaining - though nowhere near as entertaining as I did. Four-year-olds also seemed to find the car's interior squealingly hilarious. This may have had a lot to do with the inordinate provision of room for bouncing about. Between the two aeroplane-style seats in the mid-section, there is an aisle you could drive a trolley down, selling tax-free perfumes and gifts.

Indeed, uniquely, the Voyager brings to the roads the rigid class divisions of aeroplane travel. You've got the first-class seats in the front with the lordly privilege of maximum leg-room and access to the CD player. Then there are the two business class seats in the mid-section, which are a little more earnest, but still regal enough to have access to their own personal air-conditioning outlets. And then, to the rear, there's the triple bench-seat in economy, with its interesting possibilities of sleeplessness and deep vein thrombosis.

This arrangement facilitates, among other things, a whole new, class-based threat system for the in-car control of insubordinate minors: "Do that again and you're going in the cheap seats," one might say. Or, more positively, the seating may provide the opportunity for a class- based reward system: "On account of your silence over the last 35 miles, you may now upgrade to business."

The tinted windows suspend the entire rear cabin in a kind of celebrity gloaming, which is very good for doing impressions of Rod Stewart in transit. It also reminds one of the Voyager's posher aspiration, beyond the transport of children, to be, not just a people carrier, but a Very Important Person carrier - the sort of car that's sent to airports to pick up teams of American business executives, still-breaking boy bands or minor royalty.

Being a Chrysler, the car contains just enough recognisably American features to allow one to indulge the fantasy that one is driving in America - a fantasy that, admittedly, it is difficult to sustain in roadworks on the A3, but which is assisted by the gentle bonging of the alarm that lets you know you haven't fastened your seat belt, and by the eccentric gear-shift, which is mounted on the right-hand side of the steering column, and has to be tugged downwards in a motion intimately familiar to anyone who grew up watching The Waltons.

For some reason, though, the Voyager comes with a floor-mounted handbrake, and not the traditional American foot-operated parking brake that could have cleared the space between the driver and passenger seats and made it easier to scramble into the back from the front.

And clearly the back is the place to be. All in all, the Voyager is the only car I've driven where I felt a bit jealous of the people behind me, with their space to walk about in and their tinted windows. Obviously, that's where the action is.

webTitle: Comment: Labour will romp home and all this will be forgotten

fields.headline: Labour will romp home and all this will be forgotten
fields.standfirst:
When the June election comes, no one will be talking about agriculture

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair appearing in Downing St, wearing a stiff-collared shirt in statesman's white, made one thing clear about present discontents. All the rest is heavy with dissembling: by him, by his political opponents, by us in the media, by everyone in the tight little community of political activism. This is pretty insulting to everyone outside it.
fields.body:
Tony Blair appearing in Downing St, wearing a stiff-collared shirt in statesman's white, made one thing clear about present discontents. All the rest is heavy with dissembling: by him, by his political opponents, by us in the media, by everyone in the tight little community of political activism. This is pretty insulting to everyone outside it.

Here are six truths that strike this observer: six things that will happen over the next two months which deserve to be more roundly understood.

1) There will be a general election on June 7. Not a shred of doubt about it. The general election is what the decision was about, and it is not admirable that Mr Blair should fail to say so. The only political importance of the county elections is that they should not be held before the general election, because the Conservatives may do quite well in them and capture some fugitive momentum. The two must therefore be held on the same day, and the day is now specified. Besides that, the national arguments against waiting until the autumn are axiomatic.

Mr Blair made those arguments yesterday. Delaying elections indefinitely, he said, would be bad for certainty in government, bad for the image of Britain abroad, bad in every way. But a false decorum prevented him from drawing the only available conclusion, and telling the nation in an adult way that he will seek a new mandate in 10 weeks' time.

If this has a rationale, it lies in tired old political game- playing, to "wrong-foot" the opposition. Although William Hague often seems like a man with a big mouth and two right feet, even he is unlikely to fall over them here by running in the wrong direction.

2) Foot and mouth will have ceased to be a major concern for the public before the end of this month. It will still be prevalent in certain counties, but the diagnosis/ slaughter ratio will be close to one-to-one, as military efficiency comes to the aid of political reputation.

It is conceivable that there will be a horrible outbreak in some new place, which is the second unmentioned reason for not publicly committing to June 7. In fact this could never be big enough, given the controls now in place, to make an election either impossible or inadvisable.

Besides, the perception of all this will begin to change. The epidemic will acquire a truer perspective. Even if not absolutely under control, foot and mouth will have a critical path towards its end mapped out with enough good faith to satisfy voters getting sick and tired of waiting to do what they have to do.

The prime minister can orchestrate them. Voids, in this field, are a myth.

A month spent curbing foot and mouth, having done the decent thing by democracy, will produce a stronger president.

4) This episode is, and will continue to be, dominated by spinning. Even more than most in modern times, it's one where perception is political reality. Mr Blair wants to be responsible, but even more to look respectable. He wants to get foot and mouth under control, but above all to make people think he has done. He also wants to change the agenda, as in 2) above.

But the government at least can act. For the Tories there is nothing else but spin. There's not a thing they can do, except claim they would have done sooner what has been done now, and keep stretching by a few days the moment when they first presciently proposed it.

They're the greatest pretenders, because pretence is all they have. They pretend they want the election now, then they want it postponed sine die. They pretend they can't wait, but know they can't win. Knowing nothing except spin, they furiously fantasise that Mr Blair, concerned only with appearances, may be spinning better than they are.

This is the context in which to read reports that Mr Blair has just made the most agonising decision of his time as leader, involving choices fraught with danger, imperilling his party for the sake of his country. We should also remember, when sapient premonitions are solemnly read into the fall of Labour's lead from 19% to 16%, that for the Tories to have any chance of winning, they would now need to be about 10% ahead.

This may be a dull campaign, and it will be a long one. Perhaps its principal interest will be watching the effect of party war-chests much diminished by the double bind of being spent too soon and, for the first time, being limited by statute. But the horse race will be neither agonising nor fraught.

6) When the campaign begins in earnest, we may be certain of one further thing. It will have nothing to say about the event that caused it to be delayed. The issue at the heart of present discontents will be brazenly ignored. There will be no questions, probably not even from the Liberal Democrats, about the quality of British food, the rapacity of British supermarkets or the condition of British agriculture.

These are very pressing problems. It is common ground that they have their place in the explanations both for the spread of foot and mouth and for the negligence that produced the more dangerous crisis of BSE. But it is also common ground that no political party except the Greens is prepared to challenge present orthodoxies. The lobbies are too strong, and political imagination is too limited, to grapple with them. This will be the real and only, and nakedly perverse, scandal of the 2001 election.

fields.headline: Name stays the same at Harpers & Queen
fields.trailText: 11.30am: NatMags has rejected plans to drop "Queen" from the magazine's masthead, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The National Magazine Company has rejected plans mooted by the commercial director of Harpers & Queen to drop the word "Queen" from the title.

The controversial plan to modernise the magazine was put forward by publisher Tess MacLeod Smith when she joined the title from Vogue publisher Conde Nast.

However, her plan has been rejected by NatMags chiefs Terry Mansfield and Duncan Edwards.

"There was a feeling it's quite nice to keep the Queen part because it's a very distinguishing part of the brand," said Ms MacLeod Smith.

But she said she couldn't rule out an overhaul in the future.

Ms Macleod Smith confirmed she had suggested dropping "Queen" in a bid to position the magazine alongside its US counterpart Harpers Bazaar, which is a high-fashion rival to Vogue.

The overhaul would have been consistent with NatMags' strategy for the magazine, which is to move it away from its county-set reputation and towards a younger, more urban readership.

Under editor Lucy Yeomans, who joined the magazine in January, Harpers & Queen has already moved to shed its Barbour-wearing image.

Ms Yeomans' first issue featured interviews with members of the new "rockocracy", such as Jamiroquai frontman Jay Kay and Rolling Stone Ronnie Wood.

And Ms Yeomans has aimed to lower the average reader age from 40-plus to around 35.

"It isn't going to happen in the short term but, if you look at the first few issues, its heart is already much closer to Harpers Bazaar," said Ms McLeod Smith.

Harpers & Queen was formed in 1970 from the merger of the two society magazines Harpers and Queen.

Publishing executives and advertisers have felt for some time that dropping "Queen", with its associations of royalty, would help modernise the magazine.

webTitle: How to save lives with your screensaver

fields.headline: How to save lives with your screensaver
fields.trailText: Forget cyberaquariums, starry nights or pictures of Elvis. Oxford scientists are appealing for computer users to donate screensaver time in a search for potential cancer cures.
fields.body:
Forget cyberaquariums, starry nights or pictures of Elvis. Oxford scientists are appealing for computer users to donate screensaver time in a search for potential cancer cures.

Oxford University's department of chemistry hopes thousands of people who leave their computers on when not in use will install a different kind of screensaver that can do molecular research.

To neutralise a virus or block a tumour, a molecule of a drug has to lock into a human protein.

Scientists can test the drugs as 3-D shapes on a screen. The catch is that there are 250m molecules to sift.

"To test those crudely, even using supercomputers, would take more than a lifetime," said Professor Graham Richards of the centre for drug discovery at Oxford. "But if you string together a million personal computers you would have enormous computing power."

Oxford scientists have developed a computer tool called Think, and will send anyone who volunteers for the scheme an initial cyberpackage of 100 molecules and a cyberprotein known to be involved in cancer.

Office workers use only about 20% of the power in their computers. The rest could be harnessed for cancer research, with a self-organising programme which quietly sends back to Oxford those molecules that look promising.

fields.headline: News International marketing chief quits
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Patrick Sherriff, marketing director of the Times and Sunday Times, has quit News International, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Patrick Sherriff, marketing director of the Times and Sunday Times, has quit News International.

In a shock move Mr Sherriff quit the company with immediate effect to consider his next move.

Sources say he cleared his desk yesterday.

"I have greatly enjoyed my time at News International and feel privileged to have worked for the Times and the Sunday Times at such an interesting period of growth for both brands, and feel now is the right time to move on to new pastures and broaden my horizons," he said.

"I am taking a short sabbatical to allow myself a breather and consider a number of options."

Mr Sherriff will be replaced by former NSPCC marketeer Marian Rose, although the company refused to confirm she had the job permanently. It said only "she will take over the day to day running of the marketing department.

Ms Rose joined News International last October as senior marketing manager for Times Newspapers, reporting to Mr Sherriff.

At the NSPCC Ms Rose was responsible for the controversial Full Stop child abuse campaign.

She will now report directly to the Times Media Group managing director Camilla Rhodes.

"Patrick has made a valuable contribution towards the steady growth of our titles and was part of a marketing team which took the Times to its highest ever circulation in autumn 1996," said Ms Rhodes.

"During his time as marketing director Patrick was part of the teams that successfully relaunched the Saturday Times and saw the Sunday Times reach a 16-year circulation high.

"I wish Patrick all the very best for the future and success in his new endeavours."

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are still gasping at news of Geri Halliwell's £2m 'ring of steel'
fields.trailText: Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is hoping to sign Internazionale striker Hakan Sukur in a cut-price deal this summer, reports the Daily Mirror. However the Daily Express reckons Robson will only move for Sukur if he misses out on his "no 1 target" - Leeds forward Michael Bridges.
fields.body:
Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is hoping to sign Internazionale striker Hakan Sukur in a cut-price deal this summer, reports the Daily Mirror. However the Daily Express reckons Robson will only move for Sukur if he misses out on his "no 1 target" - Leeds forward Michael Bridges.

Middlesbrough will lead "a summer stampede" for Teddy Sheringham if he doesn't agree a new deal at Manchester United, reports Teamtalk. United have offered the 35-year-old a one-year extension to his current contract, which expires this summer, while Sheringham had wanted a two-year deal. Teamtalk suggests that a host of Premiership clubs - including Spurs - are watching developments at Old Trafford closely.

West Ham have revealed that Davor Suker will almost certainly be released at the end of the season. "It is unlikely that Davor will be kept on by the club and that he will be looking for a new club at the end of the season," admitted club press officer Peter Stewart. Planet Football suggests that Bulgarian champions Levski Sofia, Rapid Bucharest and Everton will battle it out for Suker's signature.

Fulham are set to sign giant striker Jan Koller, according to the Sun, who report that the Czech has been allowed to discuss personal terms with the First Division leaders before a fee has been agreed between the two clubs. But according to Planet Football a deal is less certain. A spokesman for Anderlecht told the website: "The only thing I can say is that there is interest from Fulham and that the representative of Koller was in Anderlecht yesterday. But, so far, I do not think that anything has been decided yet."

Bolton Wanderers have made an offer for Panathinaikos keeper Antonis Nikopolidis, reports onefootball.com. The 30-year-old Greece international has been informed of the offer, and the website claims the club will not stand in his way if he wants to leave.

Blackburn midfielder Marc Keller is set to join Strasbourg, reports the Star.

webTitle: Abduction claim by internet twins' parents

fields.headline: Abduction claim by internet twins' parents
fields.trailText: The saga of the twins adopted by a British couple via the internet took another twist yesterday when it emerged that the babies' natural parents had asked for them to be declared abducted under the Hague convention.
fields.body:
The saga of the twins adopted by a British couple via the internet took another twist yesterday when it emerged that the babies' natural parents had asked for them to be declared abducted under the Hague convention.

Lawyers for the parents, the Americans Tranda and Aaron Wecker, have asked the official solicitor's child protection office to deal with their request.

The news came as Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the UK couple at the centre of the transatlantic legal wrangle, returned to the high court in London to continue their fight to win custody of the nine-month-old girls.

It also emerged yesterday that Max Clifford, the PR consultant, has offered to help the parents, who have come under fire for speaking in public about the case after promising that they would not do so.

The latest hearing, which could last all week, is taking place in private but a spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's Department said that the natural parents, who are estranged and taking action separately, wanted the babies declared abducted.

The US and Britain have signed up to the Hague convention on intercountry adoption, which was designed to set guidelines for international adoptions and restrict child trafficking and fraud. If an application under the convention is successful, the children will have to be returned in the first instance to their home country.

Strict security measures were arranged yesterday to ensure no leaks from the latest hearing. Security guards searched the couple, as well as lawyers and officials entering court, to prevent recording equipment being smuggled in. An usher taped paper to the window in the door of the court to obstruct the view.

The judge hearing the case, Mr Justice Kirkwood, has been angered by the publicity about the case and has issued stern warnings against those involved revealing what has happened in court.

However, the Kilshaws, who claim they paid an American baby broker £8,200 to adopt the sisters, whom they named Belinda and Kimberley, have continued to speak out. Before a hearing last month Mr Kilshaw, 45, a solicitor, spoke on Radio 5 Live about the couple's determination to carry on fighting. They also commented as they arrived at court.

The Kilshaws, who are from Buckley, north Wales, arrived for the hearing via the back door of the high court. Mr Kilshaw told a television crew: "This is all very stressful."

The babies are in the care of Flintshire social services, and the authority wants them to be made wards of court.

Mr Clifford offered to give the couple free advice and guidance. He said: "If they follow it, it should make the best of a bad situation."

Allan Levy QC is representng the Kilshaws. Also represented at court are the babies' natural parents, the UK's official solicitor and the states of Arkansas, where the adoption took place, and Missouri, where the girls were born.

A spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's Department said that if the judge does make them wards, he would then have to decide whether to deal with the case in this country or send them to the US.

A judge in Little Rock, Arkansas, has already annulled the adoption and recommended they be returned to the US.

The saga began in January when it emerged that the Kilshaws paid for the children after contacting an internet adoption agency. Two days later an emergency protection order was served on the couple. The twins, swaddled in blankets, were taken into the care of social services and have since been looked after by foster parents.

The couple have appeared on the Oprah Winfrey show with Richard and Vickie Allen, from California, who also said they had adopted the two girls but then dropped their claim. The government here has promised to change the law so that a similar case could not happen again.

The hearing is expected to last at least until tomorrow.

webTitle: Jeanette Winterson: If only lesbians were foxes

fields.headline: If only lesbians were foxes
fields.standfirst: The case of Shirley Pearce, the lesbian teacher forced to quit after enduring years of alleged abuse from pupils, proves the law is seeking to confirm the prejudices of homophobes everywhere - that lesbians are not 'real' women, writes Jeanette Winterson
fields.trailText: The case of Shirley Pearce, the lesbian teacher forced to quit after enduring years of alleged abuse from pupils, proves the law is seeking to confirm the prejudices of homophobes everywhere - that lesbians are not 'real' women, writes Jeanette Winterson.
fields.body:
In 1998, Cherie Booth represented Lisa Grant and Jill Percy in a discrimination case against South West Trains. The pair, who were long-term partners, were not granted the same travel perks as heterosexual employees of the company. Booth argued that discriminating on the grounds of sexuality was as unlawful as gender discrimination. The Human Rights Act was not in force. The case was lost.

Last week, in her role as a human rights lawyer, with her own special set of chambers to deal with human rights issues, Booth's approach was different. She was arguing that sexual orientation is not a human rights issue, and that homosexuals who are abused because of their sexuality, have no remedy under the law.

Yells of "lezzie" and "dyke" are because you are queer, not because you are female. It seems that the law is seeking to confirm the prejudices of homophobes everywhere - that lesbians are not "real" women.

A "real" women is one sexually available to men - though I am not sure where this leaves nuns. The definition of a "real" man, is not a man sexually available to women, but one who knows where his loyalties lie - that is, with other men. Queer or not, he bonds with and maintains the power structures that privilege men above women. This is why many gay men can live without difficulty in the world. The ones who do get into trouble are the ones who expose the system in some way, either by effeminacy or cross-dressing or outspokenness, or deliberately identifying with women. Such men are a threat in the way that all lesbians are a threat: they upset the pecking order.

Shirley Pearce had taught science at Mayfield school in Portsmouth for 15 years. She had a good record and was a dedicated career teacher - just the kind the government is desperate to keep. In 1990, very privately, she started visiting gay clubs. In a small town word soon gets out and the trouble at school began.

You need not be a supporter of gay rights to understand that tolerance is essential for multi-cultural city life - the life that most people will be leading in the 21st century. Love thy neighbour becomes more urgent when we cannot avoid her.

Shirley Pearce was told by her head teacher to "grit her teeth". She was advised to take leave of absence on health grounds and, finally, she resigned. An industrial tribunal and an employment appeal tribunal both dismissed her case. Now Stonewall, the equal rights group, is supporting her in the courts.

Laura Cox, QC, defending, and Booth, for the school, have tied themselves up in knots over the case because there is no law. Cox is using Booth's old line that sex includes sexuality, with the added kick that none of this could have happened to a gay man because abuse is gender specific. Booth argues that the school had no duty to protect Pearce. Mayfield may not have acted well, but it acted legally.

Whatever happened to natural justice? No one should be discriminated against because they are different. If we don't have a law against it, let's draft one now and stop wasting time and money and ruining lives, while lawyers swank about practising their rhetoric.

In Britain we prefer case law to legislation. "Meaning is use" as Wittgenstein put it. The question is whether legal interpretations are keeping up with what is happening in society. One of the things happening is that gay people no longer want to live in the closet or have cat food thrown at them when they come out.

The law is going to have to recognise gay rights, including partnership, taxation and employment issues. Many thought Labour would encourage this change, but what is the meaning or the use of a Human Rights Act, when one of its architects, also the wife of the prime minister, argues that it does not apply to lesbians?

fields.headline: Blair delays elections
fields.standfirst:
Fixed-term parliaments are the answer
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: So now we know. Sort of. After weeks of waiting and wondering, the prime minister finally gave the word yesterday.
fields.body:
So now we know. Sort of. After weeks of waiting and wondering, the prime minister finally gave the word yesterday. There will be no local elections on May 3, he said, thereby confirming the worst kept secret in the land. He did not mention the general election explicitly, but we all knew what he meant. As the Sun informed the nation on Saturday morning, polling day is to be postponed from May 3 - almost certainly to June 7.

There is much to fault in this decision, starting with the manner of its announcement. It is an unfortunate emblem of this administration that Rupert Murdoch's staff learned of Downing Street's change of heart before the cabinet. The substance of the decision is also open to criticism. As we and most of the cabinet argued - in vain, it turns out - delay will send out a message to the wider world that Britain is indeed crippled by a national crisis wreaking a havoc unseen since the war. After all, this is the first suspension of normal democratic rules since 1945. We cannot blame the US television networks if they now tell Americans - including would-have-been tourists - that Britain is off-limits. Tourism is an industry of even bigger value to this country than farming, and we regret that that was not decisive in the prime minister's final calculations.

Whether it will prove the right political decision we will not know until June 8. It is possible that foot and mouth may still be as virulent then as it is now; the delay might make no difference. Or another "event" could come along to buffet Labour; many in the party will spend the next two months remembering the "winter of discontent" that came between Jim Callaghan's decision to delay and the eventual, fateful polling day in May 1979.

Still, that is Mr Blair's decision and the task now is to look ahead. What will happen to this extra month, inserted into the political calendar? The fear among Millbank operatives is that they now have a month to cool their heels, grow restless and make mistakes. That may not matter. As our poll today shows, voters can simultaneously believe the government is mishandling the country's problems and still favour them massively over the Conservative alternative.

So how should Labour use this bonus month? They might eschew four weeks of phoney war pre-campaigning, and instead revive some of the legislation they said they wanted to pass but which got squeezed out through lack of parliamentary time. Labour promised tough regulation of British arms sales abroad: a draft bill is there, so why not make it a real one? Labour could press again for a ban on hunting with dogs, or maybe move to place a legal limit on the number of inmates that can be housed in a single jail. There is so much to do.

But perhaps the smartest move would be to give government time to Tony Wright's private member's bill calling for fixed-term parliaments. He suggests an automatic dissolution every four years, unless elections are triggered by a Commons vote of no confidence. This is a longstanding demand: the Chartists called for annual elections. The length of term, five or four years, can be debated but the principle is surely right. It cannot make sense to have this lengthy period of uncertainty and indecision grip the last 18 months of every government. Nor is it fair to hold a running race in which one of the competitors fires the starting gun. Dr Wright is right and the government now has the time his bill needs. Surely Mr Blair won't stand in his way: the last month must have taught him that the solo power to call an election can be as much a burden as a blessing.

fields.headline: The rights stuff
fields.standfirst: It was predicted that the Human Rights Act would benefit prisoners and asylum seekers. But six months on,  Clare Dyer  finds it is being used in some surprising cases involving privacy-seeking celebrities - and a relieved family in the New Forest
fields.trailText: It was predicted that the Human Rights Act would benefit prisoners and asylum seekers. But six months on, Clare Dyer finds it is being used in some surprising cases involving privacy-seeking celebrities - and a relieved family in the New Forest.
fields.body:
Who would have predicted, when the long-awaited Human Rights Act came into force six months ago, that it would rescue a £750,000 house condemned as "the most flagrant breach of planning permission" from the bulldozers?

Councils around the country were stunned last month when Ken and Jacky Duffy won their appeal against New Forest district council's order to demolish their newly built house, erected at twice the size allowed by the council in one of England's prime beauty spots.

The inspector who dealt with the appeal, Howard Russon, agreed that the huge structure "seriously harmed the character and appearance of this vulnerable rural area". He had no doubt that allowing it to stay "undermined the objectives of local planning policies aimed at protecting the very special landscape of this part of the New Forest".

But the couple and their three young children would be homeless and possibly bankrupt if the house had to be bulldozed. Russon concluded that this would violate the family's rights under article 8 of the European convention on human rights, the right to private and family life, and allowed their appeal.

When the Human Rights Act came into force on October 2, making the European convention part of English law, it was foreseeable that prisoners, asylum seekers and people charged with criminal offences would leap on the bandwagon. Scaremongering predictions of chaos in the courts have not been borne out, but judges have seen a steady flow of human rights cases. Of 87 decided between October and mid-February, 15 succeeded, according to figures from the human rights research unit at King's College law school, University of London. As predicted, the biggest category are claims over the right to a fair trial, guaranteed by article 6 of the convention.

What was not foreseen was that this same article - which also includes the right to a fair hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal in civil matters - would threaten to throw the whole planning system into disarray.

In December the high court delivered the first "declaration of incompatibility" under the Human Rights Act, exercising a new power for judges to declare that a law passed by the UK Parliament contravenes the European convention. Powers which allow the environment secretary, rather than planning inspectors, to take the final decision himself violated the right to an impartial tribunal, said the judges, because the same person "cannot be both policy maker and decision taker". The government has now appealed against the ruling to the House of Lords, where rumour has it that the law lords may overturn it.

Ministers predicted in the run-up to the act that declarations of incompatibility would be rare. But the judges have proved them wrong. The second, made last month by the court of appeal in a case brought by a paranoid schizophrenic killer in Broadmoor, will lead to the release of dozens of patients, say mental health lawyers. The court held that procedures laid down by the Mental Health Act, under which patients detained against their will may apply for release, breach their right to liberty, guaranteed by article 5, because they reverse the burden of proof and put the onus on the patient.

In two other cases the courts are actively considering making a declaration of incompatibility - the House of Lords in a challenge to "rape shield" laws banning questioning of rape complainants about their past sex life, and the court of appeal in a claim over a section of the Consumer Credit Act which the judges thought a breach of the human rights of lenders.

Meanwhile, celebrities are queueing up to use the act to carve out the right of privacy they previously lacked under English law, and the judges seem only too keen to help them. In the case brought by Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones over sneak photos of their wedding published in Hello! magazine, Lord Justice Sedley declared: "We have reached a point at which it can be said with confidence that the law recognises and will appropriately protect a right of personal privacy."

The media feared that a burgeoning privacy law could threaten freedom of expression - guaranteed by article 10 of the convention - and lobbied successfully for a clause to be added to the Human Rights Act imposing extra hurdles where an injunction is sought to stop publication in advance. This was hailed as a victory for the press, making freedom of expression the trump card that would outweigh other rights. But judges' pronouncements in the Hello! case and others suggest that they may not see it quite that way.

Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of the toddler James Bulger, invoked the act and won an unprecedented lifetime court order banning the media from publishing any details of their new identities and whereabouts once they leave custody later this year. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, thought their privacy claim might not have been enough to justify such a drastic curb on free speech. The clinching argument for her was that revenge attacks threatened their right to life (article 2) and to freedom from inhuman and degrading treatment (article 3).

Mary Cuneen, associate director of the civil rights group Liberty, which runs an advice helpline for lawyers on the act, says fair trial issues have been the largest area for queries. But article 8 - respect for private and family life - comes next, covering a wide range of issues including the rights of transsexuals, gay relationships, access to children, CCTV surveillance and employers' rights to employees' personal data.

Deaths in custody and the failure of prisons to prevent suicides look like fruitful areas for the future. In June, Liberty is taking a case against the Home Office to the high court over the death of a prisoner, Paul Wright, from an asthma attack, claiming that his right to life was violated and that he was subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment.

Last week Lord Bingham, the senior law lord, predicted that the Lord Chancellor and the law lords would face a court challenge over their dual role as both judges and members of the legislature. The issue of whether someone who is both judge and legislator can be considered independent and impartial "is a question which I believe will become litigious at some point," he told the joint lords and commons human rights committee.

Summing up the Human Rights Act after its first six months, Lord Bingham thought it was "unquestionably a major advance" for the UK's justice system. The fact that litigants had to go to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg until last October to assert human rights claims had caused "an insidious corruption of popular confidence in our justice system". He added: "It seems to me highly destructive of popular confidence in our own system of justice for people to think they had to go elsewhere to have their rights protected. If rights are to be protected they should be protected here."

Getting in on the act

Subject: Drink-driving, speed cameras and self-incrimination

Claim: Margaret Brown, found drunk by police at an all-night superstore, confessed she was the driver of the car in the carpark. She argued that section 172 of the Road Traffic Act 1988, which makes it an offence not to name the driver, breached the right to protection against self-incrimination

Outcome: Scotland's high court threw out the prosecution, ruling that section 172 (which also applied to cars caught on speed cameras) breached the right to a fair trial. The privy council later overturned the ruling and held that section 172 did not breach the human rights convention

Subject: Privacy rights for child killers Thompson and Venables under their new identities

Claim: They argued they risked reprisals if their new identities became known, threatening their right to life and right to be spared inhuman and degrading treatment. They also argued for a lifetime ban on publication to protect right to private and family life, and to prevent breach of confidence. Newspapers argued the unprecedented ban would infringe free speech

Outcome: Lifetime ban granted

Subject: Environment secretary's right to take planning decisions

Claim: In four test cases, it was argued that a government minister was not an "independent and impartial tribunal" when he exercised powers to take planning decisions himself

Outcome: The high court held that the environment secretary's decision could not be impartial because his policy had been at issue in each case, throwing the postwar planning system into confusion. Government appealed to the House of Lords. Decision pending. Law lords may overturn ruling

Subject: Mental patients detained against their will and right to release

Claim: Paranoid schizophrenic killer in Broadmoor argued that the law which puts the onus on him to prove he is not still suffering from a mental disorder warranting detention reverses burden of proof and infringes the right to liberty

Outcome: The appeal court agreed and ruled sections of Mental Health Act 1983 incompatible with the European convention on human rights

Subject: "Two strikes and you're out" life sentence for second-time serious offenders

Claim: Four lifers, jailed despite extenuating circumstances under a 1997 law which gave judges almost no discretion, claimed it violated the right to liberty, constituted inhuman and degrading treatment, and infringed ban on making a crime retrospective

Outcome: The appeal court neutralised the law, ruling that judges could take account of whether the offender was a danger to the public. This put the law back to where it was before the "two strikes" law was introduced

webTitle: UK 'most racist' in Europe on refugees

fields.headline: UK 'most racist' in Europe on refugees
fields.standfirst: Commission blames media and government
fields.trailText: Racism against asylum seekers and refugees is "particularly acute" in Britain, according to a Council of Europe survey of prejudice across the continent.
fields.body:
Racism against asylum seekers and refugees is "particularly acute" in Britain, according to a Council of Europe survey of prejudice across the continent.

The council's European commission against racism and intolerance blames the media for "xenophobic and intolerant coverage". But it also criticises the government for adopting and enforcing "increasingly restrictive asylum and immigration laws".

The Council of Europe, in Strasbourg, promotes democracy and human rights in its 43 member states. Today's report is the second in almost as many weeks to single Britain out for its negative attitude towards refugees. Last month, the EU's racism and xenophobia monitoring centre in Vienna found that, of all 15 member states, Britain was the most hostile to political refugees.

Field work for the latest report, carried out last May and June, raised concern about the "general negative climate concerning asylum seekers and refugees in the UK". The print media were blamed for "contributing to creating such a climate" by "consistent inflammatory attacks" on asylum seekers and migrants, in local and some national newspapers.

webTitle: Israeli website mixes fact and fantasy

fields.headline: Israeli website mixes fact and fantasy
fields.standfirst: Tasteless computer games are one thing, but Brian Whitaker says that fantasy masquerading as journalism is far worse
fields.trailText: Tasteless computer games are one thing, but Brian Whitaker says that fantasy masquerading as journalism is far worse.
fields.body:
Scanning the news on the internet at the weekend, I was alarmed to see at the top of the list a headline saying: "Talonsoft announces Arab-Israeli Wars".

Who, I wondered, is Mr Talonsoft - and why did his announcement of such a momentous event appear only in an obscure publication called ZDNet?

In fact, the story proved far less dramatic than its headline. Automated news compilations on the internet list stories from hundreds of sources, but there are none of the typographical signals that printed newspapers use to indicate their importance. The first story on the list may be of no great consequence.

Talonsoft, I discovered, is a US-owned software company that specialises in computer war games, and its latest product, Arab-Israeli Wars, will be released in the summer.

"The game will feature 22 stand-alone scenarios covering a number of historical battles from the Six-Day war, the independence war, the war of the waters, and the Yom Kippur war," the blurb says, apparently unaware that the names of these wars are contentious.

"Players will control authentic units such as the M48A2 Patton, the M60, the T-62, the MiG 17, and the F-4E Phantom II. Battles will take place in a variety of Middle Eastern countries, including Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Syria, and Lebanon."

Possibly it did not occur to Talonsoft that announcing this during the worst week of Israeli-Palestinian violence since the intifada began could be perceived as tasteless. Or possibly their marketing department thought that would be the ideal moment.

Either way, there's something very disturbing about a company that turns one of the world's great unresolved political conflicts into a plaything - though it is only one of many ways that our electronic world blurs the boundaries between fantasy and reality, between tragedy and entertainment.

Last month in Beirut, I visited an internet cafe that echoed with the sound of digital gunfire. About 30 teenagers were running around virtual streets, shooting at virtual enemies. Just a few years earlier, in the real street outside, their fathers - and possibly even elder brothers - fought real gun battles during the Lebanese civil war.

Computer games may be realistic, but at least they do not purport to be anything other than a game. If some of the players can't tell the difference, that's not necessarily the makers' fault.

It's a different matter, however, when fiction purports to be journalism. There's a website called debka.com that describes itself as "an internet weekly on intelligence, politics and terrorism" and "the decision-maker's indispensable tool".

For a subscription of $120, you can have it emailed every week - which at least suggests its content is worth paying for. Debka, which is based in Jerusalem, hints at having exclusive access to Israeli intelligence sources and makes a habit of mis-spelling Arabic names.

A banner at the top of each page says: "We start where the media stop" - a claim that few could disagree with, since Debka blends fact, fantasy and propaganda in ways that make it difficult to separate one from the other.

One of Debka's recurring obsessions is its belief that the PLO, Hizbullah, Syria, Iraq and Iran have all joined a secret alliance against Israel. Many of its stories are tailored to support this theory.

Anyone who has witnessed the repeated failure of Arab countries to agree on a united course of action about any issue of importance ought to have serious doubts about the likelihood of such an alliance.

Nevertheless, some elements in the Israeli government and military seem intent on promoting the idea that it exists - and Debka supports them in their efforts.

The motive of these elements is not entirely clear. Some suggest they are seeking to provide justification for an attack on Lebanon and Syria. Perhaps more likely, they may be trying to persuade the US to grant Israel a free rein in the region and provide it with more weapons.

But there certainly is a political motive behind the stories of a PLO-Hizbullah-Syrian-Iraqi-Iranian alliance, and they should be treated with suspicion unless supported by more evidence than Debka is able to provide.

A recent "special exposé" of the new Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, gives a flavour of Debka's journalistic methods and content:

As a child, Debka says, Bashar "was always rather strange - virtually uneducable, quick-tempered and given to petty cruelties against animals and weaker playmates. No one bothered to correct his ways, never imagining he would ever come to high office."

The death of Bashar's elder brother (whom many people had expected to become the next president) suddenly changed all that, Debka says. His ailing father, Hafez al-Assad, desperately sought to prepare Bashar for the presidency.

According to Debka, he "turned to the adept image-makers of British and French intelligence, asking them to fabricate for the youthful Beshar [sic] a Western-educated, modern Arab intellectual facade."

As a result, Debka says, Britain cooked up a fictitious story that Bashar had studied ophthalmic surgery in London - though why the British were so obliging in this matter is not explained.

The Americans and Israelis knew about the Syrian-British scheme, Debka adds, but agreed to keep quiet when both Bashar and Hafez al-Assad promised to be nice to Washington and to "sign peace with Israel on acceptable terms".

Debka complains: "After several months in power, Beshar shows no sign of keeping either of those promises."

The only evidence cited by Debka to support this fanciful tale is that "the young Syrian president studiously avoids contacts with foreigners and medical people", so as not to reveal "his lack of medical knowledge and halting English."

It adds: "When he cannot avoid these contacts, he listens and nods but says little." The rest of the story is attributed to unnamed "intelligence sources".

Intelligence sources are always a useful standby in the absence of any firm evidence: the nature of their work not only suggests they have special knowledge, but also provides an obvious reason why they cannot be identified.

People who are not identified cannot be held reponsible for what they are reported to have said.

One of the problems with Debka is that its stories usually have just enough of a factual basis to sound plausible - indeed, some of them may even be true. They are also sufficiently well told and interesting to trickle out into popular gossip and occasionally into the mainstream media.

Unprovable (and probably spurious) claims about threats to Israel from Iranian Republican Guards in Lebanon and Hizbullah guerrillas in the occupied territories which originated in Debka have recently re-surfaced in two respected publications: Jane's Foreign Report and the Saudi-owned daily, Ash-Sharq al-Awsat.

fields.headline: Cordiant snaps up Irish PR firm
fields.trailText: 11am: The purchase of Gallagher & Kelly will give the marketing giant a foothold in the buoyant Irish market, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Marketing communications group Cordiant has acquired Dublin-based PR firm Gallagher & Kelly Public Relations for £5.6m, in the hope of cashing in on the "Celtic tiger" economy.

The acquisition gives Cordiant a foothold in the Irish market, which an increasing number of multinational companies are using as a base.

Gallagher & Kelly provides clients with a range of corporate communications services, including media relations, public affairs, investor relations, crisis and strategic management advice and corporate brand communications.

The company's domestic and international clients include Coca-Cola, Dell, Microsoft, Bank of Ireland, Eircom Ireland and Eircell.

Gallagher & Kelly will become part of Cordiant's Business Communications International network, which spans London, New York, Boston, San Francisco, Frankfurt and Paris.

"The acquisition of Gallagher & Kelly strengthens BCI's global capability and its position as a market leader," said Michael Bungey, Cordiant chief executive.

"This is an exciting opportunity with which to expand BCI's international presence and confirms Cordiant's continuing commitment to servicing clients' communication needs on a global basis."

webTitle: Foot and mouth and the media

fields.headline: Day 43: foot and mouth and the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Day 43: The Tories, the army and farming are perfect ingredients for a Telegraph story.
fields.body:
The Daily Telegraph
Perfect ingredients for a Telegraph story - the Tories, the army and farming. No wonder the paper put the story that William Hague is to call for the army to be put in charge of the foot and mouth crisis on its front page. The Telegraph also carries the story that the leader of the Masai tribe, who regard themselves as the spiritual owners of the world's cattle, has offered to travel to the UK to help cure the disease.

The Guardian
The time lag between diagnosis of animals with foot and mouth and their slaughter is getting longer by the day, according to the Guardian. There's also a guide to foot and mouth vaccination and a story about tourist business leaders in Cumbria calling for an extra autumn bank holiday to help them catch up on lost earnings.

The Times
No coverage of the crisis on the front page of the Times and readers have to reach to page 11 before getting their foot and mouth update. The paper writes that a university professor has begun a race against time to save 12 rare breeds of sheep.

The Mirror
The Mirror reckons it could take until Christmas to kill the foot and mouth virus. And the paper's leader says the destruction of Britain's tourist industry is just as dangerous as the culling on our farms. "At the moment all the wrong signals are being sent out", the Mirror says.

The Sun
The Sun appears to have lost interest in foot and mouth, with no direct coverage of the crisis. The only mention of the disease appears in a story on page six about Britain's action-starved gamblers rushing to place their bets on this Saturday's Grand National.

The Daily Mail
Tony Blair is caught in the crossfire between angry Labour MPs, farmers and the struggling tourist industry. But the Mail's leader says Mr Blair is right to take the risk and has shown he is sensitive to the plight of Britain's farmers.

webTitle: Jeanette Winterson: If only lesbians were foxes

fields.headline: If only lesbians were foxes
fields.trailText: Can we get this straight? Only a woman can be a lesbian but lesbians are not women? If kids pour cat food into your coat and shout "Pussy", that has nothing to do with being a woman. Yells of "lezzie" and "dyke" are because you are queer, not because you are female.
fields.body:
In 1998, Cherie Booth represented Lisa Grant and Jill Percy in a discrimination case against South West Trains. The pair, who were long-term partners, were not granted the same travel perks as heterosexual employees of the company. Booth argued that discriminating on the grounds of sexuality was as unlawful as gender discrimination. The Human Rights Act was not in force. The case was lost.

Last week, in her role as a human rights lawyer, with her own special set of chambers to deal with human rights issues, Booth's approach was different. She was arguing that sexual orientation is not a human rights issue, and that homosexuals who are abused because of their sexuality, have no remedy under the law.

If lesbians were foxes, it might be different. This is just a woman hounded out of her job. And not even a woman, according to Booth, who maintained in court that the Sex Discrimination Act protects women but not lesbians.

Can we get this straight? Only a woman can be a lesbian but lesbians are not women? If kids pour cat food into your coat and shout "Pussy", that has nothing to do with being a woman. Yells of "lezzie" and "dyke" are because you are queer, not because you are female. It seems that the law is seeking to confirm the prejudices of homophobes everywhere - that lesbians are not "real" women.

A "real" women is one sexually available to men - though I am not sure where this leaves nuns. The definition of a "real" man, is not a man sexually available to women, but one who knows where his loyalties lie - that is, with other men. Queer or not, he bonds with and maintains the power structures that privilege men above women. This is why many gay men can live without difficulty in the world. The ones who do get into trouble are the ones who expose the system in some way, either by effeminacy or cross-dressing or outspokenness, or deliberately identifying with women. Such men are a threat in the way that all lesbians are a threat: they upset the pecking order.

Shirley Pearce had taught science at Mayfield school in Portsmouth for 15 years. She had a good record and was a dedicated career teacher - just the kind the government is desperate to keep. In 1990, very privately, she started visiting gay clubs. In a small town word soon gets out and the trouble at school began.

She put up with this for five years, with little help from her colleagues or her boss. We all know what kids can be like - they gang up, and they pick on outsiders. Part of the role of education is to lead children out of this kind of tribal behaviour. Victimising difference is a bad model for adulthood. You need not be a supporter of gay rights to understand that tolerance is essential for multi-cultural city life - the life that most people will be leading in the 21st century. Love thy neighbour becomes more urgent when we cannot avoid her.

Shirley Pearce was told by her head teacher to "grit her teeth". She was advised to take leave of absence on health grounds and, finally, she resigned. An industrial tribunal and an employment appeal tribunal both dismissed her case. Now Stonewall, the equal rights group, is supporting her in the courts.

webTitle: Comment: In the jaws of the dragon

fields.headline: In the jaws of the dragon
fields.standfirst:
After his mishap in China, George Bush's tough-talking foreign policy faces its first real test
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: After his mishap in China, George Bush's tough-talking foreign policy faces its first real test
fields.body:
The British businessman explained his frustration at dealing with China: he was exhibiting, many years ago, some technical equipment at a trade fair in Shanghai. Each night, the exhibitors were told to leave the exhibition hall at 5pm and were not allowed back in until the following morning. He knew, he said, that in the 12 hours in which he was denied access, his hosts were busy taking his gear to pieces. If they concluded they could copy it, they would never buy it. He left without making a sale.

It is a little more complicated to copy a spy-plane, but George Bush has a similar problem right now. Every hour that his plane remains on the ground at that Chinese airbase on Hainan Island gives the Chinese time to crawl all over this treasure, cataloguing its classified mysteries. The situation is more than embarrassing.

Who exactly is to blame for the incident will continue to be the subject of argument. The US claims the plane was in international airspace and that the Chinese fighters - who have been playing such dangerous games of tag in recent months that the US had already lodged a protest - came too close. The US plane is a slow-moving and heavily laden turbo-prop and not something that any pilot would throw around the skies. With the reservation that Washington has refused to give the plane's coordinates at the time of Sunday's incident, I incline to believe the US version.

The Chinese claims on the South China Sea are grossly exaggerated and accepted by nobody. When the Chinese say that the US plane was over Chinese territory, therefore, it should be taken with a pinch of salt. Besides, the Chinese military are deeply upset by the defection in December of Colonel Xu Junping, director of the Chinese defence ministry's liaison office for the United States, an incident that has led to the cancellation of other visits and military exchanges.

The US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, has, in turn, frozen 40 exchanges planned for this year as part of a harder line towards China. It is not beyond the bounds of possibility that Chinese irritation overcame prudence. But arguing over who caused the incident does not change the fact that it offers the Chinese a heaven-sent opportunity for blackmail at a moment of already tense relations.

As with the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, such episodes arouse genuinely felt nationalist resentment in China which, with official sanction, easily spills over into public demonstrations and gives the government the excuse to hang tough. Right now, the view in Beijing is that there's a lot to hang tough about. Since Bush took office, the tone of US foreign policy has shifted from one of cooperation to a bluntly stated view that China is a potential military competitor, exacerbating the tensions endemic in the China policy minefield. What we have now is a stand-off between two powerful states, both of which have deep internal divisions about the conduct of foreign policy and both of which have adopted muscular nationalism as the dominant tone in their diplomacy.

Add to that confrontation a set of real and intractable disagreements and the situation becomes delicate indeed. Since Bush came to power, he has antagonised the Chinese through his cavalier approach to the warming relations with North Korea, through his enthusiasm for missile defence, his commitment to arms sales to Taiwan and his decision to pursue a resolution in Geneva censuring China for human rights violations. He has alarmed America's other Asian partners and enraged the European Union by the first two items of that list - as well, of course, as his rejection of the Kyoto accords and his cavalier dismissal of the arms control record.

All of this has left the new administration with spiky relationships around the globe, something that Bush may soon learn does not help when difficult situations, such as that created by this latest spy-plane mishap in China, are to be resolved.

Not all of Bush's China list is bad: the only disgrace in the US desire to bring about a human rights vote in Geneva is that the EU, including of course our own ethically dimensioned government, is once again failing to support it, despite the continuing deterioration in China's human rights behaviour. Taiwan, too, needs support in the face of Beijing's continuing insistence that Taiwan will be brought back into the fold by fair means or foul.

The issue, though, is the more sensitive if it is read in conjunction with missile defence. The Chinese regard the US missile defence proposals as aimed at neutralising China's long range nuclear arsenal, a system that, as yet, poses little direct threat to the US. A more urgent cause of friction, though, is in the related area of theatre defence, which leads directly to the question of Taiwan.

Taiwan is currently facing a build-up of Chinese missiles, put in place to add weight to Beijing's invitation to Taiwan to surrender to the People's Republic - or, at least, to refrain from a declaration of independence. There are currently 300 short range missiles facing Taiwan from China, and the number increases by around 50 a year. High on Taiwan's wish list of arms from the US are four Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar system and PAC-3 missile systems - improved versions of the Patriot. They would protect Taiwan's navy in the first instance but would also offer a potential platform for theatre missile defence linked to a strategic defence system.

As Donald Rumsfeld observed recently when asked about the Chinese position, "If some country decided it wanted to be aggressive to its neighbours and acquire additional territory by force, then having a missile defence system is not a bad idea." But such a system would go further, always assuming that it can be made to work: it would neutralise the medium range missiles that China has deployed and which currently threaten India and Japan. It's a prospect that is hardly likely to soften the hearts of the Chinese military as they reflect on what price they should try to exact from the US for the safe return of the spy-plane and its 24-man crew. What, then, will the Chinese demand? The resolution in Geneva is an embarrassment to China but can hardly be withdrawn now. In any event, it is likely to fail unless the US throws serious diplomatic weight behind it. The Aegis sale to Taiwan, on the other hand, due to be decided this month, can be delayed, if not denied. There, however, Bush is in the unenviable position of being caught between the conflicting views that - in the apparent absence of a president with any of his own - are fighting it out over US foreign policy.

The Republican party is divided between the hardliners who see China as a potential enemy and the business lobby pursuing its usual agenda of trade no matter what. (The same dilemma, on a smaller scale, presents itself over Cuba.) Among Bush's advisers, there is a perceptible difference between the more conciliatory State Department and the hardline military. So far, Bush's foreign policy has come across as comic cuts nationalism. In China, he faces an adversary whose nationalism is at least as deeply rooted as his own and which regards the US with profound mistrust. If Mr Bush wants his plane back, he may be forced to acknowledge that there is more to diplomacy than flag waving.
