webTitle: Parents 'should get tapes of talks with doctors'

fields.headline: Parents 'should get tapes of talks with doctors'
fields.trailText: Parents of seriously sick children should be given tapes of key consultations with hospital doctors to help end the "paternalistic" culture of the medical profession and improve trust, an inquiry said yesterday.
fields.body:
Parents of seriously sick children should be given tapes of key consultations with hospital doctors to help end the "paternalistic" culture of the medical profession and improve trust, an inquiry said yesterday.

Families should also receive detailed letters about their children's care within 20 days of the meetings and be informed of any changes to diagnoses and treatments.

The recommendations of the independent inquiry are expected to shock hospitals, where doctors already face pressure to "tell all" and abandon hierarchical attitudes towards colleagues and patients. The advice may be seen as a threat to their professionalism.

The inquiry into children's heart services at the Royal Brompton and Harefield hospitals in London, found a "serious breakdown in communication and trust" between some parents and doctors. It also accepted that doctors' behaviour towards families of Down's syndrome children led parents to view the treatment offered as discriminatory.

Some families had alleged that they were encouraged to believe surgery could make it more difficult to look after their children later in life and that they were not told fully about the risks of treatment.

The recommendation to tape consultations and send parents copies of letters from consultants to GPs, was among 102 directed at the trust.

The inquiry chairman Ruth Evans, former head of the National Consumer Council , said her team hoped other hospitals would "implement recommendations, where they are needed, across the board."

Health officials yesterday admitted it would be difficult to introduce such procedures nationwide for only a few categories of patients and operations. Some sources also said some trusts were wary of anything that could be used in litigation. But there could also be benefits in that families, overwhelmed by the seriousness of the consultations, would not otherwise take in all the doctors said. The British Medical Association said that tape recordings should not be seen as a substitute for patients and parents to have further face-to-face conversations.

The report also makes 17 further recommendations including training for all health professionals in ensuring "non-discriminatory" policies and practices, and a national system for reporting serious injury from child heart surgery.

"There is no place for discrimination in the NHS and all patients and their parents must be treated fairly, on the basis of clinical need and with respect and dignity," a health department spokesman said.

The inquiry had found that Down's Syndrome children with heart conditions were "less favoured" for operations at the Royal Brompton. But doctors were not discriminatory in the treatment delivered.

The inquiry, set up in 1999, investigated 49 cases of children treated at the two hospitals since 1987, 14 of them Down's syndrome sufferers. Many of the children died or had suffered serious brain damage following surgery .

Ms Evans said members found "a culture of paternalism that makes families frightened and disempowered". She added: "Parents are entitled to more information, better communication and more consultant time when making critical decisions."

The chairman of the trust, Sir Philip Otton, expressed "regret" to parents but added that there had been considerable debate about the appropriate method for treating children with Down's syndrome and heart disease.

Disappointed parents called the inquiry a "sham" and a "cover-up" and demanded a public inquiry.

Margaret MacRae, whose teenage son David died after treatment at Harefield, claimed the surgical interventions would have led to a public outcry if they had occurred in an animal laboratory.

fields.headline: US-Chinese relations face 'real chill'
fields.standfirst: The current spy plane row will seem inconsequential if the Bush administration agrees to bolster Taiwan's defences against China, says Julian Borger
fields.trailText: The current spy plane row will seem inconsequential if the Bush administration agrees to bolster Taiwan's defences against China, says Julian Borger.
fields.body:
The diplomatic standoff following the emergency landing of a US spy plane on China's Hainan island is loaded with the imagery of the cold war. It was caused by a seemingly random event, a midair collision with a Chinese fighter jet, yet the accident and all the accompanying tension has uncannily presaged a real chill in relations that many expect to set in this year.

The sharp exchanges over the US EP-3 will seem like idle banter if President Bush acts on the advice of a naval commission and equips Taiwan's defences with the $1.2bn (£800m) state-of-the-art destroyers Taipei wants. Each is equipped with the US navy's most advanced anti-missile radar system, the Aegis, designed to spot up to 200 incoming missiles, and to direct intercepting missiles towards them.

The Bush administration says the sale will not go ahead if China scales back its missile buildup across the 100-mile straits from Taiwan, but the change in stance is unmistakable. President Clinton turned back the self-governing island's request for the destroyers last year, deciding it would be destabilising. His successor looks set to call Beijing's bluff.

Admiral Dennis Blair, the commander of US troops in the Pacific, told Congress last week that China has 300 short range and medium range missiles pointed at Taiwan, and had been increasing the force by 50 missiles a year. His testimony has helped convince some prominent Democrats to support the sale of the destroyers.

The decision will be a further litmus test of the Bush administration's foreign policy after a string of decisions that have jarred some of Washington closest allies - like the announcement last week to abandon the Kyoto global warming treaty, the end of negotiations with North Korea and the green light given earlier this year to the development of an anti-ballistic National Missile Defence system.

All three decisions reflect long-advertised convictions among the inner core of foreign policy advisors around Mr Bush - in particular vice president Cheney and the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld - and a defeat to the "outsider" secretary of state, Colin Powell, who was brought onto the campaign as an icon of moderate Republicanism, and who now looks increasingly irrelevant and ornamental. Just days before talks with Pyongyang were dumped, Mr Powell had been saying that he wanted to pick up negotiations where President Clinton had left off. He had not been informed.

The policy choices over Kyoto, North Korea, and NMD showed who is in charge in the Bush foreign policy team. The decision over the Aegis will demonstrate how far the hawks are willing to go in the gathering showdown with China and the return to cold war-style superpower strategy.

The options are exquisitely calibrated. The administration could choose to give Taiwan Kidd-class destroyers, which are a generation old and originally made to equip the Shah of Iran's navy (they are sometimes called "Ayatollah-class destroyers").

They are equipped with a radar system which is not quite as good as the Aegis, and not nearly so expensive. Supplying the Kidds to Taiwan would also leave the option of ultimately providing the Burke-class ships, which would take up to eight more years to build and deliver.

The Bush administration would still look tough, but without the Aegis, Taiwan would not be in a position to block the Chinese missile arsenal. That confrontation, the most serious in Sino-American relations for many years, could be left for another day.

webTitle: Leader: Bush gets a grounding in China policy

fields.headline: Coming down to earth
fields.standfirst:
Bush gets a grounding in China policy
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The incident off Hainan contributes to a growing sense in the Asia-Pacific region and beyond that post-Clinton bilateral ties are fraying.
fields.body:
Strain and pain are beginning to characterise US-China relations after the incident off Hainan involving an EP-3 spy plane and a Chinese fighter, whose pilot is now presumed dead. Washington's intrusive coastal surveillance is partly to blame. Beijing has made matters worse by holding the US crew incommunicado and delaying the return of the plane and its top secret intelligence-gathering equipment. The affair demonstrates just how easily George Bush's concept of "strategic competition" with China can turn nasty. And it contributes to a growing sense in the Asia-Pacific region and beyond that post-Clinton bilateral ties are fraying. Other points of friction include the detentions of US-linked academics, a high-level Chinese military defection, the discovery of Chinese sanctions-busting in Iraq and US efforts to censure China at the UN human rights commission in Geneva. Mr Bush's missile building plans are anathema to Beijing. Yet unabashed, and without a trace of irony, Washington berates China over weapons and missile proliferation.

Bush apologists explain that policy is still being formulated, that the US still wants good relations. China, meanwhile, currently has two main reasons for restraint. One is its hope that it can yet persuade the Bushmen to opt for a pragmatic, non-ideological approach. The US must "think strategically", says President Jiang Zemin. No fewer than three high-powered Chinese delegations have been sent to Washington since Mr Bush was elected. Vice-premier Qian Qichen went out of his way to stress the positive at a White House meeting last month. China's overall aim seems clear. Aware of its relative weakness, and giving no ground on specific issues, it seeks to curb the Bush hawks' worst instincts by emphasising diplomatic realpolitik.

China's second reason for restraint is Taiwan. This is the make-or-break issue for China, transcending all others. Mr Jiang calls it the "key" to relations with the US. Beijing is desperate (not too strong a word) that Mr Bush not proceed with the sale of advanced military equipment to the "renegade province". For China, this is not in the end a matter of security. It is a fundamental matter of national pride and political credibility. Even among communists, reunification with Taiwan is an article of faith. For Mr Jiang, it is the logical, final step after Hong Kong and Macao. Anything that delays it further, and that includes equipping Taipei with state-of-the-art Aegis missile defence radar, will be seen as massively provocative. Keen that this be understood, the smiling Mr Qian says that such sales (Taiwan also wants submarines, destroyers and Patriot batteries) would constitute a "grave violation" of a Reagan-era joint communiqué.

Mr Qian has a point. "The US states that it does not seek to carry out a long-term policy of arms sales to Taiwan ... and that it intends to reduce gradually its sales," the communiqué says. That was 1982. No US administration has kept that pledge. Despite China's lobbying, Mr Bush looks set to break it, too. That would be a mistake. But if he does so, the diplomatic gloves will be off - and the Hainan affair may soon resemble mere shadow-boxing before the main bout.

webTitle: Isle of Wight hopes palace will lure visitors

fields.headline: Isle of Wight hopes palace will lure visitors
fields.trailText: One of the most spectacular interiors in England, the restored Indian style Durbar room at Osborne House, reopened to the public at the weekend, the official start of what was hoped would be an unprecedented tourist season on the Isle of Wight.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
One of the most spectacular interiors in England, the restored Indian style Durbar room at Osborne House, reopened to the public at the weekend, the official start of what was hoped would be an unprecedented tourist season on the Isle of Wight.

English Heritage and Isle of Wight tourism had been hoping for a record year. The opulent decoration created in 1890 by Indian craftsmen and English plasterers has been restored by English Heritage for the centenary of Queen Victoria's death, which was expected to boost tourist numbers significantly.

The palace was Queen Victoria's favourite home, where she died on January 22 1901. The Durbar room was added because the vast house did not have a big enough room for large receptions.

The Indian master craftsman Bhai Ram Singh designed it with constant interruptions from Victoria's daughter, Princess Louise. In one letter he wrote with courteous despair: " The Queen is very much pleased with it, but the Princess Louise suggests some alterations. The Princess Louise wants the electric light in the room, but the Queen does not like it." The room still has the electric lights he was eventually permitted to design in the form of Indian brass lanterns.

His portrait, with those of the Queen's Indian chef, Shekh Muhammad Buksh, who produced curry lunches most days, and of her Indian language tutor and secretary, Abdul Karim, hang in the corridor outside the room.

Osborne is the biggest tourist attraction on the island. In the last two years tourist numbers were increasing dramatically after the success of Mrs Brown, the Oscar winning film about the Queen's relationship with John Brown.

But last week the tourists were missing. Marinas, pubs and cafes were empty, and hotels and guest houses were reporting bookings down by up to 50%.

All ferry passengers cross disinfectant mats entering and leaving the island, which is free of foot and mouth. Although the cliff top paths remain closed, most of the main attractions are open, or will open in the next fortnight.

webTitle: Letters: The slaughter behind closed doors

fields.headline: The slaughter behind closed doors
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting is outraged at this government presiding over what she sees as the "biggest mass slaughter of animals in human history" (Who are the brutes now? March 31).
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting is outraged at this government presiding over what she sees as the "biggest mass slaughter of animals in human history" (Who are the brutes now? March 31). Forced to see on the TV what normally happens behind the closed doors of the slaughterhouse, she blames everyone but herself for this holocaust. In Britain we kill each and every week 15m poultry and 600,000 sheep, pigs and cattle for the dinner table. The animals now filling the pits and pyres are fewer than a normal day's killing quota - if you count the 2m poultry, shackled by their brittle and broken legs, which have their throats slit each day.

Where are the animal rights protesters? We are here, trying to tell the public that for the animals it does not make a lot of difference. The fact that the public, like Ms Bunting, are being made to face their guilt at what eating meat actually entails for the animal will, I hope, mean that their eating habits will change.
Sara Starkey
Tonbridge, Kent

Your article is the best I have read yet on the subject - it put into words what I had been thinking for years. I have not dared to voice my opinions for fear of being dismissed as "one of those vegetarians", so it was all the more important that the article was written by a meat eater. As you say, even meat eaters can respect animals - and indeed many in the non-developed world still do.
Louise Davies
Derby
luhazjoka@talk21.com

Animal Aid - in common with other animal rights groups - has sent out a ceaseless flow of press statements and letters to editors around the country. We have staged demos in numerous towns and cities and have sought to take part in radio debates and TV programmes on the FMD theme. We have mostly been rebuffed because, I assume, our straightforward message is unpalatable.

Does Ms Bunting really believe that producing meat for 60m Britons is, or ever could be, a smiley cottage industry? Animal farming is brutal, squalid and ruthless. That infectious disease flourishes in such systems is no accident. Salmonella, E coli, bovine TB, campylobacter, BSE, swine fever, foot and mouth signal that industrialised farming is in a state of perpetual crisis.
Andrew Tyler
Director, Animal Aid
andrew@animalaid.co.uk

The one positive thing is that the animals are not having to face the horrors of the slaughterhouse, where they are beaten and kicked before they even get to the killing line. Slaughterhouse workers are on piecework, so the more animals they kill, the more money they get, which means that many animals are not properly stunned before being slaughtered. This means the animals are still conscious when they are shackled by a chain around their hind legs to a conveyor and moved to the bleeding area where, still alive, their throats are cut. The heart must still be beating to pump out the blood and ensure blood loss. This is how they die - they bleed to death.

That is why those of us who do genuinely believe in the rights of animals are not diverting our energy and time away from educating the misinformed public about the truth hidden behind the closed doors of places such as Huntingdon Life Sciences. By killing even the healthy sheep, cows and pigs now, the government will soon be asking the EU for a huge subsidy, so the whole meat and dairy industry will rise from the ashes of the dead animals.
Pam Kinnunen
London

Wonderful piece! Even on the economic case the slaughter is lunacy: £9bn threatened to save £310m? I have repeatedly sought answers in parlia ment. We are blindly following the crazy self-interested mythology of the NFU and Maff.
Paul Flynn MP

We are told that the EU policy of not vaccinating livestock is to protect its exports to parts of the world, like Japan and North America, which will only buy meat from countries that do not vaccinate. However, only 5% of EU sales are to these countries. The other benefit is that it allows Europe to ban imports of cheap meat from countries like Russia, most of Africa and South America. We all know of the massive financial costs of the huge slaughter that is going on. Is it possible this is all to uphold a policy whose real purpose is to prevent free trade with the poorer countries?
Henry Stewart
London
henry@happy.co.uk

Where the cull involves the extermination of rare and valuable breeds, such as Herdwicks and Swaledales and the consequent destruction of the present vegetation of the fells, surely it is both unscientific, immoral and contrary to our economic interest? Why are elephants, whales, pandas and tigers more deserving of protection than our own rare breeds?
MN Rendel
London

You repeat the mistaken assertion that sheep farming is essential to Cumbrian tourism because it helps preserve the "picturesque grassland" (Leader, March 30). But there are plenty of us tourists who'd rather have scrubland, however shabby, because of its greater biodiversity. At present the land is overgrazed and sterile because of sheep farming.
Nicholas Simpson
Cheadle, Cheshire

webTitle: Extra bank holiday in autumn urged

fields.headline: Extra bank holiday in autumn urged
fields.trailText: Leaders of tourist businesses in Cumbria, the county with England's highest number of foot and mouth cases, yesterday called on the government to order an autumn bank holiday to help them catch up on lost earnings.
fields.body:
Leaders of tourist businesses in Cumbria, the county with England's highest number of foot and mouth cases, yesterday called on the government to order an autumn bank holiday to help them catch up on lost earnings.

They fear the Easter break could be a disaster and will not give them the traditional four-day boost to revenues at the start of the holiday season. "The extra holiday, from Friday to Monday, would come at the third weekend in September," said Henry Wild, owner of Skelwith Fold caravan site, near Ambleside, which has had just 13 customers since the outbreak began five weeks ago.

"This would cost the Treasury very little but would allow us to pick up what we are not going to get at Easter."

Mr Wild suggested the new holiday to tourism minister Janet Anderson as she cruised on Windermere in a downpour during a visit to the Lake District. "It's perhaps something we should look at," said Ms Anderson, who last night met more than 50 tourism industry delegates in Ambleside. During the boat trip she was told of a cancelled booking worth £800 and how foot and mouth had closed all rural youth hostels in the county.

The Cumbria tourist board estimates the disease is costing the local industry up to £10m a week, and Chris Collier, the board's chief executive, pleaded with Ms Anderson for direct cash compensation to businesses.

She said deferred payments on tax, VAT and business rates were of no use to businesses, such as guest houses, which were starved of cash.

"Thousands of businesses could be lost unless we find ways to help them now," she said. "The cost of helping them would be much less than if we allow them all to go to the wall and the economy into freefall."

Ms Anderson said: "The question of compensation is very difficult. How do you assess consequential loss and how do you decide who would be eligible?

"One of the reasons I am here today is to see if there is anything more the government can do to help.

"If we need to do more, we will have to look again at the package of measures already agreed."

webTitle: Ian Jack on the Hatfield crash

fields.headline: Breaking point
fields.standfirst:
Many people knew about the cracked rail that caused the Hatfield crash. So why wasn't it replaced, or a speed limit imposed? In the final extract from his exhaustive investigation of the accident, Ian Jack says that the answers lie in the disastrous privatisation of Britain's railways

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Many people knew about the cracked rail that caused the Hatfield crash. So why wasn't it replaced, or a speed limit imposed? In the final extract from his exhaustive investigation of the accident,  Ian Jack says that the answers lie in the disastrous privatisation of Britain's railways.
fields.body:
My morning route to work in London takes me over a railway bridge. A traveller on the top deck of a bus at this point can see a junction and a single line curving off into a tunnel. Once there were two lines; once the curve was smooth. Sometime in the early 90s, however, I noticed that one of the lines had been taken up and that the curve was really a series of angled straight rails. Bill Armstrong, a former railway engineer, described this to me as "a threepenny-bit curve", after the old British 12-sided coin. The rails had probably been used elsewhere, or turned around at the same site, and wanted to assume their previous form, "to go back," as he said, "to where they lived before". Also, around the same time, I began to notice weeds here and on other lines; weeds that grew on the ballast sometimes to the size of small shrubs. Even the busy track outside Waterloo terminus had them, with their suggestion of abandoned railways in the Argentinian pampas. I imagined that railways were obeying a new ecological stricture to ban herbicide. The cause was more straightforward.

Between 1992 and 1997, the number of workers on Britain's railways fell from 159,000 to 92,000, at a time when the number of trains increased. Within these totals, the numbers of workers permanently employed to maintain and renew the infrastructure fell from 31,000 to between 15,000 and 19,000. In March 1998 the Guardian's transport editor, Keith Harper, interviewed a group of former British Rail workers. They spoke scathingly of the methods of their new employers, the private contractors who worked for Railtrack. One told him: "At least 50% of the track is on its last legs. If it's not broken rails, it's broken components. If the public knew the full picture, it would be horrified. There are accidents waiting to happen and loads of speed restrictions. Some cowboy the other day forgot to put up a 20mph speed restriction on a 70mph route. How there wasn't an accident I'll never know."

In November last year, attending a session of the government inquiry into the Ladbroke Grove rail crash before Lord Cullen, I heard the same situation on the track described in a more academic way. Professor Christopher Baldry, head of the department of management and organisation at Stirling University, was giving evidence about safety practices among rail workers, based on recent research. Baldry described the long and unregulated hours that could be worked under the negligent eye of a subcontractor, the lack of communication between train crews, signallers and rail maintenance workers all employed by different companies and often new to their jobs - and the rivalry between different contractors or subcontractors.

"We were given on several occasions evidence that if, for example, track workers from Scotland had been sent down to York to work on a bit of track that was unfamiliar to them, they find themselves working with other employees of a different contractor. Their instinct is to ask local people about the nature of the track. The local people may have been told by their employer, 'Don't talk to these persons because they are employed by the opposition.' "

Familiarity with the track had gone, old patterns of trust had been broken; the price of the competitive spirit. There could be so many different companies employed on the same stretch of line, Baldry said, that it would take "a very brave person" to halt the work because of a potential hazard. The system that Baldry mentioned was designed by commercial lawyers, in the legal belief that punishment works, and it involves confusing flows of money and paperwork through many "interfaces" - here the term is managerial rather than scientific - between groups which have different and sometimes conflicting financial interests.

When a contracting firm repairs a track, it "takes possession" of it. Trains are stopped for the duration of these "track possessions", and this may in itself cost Railtrack money if it cannot meet its obligations to the train operating companies, and their trains are cancelled or delayed. If a track possession overruns its scheduled time, however, the penalties are fiercer. Track work usually takes place at the weekend - but say something unexpected occurs, or the contractor has underestimated the time the repairs will take, and the track possession runs into Monday morning? There is a schedule with tariffs. Rates differ. A delay to a train in the London morning rush hour, for example, can cost Railtrack £200 a minute at Waterloo. One delayed train can cause other delayed trains for hundreds of miles down the track, with Railtrack compensating their operators for each. A bill of £250,000 is quite easy to run up. Railtrack, therefore, can penalise the contractor, gathering in money with one hand as it pays out with the other.

The centre produced an extensive and highly critical report which attributed the breakages to a falling rate of rail renewals in the 1990s and a later increase in traffic, and recommended that Railtrack and its contractors should inspect and replace rails more often.

It was published eight days after the Hatfield crash. When the American researchers completed their work, nobody had died because of a broken rail since 1967. But at the curve, 16 miles up the line from the bureaucratic anger in London, the rail had continued to crack as the letters went back and forth between Winsor and Corbett. Hour after hour, day after day, expresses rode over it at 115mph.

Their superiors knew the rail would have to be replaced eventually - the question was when. Tiny cracks may grow quickly or slowly or might not grow at all. Rail-grinding, however, had been suspended soon after the railways were privatised. There was only one operational machine in the country. Nothing came of the idea at the time. Then, at a site meeting between Balfour Beatty and Railtrack in February 2000, a decision was made to replace the rail and Balfour Beatty was invited to bid for the job. Soon after, however, Railtrack decided that the work would go instead to Jarvis, the company which had the contract for track renewal as opposed to track maintenance. A 27-hour "track possession" was scheduled for March 19. But when that date came, the replacement rail had not arrived. According to John Ware, who investigated the crash for BBC's Panorama, there had been "a cock-up in delivery" which might have stemmed in part from the confusing management of the freight wagon carrying the new rails; it was owned by Railtrack but operated by men from Jarvis. Eventually, towards the end of April, the new rails were successfully delivered and laid by the trackside.

A new problem arose: in March, Railtrack and Jarvis had a track-possession slot but no new rails, now they had rails but no new track-possession slot. Could one be arranged in May? The new and busier summer timetable of trains began in that month; closing a stretch of line would cause more inconvenience and delay than in March, and incur penalty payments on Railtrack. Jarvis (again according to Ware) said it would need five eight-hour possessions. Railtrack countered with the offer of two possessions, each lasting four hours and 20 minutes. Jarvis said that to do the work in that time was impossible. The re-railing was postponed until November, when Railtrack was again prepared to offer eight-hour possessions during the less crowded winter timetable. In September, a grinding-machine finally came and wore down the rail's surface, which might have been the wrong treatment at the wrong time. (Grinding is meant to stop cracks growing; if the cracks have already grown beneath the surface, some engineers believe grinding can make a cracked rail weaker.)

In the meantime the rail continued to be inspected by Balfour Beatty, once a week by human eye (a man walking along the track), once every three months ultrasonically by a machine which is pushed by hand along the rail to scan its interior. This, for a high rail on a high-speed curve, was normal practice. The rail was scanned ultrasonically in April and again in July and by Railtrack's admission at least one of these scans was classified as unreadable. An unreadable ultrasonic scan suggests that either the cracking is so extensive that the machine can't register it, or that there is a fault in the machine. In either case, the rules suggest that a 20mph speed limit should automatically be imposed. Even without ultrasonic scanning, all the available evidence suggests that the Hatfield rail had been, or should have been, recognised as a most dangerous rail which demanded the imposition of a speed limit. When the rail was reassembled, it bore obvious signs of pre-crash metal distress. Apart from the cracking, its top surface had flaked up to a depth of three millimetres. A speed limit would have prevented four deaths.

How much did Balfour Beatty and Jarvis tell Railtrack? What were Railtrack's instructions to Balfour Beatty? Who are the guilty men? As I write police investigations continue. Witnesses have been reluctant to be interviewed. There are filing cabinets of documents to be read. The evidence may support a criminal prosecution. The public mood, so far as one can tell, would like big fish in the net and a charge of corporate manslaughter. That is unlikely; as someone close to the Hatfield investigation said to me, you would need to find a piece of paper with such improbable words written on it as "Do not repair this track, we can't afford it. Yrs sincerely, The Fat Controller." More likely is a charge of manslaughter - culpable homicide - against individuals lower down the ladder, or their prosecution for a breach of the Health and Safety at Work Act.

The Hatfield crash arose from a quagmire of divided responsibility and incompetence, inspired by an ideology that placed adversarial money bargaining over human and technical cooperation, in which "the contract" was divine. Lawyers had bent their minds to the will of a government that wanted to raise as much cash as possible from the sale of public assets; and devised a scheme driven by the crudest and most unworkable notions of the free market and its competitive benefits.

By the time of the Hatfield crash, the Labour government had had more than three years to abolish or modify the system that was so hastily and desperately devised by its Conservative predecessor. But its actions were mainly cosmetic. Government politicians said that Hatfield had created a new atmosphere within the industry, which now - at last - saw the need to "pull together", but it is difficult to find evidence to support this optimism. The world's most fragmented railway system has adversarial relationships at the heart of the philosophy which invented it, and an hour's frank conversation with most people who work in Britain's railways will eventually throw up "mess" as their most accurate description. webTitle: Moscow's media wavers on the edge

fields.headline: Moscow's media wavers on the edge
fields.standfirst: The battle for Russia's independent TV network is on, and it's getting bloodier, says Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: The battle for Russia's independent TV network is on, and it's getting bloodier, says Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
Brooding introspection has become the favourite theme for Russia's most influential weekly news analysis programme, Itogi.

Broadcast in a primetime viewing position every Sunday night, the highbrow current affairs show has begun rushing through its reports on troubled events in Yugoslavia or Israel, and its analysis of political developments in Russia.

This is to allow it to devote a large chunk of its two-hour slot to the internal problems unsettling the channel that airs it.

Imagine an edition of Newsnight devoted to the future of the BBC, with Jeremy Paxman analysing his own career prospects in the event that the channel wound up its operation. Or think of Panorama dispatching its reporters to gather material for a report on the likelihood of the series being taken off the screen.

Yet this is increasingly the tone of Itogi, presented by the highly-respected journalist Yevgeny Kiselyov, who is also the general director of NTV, the channel that broadcasts the programme.

This week the navel-gazing extended to Kukly - Russia's version of Spitting Image. Political satire was abandoned in favour of more self-analysis, introducing a plastic puppet version of the Sunday news show, complete with a latex image of presenter Mr Kiselyov.

With laboured symbolism, the script had the NTV studios on the verge of being destroyed by terrorist explosives, saved only by Russian president Vladimir Putin's rubber double, who stepped in at the last minute to defuse the ticking time bomb.

This fascination with events at the headquarters of its own television station would be extremely tedious were it not for the issues apparently at stake.

The future of NTV - Russia's only independent television network - in its current form has been in question now for almost a year and, later today, a decision at a boardroom meeting will determine whether key founding members of the staff will stay or be sacked.

Senior executives from Media-Most - the media group that owns NTV - claim that the future of free speech in Russia depends on the decision.

The complex twists of the Media-Most saga have become so tangled that the Russian public might have been forgiven for losing interest in its fate. But the tribulations of the network continue to attract attention and between 10,000 and 20,000 people turned out for a meeting in central Moscow on Saturday to protest at government-orchestrated attacks on the station.

Rallied by a week of publicity in newspapers owned by Media-Most and on NTV's broadcasts, the protesters listened to a pop concert and heard liberal opposition politicians warning of the need to fight for press freedom.

At the heart of the dispute is the Media-Most case - articulated by NTV's founder Vladimir Gusinsky - that the continuing government-initiated attempt to wrest back large loans from the company represents a deliberate attack on Russia's independent media.

The Kremlin, Mr Gusinsky argues, was infuriated by NTV's coverage of the conflict in Chechnya and its criticism of Mr Putin's government, and is determined to stifle the station's dissenting voice. The Kremlin insists that this is a purely financial matter - Media-Most owes money, which must be repaid. Mr Gusinsky has also been charged with large-scale fraud in connection with the Media-Most empire.

A meeting of shareholders has been called today by Alfred Kokh - the head of the media arm of the government-controlled natural gas giant Gazprom, which is owed debts of up to £210,641m by Media-Most.

If the meeting goes ahead, Media-Most officials fear the session will initiate a vote for a new board of directors, which will result in the removal of their own staff members and their replacement with Kremlin-friendly substitutes. If these fears are realised, then today will prove a decisive landmark in the prolonged battle for control of the television network.

Mr Gusinsky - who is under house-arrest in his villa in southern Spain, fighting an extradition request by Russian prosecutors - looks set to be ousted from the board of governors and has been doing his utmost to avert the board meeting.

In the latest tortuous development, the High Court in London was due last week to rule on which side had the right to a contested block of 19% of crucial shares in Media-Most.

The court decided that it was unable to make a ruling on the case. This meant that the shares remain frozen - and, ultimately, that Media-Most's 49% holding over NTV is reduced by 19%, giving Gazprom the decisive vote in questions of control (with 46% of the shares), thereby allowing them to replace influential figures like Mr Kiselyov as well as Mr Gusinsky.

Also last week, Media-Most attempted, through a Russian court, to block Gazprom Media's decision to hold the extraordinary board meeting today; this legal action failed.

Today, Mr Gusinsky and his team will be hoping that the Russian president echoes his puppet twin and steps in to avert the threat of NTV's destruction, but the chances of life imitating satire look slim. The Kremlin continues to insist that it plays no role in the dispute.

fields.headline: New editor's vision angers Loaded staff
fields.standfirst: Click here to read the leaked Kendrick memo setting out his vision
fields.trailText:
3pm: Keith Kendrick's blueprint for Loaded has been sidelined in response to protests from journalists, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Click here to see Kendrick's vision
fields.body:
A blueprint for Loaded, set out by new editor Keith Kendrick, has been sidelined in response to protests from journalists, who claim he wants to make the magazine more like FHM.

The magazine's managing editor John Aldred is believed to have resigned in protest.

A leaked copy of Mr Kendrick's "vision" for the magazine recommends a series of changes that insiders say go completely against the original spirit of the magazine.

It is believed Mr Kendrick has already conceded some of his ideas may not be appropriate and has backtracked.

But staff are still concerned by some of the suggestions.

Mr Kendrick's original "vision" recommended journalists "write (covers) in advance and features to fit", and suggested the magazine's letters page should be dumped in favour of persuading "friends and friends of friends" to write in.

He is also believed to have considered dropping the long-time Loaded columnists Stan Bowles and Howard Marks, the former marijuana dealer and author.

In a planned section called Badge of Honour, Kendrick suggested a possible role model for Loaded man was a bloke who was robbed by a prostitute he was trying to "pull".

A second role model was a man who "to test his new camcorder, videoed himself masturbating".

He continued: "Said video was then used to tape a christening and then the whole family were treated to a glimpse of some monkey-spanking action."

For another new section idea, University of Life, the editor recommends features on "what to do if a love rival chops your dick off" and "how to dump your girlfriend and make her feel grateful".

Mr Kendrick said the memo, leaked to MediaGuardian.co.uk, was an early brainstorm and did not represent a coherent strategy for the magazine.

"I am still going through the very long and meticulous process of deciding the way forward for Loaded," he explained.

"I've had two-hour-long meetings with each of my new team and their input has been incredible," he said.

Mr Kendrick said the staff were "fiercely passionate about their magazine and we are now meeting collectively to map out the way forward.

"Nothing will be decided about how to progress until I have been through this exhaustive consultation process."

Insiders say they feel the changes will make Loaded less distinctive from other lads' mags.

"The signs are they want to squeeze FHM-style content through the 'Loaded filter'," said one.

"The idea of doing 'ten ways to pull the wool over some poor girl's eyes and then dump her the next day' is against the spirit of what Loaded used to be about," the insider added.

Loaded, which launched in 1993 under editor James Brown, was at the vanguard of lads' magazines.

It was without an editor for almost a year after the departure in early 2000 of Tim Southwell, who left to join the now-defunct internet company Switch2.

Mr Kendrick, who formerly edited Chat, was appointed in February and took the helm two weeks ago.

Mr Brown, who is in the process of launching his own men's magazine, has recently spoken out against the men's sector, declaring it "stale" and "pathetic".

Anger at the changes to Loaded came to a head at the IPC awards, when several members of staff walked out.

Insiders say some journalists felt IPC's inability to nominate Loaded for any awards - despite the period of uncertainty it has undergone - represented a vote of no confidence from management.

Mr Aldred was not available for comment.

Jan 24: IPC in talks with Perry over Loaded role

webTitle: US granted access to grounded spy plane crew

fields.headline: US granted access to grounded spy plane crew
fields.standfirst:
 Crew 'in good condition'
 Envoy says China has searched US aircraft
 China blames US for air crash
Special report: China
fields.trailText: A US diplomat granted access to the 24-member crew of an American spy plane stranded in southern  China said today that they were in good health but offered no clue as to when they might be released.
fields.body:
A US diplomat granted access to the 24-member crew of an American spy plane stranded in southern China said today that they were in good health but offered no clue as to when they might be released.

"They are all doing fine," said General Neal Sealock, the military attache at the US embassy in Beijing.

"Their spirits are high. Our goal is to get them home as soon as possible. We are going to work cooperatively with our counterparts here. We just want to get this thing accomplished as quickly as possible."

The decision by Beijing to allow to grant US diplomats access to the crew marks what the Bush administration hopes is the first step towards the eventual release of the 24 men and women on board, a US official said. The source said the meeting took place after the US diplomats held talks with Chinese officials.

The crew and plane are still being held on the southern Chinese island of Hainan, where they were forced to make an emergency landing on Sunday after colliding with a Chinese jet. The US is demanding that China return the crew and their EP-3E Aries II surveillance plane.

The US ambassador to Beijing, Joseph Prueher, said earlier today that he believed Chinese officials had examined the spy plane, which is crammed with sophisticated surveillance equipment and is said to be the navy's most sophisticated eavesdropping aircraft.

"We are sure that the crew is not on the airplane and we have every reason to think that the Chinese have been all over the airplane," he told US breakfast television.

Mr Prueher said that the US wants a diplomatic solution to the standoff but would offer no apology.

He criticised "these assertions ... from the [Chinese] foreign ministry and the message I have been getting for the last two nights as we have been talking to the Chinese, that the United States is to blame.

"The facts are, our aircraft was operating in international airspace and was on a routine surveillance mission when the collision occurred." As the standoff continued earlier today, the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, demanded an end to spy flights off China's coast and said the US was to blame for the collision between the surveillance plane and a Chinese jet fighter, a government spokesman said.

"The responsibility fully lies with the American side. We have full evidence for that," foreign ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao quoted Mr Zemin as saying this morning.

Beijing also claimed there had been little concern expressed from Washington about the fate of the Chinese pilot, who is still missing after he ejected over the sea.

A senior US defence official said the spy plane's crew had said as it prepared for its emergency landing that it had begun destroying sensitive intelligence-collection equipment and information, in accordance with standard procedures.

Mr Bangzao refused to say whether military officials had already boarded the plane and said that China had the right to investigate.

Speaking at a news conference, Mr Bangzao questioned US assertions that the plane is protected American territory and cannot be boarded without US permission.

"The US airplane, without the authorisation of the Chinese side, illegally entered the Chinese airspace and landed on the Chinese airport," Mr Bangzao said. "There is no question of immunity at all. Therefore, China has all rights to handle this case."

Appearing to mock the American claim that the plane is protected, Mr Bangzao smiled and told reporters: "If this plane is sovereign American territory, how did it land in China?

"Based on Chinese law and international practice, we have the right to conduct an investigation," he said.

The US military argues its plane was on a routine surveillance mission in international air space.

fields.headline: 'Blair Witch Project' the TV show comes to UK
fields.trailText:
9.30am: TV viewers are to be tempted by a real-life Blair Witch Project in which contestants are dumped in a 'haunted' location. By Jason Deans.

Apr 3: Foreign broadcasters flock to BBC's Son of God
fields.body:
First voyeuristic viewers were tempted with Castaway, then Big Brother and more recently Popstars.

Now audiences are to be tempted with a real-life Blair Witch Project in which contestants are dumped in a secret "haunted" location and told to survive for 48 hours without the assistance of TV producers.

The six will have to complete a series of night-time missions to determine if the site really is haunted.

The group will record their experiences with hand-held cameras, giving the show the shaky-frame look of 1999 horror movie hit the Blair Witch Project.

There is no film or other production crew present, only remotely controlled surveillance cameras.

The show, called Fear, is currently running on MTV in America but executives from Mentorn TV are bringing the format to the UK.

It is understood they are in talks with several broadcasters including Channel 4 and Channel 5.

Mentorn, the Television Corportion subsidiary that makes BBC2 show Robot Wars, is also producing a new paintballing show, Crossfire, for Channel 4.

The US version of Fear, which has already gone out on MTV in the UK, was shot in locations including a deserted prison, a haunted house and a derelict military academy.

In the meantime Channel 4 has asked Mentorn to make a 13-part series of Crossfire.

"It's a paintballing war game show," said Mentorn International managing director Mark Rowland.

"Crossfire is Videogames meets Austin Powers. Every week the contestants have to save the world, with a mix of ingeniuty and paint ball guns."

The outfit has also just sold the Robot Wars format to Screentime, the Australian production company behind the Popstars format.

Mentorn and Screentime will co-produce the Australian version of the cult show, which has also recently been sold to Viacom in the US.

webTitle: Cyber terror threatens UK's biggest companies

fields.headline: Cyber terror threatens UK's biggest companies
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Cyber-terrorists have hacked into a third of the country's big companies and public sector organisations, including government offices, causing damage ranging from infiltrating corporate bank accounts to information theft, a survey reveals today.
fields.body:
Cyber-terrorists have hacked into a third of the country's big companies and public sector organisations, including government offices, causing damage ranging from infiltrating corporate bank accounts to information theft, a survey reveals today.

The study, thought to be the first of its kind, found that almost half of the institutions taking part considered that the security breaches, sometimes known as netspionage, posed a significant threat to their survival.

The survey underlines growing fears about the threat of cyber-terrorism and concern that the UK's leading organisations are ill-prepared to cope with the problem.

Last week, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, warned that hacking could cripple Britain faster than a military strike because computers are managing most of the country's infrastructure.

The results of the study will be published by the Communications Management Association (CMA), which is at the forefront of the fight against cyber-terrorism. CMA members, who are strictly vetted, work in the UK's big institutions to help them develop systems to combat hacking.

The CMA asked 172 of its senior personnel to report on incidences of cyber-terrorism in their organisations. Anonymity was guaranteed, though many of the companies involved are household names.

Forty-eight per cent reported that the future of their organisation "could be put at risk by a major network-related security breach", and 60% admitted that hacking posed either a "significant" or "very significant" threat to their survival. Thirty-two per cent admitted being the victim of cyber-terrorism.

Hackers had raided corporate bank accounts, stolen information and been responsible for tax evasion, investment fraud, credit card fraud and sales fraud. Half of the CMA specialists thought their businesses were not prepared to cope with security assaults.

To help tackle the problem, the CMA today launches a new body, the Institute for Communications Arbitration and Forensics, which will urge businesses to give computer security a greater priority.

"Our members are the ones in the frontline, and they represent organisations right across the spectrum," a CAM spokesman said. "These institutions have found they are at very serious risk."

fields.headline: Foreign broadcasters adopt BBC's Son of God
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BBC documentary Son of God has proved an early sales success at the MipTV programming market in Cannes, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC documentary that has created an image of what Jesus's face may have looked like has proved an early sales success at the MipTV programming market in Cannes.

BBC distribution arm BBC Worldwide had sold the documentary to seven European broadcasters before even arriving in Cannes for the start of MipTV and executives are confident of further sales during the five-day event.

Son of God has already been snapped up by Mediaset in Italy and broadcasters in Portugal, Denmark, Norway and Belgium.

Worldwide has also sold BBC1 sitcom Lee Evans - So What Now to eight countries.

The buyers include ABC Australia and broadcasters in Holland, Sweden, South Africa, Spain and Portugal.

fields.headline: Tyrants beware
fields.standfirst:
Incipient Milosevics watch out: there will soon be an international criminal court to contend with

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: After the arrest of Milosevic, let nobody say that a robust policy to promote and protect human rights cannot make a difference.
fields.body:
After the arrest of Milosevic, let nobody say that a robust policy to promote and protect human rights cannot make a difference.

Our policy in the Balkans has made a difference. Two years ago, Milosevic's thugs were terrorising Kosovo. Today he is in jail. The people of Serbia could never have risen against him if Nato had let him become stronger through victory in Kosovo.

The fall of Milosevic is a warning to dictators everywhere that the world is changing and that they cannot expect to escape justice.

Today, the House of Commons has the chance to give a further warning to dictators by giving a second reading to the bill to ratify the statute establishing the international criminal court.

As I argued in a speech last week, we reject the cynical view that a principled policy on human rights is in conflict with the national interest. The national interest is promoted, not hindered, by a commitment to human rights. Democratic governments are more reliable partners for peace and more honest trading partners.

That is why our pursuit of human rights is both principled and practical. And by becoming one of the first states to ratify the ICC statute, we can again be in the international lead on human rights.

The tragic paradox of the last century was that those who murdered one person were more likely to be brought to justice than those who plotted the genocide of millions. There has been nowhere to bring to justice the Idi Amins, the Foday Sankohs or Saddam Husseins. And nowhere for the survivors of their crimes against humanity to seek or obtain redress before the law.

The international criminal tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and for Rwanda were important steps towards righting the great wrongs of history. The creation of an international criminal court will accelerate these efforts.

First, it will help bring to justice those accused of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.

Second, a permanent court will be a permanent deterrent for those contemplating such crimes. They will know that in the future they are not beyond the reach of the law because their crimes were committed during conflict, or because the domestic judicial process has broken down.

Third, the court will promote reconciliation. By focusing criminal responsibility on individuals, it will provide an escape from the cycle of revenge killings which perpetuate ethnic confrontation.

Britain's role in delivering an ICC is already substantial. Our negotiators played an important role in ensuring the crimes would cover internal armed conflict, would include rape and forced recruitment of child soldiers as war crimes, and would provide reparations for victims.

The Rome statute represents the overwhelming determination of the international community to see justice done. In Rome, 120 countries voted for the statute and only seven against. And before the deadline for signature of December 31 2000 even more countries - 139 - had signed. Twenty-nine have ratified to date, including a significant number of Nato allies.

The United States has signed the statute, and shares our determination to carry forward the global fight against war crimes. I hope that with time the US will join its closest ally in ratifying the statute as well and will come to see that its concerns are misplaced.

Concerns about a risk to UK servicemen are based on a misunderstanding. There are safeguards to make sure the court will not proceed with allegations when they are made in bad faith. The ICC will step in only when states are unwilling or unable to investigate. We intend to be both willing and able to demonstrate that there is a remedy in British justice for accusations made against our servicemen. Allegations made against British nationals will be tried in British courts.

The definitions of war crimes in the statute are already reflected in international law and binding on our armed forces. They are part of the well-established law of armed conflict. They are rules which any self-respecting country applies and enforces as part of the discipline and professionalism of its armed forces. And they form part of the basic training of every British army officer.

Today we have the chance to send a clear message to the world's tyrants that they cannot escape justice, and a signal to the world that Britain is a country which stands up for the oppressed, for human rights and for the rule of law. I hope that all sides of the House of Commons will feel able to back the bill. We all have a responsibility to make sure the world does not provide any opening for another Milosevic.

 Robin Cook is the foreign secretary

fields.headline: The rustic idyll is still in our hearts
fields.standfirst: Townies, and even many farmers, are devoted to the countryside
fields.trailText: Townies, and even many farmers, are devoted to the countryside.
fields.body:
There was a discussion on the Radio 4 programme Front Row last Friday between Valentine Cunningham, the professor of English at Oxford, and Oliver Walston, who is always described as an arable farmer, but is on the radio so often that it is hard to imagine how he can devote any time even to that cushy and cushioned end of the agri-business.

They were supposedly discussing the way farmers are depicted in literature, and Professor Cunningham put forward an interesting thesis about how writers (Goldsmith, Hardy, Lawrence etc) used to distinguish between the honest farmer at one with the countryside, and the rich outsiders always muddling in on the side of avarice and "progress".

It was not easy to concentrate on this because Mr Walston, right at the start, made the breathtaking assertion that "no profession, even estate agents, has a worse image among the general public than farmers". He then went on to plead for accuracy and fairness.

We have endured a good deal of piffle over the past few weeks, but this must rank high on the list. During the property crash a decade ago - the estate agents' equivalent of foot and mouth - newspapers did not publish self-pitying diaries by beleaguered young men in boxy double-breasted suits detailing the latest twist in their personal catastrophe:

The vendor of 133 Acacia Avenue just rang. He's been forced to drop the price by 30K. If this goes on, I'll never get that Ferrari Testosterone...

No one cares about politicians either. MPs may now get their salary cheques for five weeks longer than they expected, but some of them are still going to be buried in quicklime soon enough. Except in the most extreme cases (Portillo and Mandelson), MPs and ministers are sucked into the vortex of oblivion with remarkable speed once they lose their seats or their jobs. (Where is John Selwyn Gummer these days? Does anyone know or care? Does he know?)

Journalists have the same problem. If my perfectly healthy pedigree words get culled by the slaughtermen from the sub-editors' department, no one wants to hear me moaning about it.

It's true that there has been a platoon of newspaper columnists who have decided to take the line that the farmers are wretched subsidy-junkies who deserve everything that befalls them. But these voices have been overwhelmed by the opposing army of words and images everywhere else about the tragedy that has befallen the countryside.

There are also urban Guardian readers who write letters demanding to know why there's so much fuss about the farmers when no one cares about the steel workers. Well, if you don't understand why the countryside matters so much to the British, I would respectfully contend that you understand nothing. That may well be doubly true for the smart-arses in Millbank who were allegedly pressing so hard for Tony Blair to go for May 3, farmers be blowed.

Think what fake rusticity even the name "Millbank" implies. The rural idyll is still deep in the national psyche, so much so that farmers may even have become the new military. Every man supposedly thinks the worse of himself if he has not marched to the sound of gunfire. Confronted by all the distraught farmers, I suspect, much of urban Britain feels a little inadequate for their failure to milk a herd of Friesians before Farming Today.

I know farmers who deserve comeuppance: incompetents, corner-cutters, curmudgeons who pretend to rugged independence but spend more time milking the system than the cows, destroyers, polluters, poltroons and aggressively disputatious bastards. I know others whose devotion to their work, their land and their animals is simply amazing in the face of so many discouragements. The second group still outnumbers the first, and most of Britain seems to sense it.

The two groups are not of course wholly mutually exclusive. The second part of Valentine Cunningham's thesis was that the farmers and the outsiders had merged in popular imagery: the custodian and the exploiter were now one and the same. In that, popular imagery is somewhere near the mark; indeed, you might argue there has been a role reversal. It is now the sentimental townie and the quasi-rural incomer who want the countryside preserved, if not how it was in Hardy's day, then at least pickled in the early postwar years, before Dutch elm disease, grants for hedgerow-grubbing, mutant chickens and cannibalistic cows.

Most farmers sold themselves to "progress" long ago. Indeed, the industry - it now transpires - sacrificed itself on its altar. The revival of the British countryside will depend on the rediscovery of a sustainable balance. But there is heck of a lot of national goodwill towards this quest, and politicians under-estimate it at their peril.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Like when watching a child take its first tottering steps, the heart swells on seeing my friend Sir Alan Sugar find the confidence to write for the Mirror sports pages under his own name. Until now, bless him, Alan has generally used a nom de plume ("Harry Harris"), but suddenly he drops the disguise in order to savage George Graham, whom he hired to manage Spurs, as a gutless mercenary.
fields.body:
 Like when watching a child take its first tottering steps, the heart swells on seeing my friend Sir Alan Sugar find the confidence to write for the Mirror sports pages under his own name. Until now, bless him, Alan has generally used a nom de plume ("Harry Harris"), but suddenly he drops the disguise in order to savage George Graham, whom he hired to manage Spurs, as a gutless mercenary.

Alan has learnt to dish it out, it seems (and if he writes like a remedial fifth former trying to parody a Minder script, so what?), but he's not yet brilliant at taking it. You will recall his continual weeping during his libel case against the Mail, and my colleague Marina Hyde rings to ask after rumours that he has been lined up to spearhead a major new TV campaign for Kleenex. "He's abroad now," says his PR Nick Hewer, "but I think you're being led up the garden path on this one." As for messages of goodwill and a promise to maintain his profile now that he has left Spurs, Nick seems unimpressed. "I'm not sure that's a profile that Alan would like maintained." Nonsense. He'll love it.

 Hats off, meanwhile, to Sion Simon, who has always written under his own name even when employed as Alastair Campbell's shorthand typist. After the most relentless campaign of ingratiation political journalism has known, Sion's absence from yesterday's Telegraph presaged the happy news that he has finally been given the safe Labour seat (Birmingham Erdington) he deserves. It may not be easy making chums with suspicious Labour backbenchers for a while, but there is encouragement. Hacks with nostrils barely less brown than his own have managed to mutate into respected public figures. Take Gerald Kaufman to the tea room on your first day, Sion, and he'll tell you all about it.

 Sion is a Turncoat of Turncoats contender, of course, albeit a rank 80-1 outsider in the reformed market Diary pundit Steptoe has made after factoring in for the first time your email votes.The new favourite is Robin Cook at 11-4, but there's little to choose between him, Bomber Short and Peter Hain (both 3-1) and Gus McDonald (4-1). All the others are on the slide, with Kim Howells, Paul Boateng and Barbara Roche at 16-1 and it's 25-1 bar those seven. Votes can be cast at theguardian.com/turncoats.

 It's important that Anglican bishops keep themselves occupied by offering their twopennorth on the issues of the day, but after their strictures on the cruciality of delaying the election we anticipate news that they are also postponing Easter. It's a movable feast, after all, so why not move the bloody thing, perhaps nearer to the middle of August when most of us like to leave Britain for a brief glimpse of the developed world?

 Plans to have Sun editor David Yelland sectioned under the mental health act are revived on reading a leader, headlined Right Again, seeking to taunt the BBC for announcing the election delay a day after the paper. Given the Sun's hilariously cack-handed performance on this, the BBC was wise to wait. As recently as March 26, the paper insisted that any delay would be a calamity for the tourist industry and a general disaster - and now it declares Mr T a hero for waiting five weeks and thus "putting country ahead of party". David, once again we are begging you, talk to someone about it. What possible harm can one nice little talk do?

 A food poisoning conference held by the Public Health Laboratory Service in Colindale, north London, has ended in the usual manner. Of the 78 delegates who attended, Environmental Health News reports, only 30 - and yes, I think you've guessed it - went down with the stomach bug campylobacter. A control team from Barnet health authority believes they were poisoned by their lunch.

webTitle: What Labour has delivered to housing

fields.headline: What Labour has delivered to housing
fields.standfirst: Housing just isn't a political battleground anymore, writes Tim Dwelly. But Labour still has made progress on its 1997 pledges
fields.trailText: Housing just isn't a political battleground anymore, writes Tim Dwelly. But Labour still has made progress on its 1997 pledges.
fields.body:
Political parties haven't competed on council house building since the 1960s. Right to buy is no longer a vote winner. And the space given over to housing in the manifestos has declined as a result.

Labour's election winning 1997 manifesto made hardly any reference to it. But six housing pledges were discernible. Here is how they have progressed:

1: Release capital receipts from right to buy sales.
Done, but no increase in housing spending. The extra money was used to plug the gap left by inherited Tory cuts in Labour's first two years.

2: Abolish compulsory competitive tendering of housing management.
Done, with best value now dominating service delivery across local government.

3: End policies that cause boom-bust in the housing market.
Attempted, but not successful. House prices rose way above inflation, despite £10bn being taken out of the housing market by abolishing Miras and increasing stamp duty. London's price boom has arguably deepened the UK regional divide and led to policies such as key worker mortgages.

4: Protect homeowners with flexible mortgages and new consumer rights.
Moves to give more consumer information about mortgages have been introduced. Attempts to end gazumping and introduce sellers' log books are now in the pipeline.

5: Restore homeless families' rights to secure housing.
Underway in legislation going through parliament with additional help for non-priority groups in low demand areas. But the housing green paper made it clear that quality private renting was an acceptable form of housing for those accepted.

6: License houses in multiple occupation.
Embarrassingly slow progress here but likely to go through in the next parliament.

Often it is the material that is missing from a manifesto that is most illuminating. Labour gave no pledge on investment in new homes and no house building targets. This is just as well, as the record of this government is to have built as many social housing units as the last Conservative administration.

There was also no pledge to slow down the transfer of council homes to housing associations. Again just as well, as transfer has more than doubled under Labour. Labour did not pledge in 1997 to "half house building and double privatisation" but that is what it has done.

Nevertheless, this government's growing interest in social exclusion and regeneration issues may produce more housing-relevant material in the 2001 manifesto.

Meanwhile, one central housing pledge that came after the 1997 manifesto - to put all social housing into decent repair within 10 years - is a dead cert to appear in 2001.

It is hard to identify any major battleground between Labour and the Conservatives. They agree on the following:

 Stock transfer is the way ahead.
 No big increase in new social housing.
 More tenants' choice in housing allocations.
 Applying more pressure on standards to housing associations as well as councils.
 People not bricks-and-mortar based regeneration.
 Crackdown on anti-social tenants.

Most of the differences are based on the pace of change, for example the speed at which remaining council housing is transferred or the extent of remedies available against anti-social tenants. But important differences remain on pushing home ownership for council tenants and blurring the distinction between the private and social landlord sectors.

 This is an edited extract of a report for the Housing Quality Network.

webTitle: Analysis: Whenever the election is held, it will mean fewer women in parliament

fields.headline: Unnatural selection
fields.standfirst:
Whenever the next election is held, one thing is already certain - there will be fewer women in the House of Commons

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The House of Commons will have fewer women members after the next general election than it did in May 1997. We can make such a projection with confidence because of the pattern of selections that has emerged in the past couple of years. Some vacancies remain and some MPs, under pressure from their leadership, will decide to retire at the last minute. But a sufficient number of the selections for the key seats, those that might change hands, have been made for us to establish what the propor tion of women is likely to be in the new house.

We can make such a projection with confidence because of the pattern of selections that has emerged in the past couple of years. But a sufficient number of the selections for the key seats, those that might change hands, have been made for us to establish what the propor tion of women is likely to be in the new house.

The next general election will be fought largely between the Conservatives on the one hand, and Labour and the Liberal Democrats on the other. This configuration of the political battleground might surprise: both Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats are, after all, in opposition to the Blair government. The present polarisation between the Conservatives and the other two main parties reflects the legacy of the 1997 general election. To win office, the Conservatives will have to capture at least 165 seats; Labour and the Liberal Democrats hold most of these. In 1997, Labour won only a couple of seats from the Liberals. At present the party holds only a handful of Liberal Democrat targets. For some of these, moreover, the Liberal Democrats are in third place.

Given their strong showing in 1997, neither Labour nor the Liberal Democrats are likely to capture many seats. For both, the election will be an exercise in damage limitation. The number of seats won by the Conservative party will, therefore, determine the gender composition of the new parliament. In the chart, each point on the x axis gives a likely snapshot of the proportion of women members for the main parties and for the House of Commons overall in the event of the Conservatives recapturing that number of seats. The projection assumes a uniform swing.

The pattern of selections to replace retiring MPs means that in the event of the Conservatives failing to win a single seat the next parliament would have around five fewer women members than in 1997, a proportion of 17.5%. Thereafter, our projection indicates, the percentage of women in the House of Commons falls as the size of any swing to the Conservatives increases. By the time Labour lost its majority, the proportion of women at Westminster would be down to around 15.5%. Should William Hague win an overall majority, that proportion would be less than 15%. At no point does the next parliament match the level set in 1997 of 18.2%.

The chart also gives projections for the main parties. In 1997, women made up 24.2% of the parliamentary Labour party. Given the failure to select women, the proportion of women MPs and candidates in Labour-held seats is now around 23.4%. Many of the women selected by Labour before the 1997 general election were chosen either for target seats or for those already held by the party; the unexpected size of victory did not contribute greatly to the number of women in the PLP. Accordingly, Labour can lose a number of seats without the proportion of women in the PLP changing greatly. Indeed, the distribution between men and women is such that, if the Tories win between 55 and 85 seats, the gender balance of the PLP would improve slightly on that attained in 1997. Thereafter, however, it would decline: by the time the Conservatives won a majority, it could be under 20%.

The declining number of women Labour MPs will be partially offset by a rise in Conservative ones. In 1997, women made up less than 8% of the Conservative presence in parliament. At the next election, given the pattern of selections, a small number of gains by the party would improve that figure. The improvement would, however, be slight: by the time William Hague won his majority, women would make up around 11.5% of Conservative MPs.

The increasing number of Conservative women in parliament will not offset the loss of Labour and Liberal Democratic women. The Liberal Democrats' performance is especially disappointing. They start from a poor position, with only three women MPs out of 47. As the swing to the Conservatives increases, so Liberal Democrat women MPs become more vulnerable. A swing of just over 5% would see two MPs, Jackie Ballard in Taunton and Jenny Tonge in Richmond Park, lose their seats. The remaining female Liberal Democrat MP, Sandra Gidley, took Romsey from the Conservatives at a byelection in 2000 and is also vulnerable. The Liberal Democrats may well come out of the election without a female MP.

Overall, the failure to build on the advances made in May 1997 is manifest. Of the 170 or so contests which will largely determine the next government, more than 100, around 60%, are between men. In these constituencies both the sitting candidate and the most plausible challenger are male. By contrast, in just six of these seats is it possible that a woman will capture a seat from a woman MP (or a female inheritor). For those who claimed that 1997 marked a breakthrough in the political representation of women, our projection provides a bleak picture.

Judith Squires and Mark Wickham-Jones are at the University of Bristol. Their review of women's representation in parliament will be published by the Equal Opportunities Commission later this year.
