webTitle: Chaos in the countryside - but Blair opens up 15 point poll lead

fields.headline: Chaos in the countryside - but Blair opens up 15 point poll lead
fields.standfirst:
Election delay to June gets strong backing
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The government's opinion poll lead over the Conservatives has surged six points to give Tony Blair a commanding lead of 15 points despite growing discontent over its handling of the foot and mouth crisis, according to a Guardian/ICM poll published today.
fields.body:
The government's opinion poll lead over the Conservatives has surged six points to give Tony Blair a commanding lead of 15 points despite growing discontent over its handling of the foot and mouth crisis, according to a Guardian/ICM poll published today.

The ranks of those who disapprove of the way ministers have dealt with the epidemic have grown sharply in the last fortnight by 10 points to 56%. Only 29% are now willing to say they approve of the way it has been handled.

The prime minister's decision to delay local elections until June 7 - which he confirmed yesterday, making it more than likely that the general election will be held on the same day - receives strong backing in the survey. The opinion poll reveals that one in three Labour voters would have liked him to delay even longer.

But Mr Blair yesterday went out of his way to repeatedly stress that he will not "indefinitely suspend the democratic process" beyond June 7. Speaking outside 10 Downing Street, he said: "This is a decision that has to be taken in the interests of the whole country, the parts that don't support the government as well as the parts that do. It is time to unify, not divide, to work together to help the communities most affected.

"Whilst this is going on, I believe it would not be appropriate to hold these elections on May 3.

"But equally we cannot, should not, and will not indefinitely suspend the democratic process. A short postponement for the reasons I have given is one thing. An indefinite delay is quite another."

The six-point surge in Labour's share of the vote compared with the last Guardian/ICM poll a fortnight ago gives Mr Blair a 49% share of the vote. It also confirms that the Conservatives have so far failed to reap any political benefit from the foot and mouth crisis. The Tory party is down one point to 34%, suggesting that it is the lack of any credible alternative which underpins Labour's large lead.

The Liberal Democrats appears to have been the party hardest hit by the crisis, with a three point drop in its share of the vote to 13% which could see its ranks at Westminster cut from 47 to only 20, particularly in their rural strongholds in the south west, mid-Wales and the Scottish borders.

The ICM poll "variometer", which takes account of regional swing, indicates that on these voting shares Labour would be returned with an overall majority of around 150, just 30 seats short of its current Commons majority.

The poll suggests that Mr Blair would have paid a significant price - cutting his lead by a full four points, worth perhaps 25 seats - if he had pushed ahead with a May 3 general election.

The poll, which was carried out on Friday and Saturday, shows that while Mr Blair may have overruled his cabinet and his party in opting for a June general election date, it is very popular among Labour voters. Only 28% of Labour voters say they wanted to see a May election, with 34% picking June and some 30% saying they wanted the election to be held later in the year. Among all voters only 17% backed a May election and 27% the June option. Some 45% wanted it delayed until later in the year.

The lack of a credible alternative is underlined by the politicians' personal ratings. While 85% of Labour voters said they thought Mr Blair would make the best prime minister, only 60% of Tory voters believe William Hague would be best at the job. Among Liberal Democrats only 30% picked Charles Kennedy.

Mr Blair's decision to delay the elections was broadly welcomed, with most ministers and backbenchers backing what they admitted was a difficult judgment call.

"This is about sentiment, psychology and sensitivity, so better a sweet victory in June than a sour one in May," conceded one Millbank veteran.

The prime minister refused to discuss a general election date, but said contests scheduled for 11 unitary authorities and all county councils in England for May 3 would now be postponed until June 7.

All council by-elections scheduled for May 3 or later, and the Northern Ireland district council elections scheduled for May 16, will also be postponed to June 7, Jack Straw, the home secretary, told MPs.

Mr Blair has concluded that the harmful signals which the five-week delay may have on the tourist trade is more than offset by the need to concentrate efforts on getting the crisis under control. There is still no decision on whether or not to vaccinate animals.

Mr Hague welcomed the delay but demanded that it be indefinite because the crisis is unlikely to be resolved by June. "We have already seen over the last six weeks or so that the government don't know, none of us know, how the foot and mouth crisis will develop," he said.

Farmers were divided, as were union leaders, some of whom fear Mr Blair is in dan ger of being bounced into the perils of an October poll.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,000 adults aged over 18 by telephone between March 29-30 2001. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Blair delays elections
fields.standfirst:
Fixed-term parliaments are the answer
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: So now we know. Sort of. After weeks of waiting and wondering, the prime minister finally gave the word yesterday.
fields.body:
So now we know. Sort of. After weeks of waiting and wondering, the prime minister finally gave the word yesterday. There will be no local elections on May 3, he said, thereby confirming the worst kept secret in the land. He did not mention the general election explicitly, but we all knew what he meant. As the Sun informed the nation on Saturday morning, polling day is to be postponed from May 3 - almost certainly to June 7.

There is much to fault in this decision, starting with the manner of its announcement. It is an unfortunate emblem of this administration that Rupert Murdoch's staff learned of Downing Street's change of heart before the cabinet. The substance of the decision is also open to criticism. As we and most of the cabinet argued - in vain, it turns out - delay will send out a message to the wider world that Britain is indeed crippled by a national crisis wreaking a havoc unseen since the war. After all, this is the first suspension of normal democratic rules since 1945. We cannot blame the US television networks if they now tell Americans - including would-have-been tourists - that Britain is off-limits. Tourism is an industry of even bigger value to this country than farming, and we regret that that was not decisive in the prime minister's final calculations.

Whether it will prove the right political decision we will not know until June 8. It is possible that foot and mouth may still be as virulent then as it is now; the delay might make no difference. Or another "event" could come along to buffet Labour; many in the party will spend the next two months remembering the "winter of discontent" that came between Jim Callaghan's decision to delay and the eventual, fateful polling day in May 1979.

Still, that is Mr Blair's decision and the task now is to look ahead. What will happen to this extra month, inserted into the political calendar? The fear among Millbank operatives is that they now have a month to cool their heels, grow restless and make mistakes. That may not matter. As our poll today shows, voters can simultaneously believe the government is mishandling the country's problems and still favour them massively over the Conservative alternative.

So how should Labour use this bonus month? They might eschew four weeks of phoney war pre-campaigning, and instead revive some of the legislation they said they wanted to pass but which got squeezed out through lack of parliamentary time. Labour promised tough regulation of British arms sales abroad: a draft bill is there, so why not make it a real one? Labour could press again for a ban on hunting with dogs, or maybe move to place a legal limit on the number of inmates that can be housed in a single jail. There is so much to do.

But perhaps the smartest move would be to give government time to Tony Wright's private member's bill calling for fixed-term parliaments. He suggests an automatic dissolution every four years, unless elections are triggered by a Commons vote of no confidence. This is a longstanding demand: the Chartists called for annual elections. The length of term, five or four years, can be debated but the principle is surely right. It cannot make sense to have this lengthy period of uncertainty and indecision grip the last 18 months of every government. Nor is it fair to hold a running race in which one of the competitors fires the starting gun. Dr Wright is right and the government now has the time his bill needs. Surely Mr Blair won't stand in his way: the last month must have taught him that the solo power to call an election can be as much a burden as a blessing.

webTitle: Two-party disharmony with the Tory glee club

fields.headline: Two-party disharmony with the Tory glee club
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: I have never seen the Tories look happier than they did yesterday afternoon, when Jack Straw announced that the local elections - in which we include the general election but are not allowed to say so - are going to be postponed. There is to be a bill which will put this into law. It'll be called the Bottling Out (Miscellaneous Provisions) 2001 Order. Or possibly not.
fields.body:
I have never seen the Tories look happier than they did yesterday afternoon, when Jack Straw announced that the local elections - in which we include the general election but are not allowed to say so - are going to be postponed. There is to be a bill which will put this into law. It'll be called the Bottling Out (Miscellaneous Provisions) 2001 Order. Or possibly not.

Even David Willetts devoted at least one of his brains to laughing uproariously at the announcement. Mrs Angela Browning, whose normal expression resembles a glum wildebeest who's just spotted a peckish lion, was suffused with giggles.

John Redwood rocked gently with happiness. Eric Forth's tie, a modest effort of only six or seven colours, seemed to wink at us as he too rolled about in pleasure. And Ann Widdecombe does a wonderful fake laughter turn. She throws back her head, waves her arms in the air, and opens her mouth as wide as you do at the dentist, in order to imply that she might otherwise implode with the sheer effort of keeping all that hilarity inside.

The net effect was rather as if Edvard Munch, painter of The Scream, had been asked to design a special souvenir Teletubby.

I can't imagine why. Five minutes after this session ended, we saw the result of the latest ICM poll in the Guardian, which shows that the Labour lead is back up again. The Tories were thus in the position of turkeys hearing that Christmas has been postponed, but by only five weeks.

The sole Tory frontbencher who seemed to me to get the right mood was Mr Portillo, who arrived late, sat down and promptly fell asleep.

Jack Straw read out his statement sombrely, trying to imply by his mien that all the merriment was as unseemly as a whoopee cushion at a funeral. It didn't work. When he talked gravely about "the scale of representations we have received", a Tory yelled "Eat it slowly, Jack!"

When he declared: "As my rt. hon. friend the prime minister has now made clear," in the manner of a biblical scholar imparting the contents of a newly discovered fifth gospel, they hooted and jeered and yelped.

Next it was the turn of Miss Widdecombe, whose own bid for the ultimate glory has also been set back five weeks. Happily for us, she seems to have relinquished her desire to appear a dignified and thoughtful statesperson. This time we got an old-fashioned, copper-bottomed, double-riveted rant. She was magnificent.

Everything the government had done had been demanded by the Tories much earlier, she screeched. The prime minister's own press secretary had flatly declared there would be no postponing the election. I thought the points she made were perfectly good, though the Labour benches - most of them privately aghast at Mr Blair's decision - decided to pretend they were evidence of outright lunacy. As their jeering and hooting grew louder, the Speaker intervened, as usual a little too late to be effective.

"The hon. lady is entitled to be heard," he remonstrated. To be heard? You might as well stand near a Heathrow runway saying: "Hush, I want to hear this jumbo jet land."

Jack Straw responded with the soft answer which only increaseth wrath. "I think the gravamen of what she said was that we should defer the elections indefinitely..."

Gravamen! There's a $15 word for you. Now I know what Cyril Connolly meant when he (almost) titled his famous book The Unquiet Gravamen.

webTitle: Search for the oldest swingers in town

fields.headline: Search for the oldest swingers in town
fields.standfirst: Only over-50s need apply for the latest manufactured pop group
fields.trailText: Calling all wannabe Tom Joneses. What the nation - and Britain's pop industry - needs is not a boy band but an over-50s man band, writes Sarah Hall.
fields.body:
Calling all wannabe Tom Joneses. What the nation - and Britain's pop industry - needs is not a boy band but a man band.

That at least is the message being pushed by Kizzi Nkwocha, a PR guru, famed for representing the octuplet mother Mandy Allwood and one of Bill Clinton's ex-lovers, and who is in the process of manufacturing "the world's first man band".

Adverts have been placed in The Stage and Music Week for Boyzone and Westlife's more mature alter egos and, in a week, nearly 2,500 would-be pop stars have responded.

The criteria are simple: they must possess "real musical ability" and, in a riposte to the cult of youth, they must be at least 50.

With the successful five due to be filmed for a Popstars style documentary, and rival record companies apparently primed to battle for the more mature ensemble, Mr Nkwocha is convinced Man-Band will fill an untapped niche in the ruthlessly competitive mainstream pop market.

"At the moment you can only buy what you're offered by the record companies and all that is a constant stream of Boyzones and Westlifes, bands which are quickly forgotten," he said. "What we're doing is investing in people with genuine ability, genuine talent and experience. We are looking for the hidden Tom Joneses, the pop stars who may have been overlooked because of the obsession with boy bands."

Many of those who applied had tried to pursue careers in music in their youth, but the publicist denied the band would comprise a bunch of failures. "Unfortunately, just being talented isn't enough in an industry that's imitative rather than innovative," he said.

Successful band members could be as old as 70, but he is adamant there will be no pipe and slippers image.

"We're going to appeal to the same sort of market as Tom Jones - from those in their twenties upwards - and those we choose will have the same sort of sex appeal as him or as Mick Jagger. They're going to have that indefinable quality that makes them stand out."

Some in the music industry were less than enthusiastic.

"I think it's a terrible idea," said Smash Hits acting editor John Hindmarch. "The reason boy bands do so well is because the age group they appeal to are the ones that buy the records. This sounds like a novelty thing, a PR stunt."

Paul Trynka, editor of Mojo, said: "The idea of manufacturing a band of 50-year-olds is bizarre. The whole point of boy bands is that they're 19 and 20-year-olds straight out of stage school who haven't had their chance to make a mark but here you'll have five failed 50-year-olds.

"Obviously if someone can get a huge amount of free publicity, as Hear'Say did with Popstars, it might have an effect. But younger fans are quite happy with bands that are fresh and by the time most people are in their fifties their musical tastes are more sophisticated than pop so I can't see them going for them.

"It's great that this is going against the normal trend of ageism, but I can't help thinking genuine mature talent and the idea of a manufactured band aren't very good bedfellows."

webTitle: Parties rush to cancel costly posters for hold-up

fields.headline: Parties rush to cancel costly posters for hold-up
fields.standfirst:
Town halls face £4m bill for polls hold-up
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Political parties are in urgent talks with advertising agencies to see if they can extricate themselves from expensive poster campaigns. By Patrick Wintour and Lucy Ward.
fields.body:
Local government is facing a £4m bill and the political parties a similar sized financial headache, following the decision to delay the local and general elections by a month.

The two big political parties yesterday started urgent talks with advertising agencies and the outdoor poster market to see if they could extricate themselves from expensive, and now badly mistimed, poster campaigns.

Local parties will also be checking the rules with the electoral commission to ensure they do not overspend on the general election.

In the Commons, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said he was considering allowing political parties to spend an extra 50% in the local elections because of the delay. He rejected calls from Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, for cash for political parties to compensate for printing local election literature urging people to vote on May 3.

The national party machines will be seeking talks with three big poster site firms - JC Decaux, Maiden Outdoors, and Mills and Allen. The parties fear they could face substantial cancellation fees if they pull out of the poster campaigns theybooked for the middle two weeks of April.

The parties also face the danger that late rescheduling will mean new poster campaigns in mid-May being sited in "back alleys", instead of mostly at premium sites on the main roads.

Jeremy Mail, chief executive of JC Decaux, said that penalties normally kick in if a client pulls out of a booked advertising campaign. Penalties across the industry are set at 90% of the planned cost if a client pulls out within a month of delivery.

Mr Mail said: "If any company fails to gets its product to market on time, then the firm may want an advertising campaign to be postponed. We cannot bear the cost of that, but if we can find someone else to take all or some of the sites, we will take that properly into account."

Mr Mail said outdoor poster advertising was buoyant at present, making it difficult for poster firms to readily find, at such short notice, premium sites for the political parties in the run up to a June 7 election.

With the US economy downturn, advertising generally in Britain is on the decline. Television advertising is thought to be down between 5% and 10%. By contrast, in the first four months of the year outdoor advertising was buoyant and is expected to have risen 10% on the previous year.

Advertising industry sources are predicting that the political parties will plan to take up only between 10% and 15% of total advertising outdoor sites - which could mean 3,500 to 4,500 poster sites. By comparison in the final two weeks of the 1997 general election there were 3,700 Conservative posters on 48 sheet hoardings, as opposed to Labour's 2,600.

The lower numbers in part reflects the caps on electoral spending introduced by the political parties, referendums and elections act. The act placed a limit of £14.8m on the parties if the election takes place in May, but this rises to £15.8m in June.

Local councils were yesterday told they would be compensated for costs they say could reach £4m as a result of postponing the local elections until June 7.

As individual authorities warned the costs of deferral could rise as high as £100,000, Mr Straw said that emergency legislation to postpone the elections would also hand the government powers to reimbursefor extra administration expenses.

Mr Straw also told MPs in a Commons statement that, in recognition of the possibility that some council candidates may incur costs as a result of the postponement - for example though re-printing election literature - the legal limit on their expenses would be raised by half.

The Local Government Association last night welcomed the arrangements, after its own initial survey of the 34 English county councils and 11 English unitary authorities affected, suggested that wasted spending would total between £2m and £4m.

Councils have paid out for printing of ballot papers and other election literature and for hiring of premises for use as polling stations.

webTitle: Hague fails to prosper from farming crisis

fields.headline: Hague fails to prosper from farming crisis
fields.standfirst:
Tories still not seen as viable alternative
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Perhaps the most startling finding in this Guardian/ICM opinion poll is how little the Conservatives have benefited politically from the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Perhaps the most startling finding in this Guardian/ICM opinion poll is how little the Conservatives have benefited politically from the foot and mouth crisis.

The one point drop in the Conservative share of the vote to 34% compared with a similar Guardian/ICM poll a fortnight ago suggests that whatever the voters think about Labour's handling of the foot and mouth crisis, William Hague's Conservative party is not seen as a viable alternative. This is reflected in the fact that only 60% of Tory voters name Mr Hague for their choice of prime minister.

At first sight the 15 point lead for Labour may seem to be out of line with recent ICM polls. But Labour enjoyed a similar lead in February before the crisis really began to bite. Tony Blair's lead dropped to 9 points in the third week of March when a majority of voters were also saying he should delay the election.

About half of the people polled in this ICM survey were telephoned on Saturday and Sunday when the radio and television were already pumping out the message that Mr Blair was believed to have decided to delay until June.

It may be that while they didn't necessarily approve of the way the epidemic had been handled, the government was seen to respond to the most important demand, ie that the election be delayed.

For the Liberal Democrats, who had not fallen below the 15% mark since October 1997, the poll marks particularly dismal reading. On ICM's "variometer" which takes account of regional swing the Liberal Democrats' band of 47 MPs would be reduced to only 20 on this showing. Many Lib Dem seats are concentrated in areas most affected by the foot and mouth epidemic such as the south west, mid-Wales and the Scottish borders.

The fact that only 30% of Liberal Democrat voters see Charles Kennedy as making the best prime minister and 24% of them think Tony Blair does a better job may reflect the low profile of the party during the last fortnight.

What if Tony Blair had pressed ahead and announced yesterday that the election was going to be on May 3? The poll shows that some 9% of Labour voters would probably have decided not to vote for the party. The indications from the poll is that the price that Mr Blair would have paid for appearing so callous to the farmers would have been somewhere in the region of four points off his lead, putting Labour on 46% and the Conservatives on 35% - a difference of about 20 to 25 seats.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of adults aged over 18 by telephone between March 29-30, 2001. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Donations revealed ahead of campaign
fields.standfirst:
Most will be named on May 2

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Many donors who have secretly bankrolled Labour and the Conservatives to the tune of £28m for the coming campaign will be named on May 2 in advance of the deferred election.
fields.body:
Many donors who have secretly bankrolled Labour and the Conservatives to the tune of £28m for the coming campaign will be named on May 2 in advance of the deferred election.

The electoral commission - the body set up to monitor party donations and campaign spending - has decided to go ahead with plans to publish at the beginning of May all donations received between mid-February and April 30.

If the election had been held on May 3 the public would have been told a day before polling who had bankrolled whom.

Now for the first time most of the major donors will be revealed before the election campaign begins.

Under the rules any national donation totalling £5,000 or more in cash or kind will be published plus any donation above £1,000 given to a local constituency party. The donor's name and amount will be released.

A number of prominent millionaire donors such as Lord Sainsbury, publishers Christopher Ondaatje and Lord Hamlyn, who backed Labour to the tune of £2m each and Stuart Wheeler, owner of the IG Index, the spread betting firm, who has given £5m to the Conservatives, declared earlier this year.

They form only a small part of the donations made to the parties.

Ironically a decision to hold a general election on June 7 will mean that donors wanting to avoid scrutiny until the end of August could give money between May 1 and May 13 and not have to declare the cash immediately.

The disclosure of weekly donations during the campaign will not begin until May 22, since this campaign provision cannot be implemented until Mr Blair announces the disolution of parliament, widely expected now on May 14.

fields.headline: Emap Fashion set for overhaul
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Two of the oldest trade magazines, Drapers Record and Menswear, could soon merge, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Emap Fashion is gearing up for an overhaul that could lead to the merger of two of the publishing industry's oldest trade magazines, Drapers Record and Menswear.

The company is currently conducting research to establish whether there is still demand for two separate magazines for the women's and men's fashion industries.

Menswear editor Peter Barton said Emap Business Media launched research in December, which had yet to be concluded.

"There's a fair bit of anecdotal evidence that people want a single magazine for the two sections of the industry," he said. "If that's what the market is saying, then that's what we are going to do.

"We are finding that a large number of people are working across the men's and women's fashion industries."

Drapers Record, which is 114 years old, and Menswear, which is in its 100th year, are two of the most established magazine brands in the marketplace.

Mark Rolfe, publisher of Emap Fashion who joined just six weeks ago, said it was "highly unlikely" the names would be changed.

He added that any changes to the department were likely to increase the output, and there was little possibility of a scaling back of resources.

He refused to speculate on the possibility that Menswear could go weekly, but said "there are key benefits to having a greater frequency in that market".

webTitle: Count goes ahead later this month

fields.headline: Count goes ahead later this month
fields.standfirst: Operation can be managed 'without risk'
fields.trailText: The government pressed ahead yesterday with plans for a national census on April 29 in spite of the decision that local elections should not be held on May 3 because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
The government pressed ahead yesterday with plans for a national census on April 29 in spite of the decision that local elections should not be held on May 3 because of the foot and mouth crisis.

Len Cook, national statistician for England and Wales, said census forms would be delivered to every household by 70,000 enumerators who would be alert to local precautions to avoid spreading the disease.

If necessary, the forms would be sent by post or handed over at the end of farm lanes, and in exceptional circumstances householders would be able to complete the questions by telephone. Similar arrangements were being put in place for Scotland and Northern Ireland.

Mr Cook said the decision to go ahead had been reviewed every week since the start of the epidemic, but there was never any reason to doubt the operation could be managed without risk.

Unlike local elections that were held on a single day, collection of census data could be spread over a longer period. "If necessary the deadline for returning forms will be extended," he said.

Mr Cook was asked why it was more dangerous for people in affected areas to vote by post than to receive and send back census forms by post. He said he was not responsible for local elections, but the census arrangements were approved by the Ministry of Agriculture and National Farmers' Union.

"Senior census officials last week visited teams in the regions worst affected by foot and mouth. They confirmed the practicality of the special arrangements for delivering census forms in rural areas where there are restrictions.

"I am certain that, with these arrangements in place, the census can be carried through without danger of contributing to the spread of the disease," he said.

Graham Jones, census director, said: "At the end of every farm lane there is a phone number, put there under Maff advisory restrictions. We'll be able to phone the farmer to check how he'd like the form to be delivered, or whether to complete via telephone if that was necessary," he added.

For the first time the census will include a voluntary question about religious beliefs. Mr Cook said the census would cost £250m. A campaign to advertise the 10-yearly event was launched yesterday.

fields.headline: Granada wins custody of ITV.com
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV has ended a 12-month battle to wrest the domain name ITV.com from a rival, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
ITV can finally launch a website with its name after concluding a 12 month battle to wrest the domain name ITV.com from a rival.

It is understood it paid £100,000 to buy the name from an executive who had registered the name in 1994.

The deal, sealed at the weekend, means ITV can press ahead with its global dot.com strategy.

The network\s inability to use the domain name had became something of an embarrassment for ITV executives, who could talk about ITV.com but didn't have any rights over the name.

Granada Media bought the domain name from Nick Rosen, director of the Online Research Agency.

He had planned to develop the site into an interactive TV website before he was approached by Granada Media last year.

Justin Judd, online controller for Granada Broadband, refused to confirm how much ITV had paid, but said it had been a "reasonable price".

Asked why there was now nothing on ITV.com, he said: "We're considering the next step now and are thrashing out the global strategic direction with ITV partners."

Mr Judd hinted that ITV.com would have different content and a different strategy from the existing ITV website, ITV.co.uk, which launched its first Who Wants to be a Millionaire? online game today.

Granada Media and Carlton Communications, the two largest ITV companies, have, until now, pursued their own disparate internet strategies.

Tthey decided last year that in order to compete on the global stage and take on the likes of bbc.co.uk, they would have to bury the hatchet and work together in ITV's common interest.

Now they own ITV.com, Carlton and Granada will be able to develop a single, focused ITV website to give them more clout.

Granada and Carlton's internet strategies have so far received muted reactions.

Carlton developed a number of strong web brands - Jamba, Popcorn and SimplyFood - but has since moved SimplyFood into Taste.co.uk, its joint venture with Sainbury's, and focused more on Carlton.com.

Granada went cold on G-wizz almost immediately following its launch, and finally shut it down last week.

webTitle: Council leaders split over polls timing delay

fields.headline: Council leaders split over polls timing delay
fields.standfirst:
Straw outlines moves to switch elections date; opposition welcomes news as Labour bows to pressure

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Straw outlines moves to switch elections date; opposition welcomes news as Labour bows to pressure.
fields.body:
Council leaders were yesterday split over Tony Blair's decision to defer all elections and byelections until June 7, with some demanding a longer delay to give more time to conquer the foot and mouth epidemic.

As farmers and the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats welcomed the decision to postpone the local polls - in line with their own demands - pressure remained on Mr Blair to delay the elections indefinitely until the outbreak is brought under control.

John Glanvill, a farmer and deputy leader of Lib Dem-controlled Devon county council, said: "If the existing scenario remains in place come June then I would have hoped that the legislation [to defer the elections] would allow some extension to allow further delay. I would suggest that the chances are 90% that the status quo would still apply for the relevant period for a June election."

While the Tories press for an indefinite postponement, Labour figures in local government are fiercely resisting any further delay, having reluctantly come to accept that Mr Blair's decision to bow to pressure and defer local polls by a month from May 3 has gone down well with voters, including Labour supporters.

Sir Jeremy Beecham, Labour chairman of the Local Government Association, told Radio 4's Today programme he would still have preferred a May 3 poll. Many Labour activistsare frustrated at the thought of a 10 week run-up to polling day.

Stewart Young, leader of Labour-controlled Cumbria county council who has previously argued for May elections to avoid scaring off more tourists, said he had come round to the view that the polls should be deferred until June. "It's a very finely balanced judgement but I think he [Mr Blair] has got it right," he said. "But it should not go later than June, or we will be into summer holidays. There is no way we should have poll in the autumn."

The National Farmers' Union president, Ben Gill, said many farmers would find the June 7 date more acceptable. He said in a statement: "Our priority remains to rein in this disease. We are beginning to see some improvements in the control of foot and mouth disease, but there is still a very long way to go."

In a Commons statement yesterday, the home secretary, Jack Straw, outlined plans to bring in emergency legislation to delay the May 3 elections in 34 English county councils and 11 English unitary authorities until June 7. The elections bill, to be debated tomorrow and rushed though in what could be an all-night sitting, will also provide for the delay of elections in 26 district councils in Northern Ireland - due on May 16 - and for any district and borough council byelections due between May 3 and June 7 to be postponed until the same date.

The deferred date could not be later than June 7, Mr Straw told MPs, because longer delay could leave some councils changing political control if councillors stood down and elections were not held to replace them.

As farmers and the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats welcomed the decision to postpone the local polls - in line with their own demands - pressure remained on Mr Blair to delay the elections indefinitely until the outbreak is brought under control. fields.headline: Take two
fields.standfirst: As a child in Taiwan, Edward Yang fell in love with the movies. As a young man in California, he decided he'd rather make computers. With Yang's new film about to open in Britain, Duncan Campbell finds out what convinced him to follow his dream
fields.trailText: As a child in Taiwan, Edward Yang fell in love with the movies. As a young man in California, he decided he'd rather make computers. With Yang's new film about to open in Britain, Duncan Campbell finds out what convinced him to follow his dream.
fields.body:
This year, as every year, the New York Times listed its critics' choices of the films and directors that should have been in the running for an Oscar. Two of the three nominations were for Edward Yang and his film A One and a Two (Yi Yi). Few people who have seen the film would question those nominations. The New York Times found it "sublime", the LA Weekly described it as "a quiet masterpiece of emotion" and when it was shown recently in cinemas in LA people burst into applause at the end.

A One and a Two is the story of a Taiwanese family experiencing the punctuation marks of life from birth to marriage to death. It deals with romance and rejection, jealousy and disappointment, optimism and alienation. Central to the film is a dying grandmother, whom the family have been encouraged to talk to even though it is not clear if she can understand what they are saying, and a small boy who likes to take photographs of the backs of people's heads so they can see the half of life they normally miss.

This is Yang's seventh film but the first to have a proper international film release and the one that may finally bring his work to wider audience. Born in China in 1947, Yang moved with his family to Taiwan as a child and was fortunate that his father was a film buff. "My dad grew up in Shanghai and loved to go to the movies," says Yang, a self-effacing man, sitting in a Beverly Hills coffee bar. "It was quite expensive and unusual, so every time I went I would tell my schoolfriends what I had seen and then I started to draw the films so that more people could see them. After that, I started to make up sequels and my own stories."

At the time Yang was growing up, Taiwan was anxious to forge good diplomatic relations and would distribute the kind of European films that might not oth erwise have been seen there. "I remember I went with my sister to [Federico Fellini's] 8, and only she and I and two bar-girls were there. The two bar-girls would keep complaining and saying, 'I can't understand the story.' We were lucky - Robert Bresson's films were commercially released in Taiwan, too. None of my French friends believe me when I tell them."

As a young man, Yang moved to the US to study electrical engineering at the University of Florida. His fascination with cinema took him to the University of Southern California to study film. But he dropped out and worked in computer design for the next seven years. "I had given up and said, 'I am not built for becoming a film-maker,' until one night when I was driving downtown in Seattle and saw this sign outside a cinema saying 'German New Wave: Aguirre, the Wrath of God' [the 1972 Werner Herzog film]. I went in and that turned me around."

He decided there and then that he had to, as they would say in Hollywood, pursue his dream. "I was telling this story later to a friend in San Francisco during the film festival there and my friend said 'Turn around' and there was Werner Herzog. We became good friends."

A friend from film school had already started to direct in Taiwan and knew that Yang had a lot of stories from the days when they drew comic books together. Yang returned to his home territory and gave up computers for ever. "Mum was really up set," he smiles, "but it was something I really wanted to do."

After working in television for a while, he made his own films. That Day, on the Beach (1983), Taipei Story (1985) and The Terroriser (1986) all won him critical admiration but his breakthrough came in 1991 with A Brighter Summer Day. Set in the 1960s, with a cold war backdrop, the four-hour film told the story of a teenager who falls in love with the girlfriend of a gang leader. Two satires, A Confucian Confusion (1994) and Mahjong (1996), followed. In the meantime his compatriot Hou Hsiao-Hsien had also been carving his own niche, making Cute Girl in 1980 and winning the critics' award at the 1986 Berlin festival for The Time to Live and the Time to Die (1985).

Did they see themselves as part of a movement, a Taiwanese New Wave? "In the beginning, it was a collective effort. Our generation was taking over and there was a new, more energetic kind of film-making. But after we made a name for ourselves we had different directions to go in, and in the last 10 years it has been pretty much individual efforts."

A One and a Two has been in gestation for more than a decade, its origins lying in a friend's dying relative. He was in a coma but the doctors felt he might benefit if people addressed him as if he could understand everything. "It was quite overwhelming to me to talk to the person pretending he's normal. In that kind of situation you have to be very honest not just to him but to yourself. That was in the 1980s but I knew I was too young to make the film then." Yang was then in his late 30s. "I let it sit in my head so that all the details came in and settled, and when I finally proposed the story [to the film's Japanese backers] two years ago, I felt I was ready."

One of the film's most memorable parts involves the obser vations of the small boy, played unselfconsciously by Jonathan Chang. "I didn't think that much about that part over the years. Most of the details developed during the writing because basically that character is the foundation of all the other characters, someone we all once were. Most of the people I talk to share similar feelings, whether they are men or women. I think we were all once that way, with all kinds of questions, and we didn't know which one was more philosophical than the other because we didn't have answers to any of them."

Yang gives credit to his largely unknown cast for the success of the film. "The writing doesn't stop at the script; that's a blueprint. There is still room with actors to accommodate their strengths and avoid their weaknesses. It's like a building - it has to be built under one concept or it doesn't work. Taiwan does not have a big pool of actors, and Jonathan was only seven at the time and I was looking for a 10-year-old. But he caught my casting director's eye and he said, 'Take a look at this kid.' I said 'Gee!' I was worried whether he would understand the things I would ask him to do but he was so smart."

While Yang's work has always found a responsive audience in Taipei, Europe was the first territory overseas to welcome it. "The London Film Festival in 1983 was the first moment that Taiwan's new cinema got a chance to be exposed to the world. I did one segment of a film done by four young film-makers that was invited to the festival and I hand-carried the tapes to London . . . After that, I think people realised what was happening and Derek Malcolm [the Guardian's film critic at the time] came to Taipei."

Japan followed suit. But it took years before the west was prepared to give proper releases to Asian films that were not exclusively concerned with martial arts. The success of Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Wong Kar-Wai's In the Mood for Love may push the doors wider open.

Yang is interested in exploring the world that the new technologies have created. "We have more and more things in common than in the past, especially in the cities. In the last 10 years, I [have become] more familiar with the streets of Tokyo and Hong Kong and some parts of Paris and LA than the rural areas of my own country." He has finished a script about "a young kid who travels the world with just a cellphone and a credit card. Those two things are all you need now. It's a new world and there are a lot of stories we can tell each other."

The success of A One and a Two has already led to new offers. "I feel like an athlete - all these clubs seeing if you would like to join the team. There are new possibilities but I think it depends on whether my style fits into their game - and if it does, it's wonderful." There had been approaches before, but at the time he felt that in Hollywood it was "bankers making the decisions". He believes that it is easier now for an independent film-maker to have control, and mentions David Lynch and Quentin Tarantino as two directors whose work he admires.

Yang hopes now to make a film in Seattle and, with the kind of budget previously unavailable to him, a second world war story set in Taiwan. His homeland's ambiguous geo-politics is a constant preoccupation for Taiwanese film-makers. "That's part of the reality so when you do a film that is genuine or authentic it has to have that element. I am an optimistic person. I think something positive will come out of this situation . . . there are a lot of things in common between [China and Taiwan] if we set aside the old ideologies."

Like the small boy with the camera in A One and a Two, Yang seems now to be in the perfect position to use film to show people the parts of their lives that they normally miss.

 A One and a Two is released on Friday.

fields.headline: All dressed up
fields.standfirst:
What does yesterday's announcement of an election postponement mean for prospective candidates? In the first of a series of campaign diaries, Paul Richards, Labour prospective parliamentary candidate for Lewes, shares his thoughts

Ask Aristotle about Lewes
fields.trailText: What does yesterday's announcement of an election postponement mean for prospective candidates? In the first of a series of campaign diaries, Paul Richards, Labour prospective parliamentary candidate for Lewes, shares his thoughts.
fields.body:
As a loyal Labour candidate I must naturally applaud the prime minister's brave decision to delay the elections. It shows statesmanship and a concern for the country. It also, in the words of a friend of mine standing for a Yorkshire seat, "pisses on our chips". That the election was to be on May 3 was the worst kept secret in politics. Everyone was ready - party machines, candidates, the media, even some voters had noticed an election was on the way.

Now all the election plans and media grids are worthless. It's back to the drawing board. I pity the campaign strategists at Millbank Tower and Smith Square who must now re-invent their campaigns - rebook poster sites, reprint leaflets, re-arrange photo opportunities, rehire helicopters and battle busses. It will cost the political parties millions in lost deposits and extra staffing costs.

But in the constituencies, local campaign plans have also been laid waste by the prime minister's decision. As a candidate, my campaign was prepared with the precision of D-Day. My campaign grid was carefully structured, my visits to schools and old people's homes all in the diary, my visits to Lewes, Newhaven, Seaford and Polegate were eagerly anticipated.

Like an expectant father, I had a suitcase packed all ready for the starting gun last Monday. I would have been down on the train from my home in London to Lewes the moment Tony Blair asked the Queen for a dissolution of parliament. My "Vote Labour on May 3rd" leaflet was designed and ready for printing.

We had teams on standby to leaflet the railway stations as people came home from work, as instructed by the official Labour Party Final Countdown document issued to all candidates. The kind Cornwall family who volunteered to put me up for the campaign month had left the key under the mat.

Like everyone else, including most of the cabinet, I first learned about the possible delay from the Sun on Saturday. I saw the headlines as I made my way from Clapham Junction to Lewes early on Saturday morning, as I have every other Saturday for six months. But even then I doubted whether it was correct. John Stockdale, my brilliant campaign manager, asked me over breakfast in a cafe on Lewes High Street whether I believed it was true. We were putting the final touches to our plan. I had just handed him a newsletter for printing with "Vote Labour on May 3rd" as the headline. I gave him my "I really know what's going on" look, and said it was all a bluff. I had a meeting scheduled for Monday evening with a member of Labour's Millbank staff - who had cancelled, with a nod and a wink, at the last minute "to keep Monday clear". As the people of Lewes came up to our band of leafleters in the street during the morning I repeated the same line - it'll be May. I've never been so sure of anything in my life.

Indeed it wasn't until Saturday night, as my wife Sarah and I relaxed with friends for the last weekend before the election, when the BBC reports started to back up the Sun's story. Finally a friend "in the know" sent me a text message to my mobile at around 10pm confirming that it was gospel, because Alastair Campbell was saying so. I had a very large glass of port, and started to assess the level of chaos it would cause.

Now, we must wait until at least June. I had a holiday with the wife booked for May 4 (it's only a long weekend and I'm still going to take it!). My election agent Arthur Hammond will be away in May because he - like everyone else - was planning for a May 3 polling day. Many others will have booked time off work for campaigning, and booked holidays as their reward straight afterwards. Local parties will have been spending their election war chests on the assumption of a May 3 poll. Now the stretched resources of the local parties must be stretched even further.

We are entering a period of frustration and phoney war. Tony Blair cannot, as yet, officially announce the general election for the June 7, the new date for the local elections - that would officially start the election. The last thing we need is a two-month election campaign. John Major tried a six-week campaign in 1997, and people were so bored by the end, turnout slumped to the lowest since 1935. If the Labour Party is worried about apathy and Labour voters staying at home, a long drawn out campaign from April to June would be a disaster. So we must continue to conduct our voter ID (knocking on doors to identify party supporters) and street stalls until mid-May, when I hope the prime minister will call the election for June 7. If ever there was a case for fixed term parliaments, the foot and mouth election of 2001 must surely be it.

 Paul Richards is Labour prospective parliamentary candidate for Lewes and author of 'How to Win an Election - the art of political campaigning'.

webTitle: Abduction claim by internet twins' parents

fields.headline: Abduction claim by internet twins' parents
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The saga of the twins adopted by a British couple via the internet took another twist yesterday when it emerged that the babies' natural parents had asked for them to be declared abducted under the Hague convention.
fields.body:
The saga of the twins adopted by a British couple via the internet took another twist yesterday when it emerged that the babies' natural parents had asked for them to be declared abducted under the Hague convention.

Lawyers for the parents, the Americans Tranda and Aaron Wecker, have asked the official solicitor's child protection office to deal with their request.

The news came as Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the UK couple at the centre of the transatlantic legal wrangle, returned to the high court in London to continue their fight to win custody of the nine-month-old girls.

It also emerged yesterday that Max Clifford, the PR consultant, has offered to help the parents, who have come under fire for speaking in public about the case after promising that they would not do so.

The latest hearing, which could last all week, is taking place in private but a spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's Department said that the natural parents, who are estranged and taking action separately, wanted the babies declared abducted.

The US and Britain have signed up to the Hague convention on intercountry adoption, which was designed to set guidelines for international adoptions and restrict child trafficking and fraud. If an application under the convention is successful, the children will have to be returned in the first instance to their home country.

Strict security measures were arranged yesterday to ensure no leaks from the latest hearing. Security guards searched the couple, as well as lawyers and officials entering court, to prevent recording equipment being smuggled in. An usher taped paper to the window in the door of the court to obstruct the view.

fields.headline: Bush faces EU wrath over snub to Kyoto deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: A European Union delegation was given a cool reception when it arrived in Washington yesterday in the hope of persuading the Bush administration to rethink its rejection of the Kyoto treaty on global warming.
fields.body:
A European Union delegation was given a cool reception when it arrived in Washington yesterday in the hope of persuading the Bush administration to rethink its rejection of the Kyoto treaty on global warming.

The chairman of the Senate environment committee, Robert Smith, cancelled a meeting with the delegation led by Kjell Larsson, the Swedish environment minister, and Margot Wallstrom. A spokeswoman for Mr Smith, a rightwing opponent of the 1997 Kyoto accord, said he would be too busy participating in Senate votes.

The EU negotiators are trying to secure a firm undertaking that the US will play a substantive role in global environment talks in Bonn in mid-July, when the implementation of the Kyoto deal is due to be discussed.

US diplomats have said a delegation from Washington would attend to put forward "alternative" means of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, but it was far from clear yesterday what those alternatives were.

An EU diplomat said: "It is a blank slate. We are as much in the dark as anyone here. We will just have to wait to hear what they have to say."

Today, Mr Larsson and Ms Wallstrom are due to meet Christine Todd Whitman, the administrator of the US environmental protection agency (EPA), whose earlier support for Kyoto was overruled by President Bush, and who was forced into a humiliating policy reversal.

Asked what a US delegation might put forward in Bonn, an EPA official yesterday would only say: "It's too early to tell."

The only other administration officials meeting the delegation are relatively junior -Richard Armitage, a deputy secretary of state, and Gary Edson, the deputy assistant to the president for international economic policy.

A US official said yesterday that the Bush administration had been angered by Ms Wallstrom's remarks last week, hinting that the EU might take retaliatory action for the US withdrawal from the accord.

The US national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, told European ambassadors a fortnight ago that the Bush administration considered the accord dead.

The position was made public last week by Ms Whitman, who said the accord put too little of the burden for controlling greenhouse gas emissions on developing countries, and too much on the US, which was supposed to have reduced its emissions by 7% from 1990 levels by 2012. Although backed by the Clinton administration, the agreement was never ratified by the Senate.

EU environment ministers meeting in Sweden at the weekend said they would continue to work towards the implementation of the Kyoto agreement with or without US participation.

Jan Pronk of the Netherlands said he was preparing a new set of implementation proposals and hoped to assemble the main 40 participating countries for a conference in New York on April 21. He suggested that the US position might eventually soften.

"Give them some time. Without the USA, the EU would have to negotiate with Canada, Japan and Australia... There is still a lot that has to be discussed with them," he said.

The White House insists it still takes the issue of greenhouse gas emissions seriously. When Mr Bush came to office in January he set up a "carbon rump group" to reassess the US position, but its report was pre-empted by an announcement last month indicating that the administration was withdrawing a campaign pledge to impose statutory limits on carbon dioxide emissions.

Meanwhile, the vice-president, Dick Cheney, is at the head of an energy task force, which is due to report in May on recent power shortages in California. His report is expected to deal with the issue of emissions but European observers in Washington don't hold out much hope. Mr Cheney is thought to be the leading hardliner on the environment in the White House, leading the move to dump Kyoto.

webTitle: Some surprising cases using  the Human Rights Act

fields.headline: The rights stuff
fields.standfirst:
It was predicted that the Human Rights Act would benefit prisoners and asylum seekers. But six months on, Clare Dyer finds it is being used in some surprising cases involving privacy-seeking celebrities - and a relieved family in the New Forest

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: It was predicted that the Human Rights Act would benefit prisoners and asylum seekers. But six months on,  Clare Dyer  finds it is being used in some surprising cases involving privacy-seeking celebrities - and a relieved family in the New Forest.
fields.body:
Who would have predicted, when the long-awaited Human Rights Act came into force six months ago, that it would rescue a £750,000 house condemned as "the most flagrant breach of planning permission" from the bulldozers?

Councils around the country were stunned last month when Ken and Jacky Duffy won their appeal against New Forest district council's order to demolish their newly built house, erected at twice the size allowed by the council in one of England's prime beauty spots.

The inspector who dealt with the appeal, Howard Russon, agreed that the huge structure "seriously harmed the character and appearance of this vulnerable rural area". He had no doubt that allowing it to stay "undermined the objectives of local planning policies aimed at protecting the very special landscape of this part of the New Forest".

But the couple and their three young children would be homeless and possibly bankrupt if the house had to be bulldozed. Russon concluded that this would violate the family's rights under article 8 of the European convention on human rights, the right to private and family life, and allowed their appeal.

When the Human Rights Act came into force on October 2, making the European convention part of English law, it was foreseeable that prisoners, asylum seekers and people charged with criminal offences would leap on the bandwagon. Scaremongering predictions of chaos in the courts have not been borne out, but judges have seen a steady flow of human rights cases. Of 87 decided between October and mid-February, 15 succeeded, according to figures from the human rights research unit at King's College law school, University of London. As predicted, the biggest category are claims over the right to a fair trial, guaranteed by article 6 of the convention.

What was not foreseen was that this same article - which also includes the right to a fair hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal in civil matters - would threaten to throw the whole planning system into disarray.

In December the high court delivered the first "declaration of incompatibility" under the Human Rights Act, exercising a new power for judges to declare that a law passed by the UK Parliament contravenes the European convention. Powers which allow the environment secretary, rather than planning inspectors, to take the final decision himself violated the right to an impartial tribunal, said the judges, because the same person "cannot be both policy maker and decision taker". The government has now appealed against the ruling to the House of Lords, where rumour has it that the law lords may overturn it.

Ministers predicted in the run-up to the act that declarations of incompatibility would be rare. But the judges have proved them wrong. The second, made last month by the court of appeal in a case brought by a paranoid schizophrenic killer in Broadmoor, will lead to the release of dozens of patients, say mental health lawyers. The court held that procedures laid down by the Mental Health Act, under which patients detained against their will may apply for release, breach their right to liberty, guaranteed by article 5, because they reverse the burden of proof and put the onus on the patient.

In two other cases the courts are actively considering making a declaration of incompatibility - the House of Lords in a challenge to "rape shield" laws banning questioning of rape complainants about their past sex life, and the court of appeal in a claim over a section of the Consumer Credit Act which the judges thought a breach of the human rights of lenders.

Meanwhile, celebrities are queueing up to use the act to carve out the right of privacy they previously lacked under English law, and the judges seem only too keen to help them. In the case brought by Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones over sneak photos of their wedding published in Hello! magazine, Lord Justice Sedley declared: "We have reached a point at which it can be said with confidence that the law recognises and will appropriately protect a right of personal privacy."

The media feared that a burgeoning privacy law could threaten freedom of expression - guaranteed by article 10 of the convention - and lobbied successfully for a clause to be added to the Human Rights Act imposing extra hurdles where an injunction is sought to stop publication in advance. This was hailed as a victory for the press, making freedom of expression the trump card that would outweigh other rights. But judges' pronouncements in the Hello! case and others suggest that they may not see it quite that way.

Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of the toddler James Bulger, invoked the act and won an unprecedented lifetime court order banning the media from publishing any details of their new identities and whereabouts once they leave custody later this year. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, thought their privacy claim might not have been enough to justify such a drastic curb on free speech. The clinching argument for her was that revenge attacks threatened their right to life (article 2) and to freedom from inhuman and degrading treatment (article 3).

Mary Cuneen, associate director of the civil rights group Liberty, which runs an advice helpline for lawyers on the act, says fair trial issues have been the largest area for queries. But article 8 - respect for private and family life - comes next, covering a wide range of issues including the rights of transsexuals, gay relationships, access to children, CCTV surveillance and employers' rights to employees' personal data.

Deaths in custody and the failure of prisons to prevent suicides look like fruitful areas for the future. In June, Liberty is taking a case against the Home Office to the high court over the death of a prisoner, Paul Wright, from an asthma attack, claiming that his right to life was violated and that he was subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment.

Last week Lord Bingham, the senior law lord, predicted that the Lord Chancellor and the law lords would face a court challenge over their dual role as both judges and members of the legislature. The issue of whether someone who is both judge and legislator can be considered independent and impartial "is a question which I believe will become litigious at some point," he told the joint lords and commons human rights committee.

Summing up the Human Rights Act after its first six months, Lord Bingham thought it was "unquestionably a major advance" for the UK's justice system. The fact that litigants had to go to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg until last October to assert human rights claims had caused "an insidious corruption of popular confidence in our justice system". He added: "It seems to me highly destructive of popular confidence in our own system of justice for people to think they had to go elsewhere to have their rights protected. If rights are to be protected they should be protected here."

Getting in on the act

Subject: Drink-driving, speed cameras and self-incrimination

Claim: Margaret Brown, found drunk by police at an all-night superstore, confessed she was the driver of the car in the carpark. She argued that section 172 of the Road Traffic Act 1988, which makes it an offence not to name the driver, breached the right to protection against self-incrimination

Outcome: Scotland's high court threw out the prosecution, ruling that section 172 (which also applied to cars caught on speed cameras) breached the right to a fair trial. The privy council later overturned the ruling and held that section 172 did not breach the human rights convention

Subject: Privacy rights for child killers Thompson and Venables under their new identities

Claim: They argued they risked reprisals if their new identities became known, threatening their right to life and right to be spared inhuman and degrading treatment. They also argued for a lifetime ban on publication to protect right to private and family life, and to prevent breach of confidence. Newspapers argued the unprecedented ban would infringe free speech

Outcome: Lifetime ban granted

Subject: Environment secretary's right to take planning decisions

Claim: In four test cases, it was argued that a government minister was not an "independent and impartial tribunal" when he exercised powers to take planning decisions himself

Outcome: The high court held that the environment secretary's decision could not be impartial because his policy had been at issue in each case, throwing the postwar planning system into confusion. Government appealed to the House of Lords. Decision pending. Law lords may overturn ruling

Subject: Mental patients detained against their will and right to release

Claim: Paranoid schizophrenic killer in Broadmoor argued that the law which puts the onus on him to prove he is not still suffering from a mental disorder warranting detention reverses burden of proof and infringes the right to liberty

Outcome: The appeal court agreed and ruled sections of Mental Health Act 1983 incompatible with the European convention on human rights

Subject: "Two strikes and you're out" life sentence for second-time serious offenders

Claim: Four lifers, jailed despite extenuating circumstances under a 1997 law which gave judges almost no discretion, claimed it violated the right to liberty, constituted inhuman and degrading treatment, and infringed ban on making a crime retrospective

Outcome: The appeal court neutralised the law, ruling that judges could take account of whether the offender was a danger to the public. This put the law back to where it was before the "two strikes" law was introduced

webTitle: How to save lives with your screensaver

fields.headline: How to save lives with your screensaver
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Forget cyberaquariums, starry nights or pictures of Elvis. Oxford scientists are appealing for computer users to donate screensaver time in a search for potential cancer cures.
fields.body:
Forget cyberaquariums, starry nights or pictures of Elvis. Oxford scientists are appealing for computer users to donate screensaver time in a search for potential cancer cures.

Oxford University's department of chemistry hopes thousands of people who leave their computers on when not in use will install a different kind of screensaver that can do molecular research.

To neutralise a virus or block a tumour, a molecule of a drug has to lock into a human protein.

Scientists can test the drugs as 3-D shapes on a screen. The catch is that there are 250m molecules to sift.

"To test those crudely, even using supercomputers, would take more than a lifetime," said Professor Graham Richards of the centre for drug discovery at Oxford. "But if you string together a million personal computers you would have enormous computing power."

Oxford scientists have developed a computer tool called Think, and will send anyone who volunteers for the scheme an initial cyberpackage of 100 molecules and a cyberprotein known to be involved in cancer.

Office workers use only about 20% of the power in their computers. The rest could be harnessed for cancer research, with a self-organising programme which quietly sends back to Oxford those molecules that look promising.

fields.headline: Crime victims gain new rights
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Victims of crime are to be consulted on the conditions of release for the 200 to 300 violent and sexual criminals who leave jail each month.
fields.body:
Victims of crime are to be consulted on the conditions of release for the 200 to 300 violent and sexual criminals who leave jail each month.

The statutory duty, to ask victims or their families if they want a say in the release of paedophiles and other sex offenders, came into force yesterday, alongside the launch of the national probation service.

Paul Boateng, the Home Office minister, said there would be a "law enforcement" emphasis in the national probation service, which replaces the old structure based on 54 localities. There will also be a £500m expansion in resources with staff increased by 4,500 beyond the existing 16,000 total. The probation service hopes to recruit an extra 3,000 staff, including former teachers and psychologists, within the next 12 months alone.

Eithne Wallis, director of the national probation service, said yesterday she was determined to see probation shed its "soft option" tag, with targets to reduce reconviction rates by 5% for the 200,000 offenders under its supervision.

Additionally, there will be "multi-agency public protection panels" involving the police, probation and clinical psychologists, who will assess risk and decide how paedophiles and other dangerous offenders are released into the community. The panels will also include representatives from the local health and education services.

All those serious offenders serving a prison sentence of more than 12 months will fall under the scheme to consult the victims over their release.

fields.headline: Further charges against Milosevic
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic was faced with further legal proceedings last night when a second warrant was issued by the international tribunal in the Hague, this time for war crimes in Bosnia.
fields.body:
The former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic was faced with further legal proceedings last night when a second warrant was issued by the international tribunal in the Hague, this time for war crimes in Bosnia.

The Serbian authorities also brought new charges of resisting arrest by force at the weekend, and masterminding the assassination of political opponents.

As the charges piled up, Momcilo Grubac, the federal justice minister, confirmed that he was putting the finishing touches to a bill covering Yugoslavia's future cooperation with the Hague tribunal. It could come into force by the end of next month.

"There is no clause to prevent an indicted person being transferred to the Hague, even if a court case is already under way here," Mr Grubac said

Mr Milosevic had hoped to benefit from President Vojislav Kostunica's repeated promise not to transfer him to the Hague, and supporters have claimed that he was given such a guarantee before he surrendered early on Sunday morning.

"I know nothing of any guarantees. I don't think anyone had the authority to negotiate about guarantees," Mr Grubac said.

Mr Milosevic and four colleagues, including Milan Milutinovic, the Serbian president, have already been indicted for war crimes in Kosovo.

The UN's chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, told an Italian newspaper yesterday that she would probably sign a warrant to arrest Mr Milosevic for crimes in Bosnia by the end of the month.

Mr Milosevic is to be charged with inciting his bodyguards to shoot at officers trying to arrest him, General Sreten Lukic, Serbia's deputy interior minister said.

The bodyguards wounded four policemen, one seriously, when the police charged the villa early on Saturday morning. The initial arrest warrant involved a summons on suspicion of abuse of power and corruption involving hundreds of millions of pounds.

Gen Lukic was in charge of police operations in Kosovo during the ethnic cleansing in 1999 and his name may figure on a secret indictment by the Hague tribunal.

He showed reporters yesterday a vast cache of weapons found in Mr Milosevic's villa after he surrendered. They include a grenade launcher, 27 AK47 rifles, a sniper rifle, a machine gun, 40 hand grenades, several handguns, and 1,700 rounds, Reuters reported.

"After the first police intervention, a number of the private security personnel left the residence... but Sinisa Vucinic and eight others stayed behind," Gen Lukic said.

"Slobodan Milosevic had a 9mm Sig-Sauer gun and 25 bullets and he was showing it to negotiators and all those present saw the gun."

Gen Lukic said his staff were investigating which weapons were there illegally. "The two armoured personnel carriers belonged to the army," he said.

The police are also trying to discover if the bodyguards and Mr Milosevic were planning an armed rebellion. Three bodyguards are in custody.

Mr Milosevic's daughter Marija fired a gun as her father left for prison and the police are investigating what or whom she was shooting at. She is not under arrest.

The former president's wife, Mira Markovic, is still living in the villa, under police guard. Investigators searching the premises found her sitting in her coat because the heating was still off: power and water were cut to force her husband to surrender.

Although the new law will allow him to order Mr Milosevic's transfer to the Hague as soon as it is in force, Mr Grubac said: "It would mean a lot for the rehabilitation of our legal system and courts to have him tried in Yugoslavia for war crimes.

"Our courts would show they can work properly even in the most difficult cases. The Hague tribunal was created as a substitute for national courts in countries where they were not working correctly."

The Yugoslav government is also close to deciding whether or not to set up a truth commission, though it would not involve amnesty for serious crimes, as happens in the South African model, Mr Grubac said.

He added that it would be best to have a regional commission for Croatia, Bosnia, and Serbia, "but it's difficult to form that, because you can't count on cooperation from all three states".

webTitle: Inside the cell with no windows

fields.headline: Inside the cell with no windows
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: "The food is very good and the accommodation is fine. He's feeling well," Mr Milosevic's lawyer, Toma Fila, said yesterday after visiting Yugoslavia's most notorious detainee.
fields.body:
"The food is very good and the accommodation is fine. He's feeling well," Mr Milosevic's lawyer, Toma Fila, said yesterday after visiting Yugoslavia's most notorious detainee. His stiff upper lip could not disguise the sudden change in his client's fortunes.

The former president's cell in Belgrade's central prison has no windows and his lavatory is a hole in the corner. He has a table, two chairs, and a bed, but no other furniture.

He was using his table yesterday to write an appeal against his detention on suspicion of abuse of power and corruption. An investigating judge has ordered his detention for an initial period of 30 days, but this can be extended for another five months before a formal indictment must be issued.

"Mr Milosevic wrote his own appeal because it is good that the person in question should write an appeal himself - he is a fellow lawyer and a former state president and what he has to say should be heard," Mr Fila said.

The Belgrade tabloid Blic published an artist's impression of the cell yesterday.

And under the front-page headline "The dictator turned himself in", Vecernje Novosti, a paper which was blindly loyal to him until he lost power last October, described the humiliation of Mr Milosevic's first moments in what is likely to be his home for a long time.

His belt, watch and documents were taken from him, it said. "He was given a sheet, two blankets and a meal." Then he was locked in a single cell.

Mr Milosevic had a stable personality, "except for that traumatic moment when he was leaving his family," Mr Fila added. "He doesn't know why he's in jail. He's not on tranquillisers. They want to keep him in prison to prevent him escaping from the country or influencing witnesses.

"But there's no reason to keep him, since he has nowhere to escape to because of the Hague indictment." Mr Fila said he did not expect the appeal to be accepted.

Mr Milosevic was seen brandishing a gun during the standoff at the weekend, but Mr Fila said this was not a serious issue to charge him with. "Ninety per cent of people have guns, and it would be sad for this country to prosecute a former head of state for having a weapon without a licence," he said.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a short profile of the News of the World reporter Mazher Mahmood, page 3, yesterday, we said that Johnnie Walker was jailed for cocaine possession. In fact, after pleading guilty, he was fined £2,000.
fields.body:
In a short profile of the News of the World reporter Mazher Mahmood, page 3, yesterday, we said that Johnnie Walker was jailed for cocaine possession. In fact, after pleading guilty, he was fined £2,000.

In our coverage of the Maxwell report, page 10, yesterday, we correctly referred to Lord Williams of Elvel, but incorrectly described him as a "former attorney general". He has never held that post. We were confusing him with the present (not former) attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn. Apologies to both.

In an article about company rebranding, page 24, March 30, we managed to confuse Andersen and Accenture. Andersen Consulting changed its name to Accenture. Arthur Andersen is now Andersen.

The Professional Association of Teachers, PAT, have asked us to say that contrary to what we stated in an article headed In harmony, page 6, Education, March 13, membership of their organisation is currently increasing and at present stands at almost 1,000 higher than the figure of 34,000 given in our article.

In A Lad's Night In, pages 37 to 39, Weekend, March 31, the omission of a decimal point in the recipe for tamale pie will have made the result unpalatable. There should have been 7.5g salt (ie, a pinch), not 75g, in the cornbread dough. Apologies
