fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Compaq cuts 700 jobs
fields.body:
Compaq cuts 700 jobs

US computer company Compaq said it was shedding 700 jobs by outsourcing the manufacture of consumer and desktop products presently made at its plant in Erskine, Renfrewshire.

The Scottish operation will continue to manufacture made-to-order PCs, as well as servers.

"Compaq remains a major employer in Scotland with more than 2,400 employees," a spokesman said.

Leighton takes Consignia post

Allan Leighton, chairman of Bhs and former chief executive of Asda, has been appointed a non-executive director of Consignia, the recently renamed holding company for the Post Office.

Mr Leighton, one of a clutch of top businessmen who are members of the Labour party, is to have special responsibility for development of the PO network. His retailing skills may help struggling branches, especially in rural areas. Sub-postmasters face the loss of up to 40% of their income when benefits payments are made direct to bank accounts from 2003.

Vote is for ever greater union

A new "super" union was formed yesterday when workers in some of the country's biggest companies voted in favour of a merger.

The Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union and the Manufacturing Science and Finance Union will unite to form a 1.2 m-strong organisation. Members voted by around 80% in favour of the merger which will create the country's second biggest trade union.

The new union, which will be the biggest affiliate to the Labour Party, will have an annual income of more than £60m and assets of over £100m.

Members are being consulted on a name for the new organisation.

Innogy offshoot to be floated

Innogy said it would float about 25% of electricity storage subsidiary Regenesys in the next two years and that brokers had valued the business at £500m-£1bn.

Chief operating officer Brian Count said the timing of the float would depend on market conditions but was unlikely to take place beyond the end of 2002.

Welsh Water's £2bn bond sale

Welsh Water is to begin marketing a £2bn multi-tranche bond, joint lead managers Schroder Salomon Smith Barney and Royal Bank of Scotland said. The bond sale will finance the company's acquisition by Glas Cymru, a not-for-profit company.

webTitle: Wright dumps QPR into financial relegation zone

fields.headline: Wright dumps QPR into financial relegation zone
fields.trailText: Loftus Road, the owner of Queens Park Rangers and rugby club Wasps, has revealed it is going into administration.
fields.body:
Loftus Road, the owner of Queens Park Rangers and rugby club Wasps, revealed it was going into administration last night as music entrepreneur Chris Wright tired of bankrolling the loss-making company.

The surprise move was intended to enable Mr Wright to separate the two sides of the business. He wants to buy Wasps and is hoping someone else will make an offer for QPR, which is fighting to avoid relegation to division two of the Nationwide football league.

Sources close to the company insisted neither club was in immediate jeopardy. Mr Wright has pledged to keep both running on a day-to-day basis. One insider said: "This is progress in getting the company sorted out, although I know it's difficult to see it like that from a supporter's point of view."

Earlier in the day, Loftus Road asked for its shares to be delisted from the Alternative Investment Market, saying it could not report its financial results as a going concern. At the time of delisting, the company was valued at £2.25m.

Mr Wright said Loftus Road was losing £570,000 a month. He said it was a "very sad day" for everyone involved with the company.

"The last six months have been a real struggle financially," he said. "Although my intention was to secure a sale to the right buyer before having to take this decision, it has not been forthcoming."

Administrators are to be appointed to Loftus Road and to its subsidiary, QPR, although Wasps is to remain in the hands of its existing management.

Reports yesterday suggested that a Knightsbridge property developer, Andrew Ellis, was considering a £9m offer for QPR. However, one source said: "A lot of tyre-kickers have come round, looked at it and walked away without making an offer."

Mr Wright, who made his fortune building music and TV business Chrysalis, has put more than £20m into Loftus Road over the past five years.

webTitle: Notebook: MPC can cut and maintain integrity

fields.headline: MPC can cut and maintain integrity
fields.standfirst: Sir Eddie has insurance option
fields.trailText: For months, the regular meetings of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee have turned into Threadneedle Street's version of Groundhog Day. A familiar pattern has emerged, with those cautious about cutting rates citing the strength of domestic demand in general, and consumer spending in particular, and those eager to cut the cost of borrowing warning that Britain is at risk from what is going on in the global economy in general, and the US economy in particular.
fields.body:
For months, the regular meetings of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee have turned into Threadneedle Street's version of Groundhog Day. A familiar pattern has emerged, with those cautious about cutting rates citing the strength of domestic demand in general, and consumer spending in particular, and those eager to cut the cost of borrowing warning that Britain is at risk from what is going on in the global economy in general, and the US economy in particular.

Both arguments have merit. For all the government's talk of abolishing boom and bust, one deeply worrying feature of the economy remains the traditional British tendency for spending to run far in excess of output, with a rising current account deficit symptomatic of the problem.

Even so, there are three good reasons for the Bank to cut rates this week.

The first is that it is worth taking out a second insurance policy following the quarter-point cut in February. The evidence from Britain's manufacturing sector is that the delayed effects of the American downturn might have started to hit order books and output quite hard now, and the signs from Europe, Japan and the US for the next few months are not encouraging. If the insurance policy proves not to be needed, the Bank can simply put up rates again.

The second factor pointing to an easing is that inflation is set to fall quite heavily over the next two months as a result of changes in both the 2000 and 2001 budgets. It is feasible that inflation excluding mortgage interest payments will drop below 1.5% when the April figures come out, forcing Sir Eddie George to write an open letter to the chancellor explaining why it has undershot the government's target by a full percentage point. Sir Eddie might think it prudent to take out some insurance of his own.

Finally, it is thought in some quarters that an independent central bank could not possibly countenance cutting rates in advance of an election. But this makes no sense. In fact, the opposite is the truth.

Cutting rates now would prove that the Bank makes its decisions on economic rather than political grounds. By doing so, it would show that it is truly independent.

Rank nonsense

Hang on to your seat: around lunchtime today the quarterly league tables on mergers and acquisitions will be published by Thomson Financial Securities Data, ranking investment banks by the size of the deals they have advised upon over the past three months.

With work suddenly thin on the ground, squabbles have broken out over which deals should be included. Recently in Sweden there was a spat between JP Morgan and Morgan Stanley over whether the latter had worked on the merger of Swedbank and SEB. (JP won.) Now, in London, there is a dispute over whether the takeover of Dresdner by Allianz "happened" at the end of the first quarter or the beginning of the second: important because a day waiting for the ink to dry could send Goldman Sachs tumbling down the table.

These rankings are viewed as crucial marketing tools by investment banks and can affect bonus payments. But the tables do not reflect the quality of corporate finance advice nor whether a strategy is successful. Performance does not seem to matter, just bulk.

Why any prospective corporate client should take any notice is not clear.

Roll up, roll up

Imperial Tobacco's chief executive, Gareth Davis, recently swapped his favourite Embassy Number One cigarettes for a packet of Excellence, to see what his new acquisition, Tobaccor, was selling to smokers in Africa.

He declared that the brand tasted "very impressive" - perhaps as palatable as the charmingly named Good Look, which is apparently big in Burkina Faso.

Mr Davis, as always, was well rehearsed yesterday. There was no question of Imps enticing people to smoke the cancerous weed in Africa, because it is already widespread. He does not even anticipate much increase in advertising and marketing. All he wants is to sell better cigarettes to the locals, more efficiently.

It would be easy to indulge in hand-wringing about a British company pushing unhealthy products in developing countries. But Imps has a point when it asks how else it is supposed to make profits when the chancellor continues to pile taxes on smokers at home. The global economy means taxation in one country has effects elsewhere.

Besides, it is naive to suggest that western cigarettes are unfamiliar in sub-Saharan Africa. Rothmans already has a big presence in the region. It will be interesting to observe the effects if Imps introduces its Rizla cigarette papers to Chad, the Congo and Gabon.

In fact, the opposite is the truth. Cutting rates now would prove that the Bank makes its decisions on economic rather than political grounds. By doing so, it would show that it is truly independent. Rank nonsense Hang on to your seat: around lunchtime today the quarterly league tables on mergers and acquisitions will be published by Thomson Financial Securities Data, ranking investment banks by the size of the deals they have advised upon over the past three months. With work suddenly thin on the ground, squabbles have broken out over which deals should be included. Recently in Sweden there was a spat between JP Morgan and Morgan Stanley over whether the latter had worked on the merger of Swedbank and SEB. (JP won.) Now, in London, there is a dispute over whether the takeover of Dresdner by Allianz "happened" at the end of the first quarter or the beginning of the second: important because a day waiting for the ink to dry could send Goldman Sachs tumbling down the table. These rankings are viewed as crucial marketing tools by investment banks and can affect bonus payments. But the tables do not reflect the quality of corporate finance advice nor whether a strategy is successful. Performance does not seem to matter, just bulk. Why any prospective corporate client should take any notice is not clear. Roll up, roll up Imperial Tobacco's chief executive, Gareth Davis, recently swapped his favourite Embassy Number One cigarettes for a packet of Excellence, to see what his new acquisition, Tobaccor, was selling to smokers in Africa. He declared that the brand tasted "very impressive" - perhaps as palatable as the charmingly named Good Look, which is apparently big in Burkina Faso. Mr Davis, as always, was well rehearsed yesterday. There was no question of Imps enticing people to smoke the cancerous weed in Africa, because it is already widespread. He does not even anticipate much increase in advertising and marketing. All he wants is to sell better cigarettes to the locals, more efficiently. It would be easy to indulge in hand-wringing about a British company pushing unhealthy products in developing countries. But Imps has a point when it asks how else it is supposed to make profits when the chancellor continues to pile taxes on smokers at home. The global economy means taxation in one country has effects elsewhere. Besides, it is naive to suggest that western cigarettes are unfamiliar in sub-Saharan Africa. Rothmans already has a big presence in the region. It will be interesting to observe the effects if Imps introduces its Rizla cigarette papers to Chad, the Congo and Gabon.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: • Say what you like about Robert Maxwell - and most people have over the years - you have to admit he was a fat, cheating old crook. While I can't recommend the DTI's Mirror Group Newspapers investigation as bedtime reading, there are some crackers tucked away in the detail. Such as the 1991 episode where Maxwell's brokers Samuel Montagu suggested Bernard Ingham - Margaret Thatcher's former press officer - as a board member for MGN at the time of its float. "[Maxwell] exploded when he saw the name of a person regarded as a supporter of the Conservative party on the list as a suggested non-executive director of the only newspaper group that supported the Labour party," says a footnote on page 176. "He swore that Samuel Montagu were hopelessly incompetent" - a view supported by the rest of the report. Samuel Montagu is now part of HSBC, so nothing of the sort could ever happen again.

Such as the 1991 episode where Maxwell's brokers Samuel Montagu suggested Bernard Ingham - Margaret Thatcher's former press officer - as a board member for MGN at the time of its float. "[Maxwell] exploded when he saw the name of a person regarded as a supporter of the Conservative party on the list as a suggested non-executive director of the only newspaper group that supported the Labour party," says a footnote on page 176. "He swore that Samuel Montagu were hopelessly incompetent" - a view supported by the rest of the report. Samuel Montagu is now part of HSBC, so nothing of the sort could ever happen again.

 The trials of running a multinational are manifold. Last month my colleague Andrew Clark wrote a profile of Gareth Davis, chief executive of Imperial Tobacco, which mentioned that he sounds like Jack Duckworth (of Coronation Street) because he's northern and has a husky voice from his 40-a-day Embassy Number One habit. Gareth's partner Andrea was not happy with the description: friends have taken to calling her Vera.

 At last! A readers' competition. Cuddly bankers at Merrill Lynch are running classes to teach its analysts how to lower equity ratings without annoying the companies involved. These are the research notes sent out by investment banks advising "buy" and "sell" etc - except that only about 1% of ratings advise "sell" because the companies tend to kick up a fuss. So, the competition is: how to help Merrill by thinking of more diplomatic terms than the crude "sell" to break the bad news. I'd suggest something like "No, thank you". If you can do better (which really should not be hard), then email the address below, or write to the usual 119 Farringdon Road, EC1R 3ER. Lashings of champagne for the winners. Really.

 Speaking of which, it's time for Dog of the Day: the brokers' advice that gets used as a lamp post. Again, it's those touchy-feely analysts at Merrill Lynch who are today's winners: a research note yesterday downgraded Centrica from "buy". And lo, Centrica's share price rose regardless. Mind you, Merrill was very nice about it.

 Foot and mouth news: a Dutch butcher in Heerlen is ready to sell worms and grasshoppers if F&M causes a meat shortage. Jon Janssen is planning to sell spring rolls with worms, and baked rice served with grasshoppers. He says 1kg of grasshoppers has the nutritional value of six pizzas: "They're extremely healthy, they contain a lot of protein, minerals and vitamins." One of his cooks, Victoria Viehoff, says grasshoppers can be used in any meal. "They scarcely have any taste - the taste comes from adding herbs."

webTitle: £179m deal puts tobacco company in lightly regulated markets

fields.headline: Imps moves into Africa
fields.standfirst: £179m deal puts tobacco company in lightly regulated markets
fields.trailText: Imperial Tobacco is planning to take its Regal and Superkings brands to smokers in sub-Saharan Africa through a £179m deal to buy 75% of Tobaccor, a leading distributor of cigarettes in the region.
fields.body:
Imperial Tobacco is planning to take its Regal and Superkings brands to smokers in sub-Saharan Africa through a £179m deal to buy 75% of Tobaccor, a leading distributor of cigarettes in the region.

Based in Paris, Tobaccor specialises in selling cigarettes in French-speaking developing countries. Its big markets include Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso and Senegal, and it has an operation in Vietnam.

The acquisition is part of Imperial's strategy of international expansion to offset its exposure to high taxes and strict health regulations in Britain.

Imperial's chief executive, Gareth Davis, said: "The incidence of smoking in Africa is significantly less than in a place like western Europe but it is gradually growing. With rapid population growth, we'd expect it to stay in growth."

Cigarettes were already well established in sub-Saharan Africa: "To the people who say we're going to go and entice people to smoke, I'd say that's not true. They already do smoke and we're going to get a share of it."

Tobaccor makes popular African brands such as Excellence, Hamilton and Good Look, which sell for 30p to 40p a packet. Mr Davis said Imperial would use the business's distribution network as a platform for its own cheaper brands.

French-speaking countries in Africa are relatively economically stable because their currencies are pegged to the French franc.

In Vietnam, Tobaccor produces Bastor, a fast-growing brand sold through a local firm, Dong Nai.

Analyst Jonathan Fell of Merrill Lynch said the deal should enhance Imperial's earnings by 3% next year: "They've done quite a few of these add-on acquisitions and pretty much every one of them has turned out to be attractive."

Imperial's profits were flat last year in Britain, where tobacco companies have been battered by steep rises in duty and advertising bans. Its earnings rose 23% to £188m overseas, partly due to sales of cigarettes later brought back to Britain by tourists and smugglers.

Tobaccor made profits of £33m from sales of £154m last year. The remaining 25% of Tobaccor will be retained by a French conglomerate, Bollore.

fields.headline: Alabama judge takes on Opec
fields.trailText: A US federal court has granted a one-year injunction against the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries as politicians in Washington turn up the heat against foreign oil producers.
fields.body:
A US federal court has granted a one-year injunction against the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries as politicians in Washington turn up the heat against foreign oil producers.

A local firm, Prewitt Enterprises, won a civil anti-competition case in an Alabama court on the basis that Opec members had conspired to fix the price of oil through production agreements.

Under the court order issued by district judge Charles Weiner, Opec is for the next year "restrained from entering any agreements among themselves or with third parties to raise, lower or otherwise determine volumes of production and export of crude oil".

The legal ruling is mainly symbolic but is seen as politically important. It arrived as new Opec production cuts - the second in a year - came into effect at the weekend in an attempt to raise prices above the current $23 per barrel.

At the same time proposed legislation was introduced to the US Senate which would give regulators authority to sue Opec. Federal law forbids such action as against all sovereign nations.

Threats against Middle East oil nations such as Saudi Arabia have continually surfaced whenever crude prices have risen steeply such as late 1999. But experts believe it is the first time a court has actually ruled against Opec.

Dr Peter Odell, an international energy expert at the London School of Economics, said the legal ruling might disrupt the ability of US oil companies to handle crude from Opec nations.

"It could lead to sanctions but its real importance is probably that it raises the political temperature against Opec at a time when there is a new administration in Washington."

Senator Herbert Kohl of Wisconsin who co-sponsored the bill to Congress, said the Opec "conspiracy" had been allowed to go unchecked for too long. But the chance of the bill becoming law is limited.

fields.headline: Wings clipped
fields.standfirst: Swissair starts restructuring
fields.trailText: Swiss pride was dented severely yesterday when the national airline group revealed it had had its worst ever financial year with a SFr2.9bn (£1.2bn) loss, and admitted it was considering asset sales.
fields.body:
Swiss pride was dented severely yesterday when the national airline group revealed it had had its worst ever financial year with a SFr2.9bn (£1.2bn) loss, and admitted it was considering asset sales.

SAirGroup, owner of Swissair, blamed what the local press dubbed Red Monday, on its growing portfolio of investments in Belgian, French and German airlines.

The loss, which compared with a SFr273m profit last year, led to an 8% slump in the share price and a request from the company that the shares be suspended from trading.

Mario Corti, brought in two weeks ago as chairman and chief executive, said "urgent" remedial work would begin with the sale of its Swissotel hotel chain, which holds a management contract for London's Howard Hotel.

Funding of its half stake in the French airline, Air Littoral, had also been halted and it would sell its stakes in Austrian Airlines and the Galileo reservations system.

SAirGroup will announce a decision on the future of its other French carriers Air Liberté and AOM on April 25 at the group's annual general meeting. The three small French carriers, in which the Swiss group holds a 49% stake, were causing a cash drain of SFr80m a month and lost SFr393m before restructuring costs.

The group is also considering the future of its half share in the Belgian national airline, Sabena, which made a loss of €325m last year. The Swissair airline itself kept its losses at SFr195m despite rising fuel costs. German charter airline LTU lost €224m (£138m).

The parent company said it would "realign its overall business strategy to lay a sound foundation on which to substantially enhance its revenue and earnings performance".

Trouble at SAirGroup has already led to the departure of the chairman and chief executive, while nine of the ten board members have elected to stand down.

Chief executive Philippe Bruggisser, chief architect of the failed policy of acquiring stakes in second and third tier arlines, went in January. Chairman Eric Honegger has just stood down. Mr Corti is expected to sell Swissair's duty free shops and concentrate on Swiss-based passenger services.

fields.headline: One-man bands lose IR35 tax fight
fields.trailText: The government yesterday won a high court battle with computer and engineering contractors who claimed that tax rules known as IR35 undermined their businesses and forced them to work abroad.
fields.body:
The government yesterday won a high court battle with computer and engineering contractors who claimed that tax rules known as IR35 undermined their businesses and forced them to work abroad.

The inland revenue said that in the new tax year starting on Thursday it would press ahead with implementation of the rules, designed to clamp down on one-person companies avoiding tax and national insurance contributions.

Mr Justice Burton said the contractors had failed to argue that ministers singled them out for special tax treatment in contravention of European free trade laws and the Human Rights Act.

The judge ruled that ending what he saw as a tax advantage in the UK was not an infringement of human rights or a limit on the transfer of business from one European country to another.

He added that the case highlighted many flaws in the tax rules, which he had been confusing and in some respects "inflexible". He said reforms to the IR35 rules were necessary and issued guidance on how they might beapplied.

The 11,000-strong Professional Contractors' Group, which brought the legal challenge, claimed that the judge's comments gave them some hope that the inland revenue would consider a review of the tax rules.

"The judgment contains a detailed and what we would say is a damning critique of IR35, and the judge has issued binding guidance which effectively rewrites the IR35 rulebook," said Gareth Williams, the chairman.

The inland revenue said it would examine the judgment and consider all the points made by the judge. A spokesman said the agency's intention was to press ahead with the new regime in the coming tax year.

"The government is glad that the court has confirmed that the IR35 legislation is not contrary to EU and human rights law and the uncertainty caused by the case can now come to an end. The legislation was necessary to assure fair taxation of all workers whether or not they use a limited company to arrange their contracts."

The revenue reviewed the tax situation of one-person companies shortly after the election of the Labour government in 1997. It concluded that thousands of contractors in industries such as IT and engineering had been advised by their accountants to switch from full time employment to limited company status to depress their tax bills.

Contractors would pay themselves a salary equivalent to their personal allowance, a salary to their spouse and the remainder in dividends, allowing them to avoid paying national insurance contributions. The revenue argued that in many cases contractors worked for one employer and should be on the payroll.

The PCG denied the practice was widespread among the estimated 100,000 contractors operating in the UK and claimed the revenue's response was heavy handed. It argued that thousands of key workers had been driven abroad by the prospect of paying tax at a rate of 50%.

Mr Justice Burton agreed that the government appeared to have assumed, "without any adequate research," that all small service companies fell within the category of disguised employment. Evidence showed that by no means all contractors fell into that category.

fields.headline: BT wants rivals to help with 3G bill
fields.trailText: Debt-laden BT has appealed to Vodafone and other rivals to help with the £1.5bn cost of building a third generation (3G) mobile phone network in Britain.
fields.body:
Debt-laden BT has appealed to Vodafone and other rivals to help with the £1.5bn cost of building a third generation (3G) mobile phone network in Britain.

Hutchison Whampoa, its Hong Kong-based competitor, has brought in leading handset manufacturer Nokia of Finland as part of a £3.6bn cash-raising move to bankroll its British 3G operation.

BT says sharing systems would cut duplication and reduce pressure from environmentalists worried about the number of base stations.

A spokesman for BT Wireless, the subsidiary responsible for building the British network, confirmed its desire to work with competitors: "We are currently in negotiations and hope to be successful." BT has spoken to all the main players in Britain and has made similar moves in mainland Europe.

Vodafone, which has rejected an offer of collaboration from BT's Viag Interkom in Germany, said it was interested in the idea of joint working. A spokesman said: "Sharing facilities is certainly worth investigating because there are cost savings and less of an environmental impact."

BT needs to share costs partly to meet a commitment to cut a third of its £30bn debt by the end of this year. The borrowings were run up to pay for expensive 3G licences.

The urgency of BT's action was underlined by a 4% fall in its share price early yesterday as investors again focused on debt issues, particularly at KPN of the Netherlands. BT closed 10p down at 500p.

The 3G systems will allow high-speed internet access and video downloads over mobile phones.

Analysts believe it makes sense for companies to share the financial burden.

Kevin Fogarty at Teather & Greenwood said: "Clearly there is a lot of scope for companies to share costs. Building a full national network is expensive."

He believed BT should have scope for alliances with smaller operators in Germany, such as E-Plus.

Some industry experts question the wisdom of Hutchison using vendor finance deals, such as that with Nokia, to fund expansion.

Nokia is pledging £460m to help Hutchison build its system but some financiers believe that this could leave Hutchison vulnerable if Nokia runs into problems.

fields.headline: Moss Bros is a casualty
fields.trailText: Moss Bros yesterday said it was concentrating on opening and modernising shops as it lurched into losses at the year-end.
fields.body:
Moss Bros yesterday said it was concentrating on opening and modernising shops as it lurched into losses at the year-end.

The company, which has 150 outlets, has been forced to revamp its image and products partly because of the introduction of dress-down customs in the workplace.

Moss Bros said it would continue to move away from formal wear but suits remained an important part of the business.

Shares dropped 5p to 27.5p after the group reported a loss of £17.5m, including exceptional charges, such as £12m for closing stores. Moss Bros posted a profit of £7.8m the previous year. Losses before exceptional items were £2.7m. Turnover in the first eight weeks of this year was up just 1% and like-for-like fashion sales for the year were up 2.5%.

The group said Neil Benson would be replaced as chairman by Keith Hamill, a former finance director of WH Smith.

fields.headline: Entrepreneur reverses out of SkyePharma
fields.trailText: The multi-millionaire architect of SkyePharma is to step down as a director, fearing a conflict of interests through his involvement with another biotechnology business.
fields.body:
The multi-millionaire architect of SkyePharma is to step down as a director, fearing a conflict of interests through his involvement with another biotechnology business.

Swiss entrepreneur Jacques Gonella, who has a 19% stake in the drug development company, announced his departure as full-year losses increased by 2% to £19.6m.

Mr Ashton said there was no indication that Mr Gonella intended to sell his shares, which are worth £84m.

fields.headline: At this price? Atlantic Telecom
fields.trailText: Atlantic Telecom was once regarded as one of the potential bright stars in the telecom firmament, and it had a share price to match. Now it has become a black hole.
fields.body:
Atlantic Telecom was once regarded as one of the potential bright stars in the telecom firmament, and it had a share price to match. Now it has become a black hole. Investors are either nursing huge losses or leaving in droves. It is in desperate need of a convincing strategy.

The company, an alternative carrier with broadband capacity, has seen its shares fall more sharply than the general slump in hi-tech stocks, particularly in the past few months.

Its shares, which peaked at £11.90 in February last year, are now languishing at around 35p. Analysts see little on the horizon to change the picture.

"All in all, there is a lack of positive news flow from the company to reassure the market that this is an alternative carrier success story," said Kevin Fogarty, Teather & Greenwood's telecom analyst.

The company tried to boost its reputation by taking analysts to Germany to see its broadband achievements there. But the move backfired when shortly afterwards it announced another change of strategy, the disposal of its French assets.

Rubbing salt in investors' wounds is the knowledge that the company's former chairman, Nick Berry, cashed in at the peak of the market, receiving £37m for shares that today would be worth under £2m.

Atlantic, like its rivals, has had to scale back plans for massive investments, not only because the demand is now uncertain but also because raising the funds in the current climate would be an almost impossible task.

The company is still very much in a development phase, absorbing cash at a time when its customer base is still relatively small.

To buck the market trend, alternative carriers need something that marks them out from the rest. There is no sign yet that Atlantic has found a strategy to lift it above its rivals. And it has little attraction as a bid target.

Its shares are strictly to be left alone by all but the most inveterate gamblers.

webTitle: Market forces: Anglo plumbs new depths

fields.headline: Anglo plumbs new depths
fields.trailText: Just as the great London Stock Exchange was spreading its wings abroad, announcing a technical alliance with the Johannesburg bourse, one of the biggest firms from down there - Anglo American - was getting a terrible kicking up here.
fields.body:
Just as the great London Stock Exchange was spreading its wings abroad, announcing a technical alliance with the Johannesburg bourse, one of the biggest firms from down there - Anglo American - was getting a terrible kicking up here.

It is almost two years since the South African mining conglomerate transferred its primary listing to London and on the whole things have gone swimmingly since. Until the last couple of months, that is.

Against a high of £47, the stock has ratcheted lower on a weekly basis. Yesterday the price suddenly fell another 172p to £38.36, leading a few souls to speculate on whether it might have been goaded into a counter-bid for Billiton (down 1.75p at 317p), its London-listed South African rival, which is busy cooking up a merger with Australia's biggest mining combo, BHP.

Such a move looks highly un likely. Aside from the competition issues that might be raised, sector followers point out that a combined Billiton-Anglo would be too heavily slanted towards South Africa which, sadly, remains a relatively risky prospect for most big international institutional investors.

In the meantime, Anglo does have its own particular problems. Its plan to unravel the complex ownership of the diamonds group De Beers is under fire from South African investors, who believe they are being short-changed. Anglo may yet have to sweeten its terms.

At the same time, Anglo is more exposed than most to the US economic downturn. On the De Beers front alone, American buyers speak for about half of the world's diamond trade.

The market as a whole was in a pretty fragile state, with dealers in London caught between hopes of a rate cut in Britain later this week and the continuing flow of bad news from across the Atlantic.

A technical spurt right at the close of business (presumed to be caused by the inflexible workings of the exchange's Sets trading system) masked much of the damage, with the FTSE 100 putting on 20 points during the last 10 minutes of business. But the Footsie still closed 15.2 points lower at 5618.5, having dropped below 5568 earlier in the day.

Despite a show of sunshine in London, the mood remained low, underlined by a survey from accountants KPMG suggesting that flotation work during the first quarter of the year was the lowest seen for more than 10 years.

The leaders were decidedly mixed, with the likes of Vodafone (up 2p at 195p) and Marks & Spencer (4p firmer at 270p) attracting a bit of bargain hunting, while Railtrack slumped 117p to 570p as the City cottoned on to the depth of its funding problems.

Barclays was perceived to be at risk from the same sort of problems affecting American Express in the US, leaving the shares 53p lighter at £21.45, but the mortgage banks man aged to hold steady and Halifax actually managed a 13p advance to 731p.

BOC jumped 37p to 988p after weekend reports suggesting the chemicals group might be considering a string of disposals in order to strengthen its balance sheet and see off the type of unwanted approaches the group was plagued with last year.

Osmetech, a little company specialising in odour sensors, said American regulators might approve a product aimed at detecting urinary tract infection. So the predictable jokes about this firm taking the mickey were doing the rounds as the price firmed 0.75p to 11.25p.

The stock is still a long way short of last year's high of 19p but the company says that recent tests involving its UTI sensor carried out at St Thomas's in London and Brigham & Women's hospital near Boston in the US have already won "proof of concept" status for the technology.

John Laing added 12p to 525p after news that the private O'Rourke Group has entered exclusive negotiations to buy its construction business. Laing said in November it wanted to concentrate on house building and property.

webTitle: Interview: Peter Cunnah, leader of D:Ream

fields.headline: Labour pains
fields.standfirst: Peter Cunnah was the man who sang that Things Can Only Get Better. But was that true for him? Nicole Veash meets the leader of D:Ream
fields.trailText: Peter Cunnah was the man who sang that Things Can Only Get Better. But was that true for him? Nicole Veash meets the leader of D:Ream
fields.body:
Every now and then Peter Cunnah gets strange phone calls from journalists. "They're only interested in one thing - whether I'm working in a chip shop or a hot dog van," the singer-songwriter says. "And they're really disappointed when I tell them I'm still in the music business."

That's the trouble when you write a song that captures a moment in history. Cunnah, the force behind D:Ream, and his songwriting partner Jamie Petrie created Things Can Only Get Better, the tune that Labour used to spread its message in the 1997 election. Cunnah even joined the future prime minister at rallies; as Blair finished his speech, Cunnah would get up on stage and rouse the audience to a mass singsong. He has never been allowed to forget it.

"It was all so surreal," recalls Cunnah in his buttered Northern Irish accent. "I was on the Prescott Express, going round the country, performing with Tony Blair and listening to loads of fortysomethings sing my song. One day Prescott told me that he was bloody fed up with the song because he'd sung it so many times. And I said: 'John, don't even go there.' I was the really fed up one."

Yet even now, the 34-year-old never knocks his number one hit. After all, it launched his career. Originally written in 1989, when Cunnah was new to London, Things was first released as a D:Ream single in January 1993 and reached a respectable 23 in the charts. But it was on the 1994 re-release that D:Ream really hit the big time. Then it was four weeks at number one.

"I can thank Take That for some of our success," he explains. "In 1993 they asked us to be their support band on tour. It was a bit of shock because we were this hip, young dance act and they were . . . well, they were Take That." It was then that Cunnah took a business decision and moved D:Ream into a new direction. "Clubbers only buy singles and 12in singles. Working with Take That meant access to a much bigger market. One where girls waved banners saying they loved you."

D:Ream's first album, On Vol 1, in 1994, was well received critically and commercially. A year later, the swiftly cobbled-together World came out. It produced several top 20 singles. By this time, however, Cunnah had a "huge drugs problem" and was arguing with D:Ream's third member, Al Mackenzie. "I became pretty obnoxious," he admits. With writs flying about over royalties (eventually settled out of court), Cunnah decided to dismantle the group. "I was out of it. I wasn't in touch with my family or the woman I loved."

Cunnah came off drugs, took time out and got himself back together. And then, in 1996, Prescott phoned. D:Ream reformed and bounced back. On a different high after the election, Cunnah went about producing a third, more mature album that was less dance-oriented. He invested £60,000 of his own money, convinced his high profile would ensure interest. He was wrong. The album was too adventurous for record company bosses.

"They wanted me to do the same old thing. But I wanted to move on," says Cunnah. The album was never released and Cunnah turned to producing and songwriting. Most recently, he has written for the boy band A1. And, with Petrie, he has co-written and produced an album for Carlton TV's Saturday morning show, Star Street.

"I've still got ambitions and I humbly hope to repeat my earlier success," Cunnah says. "But this time I want to do it with a falafel in one hand and a cup of tea in the other. And I wouldn't use my face on any promotional stuff if I went solo again. Having anonymity is more important.

"I've got good memories and bad. I'll never forget Peter Mandelson fluffing the words. Or the big bear hug that Alastair Campbell gave me as Portillo lost his seat. But even now I can't stand listening to the song. I'm sure Tony Blair feels the same. We just heard it too many times."

fields.headline: Leader of struggle to free the Nuba dies
fields.trailText: Yousif Kuwa, the teacher who turned to armed struggle to get recognition for the Nuba people of central Sudan, has died at the age of 56 after a year-long battle with bone cancer. His death strips the Sudan People's Liberation Army of a man who was the very embodiment of the "New Sudan" it is pledged to create.
fields.body:
Yousif Kuwa, the teacher who turned to armed struggle to get recognition for the Nuba people of central Sudan, has died at the age of 56 after a year-long battle with bone cancer. His death strips the Sudan People's Liberation Army of a man who was the very embodiment of the "New Sudan" it is pledged to create.

Kuwa died on Saturday in a Norwich hospital, while writing an open letter to the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, deploring the UN's failure to deliver relief to the Nuba mountains three years after Khartoum promised to end its 12-year blockade.

The 1.5m Nuba, a black African people in a country dominated by the Arab north, are the model of the political and cultural diversity which threatens the fundamentalist generals who rule Sudan, and have been at the sharp end of their increasingly violent drive to impose an extreme form of Islam.

In the past year, as Kuwa's illness removed him from effective leadership, Khartoum redoubled its efforts to defeat the rebellion he led by attacking the most fertile parts of the mountains and driving the in habitants into "peace villages". About Nuba have been displaced already this year. Many more are threatened by famine.

"It is sad that in the middle of this tragedy the UN is wasting time trying to persuade the government to permit access to the Nuba mountains," Yoanes Ajawin, director of programmes for the human rights organisation Justice Africa, said.

"The UN should comply with international humanitarian law which allows assistance to the needy without the permission of rogue governments like [the Sudanese]."

Kuwa was elected to a regional assembly but joined the SPLA in 1984, despairing of political change. As commander-governor of the Nuba mountains he oversaw the establishment of a civil administration unique in SPLA areas, and encouraged a renaissance of Nuba culture. He was the first SPLA commander to allow a human rights monitoring organisation in his territory.

"He was a thoughtful man, curious and intellectual," Jemera Rone of Human Rights Watch said yesterday. "He took liberation seriously, understanding that it included respect for the rights of all. Such a man cannot live too long."

fields.headline: Cartoonist gives Syria a new line in freedom
fields.trailText: Politics has never been much fun in Syria, but the cartoonist Ali Farzat believes that jokes are the way to bring about reform.
fields.body:
Politics has never been much fun in Syria, but the cartoonist Ali Farzat believes that jokes are the way to bring about reform.

He has just become a newspaper proprietor - the first since Syria's last privately owned paper was shut down in 1963 - and promises that his satirical tabloid Addomari (the Lamplighter) will "bring light to the political, economic, and social situation".

In the first issue articles sandwiched between cartoons tackled corruption and the quality of life in Syria. It also predicted a cabinet reshuffle: the sort of a story the official media would not touch until it happened.

In 30 years of cartooning Farzat has won 13 awards and held 31 international exhibitions. He has worked not only for the official Syrian daily Tishreen but for Le Monde and other newspapers abroad.

Seven years ago an unexpected visitor to one of his exhibitions was Bashar al-Assad, son of the Syrian president, who was then in his late twenties. He looked at the cartoons, which included some banned in Syria, and told Farzat that they should all have been published.

When the son became president on the death of his father last year, Farzat remembers the conversation and applied for permission to publish a newspaper. Amazingly, it was granted.

But getting started was far from simple. After 38 years without any independent media, printing companies were not geared up to produce a newspaper. In the end, one company printed some of its 20 pages and another did the rest.

Farzat ordered 50,000 copies - a cheeky gesture since the official daily dailies print only 40,000. He also priced the Lamplighter at 25 Syrian pounds (39p), five times the cost of a Syrian daily.

By 10am on the day of publication the first issue had sold out. "We even had newsagents coming to our office demanding copies," Farzat says.

He hastily ordered an extra 25,000 copies and increased the print run for the second issue to 100,000. Even so, there is still a shortage. Secondhand copies can be borrowed for 7p or bought outright for just over £2.

The Lamplighter, which has 15 staff, including administrators, was started on Farzat's savings. Selling his cartoons abroad for the past 30 years has earned him far more than the average Syrian journalist.

"This is an adventure," he says. He could either become very rich or lose his life savings. "I'm sitting at a green table" - recognising that it is a poker game.

As Syria's court jester he may be allowed to say things that others cannot, though some readers suggest that the paper has more bravado than substance: it grumbles about corruption without naming names.

"What matters is the issue rather than the person," Farzat retorts. "We criticise people for their work, not personally.

"I don't think there is complete freedom anywhere. The paper is liberal. We'll criticise everything, but we won't betray our country."

Seven other new papers have been approved since President Assad took office, though only two have appeared so far, and all belong to parties in the Ba'athist-led National Progressive Front.But the information minister, Adnan Umran, says they will eventually cover a broad range of views: left, right and centre.

In his 10th-floor office at the top of the Ba'ath newspaper headquarters, the minister says he is worried that opening up too quickly will lead to a chaotic free-for-all.

"We believe in going step by step."

Too many new papers, he fears, will reduce the viability of existing ones. "And we'd like to be sure there is no abuse" - by which he means newspapers being bribed to adopt a particular line.

There are no plans to privatise the two state-owned tele vision channels, Mr Umran says, "but there is no ceiling on progress. These ideas are talked about".

Information in Syria is no longer the preserve of state and party. Foreign newspapers and magazines are readily available to those who can afford them, and many people watch satellite television.

Meanwhile the regime seems unsure what to tolerate. After Assad died political salons multiplied.

But last month Vice-President Abdel Halim Khaddam clamped down on them, saying they threatened the security and stability of society. Now they must give the authorities 15 days' notice of their debates, and wait for approval.

The internet, one of Presi dent Assad's personal interests, is also censored, albeit half-heartedly. Access to some sites is blocked, including, bizarrely, Microsoft's hotmail.

This does not stop anyone visiting it: you simply go to the Microsoft homepage, msn.com, which is not banned, and click on the hotmail link.

President Assad's declared intention is to get everyone in Syria online, but so far only 9,000 are signed up. In the internet cafes of Damascus almost all the customers are foreigners.

The reason is simple: access costs about £1.40 an hour, an enormous amount of money for most Syrians.

"If I spent one hour a day on the internet," a government employee said, "it would cost me half my salary."

As Syria's court jester he may be allowed to say things that others cannot, though some readers suggest that the paper has more bravado than substance: it grumbles about corruption without naming names. "What matters is the issue rather than the person," Farzat retorts. "We criticise people for their work, not personally. "I don't think there is complete freedom anywhere. The paper is liberal. We'll criticise everything, but we won't betray our country." Seven other new papers have been approved since President Assad took office, though only two have appeared so far, and all belong to parties in the Ba'athist-led National Progressive Front.But the information minister, Adnan Umran, says they will eventually cover a broad range of views: left, right and centre. In his 10th-floor office at the top of the Ba'ath newspaper headquarters, the minister says he is worried that opening up too quickly will lead to a chaotic free-for-all. "We believe in going step by step." Too many new papers, he fears, will reduce the viability of existing ones. "And we'd like to be sure there is no abuse" - by which he means newspapers being bribed to adopt a particular line. There are no plans to privatise the two state-owned tele vision channels, Mr Umran says, "but there is no ceiling on progress. These ideas are talked about". Information in Syria is no longer the preserve of state and party. Foreign newspapers and magazines are readily available to those who can afford them, and many people watch satellite television. Meanwhile the regime seems unsure what to tolerate. After Assad died political salons multiplied. But last month Vice-President Abdel Halim Khaddam clamped down on them, saying they threatened the security and stability of society. Now they must give the authorities 15 days' notice of their debates, and wait for approval. The internet, one of Presi dent Assad's personal interests, is also censored, albeit half-heartedly. Access to some sites is blocked, including, bizarrely, Microsoft's hotmail. This does not stop anyone visiting it: you simply go to the Microsoft homepage, msn.com, which is not banned, and click on the hotmail link. President Assad's declared intention is to get everyone in Syria online, but so far only 9,000 are signed up. In the internet cafes of Damascus almost all the customers are foreigners. The reason is simple: access costs about £1.40 an hour, an enormous amount of money for most Syrians. "If I spent one hour a day on the internet," a government employee said, "it would cost me half my salary."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Nuclear waste
fields.body:
Nuclear waste

German campaigners are bracing themselves to demonstrate against another nuclear convoy after a regional radio station reported that April 10 had been tentatively set for moving spent nuclear fuel from three southern reactors for reprocessing in France. Government and company officials refused to comment.

A consignment of returned nuclear waste, the first for three years, was harried across Germany last week, and delayed by 18 hours. AP, Frankfurt

Nepal rebels

Maoist rebels opposed to the monarchy attacked police stations in two Nepalese mountain villages yesterday, killing at least 35 officers and injuring many others.

At least three of the rebels were killed, the police said. Reuters, Katmandu

webTitle: Gun culture still grips US schoolchildren

fields.headline: Gun culture still grips US schoolchildren
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: Three out of five US schoolboys say they have easy access to guns and one in five say they have taken a weapon to school in the past year, according to a survey which suggests that new security measures have not had much impact.
fields.body:
Three out of five US schoolboys say they have easy access to guns and one in five say they have taken a weapon to school in the past year, according to a survey which suggests that new security measures have not had much impact.

The Josephson Institute for Ethics, in California, also found that alcohol and guns were linked in a "toxic cocktail". More than 70% of secondary school students who said they had been drunk at school in the past year had access to a gun. Overall, 47% of the 15,877 students questioned agreed or strongly agreed that: "If I wanted to, I could get a gun."

Twenty-one per cent of students said they had taken a weapon to school in the past year, but it was not clear how many were guns. A 1999 survey found that 9% had carried a gun in the preceding 30 days.

Michael Josephson, the institute's president, said there was no sign that "the new sensitivity and new precautions" since the Columbine high school shooting in Colorado two years ago, in which two students killed 13 people and wounded 23 others, were having an impact.

"Today's teens, especially boys, have a high propensity to use violence when they are angry, they have easy access to guns, drugs and alcohol, and a disturbing number take weapons to school."

fields.headline: Sleazy shadow over Peruvian poll
fields.trailText: Peruvians go to the polls at the weekend for the first time since the disgraced president Alberto Fujimori fled to Japan five months ago.
fields.byline: Jane Diaz-Limaco in Lima and Alex Bellos
fields.body:
Peruvians go to the polls at the weekend for the first time since the disgraced president Alberto Fujimori fled to Japan five months ago. But despite the desire for a fresh start, the sleazy shadow of the old regime still hangs over the country.

Campaigning has been eclipsed by the revelation, in hundreds of secret videos, of a web of corruption extending to senior judges, army commanders, parliamentarians, ministers, business leaders, media owners, and even talk-show hosts.

Even though none of the three leading presidential candidates, Alejandro Toledo, Lourdes Flores and Alan Garcia, has appeared in any of the videos, their entourages have been tainted.

"There's a situation of generalised distrust," said Giovanna Penaflor, head of the polling company Imasen.

"Voters just don't know who to believe in any more."

The videos were shot by Mr Fujimori's spy-master Vladimiro Montesinos, mostly in the reception room at his intelligence service headquarters. The first one to appear last year caused both Mr Fujimori and Mr Montesinos to flee and provoked this Sunday's presidential and parliamentary elections.

Mr Montesinos' whereabouts are unknown: the latest reports were that he had secretly undergone plastic surgery in Venezuela. Despite his absence his spectre dominates the campaign trail.

Peruvians have been shocked to discover the extent of his power. He had almost all the Peruvian media in his pocket. One video shows him piling up hundreds of thousands of pounds in front of the owner of a popular television station. The station was being paid about £400,000 a month to give him the right to direct its news coverage.

The owner of the newspaper Expreso is under house arrest for allegedly taking £2 million from Mr Montesinos, a second television station's bosses face corruption charges, and another television magnate, Genaro Delgado Parker, was detained after a video showed him offering to shut down a hard-hitting political show in exchange for a helping hand with a court case.

Mr Montesinos' influence stretched into every arm of public life. He was filmed giving orders to senior judges and offering the new head of the electoral board an extra £7,000 a month in return for his compliance.

Investigators say that he may have built up a fortune of about £700 million from illegal commissions on arms deals, protecting drugs traffickers, corruption, blackmail and crooked business deals. So far £140 million has been found in foreign bank accounts.

Alejandro Toledo, the presidential favourite, expelled one of his MPs from the party after she acknowledged meeting Mr Montesinos twice, although she claimed that she did nothing wrong.

His senior congressional candidate, Carlos Ferrero, was also in a videos, although he was shown challenging Mr Montesinos about telephone tapping and other issues.

Mr Toledo has had to face up to his own video scandal. It is alleged that there is footage showing him consorting with prostitutes.

Mr Toledo says he may have been filmed in October 1998 when he was kidnapped by Mr Montesinos' cronies and doped.

Against this background of deceit, Peruvians are finding it harder than ever to pick a new leader. Pollsters say that the level of "don't knows" is higher than normal: about a fifth.

Ms Penaflor says: "It's not so easy to make a new start. There are too many things that you have to change at the same time - the crisis is economic, political, social and moral."

She adds: "It will probably take us five more years to make the transition to a true democracy."

webTitle: Israeli helicopter gunships kill Islamic militant in Gaza

fields.headline: Israeli helicopter gunships kill Islamic militant in Gaza
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli helicopter gunships hunted down and rocketed an Islamic Jihad commander in the Gaza Strip yesterday, the first such assassination since Ariel Sharon became prime minister.
fields.body:
Israeli helicopter gunships hunted down and rocketed an Islamic Jihad commander in the Gaza Strip yesterday, the first such assassination since Ariel Sharon became prime minister.

With yesterday's killing of Mohammed Abdel Al, 28, Mr Sharon appears to be trying to snuff out the six-month Palestinian intifada and calm Israeli anxieties about security. His security advisers say he favours assassinating Palestinian activists as part of a strategy of directly punishing the leaders of the uprising.

After the bombing of the residence of Yasser Arafat in Gaza City, and four mobile homes used by Mr Arafat's Force 17 bodguards in the West Bank city of Ramallah, yesterday's assassination further stoked passions in what is unfolding as a particularly bloody phase in the uprising. As darkness fell, a fierce gun battle was under way along the main road in the West Bank town of Bethlehem, with Israeli tanks and machine guns pounding blocks of flats fronting the Aida refugee camp.

An Israeli soldier was reportedly killed and several Palestinians injured - including a small girl who was hit in the eye by shrapnel - as a two-hour battle spilled over from the camp to the Paradise Hotel, another local landmark.

Witnesses said the hotel's top flour was almost completely destroyed by tank fire from nearby heights occupied by Jewish settlements.

The latest surge in violence is also driving up tension in Hebron, where hundreds of soldiers are deployed to protect an enclave of 400 extremist Jewish settlers. Overnight, the settlers rigged up a bomb from a gas cannister to blow up a Palestinian shop.

Yesterday's assassination is likely to provoke new international condemnation of Israel for returning to a policy which has seen the execution of at least a dozen Palestinian activists since the intifada began.

The lead-up to the killing began in Gaza yesterday morning when three attack helicopters started to circle the southern town of Rafah for several hours. Eventually, they located Abdel Al amid the squalor of the Brazil neighbourhood, whose open sewers and refugee hovels run right into the border with Egypt.

At least three missiles pierced his white Peugeot, reducing it to cinders and instantly killing the Islamic Jihad militant. "The first hit the rear of the car, and Abdel Al struggled to get out of the driver's seat. Another two missiles hit the vehicle, turning it into a ball of flame," said a witness, Salim Abu Yedin.

The assassination was the first since February, when Israel deployed helicopter gunships to kill a colonel in Mr Arafat's Force 17 unit as he was driving through Gaza City. In November, the car of Jamal Abdel Razak, a Fatah fighter, was ripped by machine guns, killing three other people.

The Israeli army accused Abdel Al of planting bombs along Israel's security road between Rafah and Egypt, and near Jewish settlements, and of arming suicide bombers who carried out a devastating attack inside Israel in 1995.

Abdel Al was jailed without charge by Mr Arafat's Palestinian Authority in 1997, when security forces of both sides waged a joint campaign against Hamas and Islamic Jihad bombers. But to Israel's fury, he and several hundred other militants were freed last October and regrouped to perpetrate a spate of bombings against Israeli civilians, including one last week that injured three people.

Efraim Sneh, Israel's deputy defence minister, defended the assassination. "He is the type of person we must target if we are serious about combating the violence," Mr Sneh told Israel radio yesterday. "People involved in terror are targets."

However, the Palestinians, still smarting from the seizure of five members of Force 17 by Israeli undercover units on Sunday, claimed the attack amounted to Israeli state-sponsored terrorism.

Last Friday, one of Mr Arafat's legion of advisers warned the Palestinian leader in writing that he had learned from his contacts in Israeli intelligence of a plan to assassinate senior members of the administration.

In Beirut, a statement from Islamic Jihad threatened revenge: "We say to the enemy leaders that assassinations and liquidations will not scare us. We are a people stronger than death"

fields.headline: Outrage at secret Botswana hanging
fields.standfirst: White South African woman sent to gallows
fields.trailText: Botswana secretly hanged a South African woman for murder at the weekend, without informing her husband, children or lawyers.
fields.body:
Botswana secretly hanged a South African woman for murder at the weekend, without informing her husband, children or lawyers.

Mariette Bosch, 50, was only the fourth woman hanged since independence in 1966, and the first white person to go to the gallows in Botswana. She was convicted of murdering a friend so that she could marry the woman's husband.

The government justified conducting the execution secretly at 5.30 on Saturday morning in the maximum security prison in Gaborone on the grounds that "controversy" surrounded the death sentence. But Bosch's lawyers said she was sent to the gallows with unusual haste.

Bosch was convicted last year of shooting Maria Wolmarans in 1996. A year later she married Wolmarans's husband, Tienie, with whom she had been having an affair.

The trial judge, Timothy Aguda, described her as a wicked and despicable woman who concocted an implausible story accusing the victim's employer of the killing. Her appeal against the conviction was rejected in January.

Yesterday Mr Wolmarans said he was bitter that the Botswanan authorities had prevented him and Bosch's two daughters visiting her on Friday. He was phoned on Sunday evening and told to go to the prison the next day. Only then did he learn that his wife had been hanged.

"They read her the death warrant on Friday night. The note she left said they would not allow her to see me or the children on Friday. They kept the whole thing a secret from us," he told the South African Press Association.

"I was going to take her some things on Friday. It was a scheduled visit. When I got to the prison I was told neither I nor the children could see her because there was an inspection going on. Now I know they were lying."

Mr Wolmarans said he does not know where his wife is buried. It is likely to be in an unmarked grave in the prison grounds.

Bosch's trial lawyer, Edward Fashole-Luke, questioned why she was executed so soon after an appeals court of Commonwealth judges upheld the conviction.

"Other guys have been on death row for years after their appeals. She was there only two months," he said.

Newly appointed lawyers were in the process of completing an application for clemency to President Festus Mogae, who alone has the power to commute the death penalty.

But Mr Mogae, who was in London when the sentence was carried out, has said that he believes in hanging as a form of retribution for murder.

Mr Wolmarans accused the South African government of failing to back his campaign to have the sentence commuted. A spokesman for Thabo Mbeki's office said the president had asked Mr Mogae to show clemency, but the Botswanan foreign ministry said it had received nothing in writing.

fields.headline: Robinson to stay on in UN post
fields.trailText: Mary Robinson has reversed her decision to step down as the UN commissioner for human rights, it was revealed last night. She has asked for a one-year extension to her term.
fields.body:
Mary Robinson has reversed her decision to step down as the UN commissioner for human rights, it was revealed last night. She has asked for a one-year extension to her term.

Two weeks ago she said she would leave her post at the end of a four-year stint in September, because she thought she could do more outside the "constraints" of the UN system.

But, said UN officials, she changed her mind after expressions of regret at her impending departure from many quarters.

Ms Robinson first informed senior UN officials of her decision at a lunch on Friday in Geneva for the secretary general, Kofi Annan, hosted by the French president, Jacques Chirac. Mr Annan and Ms Robinson both then attended a retreat at a resort outside the city later that day and she also made her decision known there, UN officials said last night.

She had previously complained that her office receives only about $20m from the UN's billion-dollar annual budge - not enough to cover the increasing workload of the body, which investigates human rights abuses around the world.

Mr Annan had expressed "great regret" at her decision to step down, saying she had been a "staunch and fearless spokesperson for human rights throughout the world" and had made a "critical contribution to giving human rights a central role in the United Nations system". AP

webTitle: Rebecca Mead: Why boys are not the new girls

Later this month, the United States celebrates its ninth annual Take Our Daughters to Work Day, dedicated to elevating the self-esteem of little girls by telling them that they, too, can have a career if they work hard in school and avoid eating disorders and teenage pregnancies and other such pitfalls of the feminine condition. It's too early to tell whether early exposure to the pleasures of the American workplace - the climate-controlled interiors, the machines that dispense bad coffee, the necessity of wearing uncomfortable hosiery - has had the desired effect; but the day itself, which was devised by the feminist Ms Foundation, has become part of mainstream American culture.

It has, as such, become an opportunity for shopping, an activity which is the American common denominator. The campaign for equality between the sexes can now begin in prepubescence with the purchase, via the Ms Foundation's website, of a close-fitting, baby style T-shirt bearing the Take Our Daughters to Work logo, a TODTW refrigerator magnet, or a mirror and lip balm set, the sales blurb for which reads: "Looking for a role model? Open our 2x3in hand mirror to see the Girl Force of the future!" The mirror is available in what the website describes as "five stylish colirs", spelling clearly not being one of the skills a girl needs to be taking seriously in the working world.

The merchandising of Take Our Daughters to Work was perhaps inevitable; as has been the criticism of the movement from the parents of sons who have voiced their concern that boys need attention, too, though they can perhaps do without baby Ts and lip balm. A cultural preoccupation with the perils of adolescent girlhood, best represented by Mary Pipher's 1994 bestseller, Reviving Ophelia, which described the familiar transformation of bright, peppy grade-schoolers into sullen, insecure teenagers, has been joined over the past couple of years by a chorus of experts pointing to the frailties of the male. Books with titles such as Raising Cain and Real Boys have argued that boys, too, are hemmed in by rigid gender stereotypes of toughness: that boys are inducted into a culture of cruelty, in which their capacities for compassion and sensitivity are squashed. Boys are the new girls, in need of remedial encouragement and support. The increasing occurrence of school shootings in America - a kind of Take Our Parents' Guns to School movement for alienated teenage males - has encouraged further examination of the pathologies of a standard boyhood.

This means that some workplaces have abandoned Take Our Daughters to Work Day in favour of Take Our Children to Work Day. Unsurprisingly, companies have found it hard to justify including boys by simply arguing that it's not fair to leave the boys out, since the whole point of TODTW was to counterbalance the inherent unfairness of the cultural hand that is dealt to girls. Rather, the prevailing argument for inclusion seems to be that such strides have been made for women in the workplace that it's time to let boys in on the annual event.

Anyone who believes that sunny diagnosis should take a look at a coruscating new book by Ann Crittenden, The Price of Motherhood: Why the Most Important Job in the World is Still the Least Valued, which details the myriad ways in which women who become mothers are penalised financially, compared with their childless sisters or the men who father those children.

The data in Crittenden's book reveal the dispiriting irony of Take Our Daughters to Work Day: that on every other day of the year, the American workplace is thoroughly inhospitable to children and their needs. There's no national entitlement for American mothers to a single day of paid maternity leave. Childcare provisions are thoroughly inadequate; you need a licence to own a dog in most states, but not to run a daycare centre. High-flying lawyers and factory workers alike are discouraged or prevented from adopting a part-time schedule by companies that ignore the demands of motherhood.

These, of course, are the kind of issues that feminist organisations like the Ms Foundation have been campaigning over for years; and the truth is that their efforts have improved the lot of the current generation of working women over that of their mothers.

Still, the little girls who go to Take Our Daughters to Work day would be well served by changes in the law that would make it easier for mothers to be available to their children and to hold down a job at the same time. If girls could look forward to a future in which their own career choices would not be unnecessarily compromised by having children - well, that would certainly beat having a day out at the office every year, even one that includes coming home with a goodie bag filled with feminist trinkets.

The Times they are a' changin'

The New York Times, the city's only daily broadsheet and the closest thing America has to a quality national daily newspaper, announced this week that it would start accepting personal ads from readers.

This is only the latest development in the mod ernising of the newspaper that has traditionally been known as the Grey Lady, and which bears on its front page the now rather quaint slogan: All the News that's Fit to Print. Colour printing was added some years ago. Next, the newspaper introduced a distinctively Timesian gossip column: there's no salaciousness or rumour, and instead there are a lot of well behaved items about parties attended by the rich and famous.

The Times's personals column will be in competition with some others that are so well known as to be institutions. The Village Voice offers the widest variety of gender/race/sexual orientation combinations that anyone in the market for a relationship, or even just a fling, could hope for. The New York Review of Books is the place to look for Ivy League graduates who enjoy opera, walks in the country, and travel to Paris, wistful francophilia being one of the endemic characteristics of the American educated classes. The best-known personals in town are those that appear in the back pages of New York magazine, which typically seem to be placed by a petite, vivacious Jewish woman in her late 30s or early 40s looking for a kind, non-neurotic, unattached, professional man to marry. The decision of the New York Times to run personals is, of course, itself a pursuit of a similarly elusive and desired love object: the advertiser's dollar.

 Rebecca Mead is a staff writer at the New Yorker. An archive of her work can be found at Rebeccamead.com. Charlotte Raven is away

fields.headline: No 1852: the black-bellied hamster
fields.trailText: Appearance: A foot-long rat.
fields.body:
Appearance: A foot-long rat.

Also called: Cricetus cricetus in Latin; Korenwolf in Dutch.

Not cute, then? It has an aggressive and solitary personality.

But it is veggie? It'll eat anything from lentils to baby birds.

Causing problems? You bet. It's stopping a hi-tech pan-European business development being built in Heerlen, on the Dutch-German border.

What's the damage? The Avantis European Science and Business Park was set to create thousands of jobs. The proposals won a European Commission prize for urban and regional planning in 1998. Millions in subsidies and investment are in the balance.

Ooh, the cheeky rodent! Well, it does inflate its big face pouches to help it swim around muddy fields.

Will it cause similar problems in British puddles? No, our engineers' pet hates are badgers and newts.

So how many live on the proposed site? Well, none actually. It's a hypothetical hamster.

How so? The local paper Limburgs Dagsblad has yet to find anyone who has seen one. The town's council says an 84-year-old farmer remembers spotting one in 1949.

So it's extinct? Endangered, says the commission, which is now taking legal action against Germany and the Netherlands for not protecting it.

Who says it lives there? The commission asked Professor Michael Stubbe, a world authority on hamsters, to investigate. He spent a few hours at the site in winter (when hamsters hibernate) and didn't see any, but thought it was a natural habitat for them.

Holes in his argument? Investors say the odd burrow at the site could have been made by workmen's sticks.

Who is going to win? The hamster, if it bothers to turn up to court.

Public reaction? Well, environmentalists are fuming.

Not to be confused with: George Bush.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Clock-watching
fields.trailText: Clock-watching
fields.body:
Somerset

On a Saturday afternoon at the village of West Lydford, beside the Fosse Way, I was shown a letter to a newspaper dated December 1 1847 which described the proposal to standardise time across the nation for the sake of railway timetabling as "transcendentally absurd". The sun's vertical noontide height in this part of Somerset is some 9 minutes behind the equivalent at Greenwich, and on the Sunday morning I went to see how the sexton at Martock had ensured by means of "Scratch dials" on the south wall, that (at least when the sun was shining) the bell for Matins rang at just the right moment every day by Martock time. And why should medieval Martock folk care what the time might be in Taunton, much less Greenwich? There are several dials scratched on this particular church, the simplest just a small semicircle with a hole for the shadowstick or "gnomon", and four grooves to mark service times.

By chance, on the same day, I passed the famous 14th-century Wells Cathedral clock, whose elaborate mechanisms record hours, minutes, days of the lunar month and phases of the moon. But experts say that, unlike the sexton's simple dial at Martock, the Wells clock could have been out by as much as two hours in a day. A monk from Downside in the early 1900s found more than 200 "mass" or "scratch" dials on Somerset churches, and now my hosts at Lydford (she a retired teacher of Mathematics and he a retired Engineer) have revived his study, and themselves fashioned lovely modern examples such as the one that marks the centenary of Wincanton School, and a millennium dial commissioned by Somerton's University of the Third Age.
