webTitle: DJ Taylor unravels the mystery of his grandfather

fields.headline: You must be joking
fields.standfirst: John William Taylor was a famously reserved first world war veteran who worked for the electricity board. He was also TT Taylor, semi-professional comedian and exhibitionist. DJ Taylor tries to unravel the mystery of his grandfather
fields.trailText: John William Taylor was a famously reserved first world war veteran who worked for the electricity board. He was also TT Taylor, semi-professional comedian and exhibitionist.  DJ Taylor tries to unravel the mystery of his grandfather.
fields.body:
My grandfather died in 1951, nearly a decade before I was born. Half a century later, not much of him survives: a few postcards sent home from the western front; a row of medals that go back even further to the Boer war; a snap or two of an ironic-looking party, him in a straw hat supervising a charabanc trip on Great Yarmouth front sometime in the 20s. But by far the most vivid representations of him are a bundle of postcard-size photographs that my father kept in a box under the stairs, along with the scrapbook record of his career as an amateur footballer and the stacks of antique Norwich City match programmes.

There are five or six of these mementoes. One, captioned "TT Taylor: Comedian" (my grandfather's baptismal names were John William), shows him in evening dress with slicked-down hair athwart a series of pictures of himself in "character sketches". The others are blow-ups of this thumb-size gazetteer: a tragic clown in a feathered cap; a bowler-hatted, cane-toting boulevardier. Presumably intended for use as professional calling cards, each is signed: "Yours sincerely, TT Taylor."

I can see my own face in these half-dozen prints, and also my father's (although the tragic clown portrait bears a faint resemblance to Tony Hancock). Yet their oddity lies in the landscapes from which I know - or suspect - them to have emerged. Every heritage sleuth worth his salt is familiar with the idea of a bygone family life - especially a Victorian family life - that conceals mighty secrets, but my grandfather's early years are as impenetrable as a briar hedge. His son, for example, now nearing 80, has no idea who his own grandparents were. In the three decades they spent together in "furnished rooms" and council houses on the western side of Norwich, my grandfather never once directly mentioned his parents. A few oblique references to "a certain gentleman" (as in "a certain gentleman liked mustard on his sausages"), whom my father reckons to have been his grandfather, but nothing more.

There are a few indisputable facts. Born in 1882. (My father thinks that the parents died young, leaving John William and his four brothers and sisters to be brought up in care.) Under-age enlistment in the Boer war. Four years in Flanders before being invalided out with shrapnel wounds at Mons. Marriage to my grandmother in 1920. A quarter-century working for the local electricity board. My father remembers a tallish (5ft 9in - a respectable height for a working-class man 80 years ago), rake-thin character, famously reserved and uneasy in the field of personal relationships (he apparently conducted whole conversations using the words "Just so" and "Indeed"), and capable of nursing the most fanatical resentments. He spent the last decade of his life not speaking to his sister's family after his nephew Gordon registered as a conscientious objector, and even on his death-bed refused to allow them to be sent for.

Squaring this with the idea of TT Taylor, who delighted in putting on fancy dress and making a semi-professional exhibition of himself at local concert parties, involves a certain amount of psychological guesswork. It was 60 and more years ago, and the only extant witness is my father (he maintains that "TT" singing a music-hall number like Ours Is A Nice House Ours Is, or Everything At Home Goes Underneath The Bed (sample verse: I'm fond of English history, so to my wife I said/ "Can you tell me, my darling Kate, where King Charles lost his head?"/ She said: "I don't know, I'll have a look, perhaps it's underneath the bed") was the funniest thing he ever saw.) Clearly the greasepaint, the comic hats and the jokes ("My wife's so thin that when she drinks tomato juice she looks like a thermometer") brought out a side to my grandfather's character that would otherwise have lain dormant, providing a kind of emotional release that reconciled him to the Norwich back-to-backs and the meter-reading.

Or perhaps, on the other hand, there was more humour to my grandfather's life than anyone ever realised. Certainly, there were comic misunderstandings. Politically, he was an old-style Liberal, contemptuous of the Conservatives ("What have they ever done for the working man?") and Labour ("a load of riff-raff") alike. Come the 1935 general election, and the preordained return of the National Government, my father - then aged 14 - asked him who he intended to vote for. "I shall be voting for Mr Geoffrey Shakespeare, the Liberal candidate," he replied. "But dad, he's a National Liberal. They vote with the Conservatives." "I don't know anything about that," he said.

He had, too, a definite gift for dead-pan repartee. On one occasion, reading the meter somewhere, the woman who admitted him asked if "that Mr Taylor" still worked for the electricity company. My grandfather acknowledged that this was so. Various other remarks followed. "A very pleasant gentleman," the woman summed up, "although he always seemed to have a very great deal to say for himself." "By the way, madam," my grandfather remarked, as he was quitting the premises, "I am that man."

It would be wrong to pretend that my grandfather "inspired" in the conventional sense my latest book, The Comedy Man, whose cover he adorns. For a start, the chronology is all wrong: the book starts in 1945, whereas TT's concert-party days ended a decade-and-a-half before. Added to that, Upward & King, the novel's fictitious double-act, are cast as genuine celebrities, whereas JW Taylor carried on living in his council house, "paying his football" (his description of the Friday night trip to the pub) and working for the electricity board. At the same time, throughout the writing, I was always conscious of him there in my mind - the mournful clown in the feathered cap, the Max Milleresque cheeky chappie with the bowler and cane - and behind him that great, lost, early 20th-century English world that even now has the capacity to make us what we are.

 D J Taylor's The Comedy Man is published by Duck Editions, price £9.99

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Howling At The Moon | Barking Or Biting |
fields.body:
Brian Morton tells the strange story of Louis Hardin in Howling At The Moon (1.30pm, Radio 4). Accidentally blinded in his youth, Hardin was musically trained at a special school in Iowa and continued at the Memphis Conservatory. Moving to New York in the 1940s he survived for three decades as Moondog, a busker working in full Viking dress. But he had orchestral ambitions, and typed his scores in Braille. When Columbia Records issued an LP of his work, Hardin gratefully moved his street performances to outside their studios.

It's 12 months since the Disability Rights Commission started work, and Peter White casts an anniversary eye over its record so far. The commission is there to ensure that employers and other organisations observe the recently introduced law requiring proper arrangements for people with a handicap. In Barking Or Biting (8.0pm, Radio 4) White tracks various commissioners' experiences since they took up their jobs. They have already uncovered a variety of unforeseen problems in making the legislation effective.

In the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) Nicholas Tresilian retrieves some of the less familiar musical offerings inspired by Shakespeare's plays. He can only skim lightly over what is clearly a vast range. There are more than 400 operas and musicals and someone has worked out that 20,000 shorter works can be added to them.

In the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) Nicholas Tresilian retrieves some of the less familiar musical offerings inspired by Shakespeare's plays. He can only skim lightly over what is clearly a vast range. There are more than 400 operas and musicals and someone has worked out that 20,000 shorter works can be added to them.

fields.headline: Super furry animal
fields.trailText: Yeti: Hunt For The Wildman | Coronation Street
fields.body:
"This is the forest primaeval"

Longfellow

Yeti: Hunt For The Wildman (Channel 4) was well worth the walk for the beauty of Bhutan (Tibet and turn south) and the charm of the people, who all seemed either related to the king or employed by him. If you fancy being a king, trust me, Bhutan is the place to be.

One eyewitness was a royal guard walking home on leave. "Suddenly," he said, "I saw a creature like an ape. For two or three minutes we stood opposite each other. It was huge. It must have been nine feet tall. The arms were enormous and hairy. The face was red with a nose like a chimpanzee." (And if you are going to have a guard, this is the kind of guard to have. Someone who will face a nine- foot ape for three minutes.) "I have heard", he added kindly, "that people in Western countries only believe in what they see. I have seen the meegur and it is real." What Tibetans call the yeti, Bhutanese call the meegur.

The Westerners seeking ocular evidence were Rob, a zoologist, Ted, a cameraman, and Sarah, a specialist in primates. They were all young and hopeful except Richard, a science writer, who prefaced every sentence with, "As a sceptic...". This irritated Sarah into saying that in any Hollywood film he would be the first to go. He would too.

Their interpreter, a cousin of the king, took them to a monastery to see a yeti, which had been killed by local people. It's face was set in a black mask of tragedy. On the analogy of the Salem witch trials, Richard concluded it was some unfortunate misfit. "It seemed to me that what had died that night was a scapegoat, and it's human face was still permanently fixed in a moment of horror and surprise."

Yak herders, not widely known as wags, offered practical advice. If you meet a female yeti, run downhill. Her breasts, which she slings over her shoulders, will fall down and trip her up.

The disconsolate little group were straggling home when they came across an impromptu party in honour of the king's birthday. Among them was the King's Yeti Hunter. Posh or what! Queen Victoria once asked the painter Landseer, as you would, why he had a dog in his pocket. Landseer said it was a champion ratter. The queen called for a rat, which was promptly produced by the Queen's Rat Catcher. Those were the days. I do feel that royalty has gone downhill since then, like a yak herder being chase by a female yeti.

The air was thickening like whipped cream, and the first snow was powdering the mountain passes, as the King's Yeti Hunter guided them to a magnificent hollow cedar which was, he assured them, a yeti's lair. My respect for the occupant grew. Cedar not only smells nice, it repels moths, a boon for the furry. Dr Rob McCall, the zoologist, found one long, black hair caught on the wood. You could hear him struggling with his own incredulity. "Our guide understands animals so well, I'm trusting him that this isn't a bear. But everything else suggests that it is."

They took the hair back to Professor Bryan Sykes in Oxford, a pioneer of DNA identification. It was not a bear. It was not a primate nor a human being. Professor Sykes could not match the DNA to any known species. He said, "It's mysterious. It's certainly mysterious. There was a nice, plump hair follicle. We normally wouldn't have any difficulty at all. It's a mystery and I didn't think this would end in a mystery." He spoke on a sigh. The West does not like mysteries unless the butler did it. The king's cousin sees things differently. "The Bhutanese are not particularly bothered to prove its existence. They know there is something there. Let it be there."

Coronation Street (ITV) has got itself in a pretty pickle. They are committed to two story lines which have been overtaken by events in the lethal sense that hares are overtaken by greyhounds. One is The Great Weatherfield Prime Pork Sausage Contest (which has trundled on helplessly, not daring to mention foot and mouth disease) and the other is Cllr Audrey Roberts's campaign in the forthcoming council elections (which have just been postponed until June). As things are, Audrey will be running for office for months, while the poor pigs can run at all.

Don't mention the viewing figures for Who Shot Phil Mitchell? Can't you see you're upsetting them?

fields.headline: Loyalists recruit the next generation
fields.standfirst:
Alarm as teenagers flock to join paramilitaries

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Loyalist paramilitaries are signing up hundreds of teenagers as recruits, even though they are supposed to be on ceasefire.
fields.body:
As the Real IRA ups its terrorist campaign in Northern Ireland and mainland Britain, loyalist paramilitaries are signing up hundreds of teenagers as recruits, even though they are supposed to be on ceasefire, sources said.

A small renegade group, the Orange Volunteers, which opposes the peace process, is recruiting on a modest scale for a doomsday "defend Ulster" scenario. It is on "strategic cessation" but has threatened that dissident republican attacks in London could soon spark retaliation, possibly in the Irish Republic.

But the two main Protestant organisations, the Ulster Defence Association/Ulster Freedom Fighters, and the Ulster Volunteer Force, both on ceasefire since October 1994, are also taking on new members at an alarming rate.

They argue that they are doing this is to keep young people out of the clutches of dissidents and drug barons.

However, security sources are concerned that the network of paramilitary influence is widening rather than shrinking following the Good Friday agreement, and that it could pose big problems, should the political process break down.

Recent police finds in Belfast of a pipe bomb factory, thought to belong to the UVF, and of weapons linked to the dissident Loyalist Volunteer Force, are worrying the security forces.

"We are aware of recruitment but a more dramatic increase might be expected before Drumcree [the anniver sary of the disputed Portadown Orange Order march in July]," said a security source.

The leader of the UDA's south Belfast brigade said: "In the past, it was the done thing in many loyalist areas to join the paramilitaries, and a lot of kids still want to get involved. Now, they are growing up in a void and we've got to keep control and give them a sense of identity.

"The Ulster Young Militants [the UDA youth wing] used not to take them until they were 17 or 18, but now it's 14 or 15 because they are at an age where they are bowing to peer pressure. We've taken on hundreds in south Belfast alone and around the country.

"We're not teaching them to shoot or bomb, but we're trying to educate them about history, computers, and job skills. Most of us were sceptical about the agreement from the start, and all six UDA brigades are against it now, but we do want peace."

Security sources blamed individuals within the UDA for the recent pipe bomb campaign, which has targeted more than 50 Catholic homes since the start of the year, but seems to have petered out since the UDA command issued an edict for them to stop.

The UDA south Belfast brigadier condemned the attacks, and said he thought renegade groups and youths who did not belong to any organisation were responsible.

Security sources have accused the UDA/UFF in Belfast's lower Shankill area, under the command of the jailed Johnny Adair, of serious involvement in drug dealing. Teenage loyalists in other parts of Northern Ireland, such as Ballymena, Co Antrim, have been involved in sectarian intimidation. The south Belfast brigadier said that neither the UDA nor the rival UVF could deny some members were drug dealers or had got into sectarian fights but claimed responsible leaders were trying to educate young people about drug dangers.

A senior UVF man said his organisation, which he stressed was totally behind the Good Friday deal, was recruiting young members, from 17 upwards, but mainly to keep them from the UDA, which they believed was heavily involved in drugs.

He admitted there was still a level of weapons training "to maintain their interest". Regarding recent police finds of pipe bombs and dossiers on republicans, he said: "If people think the UVF doesn't have war material, they are gravely mistaken."

While the UDA/UFF and UVF have thousands of members, the dissident Orange Volunteers are believed to have only around 100 active members, but a source close to the leadership insisted that there was a steady stream of people of all ages interested in joining.

The Orange Volunteers want an independent Northern Ireland with a majority unionist government.

The source claimed many were also members of the Orange Order and a significant number were former soldiers or policemen.

"Many are also born again Christians. There have been wild stories about guns and bombs being blessed before an operation, but that is not true."

The Orange Volunteers have hinted they could launch gun and bomb attacks on republican areas of Northern Ireland, and also in Dublin, in future if they believed it would further their cause.

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: A Matter Of Life And Death | The Duellists | The General's Daughter | Gloria | Solaris
fields.body:
Films

A Matter Of Life And Death (Michael Powell, Emeric Pressburger, 1946) 6pm, FilmFour: RAF airman David Niven bales out of his blazing bomber and survives, but headless Marius Goring, a fatality of the French Revolution, is unimpressed: he is dispatched from heaven to tell the flier he should not have missed his date with death. This is one of P&P's wittiest, funniest, most involving fantasies, as Niven argues for his life in an otherworldly court.

The Duellists (Ridley Scott, 1977) 10pm, FilmFour: Scott, director of the Oscar-winning Gladiator, showed here in his feature-film debut that he already knew a thing or two about swordplay. Based on a Joseph Conrad story, it stars Keith Carradine and a demonic Harvey Keitel as a pair of Hussars who can't resist a slice of the action. So during pauses in the Napoleonic wars they take to carving each other up in a series of duels of honour.

The General's Daughter (Simon West, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier: A glossy, professional and nasty thriller in which John Travolta's army cop investigates the rape and murder of an officer (Leslie Stefanson) at a Florida military base. She's the daughter of General James Cromwell, and when Travolta uncovers evidence of her S&M sessions with fellow officers, the trail gets murky indeed. It's not written well enough to justify the tacky voyeurism, but there are decent performances, with Madeleine Stowe as Travolta's colleague and ex, and best of all James Woods as a colonel who is the prime suspect.

Gloria (Sidney Lumet, 1999) 12midnight, Sky Premier: An ambitious remake of John Cassavetes' classic 1980 thriller. Sharon Stone makes a creditable attempt at Gloria, the hard-as-nails moll who takes a young orphan (Jean-Luke Figueroa) under her wing to protect him from the mob; trouble is, Cassavetes' wife Gena Rowlands pretty much made the role her own in the original, and Lumet's direction seems oddly distracted.

Solaris (Andrei Tarkovsky, 1972) 1.25am, FilmFour Based on the novel by Polish author Stanislaw Lem, this cult sci-fi movie was considered the Soviet riposte to 2001: A Space Odyssey. It certainly matches the cerebral scheme of Kubrick's film, although it lacks the visual pyrotechnics. Cosmonaut Donatas Banionis is sent to a space station on the mysterious planet Solaris to investigate why most of the 80-odd crew have died, and finds that the whole planet is a sentient force mirroring human desires. It's a long, slow, but hypnotic voyage.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Football 7pm, ONsport 1: It's European week again, and over the next three days the best of British (well, they're all English to be fair) take on the best of Europe (mostly Spain, to tell the truth) in the serious, no-second-chances, knock-out stages. Kicking off the whole extravaganza is Manchester United, the only English team to have avoided Spanish opposition, although, facing a repeat of their 1999 European Cup final against Bayern Munich, that is a dubious privilege.
Simon Burnton

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.trailText: Daily Telegraph
fields.body:
Daily Telegraph

Deferral is a victory for William Hague, who has shown himself to be more in touch and more statesmanlike than anyone in the government ... It is still open to Mr Blair to do the truly patriotic thing and announce that elections will be held back until the crisis is over.

Financial Times

An election might well have restored a sense of perspective. The risk of even this short delay is that it will reinforce the perception outside the UK that the country is in a state of uncontrolled chaos.

Daily Express

Postponement is the correct course ... The government must concen trate on defeating foot and mouth rather than fighting party political battles. The Conservatives should resist the temptation to make cheap political capital from farmers' misery.

Daily Mail

Delaying for a month is not the answer - certainly not for an administration that has over a year of its term still to run...

He should not even be thinking of his re-election until this calamity is well and truly behind us.

The Times

The public would probably have re-elected Labour if polling had gone ahead on May 3; but they would have seen the exercise as distasteful.

The Mirror

Not for the first time, Tony Blair has rolled over and given in when faced with a tough decision. Postponing the election is sending out completely the wrong message. It's time to show that Britain is open for business.

fields.headline: Sidney Dillon Ripley
fields.standfirst: He transformed Washington's museums from stuffy bastions of culture into centres for the people
fields.trailText: He transformed Washington's museums from stuffy bastions of culture into centres for the people.
fields.body:
As its secretary from 1964 to 1984, the American zoologist and museum director Sidney Dillon Ripley, who has died aged 87, led the transformation of the Smithsonian Institution, in Washington, from a stuffy bastion of science and culture into a combination of education, amusement and entertainment with widespread appeal. He wanted to "awaken all Americans to the fact that the Smithsonian belonged to them, not to a bunch of curmudgeons on Capitol Hill".

This became evident during 1968 as poor people's campaigners camped out near the Lincoln Memorial after the Washington riots and the assassination of Martin Luther King. Ridley reminded worried staff that "these people are American citizens, and they must be made to feel welcome in our museums". When thousands of anti-Vietnam war demonstrators converged, he told Smithsonian guards to treat them with dignity and respect.

Ripley's empire in the US capital also included the National Portrait Gallery, the National Zoo, the National Museum of American Art, the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute and the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory. Another centre, the Renwick Gallery, resulted from his suggestion to President Lyndon Johnson that a building opposite the White House would be an ideal place to show off US art to visiting dignitaries.

Ripley was also a prime mover in the launch of the Anacostia Neighborhood Museum, especially for Washington's black community. The Hirshhorn Museum, housing a uranium millionaire's unprecedented modern art collection, and the $75m South Quadrangle complex for the museums of Asian and African Art were further achievements.

His younger life had been an adventure of a very different sort. The son of a Manhattan stockbroker, his great grandfather was Sidney Dillon, the Union Pacific railroad's first chairman, who acquired the 2,000-acre Connecticut estate where the 10-year old Ripley diverted a stream to create a wildfowl pond. At 13, he went on a walking tour of Tibet.

His professional life was to be largely shaped by his passion for natural history - birds, in particular - and travel. Educated at a Massachussetts boarding school, his realisation that museums should be accessible and varied was fired by a holiday in Paris - with visits to the Louvre, rides on a carousel and watching Punch and Judy shows in the Tuileries gardens. After becoming secretary at the Smithsonian, he had a carousel installed on Washington's National Mall. He marked his graduation in history from Yale University in 1936 by joining an 18-month expedition to the South Seas aboard a 59ft schooner.

After gaining his doctorate at Harvard in 1943, Ripley joined the Office of Strategic Services, the forerunner of the CIA, and was sent to south-east Asia. His duties included coordinating Anglo-American intelligence efforts and training agents bound for Japanese-held territory. When opportunities arose, he added to his specimen collections.

Joining the Yale faculty in 1946, he gained international recognition as a zoologist, and became a professor of zoology, a professor of biology and director of the uni versity's Peabody Museum, from 1959-64, after which he went to the Smithsonian.

On his retirement 20 years later, the Smithsonian had 4,500 employees, a $250m annual budget and more than 30m visitors a year. He described the job as "one of the most complex and pleasurable in the world". The institution had "electricity, and surprise and sometimes shock. Excitement pervades the place."

Ripley embarked on many expeditions. He spent almost a year with the Karoon cannibals of New Guinea, ret-urning with 1,300 rare birds for museums. He explored parts of Nepal never before seen by westerners, and found a bird species - the spiny babbler - that had not been recorded for a century. These experiences were reflected in two of his 10 books, Trail Of The Money Bird (1942) and Search For The Spiny Babbler (1953). His most distinguished work was the 10-volume Handbook Of The Birds Of India And Pakistan (1968-74), co-written with Salim Ali, a comprehensive guide to the sub-continent's 1,200-plus species.

When he retired, the Smithsonian gave Ripley the title of secretary emeritus and an office to continue his research. An ultimate tribute was paid in 1985 when he was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, America's highest civilian honour.

His wife, Mary, whom he had married in 1949, died in 1996. He is survived by his three daughters and 11 grand- children.

Sidney Dillon Ripley, ornithologist and museum director, born September 20 1913; died March 12 2001

At 13, he went on a walking tour of Tibet. His professional life was to be largely shaped by his passion for natural history - birds, in particular - and travel. Educated at a Massachussetts boarding school, his realisation that museums should be accessible and varied was fired by a holiday in Paris - with visits to the Louvre, rides on a carousel and watching Punch and Judy shows in the Tuileries gardens. After becoming secretary at the Smithsonian, he had a carousel installed on Washington's National Mall. He marked his graduation in history from Yale University in 1936 by joining an 18-month expedition to the South Seas aboard a 59ft schooner. After gaining his doctorate at Harvard in 1943, Ripley joined the Office of Strategic Services, the forerunner of the CIA, and was sent to south-east Asia. His duties included coordinating Anglo-American intelligence efforts and training agents bound for Japanese-held territory. When opportunities arose, he added to his specimen collections. Joining the Yale faculty in 1946, he gained international recognition as a zoologist, and became a professor of zoology, a professor of biology and director of the uni versity's Peabody Museum, from 1959-64, after which he went to the Smithsonian. On his retirement 20 years later, the Smithsonian had 4,500 employees, a $250m annual budget and more than 30m visitors a year. He described the job as "one of the most complex and pleasurable in the world". The institution had "electricity, and surprise and sometimes shock. Excitement pervades the place." Ripley embarked on many expeditions. He spent almost a year with the Karoon cannibals of New Guinea, ret-urning with 1,300 rare birds for museums. He explored parts of Nepal never before seen by westerners, and found a bird species - the spiny babbler - that had not been recorded for a century. These experiences were reflected in two of his 10 books, Trail Of The Money Bird (1942) and Search For The Spiny Babbler (1953). His most distinguished work was the 10-volume Handbook Of The Birds Of India And Pakistan (1968-74), co-written with Salim Ali, a comprehensive guide to the sub-continent's 1,200-plus species. When he retired, the Smithsonian gave Ripley the title of secretary emeritus and an office to continue his research. An ultimate tribute was paid in 1985 when he was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, America's highest civilian honour. His wife, Mary, whom he had married in 1949, died in 1996. He is survived by his three daughters and 11 grand- children. Sidney Dillon Ripley, ornithologist and museum director, born September 20 1913; died March 12 2001

fields.headline: Michael Leifer
fields.standfirst: Political scientist with unrivalled knowledge of south-east Asia
fields.trailText: Political scientist with unrivalled knowledge of south-east Asia.
fields.body:
Professor Michael Leifer, who has died aged 67, was the doyen of British scholars specialising in the politics and international relations of south-east Asia. His expertise extended from Indo-China, and particularly Cambodia, to the Philippines, embracing Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia. He was also general editor of Politics In Asia, the Routledge series that comprises nearly 40 volumes.

Leifer was professor of international relations at the London School of Economics, and its pro-director from 1991-95. In the latter role, he offered wise advice and a steadying influence at a time when the LSE was audaciously vying to relocate to County Hall, the headquarters of the defunct Greater London Council.

Leifer was the elder son of a tailor, born and brought up in Clapton, east London, an area that has produced many distinguished academics from relatively humble origins. Nurtured in an observant Jewish household, he attended Davenant Foundation grammar school in Whitechapel, and became a violinist with the London Youth Orchestra.

He graduated from Reading University in 1956, and moved to the LSE, where he studied for his doctorate on the politics of the Middle East under the vigorous supervision of Elie Kedourie. He then became a lecturer at the University of Adelaide, where he refocused his research to south-east Asia.

In 1963, with the expansion of British universities in the wake of the Robbins Report (1963), Leifer was recruited by AH Birch, who had recently been appointed to the foundation chair of politics at Hull University. By a mixture of luck and judgment, Birch gathered round him a remarkable group of young academics, almost all of whom were destined for professorships and who established a momentum for scholarly prowess that has been sus tained by the Hull department of politics to this day. Leifer was doubly fortunate in that, following the 1961 Hayter Report, Hull had been designated a specialist centre for south-east Asian studies.

In 1969, he was recalled to the LSE, where he rose steadily from lecturer to reader, and then to professor of international relations. His scholarly output was characterised by a breadth of interest, combined with a meticulous dedication to detail. He held a series of visiting appointments at the Australian National University, Cornell, Singapore and the Philippines. As a teacher, his strength lay in graduate supervision, and many of his protégés, who comprised many nationalities, now occupy academic and diplomatic posts throughout the world.

Beneath a gentle, cautious and unassuming demeanour, Leifer had a shrewd and pragmatic mind. When he retired from his chair in 1999, the LSE retained him part-time as the Sir John Bembridge director of its Asia research centre. He was appointed CMG earlier this year. He was, above all, a devoted family man.

He is survived by Frances, his wife of 45 years, and their three sons.

fields.headline: Ebou Dibba
fields.trailText: Ebou Dibba, who was found drowned at the age of 57, was an important Gambian novelist, who, earlier, as director of the adult education centre at Bletchingley, Surrey, left an indelible mark on a typical home counties community - the last place where an unconventional, creative African might choose to work.
fields.body:
Ebou Dibba, who was found drowned at the age of 57, was an important Gambian novelist, who, earlier, as director of the adult education centre at Bletchingley, Surrey, left an indelible mark on a typical home counties community - the last place where an unconventional, creative African might choose to work. It was a strange destiny, and one of remarkable power and influence, but when he lost the position in 1993, it seemed to break his spirit.

Ebou was born in Bathurst (now Banjul), the capital of the Gambia, then a British colony. His father's family was from Baddibu, a Mandinka area up-river, but his mother was a Wollof, and he grew up in the prevalent Wollof culture of the capital. His recollections of that urban life infuse his first two novels, Chaff On The Wind and Fafa, both written in the 1980s.

Both convey a strong sense of period, with an awareness of African culture confronted with colonial reality. Chaff, in fact, is set in the 1930s, before Ebou was born, but it has an almost psychic feeling of what it was like at that time. His third, short novel, Alhaji, was set in a contemporary Gambia of tourists and conmen, in which everything is changed. Unfortunately, this exploration of new subject matter was never followed up.

Educated at the Gambian Methodist high school, Ebou was an exceptionally bright student; he is still remembered as the first Gambian to gain three A-levels. He won a scholarship to University College, Cardiff, in the late 1960s, at a time when Neil Kinnock was president of the students' union. He studied French classical literature, and took a year out teaching English in Toulon, before graduating and moving to King's College London to complete his MA.

In the early 1970s, Ebou worked as a teacher at an adult education centre in Muswell Hill, north London, and at a drug clinic, as well as helping at the Phoenix youth club in Kilburn. He moved to Bletchingley in 1974, initially to teach modern languages and organise classes for the disadvantaged, before becoming principal in 1975.

At the centre, he created a realm the like of which neither Bletchingley or Surrey adult education had seen the like before; he saw his role as that of a missionary for African culture and values in the darkest of home counties. This was not a case of simply bringing African drummers and writers to the heartland of southeast England, but of sharing himself freely with an English community.

Dibba knew everyone; for him, a walk through the village, stopping and passing the time of day with everyone, turned into a pilgrimage. He also developed a remarkable network of contacts that he inveigled into visiting the centre. Yehudi Menuhin opened the new building in 1986, and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, of Cape Town, inaugurated a further new block in 1993. Judi Dench, Melvyn Bragg, Jonathan Miller, John Cleese, Mike Brearley, Ian Botham and many others also made appearances.

In 1993, Ebou was awarded an MBE, which he was both proud of and ironic about, since it made him a member of the British empire. His departure from the centre - he was "rationalised", according to local sources - was a great blow, partly because he felt he had been personally rejected. Although he tried to make a new life not far away in Edenbridge, Kent, he never really recovered. He was found dead in a river near a flooded cricket pitch he used to walk around.

Motivated by a sense of common humanity, Ebou had the boldness, as a sensitive and outgoing African, to reach to the heart of middle England. Like Icarus, he had the temerity to fly too close to the sun, and the wings which had borne him so high melted in disappointment and despair. But multicultural Britain has need of more like him.

He is survived by four children from two marriages.

Ebrima 'Ebou' Dibba, writer and teacher, born August 10 1943; died late 2000

fields.headline: John Napper
fields.standfirst: Artist who invented a unique way of focusing the radiance of colour
fields.trailText: Artist who invented a unique way of focusing the radiance of colour.
fields.body:
Self-questioning, experimentation and hard work were the keys to the art of John Napper, who has died aged 84. His work went through many periods and stages of development and, in the last 15 years, when he mainly painted in water-colours, he invented a unique way of focusing the radiance of colour which watercolour artists, notably Turner and Whistler, had discovered through the diffusion of light in the watery medium.

Napper always wanted to be a painter. His mother was an opera singer and his father an actor and watercolourist. Their son grew into a large, gentle-mannered man, an expert on everything, with a twinkle of self-parody in his eye.

He was educated at Frensham Heights, Surrey, and privately. He trained at the Dundee School of Art and the Royal Academy School, under Sir Gerald Kelly, one of the leading portraitists of the era, in the demanding and traditional manner of classical painting. At the end of every day, he had to clean the brushes Kelly had used, frequently hundred or more of them. That way, Kelly said, Napper would learn more about technique than by watching him paint. The young artist never forgot this lesson and, in an arts and crafts sense, his technical ability, knowledge and workmanship were superb.

During the second world war, Napper was sent as a war artist to Ceylon and east Africa. The violent sensuality, colour and form of the tropics had a profound effect on his work and composition. His 1935 marriage to Hedvig Armour had ended in divorce; back in London in 1945, he met and married his great love, the beautiful Pauline Davidson, who became his lifelong muse, model, companion and inspiration.

He taught life art at St Martin's School of Art from 1949-57, and became a fashionable portrait painter. His portrait of the Queen in the Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool, is impressive, although, as he often said, it was "not a portrait of the Queen but of a queen". As if in unconscious protest at the formality of the composition, the head is slightly out of proportion with the magnificent scale of the rest of the work.

Napper did not want to emulate Kelly by becoming a society portrait painter, so, in 1957, he and his wife moved to Paris, and a studio in La Ruche (the Beehive) in outer Montparnasse. From 1900-25, the area harboured some of the greatest Russian emigré artists, among them Leger, Zadkine, Brancusi, Chagall, Kisling and Soutine. Modigliani often stayed there, as did Lenin and Trotsky. When the Nappers arrived, they had virtually no money, and it was intensely cold - they often slept fully-dressed in their overcoats.

La Ruche was next door to the Vaugirard slaughterhouses, then the largest in Paris, and the Nappers benefited from the culinary generosity of the abattoir workers (as had Soutine 35 years earlier). John produced dark brooding oils, powerful expressionist works which he occasionally showed to acquaintances in later years. But the trauma of making them in the midst of poverty, depression and alcoholism finally forced him to leave La Ruche.

His next port of call was Brittany, where he became friendly with Georges Braque, and began a fascination with folk music and musicians which would last for the rest of his life. After spending time in the remote Auvergne, he associated with the separatist, environmentalist, Breton folk music move-ment, and met musicians like Youenn Gwernnig, the spiritual brother to Jack Kerouac, also of Breton origin.

Napper's worldwide folk music contacts dated from this period, and from the time he spent as visiting professor of art at the University of Southern Illinois (1968-69). There, he came into contact with the American east coast folk scene.

In 1971, the Nappers moved to a farmhouse near Ludlow, surrounded by some of the most lyrical countryside in the British Isles. Visitors some- times had surprise encounters with bluegrass banjo pickers and Appalachian singers, or heard the artist singing I Wish I Was A Mole In The Ground as he worked. Here, over 30 years, he found a fulfilment which was reflected in his work.

Napper painted his wife, domestic interiors, landscapes, animals, birds, buildings and mythological series, in which all these local elements had a place. The paintings became instantly recognisable, with a subtle mode of composition and colour, the best of them as brilliant as any of the Japanese prints and woodcuts he revered, especially Hokusai.

His last piece, at the instigation of the Prince of Wales, was a design for a large stained glass window for the chapel at St James's palace.

Behind Napper's manner, and the appearance of a biblical sage, was a humility and reverence towards his profession. He was a spiritual man who looked for the springs of life which he could try to interpret, ritualise and compose. He relished life, especially in generous conversa- tion, food and drink - with music to follow. But the primary traits of his character were kindness, generosity and enthusiasm.

Napper preferred to exhibit in small local galleries and to sell his work privately. He had many admirers among critics and gallery owners, including the late Robert Fraser, who said of him: "John Napper is a real artist." He is survived by Pauline.

fields.headline: AN Sivaraman
fields.trailText: The journalist Ambur Nanuiyer Sivaraman, popularly known as "ANS", who has died aged 97, was a campaigner for Indian independence, an opponent of Indira Gandhi's 1970s state of emergency, and a key figure in the Indian - and specifically Tamil - press for more than half a century.
fields.body:
The journalist Ambur Nanuiyer Sivaraman, popularly known as "ANS", who has died aged 97, was a campaigner for Indian independence, an opponent of Indira Gandhi's 1970s state of emergency, and a key figure in the Indian - and specifically Tamil - press for more than half a century.

Born in Kochi, in southern Tamil Nadu, he imbibed nationalism as a schoolboy. During the first world war, he was influenced by the internment, in India, of the British socialist Annie Besant, a campaigner for Indian home rule. In 1921, while still the first student from his village to enter Tirunelveli college, he joined Mahatma Gandhi's civil disobedience movement. This terminated his college education, as it resulted in an 18-month imprisonment.

After a spell as a school-teacher, Sivaraman joined TS Chockalingam, another pioneering Tamil journalist, who was then editing a periodical called Gandhi. In 1934, when Chockalingam became editor of the new and influential Tamil daily, Dinamani, Sivaraman became his deputy. Taking over as as editor himself in 1944, he spent 53 years on the paper, which was then backing the Indian National Congress struggle for independence. His mission was to remove the strikingly wide gap in coverage between English-language and Tamil newspapers, and to raise Tamil readers' level of awareness to that of the more privileged English-speaking readers.

In 1975, when prime minister Indira Gandhi imposed a state of emergency throughout India, stifling dissent through censorship and arbitrary arrests, Sivaraman left the space meant for Dinamani's editorials blank. When even this triggered objections from the censors, he penned pieces that ironically referred to democracy around the world, implying that the local variety was then a farce.

After the emergency was lifted, Sivaraman called for an apology from Mrs Gandhi's Congress party to the nation, and insisted on statutory protection against a repetition of that 1975-77 misadventure. He retired in August 1987, but continued to write.

webTitle: Parents 'should get tapes of talks with doctors'

fields.headline: Parents 'should get tapes of talks with doctors'
fields.trailText: Parents of seriously sick children should be given tapes of key consultations with hospital doctors to help end the "paternalistic" culture of the medical profession and improve trust, an inquiry said yesterday.
fields.body:
Parents of seriously sick children should be given tapes of key consultations with hospital doctors to help end the "paternalistic" culture of the medical profession and improve trust, an inquiry said yesterday.

Families should also receive detailed letters about their children's care within 20 days of the meetings and be informed of any changes to diagnoses and treatments.

The recommendations of the independent inquiry are expected to shock hospitals, where doctors already face pressure to "tell all" and abandon hierarchical attitudes towards colleagues and patients. The advice may be seen as a threat to their professionalism.

The inquiry into children's heart services at the Royal Brompton and Harefield hospitals in London, found a "serious breakdown in communication and trust" between some parents and doctors. It also accepted that doctors' behaviour towards families of Down's syndrome children led parents to view the treatment offered as discriminatory.

Some families had alleged that they were encouraged to believe surgery could make it more difficult to look after their children later in life and that they were not told fully about the risks of treatment.

The recommendation to tape consultations and send parents copies of letters from consultants to GPs, was among 102 directed at the trust.

The inquiry chairman Ruth Evans, former head of the National Consumer Council , said her team hoped other hospitals would "implement recommendations, where they are needed, across the board."

Health officials yesterday admitted it would be difficult to introduce such procedures nationwide for only a few categories of patients and operations. Some sources also said some trusts were wary of anything that could be used in litigation. But there could also be benefits in that families, overwhelmed by the seriousness of the consultations, would not otherwise take in all the doctors said. The British Medical Association said that tape recordings should not be seen as a substitute for patients and parents to have further face-to-face conversations.

The report also makes 17 further recommendations including training for all health professionals in ensuring "non-discriminatory" policies and practices, and a national system for reporting serious injury from child heart surgery.

The inquiry had found that Down's Syndrome children with heart conditions were "less favoured" for operations at the Royal Brompton. But doctors were not discriminatory in the treatment delivered.

The inquiry, set up in 1999, investigated 49 cases of children treated at the two hospitals since 1987, 14 of them Down's syndrome sufferers. Many of the children died or had suffered serious brain damage following surgery .

Ms Evans said members found "a culture of paternalism that makes families frightened and disempowered". She added: "Parents are entitled to more information, better communication and more consultant time when making critical decisions."

The chairman of the trust, Sir Philip Otton, expressed "regret" to parents but added that there had been considerable debate about the appropriate method for treating children with Down's syndrome and heart disease.

Disappointed parents called the inquiry a "sham" and a "cover-up" and demanded a public inquiry.

webTitle: Breastfeed for six months says WHO

fields.headline: Breastfeed for six months says WHO
fields.trailText: The World Health Organisation yesterday concluded a year of fraught deliberations with a global recommendation that most women should exclusively breastfeed their babies for six months.
fields.body:
The World Health Organisation yesterday concluded a year of fraught deliberations with a global recommendation that most women should exclusively breastfeed their babies for six months.

The WHO's experts accept that some women who cannot breastfeed, some who do not want to and others who for health reasons would be best not to, but they say that in general, six months of exclusive breastfeeding is the healthiest start to life for a baby and complementary feeding should not ideally start any earlier.

Their conclusions fly in the face of a recent study published in the British Medical Journal which found that adults who had been breastfed for more than four months as a baby tended to be at a greater risk of dying from heart disease. That study was one of the 3,000 the experts considered but not one of just 17 thought sufficiently powerful to be accepted in evidence. Two additional small trials were carried out for the review.

The issue has caused huge controversy within the WHO, where there has been a north-south split, with countries such as Britain and the US favouring shorter breastfeeding duration - only a small minority of women in the UK breastfeed their babies to six months. The previous guidance recommended four to six months. The change is likely to be ratified by the World Health Assembly in May.

The report says there are mothers who would be best advised to stop feeding exclusively at four months. If they are malnourished or anaemic themselves, the baby may not get enough iron or micronutrients. But in developing countries generally, exclusive breastfeeding for six months protects babies against illness and death from gastrointestinal infections.

Patti Rundall of the pressure group Baby Milk Action said she was delighted at the recommendation."For too long we have allowed the companies to influence health policies, forgetting that they have only one objective which is to sell more foods - in this case an extra $1bn worth every year."

webTitle: Train companies slash fares to win back passengers after disruption

fields.headline: Train companies slash fares to win back passengers after disruption
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Two of the largest train operators have slashed ticket prices to tempt beleaguered passengers back on to the railways after months of disruption to services.
fields.body:
Two of the largest train operators have slashed ticket prices to tempt beleaguered passengers back on to the railways after months of disruption to services.

Virgin Trains and GNER each announced a package of special offers yesterday in an attempt to reverse the slump in business after the Hatfield derailment in October, which saw passenger numbers fall by up to 50%.

GNER will offer a flat fare of £5 one way on 150,000 tickets to any destination between April 23 and May 3. The 580-mile trip from London to Inverness, the longest journey on its network, normally costs £63 if it is prebooked.

Virgin has cut the price of a 1m tickets in its Virgin Value range by a third, reducing the cost of a journey from Manchester to London from £20 to £13 between April 6 and May 19.

The two companies, which operate the east and west coast main lines respectively, were particularly badly affected after the derailment forced emergency maintenance and widespread delays on the railway network.

A spokesman for GNER said numbers had been increasing steadily but were still 15% below pre-Hatfield levels.

"This offer is to say to people, 'We're back in business, come and try our service'," he said.

"We now have a timetable in place that is very close to what was in place before the speed restrictions were imposed. The journey times are much improved and we have been working very hard to improve passenger service at stations and on the trains." The rail passengers' council, the statutory railway watchdog, welcomed the offers, but expressed regret that discounts would not apply across all operating companies.

"This is part of the payback for passengers after the disruption," said Phil Wilks, policy director. "If the railways are to recover their image, this is the sort of deal they have to offer."

Virgin and GNER are not the only operators to introduce offers to prop up faltering passenger numbers. Wales and West announced yesterday it will post a million free tickets to households in the south west for use on restricted services.

A spokesman for Central Trains said its "two for one" offer was being extended beyond the Easter period, and widened to cover more journeys.

First Great Western also said it planned to extend its offer of £10 or £15 return fares on its London to Bristol route to its west of England routes.

The association of train operating companies, the umbrella body for the railway operators, said it had considered a package of offers across the board but decided to leave special offers to independent operators.

fields.headline: Tate Modern triumphs with 5m visitors
fields.trailText: The new Tate Modern almost singlehandedly pushed visitor numbers to national museums up by a fifth, with all but 700,000 of the extra 4.7m people who visited galleries last year walking through the cavernous entrance to the former power station on London's Bankside.
fields.body:
The new Tate Modern almost singlehandedly pushed visitor numbers to national museums up by a fifth, with all but 700,000 of the extra 4.7m people who visited galleries last year walking through the cavernous entrance to the former power station on London's Bankside.

Tate Modern's amazing performance, which makes it the most successful new museum in the world, masks big rises for smaller institutions like the newly refurbished National Portrait Gallery, which saw its visitors go up by a nearly a fifth, and smaller though significant rises for the Victoria and Albert museum and the British museum, whose revamped great court did not open in time to be fully reflected in the figures.

The Tate's triumph - its four galleries in London, Liverpool and St Ives taken together attracted 6.7m people - was further enhanced last night when Tate Modern's Swiss architects, Herzog and De Meuron, won the Pritzker prize, the most prestigious architecture award in the world , for their conversion of the 1950s building.

"This is doubly fantastic news," a Tate spokeswoman said last night. "We anticipated 2m visitors in our first year for Tate Modern, and the way things are looking now we will have hit the 5m mark by its first birthday in May."

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, said the overall number would be even better next year since the announcement that admission charges are to be scrapped in all of the 17 galleries which his department helps to fund. Significantly, visitors numbers at the main dissident charging museums, the Science and Natural History museums in London, were among the few to remain static.

Mr Smith said: "These figures are great news and are further evidence of just how popular our national museums and galleries are with the public. They are giving millions of people the opportunity to be stimulated, educated and inspired.

"The huge success of Tate Modern shows there is a very real interest in contemporary art, an area which is often criticised for being impenetrable and deliberately controversial," Mr Smith added.

fields.headline: Error caused fatal bus crash
fields.trailText: A coach driver who pleaded guilty to manslaughter for the crash in which 27 British tourists and a South African guide were killed is expected to receive a suspended sentence today after the prosecution accepted the tragedy was due to human error not negligence.
fields.body:
A coach driver who pleaded guilty to manslaughter for the crash in which 27 British tourists and a South African guide were killed is expected to receive a suspended sentence today after the prosecution accepted the tragedy was due to human error not negligence.

Titus Dube told a South African court yesterday that he put his foot on the accelerator instead of the brake as he careered off the Long Tom pass near Lydenburg in September 1999. His coach rolled several times, tearing off the roof and flinging passengers from the vehicle. Most of the dead were elderly Britons.

Dube, a father of five who lost his job after the accident, has admitted culpable homicide.

He initially claimed the brakes had failed. But his lawyer, Gerhard Kotzee, said Dube now accepted that he had been pressing the accelerator by mistake.

The prosecutor, Chris Kok, said he was not pressing for a custodial sentence because the accident was the result of human error and that Dube was neither reckless nor highly negligent.

fields.headline: FO nets £50m from sale of embassies
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office has raised £50m by selling 53 of its overseas properties, including such prime slices of real estate as the former ambassador's residence in the Irish Republic.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office has raised £50m by selling 53 of its overseas properties, including such prime slices of real estate as the former ambassador's residence in the Irish Republic, it revealed yesterday.

The former embassy in Bonn - a nondescript concrete block sometimes mockingly called the "biscuit factory" - has also been sold, as has the ambassador's residence there, and ageing imperial buildings in Singapore and Jakarta.

Also sold was the ambas-sador's four-bedroom home in Bogota, Colombia.

In Ireland, the 34-acre Glencairn estate, outside Dublin, was valued at £30m and has been home to British ambassadors since 1957. Its sale in 1998 capitalised on the boom in the Dublin property market and it is due to be redeveloped for housing and offices.

While it was a focal point for Irish society, the Victorian mansion, which has a tower with battlements and a verandah with granite columns, has also been disparaged by diplomats for its lack of architectural merit.

One former ambassador, Sir Robin Haydon, considered it a "failed Balmoral". It has now been swapped for a more modest home in Ballsbridge, Dublin's embassy belt.

A Foreign Office spokesman said: "This is not about selling the family silver but the kind of savings any sensible organisation would make. And we've invested in new posts abroad, staffing and new technology."

webTitle: Animals for slaughter about to top 1m

fields.headline: Animals for slaughter about to top 1m
fields.standfirst:
Toll: Kill rate of 20,000 a day is far behind those condemned

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth epidemic continues unabated with new outbreaks in 13 counties - some where the Ministry of Agriculture had hoped the disease was isolated and on the wane. The total number of animals to be slaughtered was expected to pass 1m today.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth epidemic continues unabated with new outbreaks in 13 counties - some where the Ministry of Agriculture had hoped the disease was isolated and on the wane. The total number of animals to be slaughtered was expected to pass 1m today.

Evidence that the government is losing the battle came in the numbers of animals condemned but still waiting to be slaughtered. The toll had risen to 345,000 yesterday morning - an increase of 20,000 a day since Thursday.

Cumbria was again the worst blackspot on Sunday with 23 new cases and another 11 notified by lunchtime yesterday, making a total for the county of more than 380, out of a national total of 933, defeating all the combined attempts of the army and the Ministry of Agriculture to keep pace. There now seems no immediate prospect of implementing the policy of slaughtering all animals on farms within 24 hours of the disease being discovered, as the prime minister promised last week when he personally took control of the crisis.

Just as disturbing for the government were the new cases in the north-east. There were four in Northumberland on Sunday, two in Durham and two in Tyne and Wear. The latter were the first in the county since March 22, ending hopes that the disease was being confined.

At the other end of the country there were another seven cases in Devon and one in Cornwall, the first for four weeks. Cheshire, Staffordshire, Herefordshire, Gloucestershire, Monmouthshire, Powys and Dumfries and Galloway all had new outbreaks.

The Ministry of Agriculture kept hidden over the weekend a record number of 64 new cases on Friday. There were another 20 cases on Saturday and 54 yesterday.

Elsewhere, there were no new cases in France or Ireland, but Holland seemed to be struggling to contain the disease with the number of outbreaks reaching 12. Estimates of the cost in Holland have risen to £50m as the Dutch slaughter all animals within two miles of outbreaks. They have also reportedly begun ring vaccination.

In Cumbria the government is still undecided on vaccination. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, was in the county yesterday apparently trying to convince dairy farmers that vaccination should be implemented. But they were worried their milk might be unsaleable.

Mr Brown said: "I have not come here to make any announcement. The issue is still under review. The arguments are not all one way. There are a range of strategies under consideration."

The European Commission has advised Britain also to consider vaccinating zoo animals if there is a risk of rare animals catching the disease.

The government yesterday gave the army the go ahead to bury 25,000 cattle at the disused Great Orton airfield. More than 40 trucks laden with about 2,500 carcasses had been held up at the airfield because of Department of Health fears that burying cattle could spread mad cow disease. But Mr Brown said that as long as the animals were born after August 1996 there was no danger of spreading BSE.

"We are now clearing the backlog," said Lt Col Andrew Taverner, the army's spokesman. "But we will still be burning and rendering cattle as well as burying animals under five years old.

"We are anxious not to over fill the Great Orton site and so use up all our sheep space. But we now feel we have the matter in hand."

By yesterday 3,657 farmers had asked for 1,354,000 animals to be slaughtered because of restrictions on animal movements. Nearly 1m of these were sheep and 312,000 were pigs.

The government is prepared to compensate for 90% of the value of the animals under the so-called welfare slaughter scheme.

A spokeswoman for the intervention board in Newcastle said 31,811 animals had been slaughtered and 19 abattoirs were dedicated to the scheme. As soon as they were all operating they would have a capacity to kill 280,000 animals a week. The carcasses would be taken to six landfill sites and one rendering plant for disposal. Applications to the welfare scheme were still being received.

The chaos in Cumbria mounted yesterday when a pyre for burning cattle at a farm was scrapped after complaints that it was too close to houses in Carlisle. It was built last week to burn 120 cattle at Cummersdale Grange Farm, plus another 250 from a farm near Rose Castle.

The decision came after the intervention of Eric Martle, Labour MP for Carlisle. The animals will now be taken to a rendering plant instead and the pyre dismantled.

webTitle: Why vaccination took so long to emerge as option

fields.headline: Why vaccination took so long to emerge as option
fields.standfirst:
Control: wide disagreement reflects differing interests

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Why are we thinking of vaccination now?
fields.body:
Why are we thinking of vaccination now?

The government has known about vaccination for years and came close to using it in 1967 after public and veterinary pressure. At the start of this epidemic, Maff officials were totally against vaccination, but this position has softened.

Why the delay in making the decision?

The decision will be political, scientific and economic. The government is keen to take farmers with it and is embarrassed that Britain imposed the slaughter-only policy on Europe in 1995. It was on the point of giving the go-ahead for vaccination more than 10 days ago, but since then NFU leaders have hardened their position and now say vaccination would be a mistake.

Who is in favour?

Many independent, foreign and academic vets agree that there is a place for vaccination to control the disease, but fear that they could compromise their careers if they say so openly. Elm Farm, the leading organic farming research institute, argues that it should be used now because the authorities cannot keep up with the spread of the present epidemic with slaughter-only methods .

Who is against and why?

Many Maff officials and the NFU argue that Britain will lose its export market for between three and 12 months if vaccinations start, that they are not 100% effective, require booster injections and take time to build up immunity. Others say the epidemic has gone in places too far to control even with vaccination and that it would be logistically impossible to vaccinate large areas.

Can it be controlled without vaccination?

In normal circumstances, a slaughter policy would eventually eradicate the disease. But epidemiologists say we are now in uncharted scientific territory because no other industrialised farming system in the world has ever experienced foot and mouth on this scale.

Would it control the disease?

All vets agree it would dampen it down rapidly.

Could the slaughter-only policy be worsening the epidemic?

Some vets and epidemiolgists say that if animals are not slaughtered and disposed of immediately - as they are evidently not being in some areas - then it can spread by air or by rats or other wildlife feeding off the carcasses. They say undiagnosed infection may already have spread far and wide and a massive screening and eradication programme may be needed after the epidemic has subsided.

How could vaccination be used?

The government is thinking of emergency vaccination of cows, all of which would later be slaughtered. This, they say, would give vets, slaughtermen and the army time to catch up with the growing backlog of animals waiting to be culled, collected and buried. But vaccination could also be used to create long distance barriers and some breeders want to use it to save specialist herds and flocks which are not for export and could then be spared from slaughter.

What's happening abroad?

Holland has started vaccinating and many German regions are pressing for it.

What does vaccination actually do?

It adminsters a tiny dose of the virus which triggers the animal's immune system and prevents it getting infected. It kicks in immediately but can take between five and 12 days to build up fully. One dose for a cow can immunise five sheep.

Would mass vaccination of an area completely rid animals of foot and mouth?

No. Because vaccinated animals carry the disease, it would be seen as endemic in those herds or flocks. But tests are available to check if herds have had the disease. Those without it could still in theory be exported.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Court clears doctor
fields.body:
Court clears doctor

Dr Ziad Kawa, 58, of Sawbridgeworth, Hertfordshire, was cleared at the Old Bailey yesterday of the manslaughter of Dean James, 17, who died in September 1997 from an overdose of a heroin substitute.

Binge eating link to infertility

Women who binge eat could trigger polycystic ovary syndrome, the most common cause of female infertility, researchers from St George's and Middlesex hospitals in London, will tell a conference on eating disorders in London today.

Still 1p to spend a penny

It still only costs 1p to spend a penny, the water industry regulator said yesterday. But a bath costs an average 10p, Ofwat disclosed in its leaflet Water and You. It said the average costs of everyday water use was mostly unchanged in the past year.

Three die in car crash

Three men in their 20s were killed and another seriously injured when the car they were travelling in careered into a brick wall at Muckley Corner near Lichfield, Staffordshire, the ambulance service said yesterday. The injured man was airlifted to Selly Oak hospital in Birmingham.

Four on bomb charge freed

Alan McGovern, 32, Patrick Dunne, 29, Patrick Gallagher, 45, and Robert Lee, 35, were freed at the Old Bailey yesterday after a charge of making a pipe bomb was dropped by the prosecution. They were held following an anti-terrorist squad raid on a house in Ealing, west London.

webTitle: Yacht capsize: one dead, one missing

fields.headline: Yacht capsize leaves woman dead and another missing
fields.trailText: One woman was found dead and another was still missing last night after a yacht carrying six British tourists capsized and smashed on rocks off the coast of New South Wales early on Sunday.
fields.body:
One woman was found dead and another was still missing last night after a yacht carrying six British tourists capsized and smashed on rocks off the coast of New South Wales early on Sunday.

The four survivors spent more than 24 hours in the Tasman sea clinging to a liferaft from the wrecked vessel, before they were found washed up on a remote beach by members of the Royal Australian Air Force.

The Foreign Office named the dead woman as 35-year-old Linda Yarr, of Beckenham, Kent. Neighbours said the former telecommunications expert and financial worker had gone to Australia as part of a training course to captain a yacht. She had been due home next month.

Police said a crew of six had been sailing south down the east coast of Australia on a 180-mile route from the Queensland coastal resort of Surfers Paradise to Coffs Harbour when their yacht hit the treacherous Evans reef, near Evans Head, 450 miles north of Sydney.

Marine rescue authorities said the yacht had set out in "awful" conditions."

Chris Leech, president of Volunteer Marine Rescue at Southport, told the Sydney Morning Herald: "The seas were awful. There was a storm wind warning and we banned another boat from coming in twice. We told him to go back out to sea until the conditions changed."

Mr Leech said he did not know how much experience the tourists had, but believed it would have been a uncom fortable trip. John Bankart, representative of the Isle of Wight-based company that operated the sail boat training, Leisure Management International, said the capsized yacht had been sailing in tandem with another yacht. Both were headed for Coffs Harbour and then Sydney.

Mr Bankart was aboard the second yacht. "The Rising Farrster crew were sailing along when for some unknown reason, the keel fell off and the boat inverted 180 degrees," he said.

Following its capsize, the 11.9m (39ft) Rising Farrster smashed into small pieces during the night. Inspector Mal Turner, of Ballina police, said the yacht's skipper, one of the four survivors, believed the two missing members of their party were trapped in the hull.

Inspector Turner said: "Four out of the six crew managed to get into a liferaft. Some time the next morning, the liferaft deflated and they ended up in the water."

The four Britons, three men aged 32, 30 and 26, and a 22-year-old woman, then managed to swim four miles to the shore, clinging to debris from the wreckage.

The survivors were treated for minor cuts, bruises and dehydration at Ballina hospital after air force officers found them on a prohibited bombing range at South Evans Head beach yesterday morning.

"The survivors are in a remarkably good way considering they spent all that time in the waters," said Inspector Turner.

Two hours after the survivors were discovered, search teams including police boats, coast guards and a helicopter located the body of one of the missing women six nautical miles offshore.

The search for the final member of the crew will resume today after it was suspended at dusk yesterday.

Rising Farrster, a training yacht, is regularly sailed up and down the New South Wales coast. Two of the survivors are reported to be from Cheshire, one from Surrey, and one from Gloucestershire.

Friends and neighbours of Ms Yarr told of their shock last night.

Jim Reynolds, 71, had been looking after her flat. He said: "She went out to Australia to get her masters in yachting. She wanted to go to the Caribbean and work as a yacht master. She had been out there since September.

"Linda was a delightful person, a wonderful conversationalist. She was quick on the uptake, and one felt alive in her company."

Ms Yarr graduated in physics at Strathclyde University, before receiving a commission in the RAF as an engineering officer. She served in Bosnia and the Ascension Islands and later joined the United Nations, said Mr Reynolds.

"But she really wanted to take her masters certificate in sailing. She intended to get a post as a yacht master in the Caribbean."

Australia has the highest annual rate of aquatic injuries in the world. Two British holidaymakers were among four tourists who drowned last month in separate incidents after getting caught in fierce underwater currents at Surfers Paradise beach.

webTitle: Gap grows between diagnosis and killing

fields.headline: Gap grows between diagnosis and killing
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The time lag between the diagnosis of animals with foot and mouth and their slaughter is getting longer every day despite a pledge by Tony Blair to cut it to 24 hours.
fields.body:
The time lag between the diagnosis of animals with foot and mouth and their slaughter is getting longer every day despite a pledge by Tony Blair to cut it to 24 hours.

There is a discrepancy between the figures issued by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and those given out by Downing Street - and yesterday charts and tables describing the progress of the disease were removed from Maff's website.

Fewer than 610,000 animals have been slaughtered, of which 178,000 are lying in fields and barns waiting to be disposed of. Crucially, there were 345,000 animals awaiting slaughter yesterday - almost 53,000 more than three days before.

This figure was posted on the Maff website yesterday, but all the comparative figures for the six weeks of the outbreak were stripped off .

With the number of new cases continuing to rise sharply - 933 by yesterday afternoon - the number of animals to be slaughtered was expected to pass 1m today. In addition, 3,657 farmers have applied to have 1.3m healthy sheep, pigs and cows slaughtered under the animal welfare scheme. Added to those already in the slaughter schemes, this is 5% of all farm animals in Britain.

The first sign that the government was keen to avoid questioning came a week ago with the suspension after 28 days of daily press conferences by Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, and Jim Scudamore, the chief vet.

From Monday last week, on the instructions of Downing Street, briefings for political reporters switched to No 10 via the twice daily lobby briefings.

Crucially, the Maff website gave the figures of the number of animals actually slaughtered, carcasses disposed of and those waiting to be killed. No 10 last week briefed that this last figure was falling, but Maff's statistics showed it was rising.

By Friday the discrepancy had become an embarrassment. Maff figures showed that 788,956 animals were marked for slaughter, of which 496,821 had already been killed and 349,379 carcasses disposed of. There were still 292,125 animals waiting to be killed. It was this delay that epidemiologists said had to be reduced to 24 hours to stop the epidemic worsening.

A Maff spokesman said: "Taking the figures off the website was not a deliberate pulling of a plug on information.The figures have sometimes not been fully up to date and so may have been misleading. We will try to get them reinstated."

fields.trailText: In response to the tourist industry's plea (Walk this way, Travel, March 31) I arrived in Cumbria just before 9pm and found accommodation in a pub in a popular Lakeland village. The cost, £50, was roughly double that of an equivalent hotel in the south of France.
fields.body:
In response to the tourist industry's plea (Walk this way, Travel, March 31) I arrived in Cumbria just before 9pm and found accommodation in a pub in a popular Lakeland village. The cost, £50, was roughly double that of an equivalent hotel in the south of France.

I asked about dinner. Sadly it was finished. In fact, there was no food available. After a tour of the area which included three pubs, a restaurant and a bistro, all advertising food, I located a Chinese restaurant about five miles away.

Instead of berating the current foot and mouth outbreak, perhaps the tourist industry should be thankful that any overseas visitors turn up at all.
Roger Alexander
Manchester
rmalexander@barclays.net
