webTitle: Letters: On socialists who bash the Bible

fields.headline: On socialists who bash the Bible
fields.trailText: Stephen Bates refers to "the issues on which the religious communities are getting steamed up" (Taking orders from God, March 30) and lists abortion, human embryo research, gay equality, marriage and traditional morality. If he went to the same Christian Socialist conference, or read the report prepared for it, he will know that leaders of major faith communities had a very different list, including poverty overseas and at home, asylum and refugees, families and marriage, regeneration and consultation, education, employment, housing and homelessness.
fields.body:
Stephen Bates refers to "the issues on which the religious communities are getting steamed up" (Taking orders from God, March 30) and lists abortion, human embryo research, gay equality, marriage and traditional morality. If he went to the same Christian Socialist conference, or read the report prepared for it, he will know that leaders of major faith communities had a very different list, including poverty overseas and at home, asylum and refugees, families and marriage, regeneration and consultation, education, employment, housing and homelessness.

The concern of Christians and other religious believers in politics is to promote fairness for every individual, freedom of belief and the well-being of the entire community. Only a minority imagine that politicians could or should try to impose particular religious doctrines.

Tony Blair did not offer to satisfy every policy demand of the faith communities. He demonstrated that his personal aims are underpinned by firmly held beliefs and values. There is no political benefit in leaders "wearing their religious hearts on their sleeves". So why not imagine the impossible - that they talk about their faith because they believe in it and find it important?
Robert Dimmick
Caversham, Reading
robert@dimmick33.freeserve.co.uk

Christians have no need to run away from political ideology (Socialism is the best religion, April 2). As a party activist for 40 years, and a candidate in three general elections, I have always felt that the proper relationship between Christianity and my political beliefs is one of mutual criticism. Fortunately, as a Liberal Democrat, I belong to a party that has been rather more successful at retaining its ideological roots than Roy Hattersley's.
Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford

I think Roy Hattersley has got himself in a fix dividing Christian and socialist and putting RH Tawney only on the socialist side of the equation. Memory suggests that RH Tawney was himself a Christian socialist and might have derived something of what he said from the Bible.
Rev Simon Bannister
Brasted, Kent
SBanni@aol.com

fields.headline: Coliseum is a circus
fields.trailText: Many lovers of good singing and opera fans will be dismayed by the news that many millions of pounds of lottery money and money from taxpayers (via the Arts Council) is to be used to refurbish the Coliseum theatre (ENO's Coliseum to get £41m facelift, March 30).
fields.body:
Many lovers of good singing and opera fans will be dismayed by the news that many millions of pounds of lottery money and money from taxpayers (via the Arts Council) is to be used to refurbish the Coliseum theatre (ENO's Coliseum to get £41m facelift, March 30). This theatre, the largest in London, is totally unsuitable for the nation's indigenous opera company. How can young singers be nurtured into fully trained and vocally equipped operatic artists if from the outset they have to be able to project into the cavernous areas of this theatre? No wonder the chorus often sounds tired.

We need a smaller theatre capable of mounting appropriate productions of intimate works by Handel, Mozart and Rossini. Ideally it would be better to spend these sums on making two smaller theatres out of the present site but that would unfortunately mean the destruction of Matcham's grand and ebullient design.

Perhaps a return to the rebuilt Sadlers Wells theatre would be the best option now that so many smaller London venues have vanished, although this place is still not ideal for intimate opera. The suggestion that the management may consider presentation of arena operas similar to Ramon Gubbay's should set alarm bells ringing. How long before no one can perform at our opera houses unless they have a microphone hidden in their clothing or strapped to their heads?

Let us take our example from Richard Wagner. He designed an ideal theatre for his works which would also suit most other composers: at Bayreuth.
Terry Mullins
London

fields.headline: Bush whack
fields.trailText: Austin's cartoon shows German nuclear waste protesters wondering if the train is late because the British are organising the transport (March 28).
fields.body:
Austin's cartoon shows German nuclear waste protesters wondering if the train is late because the British are organising the transport (March 28). The train was late due to peaceful protest. We would never ask the British to transport our waste. However much we want trains stopped, we do not want them derailed!
Daniel Mittler
Friends of the Earth, Germany
daniel.mittler@bund.net

Linda Gunter implies (Letters, April 2) the US withdrawal from Kyoto shows Bush's support for nuclear power. On the contrary, the nuclear industry, which does not emit carbon dioxide, would be delighted with Kyoto. Bush's decision is an endorsement of fossil fuels: what you'd expect from an oil man.
Stephen Tarlton
Nuclear Engineering International magazine

webTitle: Marcel Berlins: Does the word unbranding exist?

fields.headline: Does the word unbranding exist?
fields.standfirst: Runners and riders for the first woman law lord and chambers in search of a new brand
fields.trailText: Runners and riders for the first woman law lord and chambers in search of a new brand.
fields.body:
 There was never any real chance of the Fawcett Society succeeding in persuading the all-male law lords to include a woman judge on their panel when they heard last week's crucial appeal on the law of rape, in particular on the issue of consent. For one thing, there is no woman judge entitled to sit, because the law lays down that law lords have to be peers, and there isn't a senior woman judge in the House of Lords. I gather that at least some of the five men who did hear the case are sympathetic to the general point that it would have been helpful to have had a woman's contribution to their deliberations. It's not much of a consolation, I know, but their male lordships will be paying particular attention to judgments in similar cases given in the Canadian supreme court by women judges, who include their chief justice.

 How long will it be before the House of Lords gets its first woman law lord (and yes, I am aware of the gender specificity problem of that title)? And who will it be? The answer to the first is soon, this year or next. Who? There are only three local candidates with the judicial seniority to be potential law lords. The highest ranking, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the High Court's family division, has, at 67, almost certainly missed the boat. Of the two woman appeal court judges Dame Mary Arden, excellent as she is, is the less experienced. That leaves as clear favourite Dame Brenda Hale, about whose performance in the appeal court I've heard only raves; moreover, she would bring to the highest court an unusual background as an academic and a breadth of knowledge of things outside the law. There's another possibility. They could ennoble the chief justice of New Zealand, Dame San Elias, which would make her eligible to sit. There is a precedent: Lord Cooke of Thorndon, a former head of New Zealand's appeal court, has frequently sat as a law lord. Of course, Dame San already has a full-time job, but she could perhaps be called in occasionally to sit on cases that require a woman's input.

 The Law Society is thinking of joining the insane but seemingly unstoppable rush to list everything in league tables. The idea is risk-lists for solicitors, based on the number of complaints against them. If they're near the top of the league, they might as well put up a sign saying "whatever you do, don't come to us". Anyway, league tables are never an accurate guide to ability. For instance, Aston Villa is clearly the second best football team in the country; yet if you look at the league table, they're listed as only 11th.

 I feel a little sorry for Matrix - the most famous chambers in the history of the world - though my slight compassion is not shared by others I come across in the legal world. "Serve them right" is the more general view. I blame branding. Barristers chambers never knew anything about branding. When they were first allowed to promote themselves, they did so by pointing out what a talented bunch of barristers they had, and what legal areas they covered. Then someone must have read an article in a marketing magazine, and discovered branding. When Matrix was launched, it had to be identified with something warm and sexy: human rights. And because of the nature of the publicity, it was widely but wrongly assumed that Matrixians would always be on the side of the oppressed, the disadvantaged, those denied their rights. So when Cherie Booth QC appears on behalf of a school against a lesbian teacher seeking her human rights, or Rabinder Singh defends the Home Office in cases brought by immigrants or asylum seekers, or Nicholas Blake QC goes to Fiji to act for the military junta, the chambers is accused of hypocrisy and greed. And last week the star barrister Michael Beloff QC, who Matrix had proudly announced was to join them, changed his mind and has gone to rival Blackstone chambers. There was quite a lot of satisfaction in the Temple at this new publicity blow. But are we - the press, other lawyers - being unfair to Matrix? Probably. Is it Matrix's own fault? Largely. Are they reaping what they have sown? Definitely. The chambers had its AGM over the weekend. The members were generally bullish. But it was also decided to have a shift in marketing strategy. Does the word unbranding exist?

fields.headline: Muscle power rules the day
fields.standfirst: Charity walker Wendy Stafford encounters some steep highs and dramatic lows during the latest adventures of the British Agenies for Adoption and Fostering China Trek 2001
fields.trailText: Charity walker Wendy Stafford encounters some steep highs and dramatic lows during the latest adventures of the British Agenies for Adoption and Fostering China Trek 2001.
fields.body:
Bright sunshine and a cloudless blue sky heralded us to an uncompromised Chinese breakfast of cold vegetables, warm hard boiled eggs and stale white bread - as we prepared, amid anxious exchanges about the rigours of walking the wall the previous day, for our foray into the Black Dragon Paw Park.

A steep climb up steps hewn into large rocks, followed by a downward trail equally demanding, although on different muscles, brought us to the path of the river that winds silently, frequently strewn with patches of ice and snow, over a rocky river bed.

Almost without intent, the trail then turned away from the dramatic ravine of the river punctuated by the occasional frozen waterfall to become a meandering narrow soil track, sometimes confusing as to its direction. This led ultimately to our lunchtime destination some way up the valley bank. Calls of "knee how" - Chinese for "good day" - reverberated round the valley between the bestraggled line of trekkers.

The group's concerns for individual members has been evident from the start, and six days on bonds are forged more solidly, promoted by the shared experiences of this different culture and the impact of walking the wall.

As we strike on up the hillside after lunch (yet more boiled eggs, a staple food so it seems) I remember the descriptions of the children in Chinese orphanages given by fellow trekkers from Care for Children. They explained that when children are moved into foster homes they arrive with nothing to call their own, having spent a year or two or more living essentially in one room where they sleep, eat and play.

If the contribution from Care for Children is only 100 English pounds a year for a foster placement, there must be the possibility of increasing the number of children given the opportunity of family life rather than remaining in emotionally-impoverished residential care.

A rapidly descending, narrow, loose earth track, bordered on both sides by sharply prickled bushes takes us uncomfortably and cautiously down to a lower valley, from where we progress with greater ease to the dramatic waterfall which marks our resting place for the night. This is at the Waterfall Resort Hotel, aka "The Wooden Huts" - as indeed they are, with no heating, little to no hot water, ill-fitting window frames and outside temperatures of below freezing. Not that these lacks impinged when we arrived, as the afternoon sunshine provided hospitable respite from the trek. It also gave Herbie the bear (one of the Care for Children collective) the opportunity to abseil from a great height down the path of the waterfall, and Michelle and Julie to demonstrate their hair cutting skills on two willing volunteers, who achieved the "wet" for the cut by a backhead plunge into the icy river water.

Later in the afternoon a group of us climbed to a high peak overlooking the wall bathed in sunlight with a vista of mountains as far as the eye can see all ways round. The size and magnitude of this country is always with us, whether we are talking about its geography, economy, population or social issues.

Care for Children, with a clear philosophy of facilitation, has in two years achieved significant progress in engaging the Chinese government in the issues and benefits for children of foster care. There are now plans for expanding into other cities, and for planning fostercare for children of prisoners. Discussions about the principles and practice of fostercare in the UK, and consideration of the differences and parallels in China, have continued throughout the trek. But there is always the key factor that whatever changes and developments in childcare practice are to take place in China, they can proceed only at the pace - and in keeping with the views and wishes - of the Chinese government.

Night descends and we convene at the open-air barbecue. It already feels like below freezing. After the charcoal has cooked our food, we gather around the fire fuelled by pieces of wood offcut (from what looks like wartime furniture) and enjoy locally homemade fireworks - producing a need for a dramatic firefighting attack - assisted by some trekkers, on the very dry hillside, which is set alight in two places. The strains of antique UK tracks are replaced by trekker CDs from the 21st century, and finally the icy temperatures beneath the richly dark sky drive us to bed, fully clothed and with numbers of duvets, hoping to recharge the batteries for another day.

 Wendy Stafford is being sponsored by Time For Children, an independent fostering agency specialising in sibling placements. She is a Guardian ad litem.
